    Any aid or assistance given by any private person or organization to a financially insolvent or welfare emergency person through the program established by this subdivision shall be given without any recognition being given to the donating person or organization, and this program shall, under no circumstances, reveal the names or identities of any person receiving any such aid or assistance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-226) 
Sec. 2-259. - Records. 
(a)  For the protection of applicants and recipients, city officers or employees are prohibited, except as provided in this section, from disclosing the contents of any records, files, papers and communications, except for purposes directly connected with the administration of the emergency temporary family assistance program under this subdivision. 
(b)  The director shall keep records of all assistance given and denied to financially insolvent or welfare emergency cases through the emergency temporary family assistance program. The recordkeeping shall include complete applications, ledgers for disbursements, and proper documentation of need and coordination of services with other social service agencies, in accordance with policy standards set by the city council. 
(c)  The director may maintain application materials, program financial records and the checkbook for the program outside the city hall for purposes of administrative efficiency with the consent of the city manager. All records related to complete files, specifically where assistance has been granted or denied; canceled checks; and bank statements for the program shall be kept by the director in a file cabinet at city hall designated by the city manager, in a confidential and secured location. 
(d)  Direct access to the program files shall be limited to the director, and the treasurer and the city manager. Any files removed from their storage location shall be noted on a ledger, indicating who, when and for what purpose the file was removed. The return of the file shall be marked on the ledger as well. 
(e)  City council members wishing to review any and all files to fulfill oversight responsibilities for the program shall coordinate their request through the city manager, who shall make arrangements for the review. 
(f)  In any judicial proceeding, except a proceeding directly concerned with the administration of the emergency temporary assistance program provided for in this subdivision, such records, files, papers and communications and their contents shall be deemed privileged communications and shall be disclosed only upon the order of a court having jurisdiction thereof, where the court finds such disclosure necessary in the interest of justice. 
(g)  Recipients of assistance from the city's emergency temporary family assistance program are required to complete all program application materials and provide support documentation under their control in accordance with the city council's policy on the program. Persons failing to comply with this requirement or providing false information in order to secure funds from the city shall be required to reimburse the city all moneys provided and/or be subject to prosecution for a misdemeanor for violation of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 2-227; Ord. No. 97-14, § 3, 2-25-1997; Ord. No. 03-27, § 2, 3-25-2003) 
Sec. 2-260. - Reports. 
    The director of the emergency temporary family assistance program shall be required to submit quarterly reports, specifically for the periods January through March, April through June, and July through September; and annual year-end reports to the city council and city manager as to their activities and the status of the funds assigned to operation of the program. All reports shall be provided within 60 days of the conclusion of the quarter or the end of the fiscal year. Supplemental reports shall be provided by the director as may be required from time to time by the mayor, city council or city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 2-228; Ord. No. 97-14, § 3, 2-25-1997; Ord. No. 03-27, § 2, 3-25-2003) 
Sec. 2-261. - Reimbursement for expenses of director. 
    The director of the emergency temporary family assistance program shall be entitled to receive reimbursement for travel and other necessary expenses incurred by them in the performance of the duties of this office, in accordance with the annual appropriation approved by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-229; Ord. No. 97-14, § 3, 2-25-1997; Ord. No. 03-27, § 2, 3-25-2003) 
Secs. 2-262-2-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-291. - Election and term. 
    The city clerk shall be elected and shall serve a four-year term and until his/her successor is appointed and qualified as provided by statute. 
    Effective for the city clerk's election in 2003, the number of consecutive four-year terms which one person may serve as city clerk is limited to three terms. 
(Code 1967, § 2-127; Ord. No. 02-38, § 1, 7-9-2002) 
State Law reference- Election and term of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-20-5. 
Sec. 2-292. - Compensation. 
(a)  The city clerk receives as compensation the sum of $75.00 for each regular, special or committee of the whole meeting of the city council actually attended by the city clerk. The compensation shall be paid monthly. 
(b)  Effective May 1, 2003, the city clerk shall receive the sum of $3,000.00 per year, payable in equal monthly installments. 
(Code 1967, § 2-129; Ord. No. 98-23, § 2, 5-12-1998; Ord. No. 02-22, § 1, 5-14-2002) 
Sec. 2-293. - Sealing, attestation of documents. 
    The city clerk shall seal and attest all city contracts and all other documents as shall require this formality. 
(Code 1967, § 2-130; Ord. No. 98-09, § 9, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-294. - Custody, use of seal. 
    The clerk shall be the custodian of the city seal and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required. 
(Code 1967, § 2-134) 
State Law reference- Custody of seal, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-295. - Custody of documents. 
    The city clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the city, which are not assigned to the custody of some other city officer by law. 
(Code 1967, § 2-135; Ord. No. 98-09, § 10, 3-24-1998) 
State Law reference- Custody of documents, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-296. - Indexes of documents and records. 
    The city clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
(Code 1967, § 2-136) 
Sec. 2-297. - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties provided in this division, the city clerk shall perform such duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-137) 
Sec. 2-298. - Deputy clerk's office created; appointment; power to execute documents. 
    There is created the office of deputy clerk. The city manager is authorized to appoint a deputy clerk, who shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by law or ordinance to be executed by the city clerk and affix the city seal thereto whenever required. 
(Code 1967, § 2-138; Ord. No. 98-09, § 11, 3-24-1998) 
State Law reference- Deputy city clerks, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-95. 
Sec. 2-299. - Form of signature of deputy clerk. 
    When signing documents the deputy clerk shall sign the name of the city clerk followed by the word "by" and the deputy clerk's own name and the words "deputy clerk." 
(Code 1967, § 2-139) 
Sec. 2-300. - Deputy clerk's exercise of powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties described in this division shall be exercised by the deputy clerk only in the event of a vacancy in the office of city clerk, or the absence or unavailability of the city clerk. Absence shall be defined, for the purpose of this section, to mean being physically away from the city during regular business hours. Unavailability shall be defined, for the purpose of this section, to mean being physically incapable of attending to the duties for the city clerk during regular business hours because of other commitments or incapacity. 
(Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, 5-10-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-13, § 1, adopted May 10, 2011, repealed the former § 2-300 and enacted a new § 2-300 as set out herein. The former § 2-300 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1967, § 2-140 and Ord. No. 98-09, adopted March 24, 1998. 
Sec. 2-301. - Statutory powers of deputy clerk. 
    The deputy clerk shall have the authority and power described in this division and such further power and authority as may be provided by statute. 
(Code 1967, § 2-141) 
State Law reference- Powers of deputy clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-95. 
Sec. 2-302. - Termination of powers of deputy clerk. 
    The deputy clerk shall cease to exercise all the powers of the city clerk as authorized in this division whenever the city clerk shall return to the place where the city clerk's office is maintained for the purpose of assuming the duties of his office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-142) 
Secs. 2-303-2-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY TREASURER 

Sec. 2-331. - Position created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of city treasurer. The city treasurer is subject to appointment by and serves at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 06-13, §§ 1, 2, 5-9-2006) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-13, adopted May 9, 2006, amended § 2-331 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-331, pertained to the election and term of the city treasurer and derived from the 1967 Code, and Ord. No. 02-38, adopted July 9, 2002. 
State Law reference- Election and term of treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-20-5. 
Sec. 2-332. - Salary. 
(a)  The salary of the city treasurer is $4,500.00 per year, payable in equal monthly installments. 
(b)  Effective May 1, 2003, the city treasurer shall receive the sum of $6,000.00 per year, payable in equal monthly installments. 
(Code 1967, § 2-155; Ord. No. 98-23, § 3, 5-12-1998; Ord. No. 02-22, § 1, 5-14-2002) 
Sec. 2-333. - General duties. 
    The city treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid in to the city, either directly from the person paying it or from the hands of such other officer as may receive it, and he shall pay out only on warrants, vouchers or orders properly signed by the city comptroller and/or the city clerk and by the mayor. 
(Code 1967, § 2-156) 
State Law reference- Duties of treasurer, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-40. 
Sec. 2-334. - Deposit of funds; intermingling monies. 
    The city treasurer shall deposit the city funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as is provided by law, and he shall keep the city money separate and distinct from his own and shall not intermingle his own money with it or make private or personal use of the city funds. 
(Code 1967, § 2-157) 
State Law reference- Intermingling, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-55. 
Sec. 2-335. - Records required. 
    The city treasurer shall keep records showing all money received by him, the source from which it was received, and the purpose for which it was paid out; and he shall keep a record showing at all times the financial status of the city. The treasurer shall keep such additional books and accounts as may be required by the city council and shall keep them in the manner required by the council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-158) 
Sec. 2-336. - Records of bonds, orders, vouchers. 
    The city treasurer shall keep a register of all bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him and of all vouchers. 
(Code 1967, § 2-159) 
Sec. 2-337. - Books of appropriations, expenditures, receipts required. 
    The city treasurer shall open and keep, in a neat and methodical manner, a complete set of books in which, among other things, shall be set forth the appropriations of the fiscal year, each distinct object and branch of expenditure, and also the receipts from each and every source of revenue, so far as he can ascertain. Such books and all other papers kept in his office shall be subject to the examination of the mayor, the city council or any committee thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 2-160) 
Sec. 2-338. - Accounts of funds, debts. 
    The city treasurer shall keep a detailed account of the city revenue and of each separate fund, crediting the fund with all receipts or appropriations and charging it with all warrants drawn thereon, and he shall charge each warrant to the fund or appropriation against which it is drawn, to the extent authorized by an appropriation ordinance. He shall also keep an accurate account of all debts due from or owing to the city and shall keep a book in which he shall enter a correct list of all bonds, notes or other obligations given by or payable to the city, with the date thereof, the person to whom or by whom payable, the rate of interest, the time and manner in which the principal and interest are payable and such other particulars as may be necessary to the full understanding thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 2-161) 
Sec. 2-339. - Records relating to public improvements. 
    The city treasurer shall keep in his office a correct list of all local or public improvements ordered by the city council and let under contract by the city. All contracts and specifications therefor made by authority of the city council or by any city officer pursuant thereto in relation to such improvements shall be filed in the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-162) 
Sec. 2-340. - Monthly statements required; records of warrants. 
    At the end of every month and more often if required by the council, the city treasurer shall render an account under oath to the council or to such officer as may be designated by ordinance, showing the state of the treasury at the date of the account and the balance of money in the treasury. He shall accompany the account with a statement of all money received into the treasury and on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him. On the day he renders an account, these warrants, with all vouchers held by him, shall be delivered to the city clerk and filed, together with the account, in the clerk's office. He shall return all warrants paid by him marked "paid." He shall keep a register of all warrants, which shall describe each warrant; showing its date, amount, and number; the fund from which paid; the name of the person to whom paid; and the date when paid. 
(Code 1967, § 2-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-45. 
Sec. 2-341. - Annual reports. 
(a)  Within six months after the end of each fiscal year, the city treasurer shall prepare and file with the city clerk an account of all monies received and expenditures incurred during the preceding fiscal year. The treasurer shall show the following in such account: 
(1)  All monies received by the city, indicating the total amounts, in the aggregate, received in each account of the city, with a general statement concerning the source of such receipts; provided, for the purposes of this subsection, the term "account" shall not be construed to mean each individual taxpayer, householder, licensee, utility user, or such other persons whose payments to the city are credited to a general account. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (a)(3) of this section, all monies paid out by the city, where the total amount paid during the fiscal year exceeds $2,500.00 in the aggregate, giving the name of each person to whom moneys were paid and the total paid to each person. 
(3)  All moneys paid out by the city as compensation for personal services, giving the name of each person to whom moneys were paid and the total amount paid to each person from each account. 
(4)  A summary statement of operations for all funds and account groups of the city, as excerpted from the annual financial report as filed with the appropriate state agency. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the account from the city treasurer, the city clerk shall publish the account at least once in one or more newspapers published in the city or, if no newspaper is published in the city, then in one or more newspapers having a general circulation within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-164) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-65. 
Sec. 2-342. - Deputy treasurer. 
    There is hereby created the office of deputy treasurer. The city manager is authorized to appoint a deputy treasurer, who shall have the power and authority to perform all the duties and functions of the city treasurer as required by state statute, city ordinance or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 03-36 § 1, 5-27-2003) 
Sec. 2-343. - Signing documents. 
    When signing documents, the deputy treasurer shall sign the name of the city treasurer followed by the word "by" and the deputy treasurer's own signed name followed by the words "deputy treasurer." 
(Ord. No. 03-36 § 1, 5-27-2003) 
Sec. 2-344. - Exercise of power and duties. 
    The powers and duties described herein shall be exercised by the deputy treasurer only in the absence or unavailability of the city treasurer. Absence shall be defined, for the purpose of this section, to mean being physically away from the city during regular business hours. Unavailability shall be defined, for the purpose of this section, to mean being physically incapable of attending to the duties for the treasurer during regular business hours because of other commitments or incapacity. 
(Ord. No. 03-36 § 1, 5-27-2003; Ord. No. 05-67, § 1, 12-6-2005) 
Sec. 2-345. - Termination of powers. 
    The deputy treasurer shall cease to exercise all the powers of the city treasurer as authorized in this division whenever the city treasurer shall return to the place where the city treasurer's office is maintained for the purpose of assuming the duties of the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 03-36 § 1, 5-27-2003) 
Sec. 2-346. - Fidelity insurance. 
    The city shall at its cost maintain fidelity and crime insurance from its self-insurance provider for the same coverage's and amounts of insurance as provided to the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 03-36 § 1, 5-27-2003) 
Secs. 2-347-2-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCE 

Sec. 2-371. - Office created. 
    There is created the office of the city director of finance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-174) 
Sec. 2-372. - Duties. 
    The city director of finance shall be the financial officer of the city and shall be responsible to the city manager for all matters regarding the city finances. 
(Code 1967, § 2-174.1) 
Sec. 2-373. - Appointment. 
    The city director of finance shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 2-174.2) 
Sec. 2-374. - Authority to collect a fee for checks returned due to insufficient funds. 
    The director of finance is responsible for collecting various fees and charges as enumerated within the code of ordinances. The director of finance is authorized to assess a fee on all checks returned to the city from the financial institution where the check originated due to insufficient funds within the account of the writer of the check, as determined by the city council by the adoption of an ordinance, and detailed in appendix C of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 98-63, § 1, 12-15-1998) 
Secs. 2-375-2-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CITY BUDGET OFFICER 

Sec. 2-401. - Creation of office. 
    The office of budget officer is created. The city manager shall serve as the budget officer. In the absence of the city manager, i.e., being away from the city in excess of 24 hours, or physical/mental incapacity of the city manager to perform his duties, the director of finance shall serve as the budget officer. 
(Code 1967, § 2-167; Ord. No. 98-09, § 13, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-402. - Powers and duties. 
    The city budget officer shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Permit and encourage the use of efficient planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting, and other fiscal management procedures. 
(2)  Compile an annual budget. 
(3)  Examine all books and records of all municipal departments, commissions, and the boards which relate to moneys received by the city, city departments, commissions, and boards and paid out by the city, city departments, commissions and boards; debts and accounts receivable; amount owed by or to the city, city departments, commissions and boards. 
(4)  Obtain such additional information from the city, city departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the budget officer for purposes of compiling a city budget, such information to be furnished by the city, city departments, commissions and boards in the form required by the budget officer. Any department, commission or board which refuses to make such information as is requested of it available to the budget officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any subsequent budget for the city until such city department, commission or board shall comply in full with the request of the budget officer. 
(5)  Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no expenditures are made by the city, city departments, commissions or boards except as authorized by the budget. 
(Code 1967, § 2-169) 
Sec. 2-403. - Additional duties. 
    The budget officer shall have such additional duties, obligations and responsibilities as are imposed by law or by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-170) 
Sec. 2-404. - Compensation. 
    Budget officers shall receive such compensation as is provided by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-171) 
Sec. 2-405. - Annual budget inspection; public hearing. 
    The city shall make the tentative annual budget conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget, by publication in the minutes of the city council or in such other form as the city council may direct. Not less than one week after the publication of the tentative annual budget and prior to final action on the budget, the corporate authorities shall hold at least one public hearing on the tentative annual budget, after which hearing the tentative budget may be further revised and passed without any further inspection, notice or hearing. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least one week prior to the time of the hearing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-173) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/8-2-9.9. 
Sec. 2-406. - Same-Inspection; public hearing; notice of public hearing. 
    The city shall make the annual budget conveniently available to public inspection for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget, by publication in the minutes of the city council or in such other form as the city council may direct. Not less than one week after the publication of the annual budget, and prior to final action on the budget, the corporate authorities shall hold at least one public hearing on the annual budget. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least one week prior to the time of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 459, § 5, 4-23-68) 
Sec. 2-407. - Property tax levy limitation. 
    The city's property tax levy may not be increased annually more than five percent or the annual increase in the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers - Chicago, whichever figure is greater, except in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Any new mandate or newly mandated costs on an existing mandate not funded by the mandating governmental body required or imposed by any governmental unit including, but not limited to, the United States Government, State of Illinois, Cook County, Metropolitan Water Reclamation District, Intergovernmental Risk Management Agency, Illinois Commerce Commission, Intergovernmental Personnel Benefits Cooperative; 
(2)  Funds required to satisfy judgments against the city; 
(3)  The amount of real estate taxes levied the first year on real estate annexed to the City of Rolling Meadows after January 1, 1992. 
(4)  Property taxes levied for the city to pay interest or principal on bonds issued to refund or continue to refund general obligation bonds. 
(5)  Property taxes levied by the city to pay principal, interest and issuance costs on general obligation bonds issued to fund certain public infrastructure improvement set forth in the amendment to 3Com Development Agreement approved by the city council on November 25, 1997, by Resolution 97-R-113. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, § 1, 1-12-93; Ord. No. 96-49, § 1, 10-8-96; Ord. No. 97-105, § 1, 12-16-97; Ord. No. 08-30, § 1, 8-12-2008) 
Sec. 2-408. - Library board. 
    The amount of the annual tax levy for the Rolling Meadows Library Board, which is included in the city's annual tax levy ordinance, shall be considered a separate and distinct tax levy for the purposes of this section. The property tax levy limitations set forth in section 2-173.1, above, shall be applicable separately to the city and library board annual tax levies. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, § 1, 1-12-93) 
Sec. 2-409. - Tax levy reduction. 
    The proposed annual budget shall, if applicable, indicate what services or personnel have been reduced or eliminated in order to stay within the foregoing property tax levy limitation. 
(Ord. No. 93-03, § 1, 1-12-93) 
Secs. 2-410-2-430. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-431. - Position created; appointment. 
    There is created the office of city attorney. The city attorney is subject to appointment by and serves at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 2-193; Ord. No. 98-09, § 15, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-432. - Advisory duties. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal advisor of the city and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting the city, whenever requested to do so in accordance with procedures established by the city manager. For such duties and for attendance at meetings of the city council, the city attorney shall be compensated on a basis agreed to by the city manager, with funds appropriated by the city council through the adoption of the annual budget resolution. 
(Code 1967, § 2-194; Ord. No. 98-09, § 16, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-433. - Duties in litigation. 
    The city attorney shall report to the mayor any action against the city which shall be brought to the attention of the city attorney. The city attorney shall, unless some other attorney is designated by the city council, with the advice of the city attorney first having been obtained, prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions to which the city may be a party and shall perform such other services as directed by the mayor or city council from time to time. For such services, the city attorney or such other attorney designated shall be paid reasonable compensation. 
(Code 1967, § 2-195) 
Sec. 2-434. - Duty to turn records over to clerk. 
    The city attorney or any other attorney handling matters on behalf of the city shall, upon the completion of such matters or upon the termination of employment, forthwith turn over to the city clerk all papers or documents in his hands belonging to the city or prepared by him for use in connection with such matters, together with any information he may possess with respect to the matters. 
(Code 1967, § 2-196) 
Sec. 2-435. - Drafting of documents, ordinances. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney to draft or supervise the phraseology of any contracts, leases or other documents or instruments to which the city may be a party and, upon request by the city council, to draft ordinances covering any subjects within the power of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-197) 
Sec. 2-436. - Reports required. 
    The city attorney shall make monthly reports to the city manager on all actions handled by him during the previous month. The city manager shall forward the report to the city council for its review. 
(Code 1967, § 2-198; Ord. No. 98-09, § 17, 3-24-1998) 
Secs. 2-437-2-465. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - CITY PROSECUTOR 

Sec. 2-466. - Office created. 
    There is created the office of city prosecutor. 
(Code 1967, § 2-209) 
Sec. 2-467. - Appointment, qualifications. 
    The city prosecutor shall be appointed by the city manager. The city prosecutor shall be an attorney duly licensed to practice in the state. 
(Code 1967, § 2-210) 
Sec. 2-468. - Duties. 
    The city prosecutor shall prosecute all violations of the city traffic ordinances and the state Uniform Act Regulating Traffic, including the collection of any costs of prosecution to which the city is entitled under the acts of the state or as provided in sections 106-69 through 106-74 of this Code and enforcement of liens, if any, for such costs of prosecution and to prosecute all other violations upon the written or oral direction of the city attorney. 
(Code 1967, § 2-211) 
Sec. 2-469. - Reports required. 
    The city prosecutor shall make such reports as may be required from time to time by the mayor or by the mayor and city council or by the state statutes. 
(Code 1967, § 2-212) 
Sec. 2-470. - Salary. 
    The salary of the city prosecutor shall be as determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-213) 
Secs. 2-471-2-495. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - CITY ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-496. - Office created. 
    There is created the office of city engineer, an executive office of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-239) 
Sec. 2-497. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be appointed to the office of city engineer unless he is registered under the provisions of 225 ILCS 325/1 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 2-240) 
Sec. 2-498. - Duties generally. 
    Whenever directed by the city manager, the city engineer shall make out plans, specifications and estimates of any public work. He shall also superintend the construction, shall inspect and measure the material of all public work and shall perform such other duties as are elsewhere prescribed or that may be imposed by law, this Code or any city ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 2-241) 
Sec. 2-499. - Compensation. 
    For the superintendence, inspection and recommendation of acceptance of construction of public works and inspection and measuring of the material of all public work, the city engineer shall be entitled to a salary as provided by the city council. For the performance of such other services performed by the city engineer, he shall be entitled to reasonable compensation. 
(Code 1967, § 2-242) 
Secs. 2-500-2-509. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-510. - Office created. 
    There is created the office of city fire marshal. 
( Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-511. - Appointment qualifications. 
    The city fire marshal shall be appointed by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-512. - Duties.

( Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-513. - Reports required. 
    The city fire marshal shall make such reports as may be required from time to time by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-514. - Salary. 
    The salary of the city fire marshal shall be as determined by resolution of the city council. 
( Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Secs. 2-515-2-550. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, adopted March 12, 2002, repealed and restated this division 2 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 122. 

Sec. 2-576. - Department created. 
    There is created the community development department. The community development department shall consist of three divisions: 
(1)  Planning and economic development division. 
(2)  Permits and inspections division. 
(3)  Health and housing division. 
(Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 2-577. - Community development director. 
    There is hereby created the office of community development director, an executive office of the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 2-578. - Duties of community development director. 
    It shall be the duty of the community development director to administer the community development department, including each of its divisions and to see to the enforcement of all provisions of this code and other city ordinances relating to land development, buildings, zoning and property maintenance and to inspect all buildings and premises, new and existing as may be necessary to ensure compliance. 
(Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 2-579. - Issuance of stop orders by community development director. 
    The community development director shall have power to order all work stopped on construction, alteration or repair of buildings and private or public site improvements in the city when such work is being done in violation of any section of this Code or any ordinance relating thereto or in violation of chapter 122 of this Code pertaining to zoning. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such order except on the written permission of the community development director. However, if the stop order is verbal, it shall be followed by a written stop order within three hours. Such written stop order may be served by any police officer or designee of the community development director. 
(Ord. No. 02-12, § 1, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 2-580. - 6(b) tax incentive application fee. 
    The director of community development shall charge a fee for reviewing and processing an application for a 6(b) tax incentive. The application fee is set forth in appendix B at paragraph III.C. 
(Ord. No. 10-15, § 1, 5-11-2010) 
Sec. 2-581. - Temporary signs in the public right-of-way. 
    The director of community development is hereby authorized and directed to prepare rules and regulations pertaining to, but not limited to the requirement for applications to be filed with the department of community development to place temporary signs in the public right-of-way and regulating the location(s) and duration of time temporary signs shall be permitted in the public right-of-way together with such other rules and regulations deemed appropriate by the director of community development. 
(Ord. No. 12-18, § 1, 4-24-2012) 
Secs. 2-582-2-605. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC WORKS 

Sec. 2-606. - Created; supervision. 
    There is created and established an executive department of the city government to be the department of public works under the supervision of an officer of the city to be the director of public works. 
(Code 1967, § 2-253) 
Sec. 2-607. - Office of director created. 
    There is created the office of director of public works, an executive office of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-254) 
Sec. 2-608. - General duties. 
(a)  The department of public works, under the direction of the director of public works, shall have charge of the repair, maintenance and operation of all sewers and drains in public ways; all public streets, alleys and other public places; and all public property and buildings not assigned by ordinance to some other city officer. 
(b)  The director of public works is authorized and directed to enter into a release and indemnity agreement on behalf of the city for all persons assigned by the circuit court of the county to perform community service work for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-255) 
Secs. 2-609-2-660. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) ---

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-661-2-685. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Fire protection and prevention, ch. 42; law enforcement, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Boards of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1. 

Sec. 2-686. - Appointment, qualifications and terms; chairman; quorum; oath and bond; removal. 
(a)  The mayor shall, with the consent of the city council, appoint a board of fire and police commissioners. The board shall consist of three members whose terms of office shall be three years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified. No such appointment, however, shall be made by the mayor within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office. Vacancies on the board of fire and police commissioners shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(b)  The board members shall elect a chairman to serve during the municipal fiscal year. A majority of the board constitutes a quorum for the conduct of all business. 
(c)  The members of the board shall be considered officers of the city and shall take an oath or affirmation of office and give bond in the same manner as other appointed city officers. 
(d)  No person holding an office in the city shall be a member of the board of fire and police commissioners or secretary thereof. The acceptance of any office by a member of the board shall be treated as resignation of his office as a member of the board or secretary thereof. No person shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police commissioners who is related either by blood or marriage, up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected city official. 
(e)  Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within 30 days in his own defense before a regular meeting of the city council. A majority vote of the elected members of the city council shall be required to remove any such member from office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-293; Ord. No. 02-11, § 1, 3-12-2002) 
Sec. 2-687. - Appointment of fire and police officers. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all sworn officers of the fire and police departments, except the chief and deputy chief of the fire department and the chief and deputy chiefs of the police department. All appointments to each department other than that of the lowest rank shall be made from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made, except in the respective appointments of the chief and deputy chief of the fire and police departments. Appointments of the chiefs and deputy chiefs of the fire and police departments need not be from among the members of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1967, § 2-294) 
Sec. 2-688. - Powers. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the board of fire and police commissioners shall have only such powers and shall make only such rules and appointments as are provided in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1-5/10-2.1-30 and in this Code. 
(b)  The board of fire and police commissioners, pursuant to the city's home rule authority, is specifically granted the power and authority to adopt, enact, implement, and enforce rules and regulations inconsistent with the following provisions of 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1-5/10-2.1-30: 
(1)  The limitation on maximum age for hiring police officers provided in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6. 
(2)  The limitation on promotional probation provided in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6. 
(3)  The awarding of military preference points, pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-10 and 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-11, to eligible veterans whose names appear on promotional eligibility registers. 
(4)  To require, contrary to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6, that a person is not eligible to apply for the position of police officer or firefighter unless they possess as a minimum a high school diploma and 48 college credit hours from a college or university accredited by the state in which it is located and which consists of a curriculum approved by the board of fire and police commissioners, or, in lieu thereof, a person may apply for the position of firefighter if they possess a high school diploma, be an Illinois state certified firefighter II and a certified emergency medical technician. 
A person that is appointed a police officer or firefighter that was eligible to apply for the position because they possessed as a minimum a high school diploma and 48 college credit hours as described above must have a total of 60 college credit hours and, in addition, for police officers successfully completed the minimum basic requirements as adopted by the Illinois Local Governmental Law Enforcement Officers Training Board, by the conclusion of their probationary period, or any extension thereof, to be certified by the board of fire and police commissioners as having completed their probationary period. 
(5)  To require, contrary to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-15, that a person is not eligible to apply for the position of police sergeant unless he possesses as a minimum a high school diploma and 60 college credit hours from a college or university accredited by the state in which it is located and which consists of a curriculum approved by the board of fire and police commissioners, unless the person was a member of the police department prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection derives, in which event the minimum statutory education standards shall apply. 
(6)  To require, contrary to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-15, that a person is not eligible to apply for the position of police commander, unless he possesses as a minimum a bachelor's degree from a college or university accredited by the state in which it is located, unless the person was a member of the police department prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection derives, in which event the minimum statutory education standards shall apply. 
(7)  To permit, contrary to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1 et seq., that all police and fire personnel that are currently employed full-time and in good standing, and have completed their probationary period (unless waived by the board of fire and police commissioners) as a certified police officer or Illinois State certified firefighter II, certified emergency medical technician or paramedic with a municipality or fire protection district may be considered for accelerated entry and preference in appointment as a police officer or firefighter of the city pursuant to applicable rules adopted by the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(Code 1967, § 2-295; Ord. No. 97-19, § 1, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 97-101, § 1, 12-16-1997; Ord. No. 00-17, § 2, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 01-15, § 1, 4-24-2001) 
Sec. 2-689. - Annual report required. 
    Annually, within 90 days following the end of the fiscal year, the board of fire and police commissioners shall submit to the mayor a report of its activities and of the rules in force and the practical effect therefrom. The mayor shall transmit this report to the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-296; Ord. No. 98-09, § 21, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-690. - Secretary. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may secure a secretary or may designate one of its own members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as the board shall prescribe. 
(Code 1967, § 2-297) 
Sec. 2-691. - Recruit testing. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners is authorized to utilize the Northwest Municipal Conference Area Police Recruitment and Testing Consortium to administer such segments of recruit testing as the fire and police commissioners shall determine to be in the best interests of the city from time to time. 
(Code 1967, § 2-298) 
Sec. 2-692. - Use of recruit test results. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners is authorized to utilize the results of recruit testing, as provided in section 2-691, in establishing its list of eligibles for service in the police department. 
(Code 1967, § 2-299) 
Sec. 2-693. - Use of eligibility lists compiled from test results. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners is authorized to utilize eligibility lists compiled by utilization of test results reported by the Northwest Municipal Area Police Recruitment Testing Consortium in making appointments to positions in the police service. 
(Code 1967, § 2-300) 
Sec. 2-694. - Testing agency. 
    The Northwest Municipal Area Police Recruitment Testing Consortium is authorized to act as an agency of the board of fire and police commissioners for the purpose of administering tests as authorized in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 2-301) 
Sec. 2-695. - Bylaws of consortium approved by city. 
    The city approves the bylaws of the Northwest Municipal Area Police Recruitment Testing Consortium, a copy of which is expressly incorporated by reference in this section and made a part of this section as though fully set forth in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 2-302) 
State Law reference- Intergovernmental cooperation, Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, art. VII, § 10. 
Sec. 2-696. - Fire lieutenants' promotional process. 
    Contrary to 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1 and 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-15, the board of fire and police commissioners shall have no jurisdiction or authority regarding the promotional testing and/or appointment processes for the rank of fire lieutenant. The jurisdiction and authority for administering the promotional testing and/or appointment processes for the rank of fire lieutenant shall reside in the office of city manager or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 06-65, § 1, 11-28-2006) 
Secs. 2-697-2-720. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - COMMISSION FOR THE DISABLED 

Sec. 2-786. - Created. 
    There is created a commission to be known as the Rolling Meadows Commission for the Disabled. 
(Code 1967, § 2-521) 
Sec. 2-787. - Purpose. 
    It shall be the purpose of the commission for the disabled to make recommendations to the city council on matters pertaining to the health and welfare of the citizens of the city who are disabled; to evaluate, implement, sponsor, and promote programs for the disabled citizens of the city; to assist existing groups in providing programs for the disabled citizens of the city; to act as a liaison between residents and other organizations on issues related to the disabled, and encourage participation by the disabled in programs offered by the commission and the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-522) 
Sec. 2-788. - Urban affairs committee. 
    The urban affairs committee shall administer and perform the functions and duties of the commission for residents with disabilities. The commissions for residents with disabilities is a subcommittee of the urban affairs committee. 
(Ord. No. 04-04, § 4, 2-10-2004) 
Sec. 2-789. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-790. - Powers, duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The commission for the disabled shall prepare and submit, annually, to the city council, a statement of goals and objectives for the coming year and a summary of activities for the current year. Such report shall be submitted to the city council on the anniversary of the establishment of the commission. 
(b)  The commission shall prepare, adopt, and implement such rules and regulations as are necessary to conduct the business of the commission. 
(c)  The commission shall investigate the needs and concerns of the people with disabilities including housing, employment, education, physical and mental health, nutrition, legal aid, retirement roles and activities, spiritual well-being, transportation. 
(d)  The commission shall analyze complaints of citizens with disabilities. 
(e)  The commission shall create programs of publicity and public education and sensitivity about persons with disabilities. 
(f)  The commission shall develop programs of benefit to persons with disabilities. 
(g)  The commission shall conduct public hearings, carry on research, obtain data, and issue reports and recommendations to the city council. 
(h)  The commission shall evaluate, implement, sponsor, and promote programs for the disabled and make recommendations to the city council for sponsorship of such programs by the city. 
(i)  The commission shall, not less than annually, report to the city council its revenues from all sources and its expenditures. The commission shall also submit to the city council, not less than annually, a proposed annual budget of the amounts required to support the administrative functions of the commission. The city council may, in its sole discretion, determine whether or not to fund any or all of the request of the commission for funds. 
(Code 1967, § 2-525) 
Sec. 2-791. - Meetings. 
(a)  The commission for the disabled shall hold its regular meetings at the call of the chairperson. 
(b)  Four members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. A majority of a quorum is required for approval of all motions to come before the commission. 
(c)  The commission shall keep written minutes of its meetings and proceedings, which shall be available at the office of the city clerk, except to the extent minutes may not be disclosed to the public pursuant to the provisions of the Open Meetings Act. 
(d)  Commission meetings shall be open to the public and shall be conducted pursuant to the requirements of the Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 2-526; Ord. No. 98-09, § 23, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 2-792. - Subcommittees. 
    The commission for the disabled may appoint residents, not members of the commission, to serve on subcommittees created for the purpose of special programs, projects, or activities. 
(Code 1967, § 2-527) 
Sec. 2-793. - Parliamentary procedures. 
    The rules of parliamentary practice comprised in the latest published edition of Roberts Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern the commission for the disabled in all matters to which the rules are applicable and to the extent they are not inconsistent with the commission's adopted rules of procedure. 
(Code 1967, § 2-528) 
Secs. 2-794-2-820. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Human relations, ch. 54. 

Sec. 2-821. - Created. 
    There is created a human relations commission for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-500) 
Sec. 2-822. - Purposes. 
    The purposes for which the human relations commission is created are to: 
(1)  Encourage understanding and respect between residents of the city of various racial, religious and nationality backgrounds. 
(2)  Safeguard the rights of all citizens, as defined by city ordinances, state statutes and constitution. 
(3)  Promote the amicable settlement of disputes between neighbors. 
(Code 1967, § 2-501) 
Sec. 2-823. - Urban affairs committee. 
    The urban affairs committee shall administer and perform the functions and duties of the human relations commission. The human relations commission is a subcommittee of the urban affairs committee. 
(Ord. No. 04-04, § 6, 2-10-2004) 
Sec. 2-824. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-825. - Meetings, quorum, rules of procedure. 
(a)  The human relations commission shall meet not less than annually on a day and time designated by it and may further meet at such other times as it may designate or as otherwise required and shall keep minutes of its meetings, which shall be available to the public. 
(b)  The facilities of the city hall shall be available to the commission for all meetings. 
(c)  Four members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
(d)  The commission may adopt rules of order and procedure for the conduct of its business. 
(e)  The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, is authorized to fill any vacancy which may arise for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1967, § 2-504) 
Sec. 2-826. - Functions. 
    The functions of the human relations commission shall be to: 
(1)  Consult and cooperate with other public agencies in furthering the purposes of the commission as set forth in section 2-822. 
(2)  Pursue a communitywide program of education to encourage intergroup understanding. 
(3)  Inquire into human relations matters referred to it by citizens or city authorities. 
(4)  Seek voluntary compliance with ordinances and statutes relating to civil rights. 
(5)  Enlist the aid of schools, religious institutions, service organizations and civic groups to promote understanding and good will among the people of the community. 
(6)  Administer and adjudicate, when required, matters arising under the article II of chapter 54 pertaining to fair housing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-505) 
Secs. 2-827-2-855. - Reserved.

DIVISION 8. - VETERAN'S COMMITTEE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1999, set out provisions pertaining to the creation and duties of the veteran's committee. To maintain the numeric sequencing of this Code, these provisions have been included as §§ 2-875-2-881 at the editor's discretion to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-875. - Veteran's committee created. 
    There is hereby created a committee of the city to be known as the veteran's committee. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-99) 
Sec. 2-876. - Committee make-up/qualifications/term of office. 
(a)  The veteran's committee shall be made up of seven members appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. 
(b)  Members shall be selected on the basis of experience and or knowledge of veteran's affairs and concerns; at least five of the members must have served in one of the American military branches. 
(c)  Members shall serve overlapping three-year terms. At the time of initiation of the committee, the members shall use a lottery to determine which members shall serve one-, two-, or three-year terms to commence the overlapping practice. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-877. - Chairman and vice chairman. 
    The chairman and vice chairman shall be subject to designation by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-878. - Purposes of the committee. 
    The purposes of the committee are to: 
(1)  Promote awareness and recognition of the contributions made by active and veteran members of the armed forces to sustaining and improving the quality of life in the community and country. 
(2)  Ensure that proper maintenance is provided for the city's veteran's monument. 
(3)  Encourage and coordinate veteran's organization participation in city related activities. 
(4)  Examples of projects that the committee could be involved with include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Planning and implementing an annual Memorial Day service and parade; provide joint sponsorship of programs with the city's veteran's groups such as Veteran's of Foreign Wars, American Legion, and Vietnam Veterans; 
b.  Representing the city at veteran functions; 
c.  Providing for ongoing opportunities to recognize outstanding contributions made by veterans who are residents of the city; 
d.  Providing formal recognition to city residents who might become candidates for appointment to the armed forces academies; 
e.  Reviewing and approving the annual maintenance and improvement plans for the veteran's monument; 
f.  Studying and considering possible activities, informational, educational, and recreational that may be supported by the city relating to veteran affairs; 
g.  Working with the local school district officials on programs to promote awareness of veteran's issues; and 
h.  Making recommendations to the mayor and city council on issues delegated to the veteran's committee involving veteran's affairs. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-879. - Meetings. 
    The committee shall meet on an as needed basis, at the call of the chairman. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-880. - Quorum. 
    A quorum shall be a majority of the actually appointed members. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 2-881. - Expenditures. 
    Any committee expenditures shall be subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 99-48, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Secs. 2-882-2-884. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - URBAN AFFAIRS COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-885. - Urban affairs committee created. 
(a)  Appointment. The committee shall consist of nine members to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(b)  The committee members shall be appointed to serve three year staggered terms. The initial committee members shall be appointed three for one year, three for two years and three for three years. 
(c)  Vacancies. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council shall appoint a person to fill a vacancy caused by the resignation, death or removal of a member. 
(d)  Compensation. Members of the committee shall serve without compensation. 
(e)  Procedural rules. The procedural rules set forth in section 2-44, Special committees, of this chapter 2 shall be applicable to the urban affairs committee, except as otherwise provided for a specific committee, commission or board. 
(f)  Chairman. The committee shall elect from among its members its chairman to serve for a one year term or until a successor is appointed. 
(g)  Purpose. The following committees, commissions and boards shall be subcommittees of the urban affairs committee: 
(1)  Human relations commission; 
(2)  Board of health; 
(3)  Commission for residents with disabilities; 
(4)  Ethics commission (Gift Ban Act). 
    In addition to the above duties the urban affairs committee may be assigned by the city council or city manager to review and act on other matters concerning health, safety or welfare, senior issues or special projects or investigations. 
(Ord. No. 02-07, § 7, 2-26-2002; Ord. No. 04-04, § 1, 2-10-2004) 
Secs. 2-886-2-915. - Reserved.

    That certain booklet entitled "Personnel Rules and Regulations for the City of Rolling Meadows," is adopted by reference thereto as the personnel rules and regulations for the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-320) 
Sec. 2-917. - Pay plan for city employees. 
    The position salary ranges assigned to each job classification as set forth in exhibit A, attached to Ordinance No. 81-46, which by reference is made part of this section, are adopted as the pay plan for city employees, effective December 1, 1981. 
(Code 1967, § 2-321) 
Sec. 2-918. - Pickup of employee contributions to pension fund. 
    In accordance with 40 ILCS 5/7-173.2, the city will pick up the employee contributions being paid to the pension fund. Upon receipt of a favorable ruling in regard to section 414(h) from the Internal Revenue Service by the pension fund, the city, as soon as practicable, will exclude these contributions from the gross pay of employees and will withhold federal and state income taxes on the gross pay less the contributions. This pickup of contributions will apply to all employees who are members of the pension fund. 
(Code 1967, § 2-322)

ARTICLE VII. - ETHICS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-20, § 1, adopted May 11, 2004, repealed §§ 2-968-2-977, which pertained to penalties and provisions. For complete derivation, see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 

Sec. 2-966. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms shall be given these definitions: 
    Campaign for elective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's officials duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in Section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, "compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her officials duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
    Contribution has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
    Employee means a person employed by the City of Rolling Meadows, whether on a full-time or part-time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
    Employer means the City of Rolling Meadows. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
    Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive (i) compensation for employment, (ii) service credit towards pension benefits, and (iii) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
    Officer means a person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
    Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's officials duties. 
    Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk. 
    Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in the capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
    Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 04-20, § 3, 5-11-2004) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-967. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time, as defined herein. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the city in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require another officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity (i) as part of that officer or employee's duties, (ii) as a condition of employment, or (iii) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this article. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the Federal Standards for a Merit System of Personnel Administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political party, or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 04-20, § 3, 5-11-2004) 
Secs. 2-968-2-977. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-978. - Campaign contributions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contribution means moneys, loans, debts incurred, property-in-kind, or things having a monetary value incurred or received by a candidate or his agent or other person on behalf of the candidate for use in advocating the election of the candidate; it does not include any activity to which an individual is invited in his/her official capacity. 
    Organization means a trust, partnership, committee, association, corporation, or any other group of persons. 
(b)  The following limits on campaign contributions apply to any persons campaigning for elected offices of the city every two-year period, which shall be defined as the calendar year preceding and the calendar year in which a consolidated election is held: 
(1)  Individuals. No individual may make, and no candidate for city office and/or their campaign committee may accept, a contribution of more than $250.00 in cash or in kind services. 
(2)  Organizations. No organizations shall make and no candidate for city office and/or their campaign committee may accept a contribution of more than $500.00 in cash or in kind services. 
(3)  Personal funds. The above noted limitations on campaign contributions shall not apply to the candidate's own contributions to his campaign committee. 
(Ord. No. 98-22, § 2, 5-12-1998) 
Sec. 2-979. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person subject to this article who violates any section of this article shall be subject to the following sanctions and/or penalties: 
(1)  The city council, after review of the board of ethics recommendations and conclusions, may take the appropriate corrective or disciplinary action against any person who is subject to the terms of this article and who is found by the board of ethics to have violated the provisions thereof. 
(2)  In appropriate circumstances, the city council may direct that appropriate legal proceedings be commenced for the purpose of removal from office. 
(3)  The city council may recommend a judicial proceeding to be brought, and if the person is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be guilty of knowingly violating any of the sections of this article or furnishing false, misleading, or incomplete information to the board of ethics with the intent to mislead, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine as provided in appendix B to this code. 
(Code 1967, § 2-403; Ord. No. 98-22, § 2, 5-12-1998) 
Sec. 2-980. - Effect of state law. 
    Nothing in this article shall be deemed to in any way restrict the application of any state statute or any common law provision with respect to conflict of interest, malfeasance, misfeasance, or nonfeasance in office which would otherwise be applicable to any person subject to this article. This article shall be deemed additional requirements and shall in no way be construed as a derogation under home rule of present statutory remedies or penalties or other local remedies for acts prohibited by this article. 
(Code 1967, § 2, 2-405) 
Sec. 2-981. - Sunset provision. 
    Section 2-973 pertaining to conflict of interest, and section 2-975(g) pertaining to disclosures, will expire and be of no further force and effect two years after the effective date of Ordinance No. 98-22, unless the city council within the two-year period renews section 2-973 and section 2-975(g). 
(Ord. No. 98-22, § 2 (2-405), 5-12-1998) 
Secs. 2-982-2-1015. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FREEDOM OF INFORMATION 

Sec. 2-1016. - Definitions. 
    The words used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in 5 ILCS 140/2. 
(Code 1967, § 2-360; Ord. No. 09-53, § 1, 12-15-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-1017. - Request procedures for inspection or copying of public records. 
(a)  The city shall make available to any person for inspection or copying all public records, except as otherwise provided in section 2-1022 of this article and except as such disclosure would be inconsistent with the public policy of the state as set forth in 5 ILCS 140/1. Notwithstanding any other law, the city may not grant to any person or entity, whether by contract, license, or otherwise, the exclusive right to access and disseminate any public record as defined in the Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
(b)  Subject to the fee provisions of section 2-1021 of this article, the city shall promptly provide, to any person who submits a request, a copy of any public record required to be disclosed by subsection (a) and shall certify such copy if so requested. 
(c)  Requests for inspection or copies shall be made in writing and directed to the city. Written requests may be submitted to a public body via personal delivery, mail, telefax, or other means available to the city. The city may honor oral requests for inspection or copying. The city does not require that the request be submitted on a standard form or require the requester to specify the purpose for a request, except to determine whether the records are requested for a commercial purpose or whether to grant a request for a fee waiver. All requests for inspection and copying received by the city shall immediately be forwarded to the city's freedom of information officer or designee. 
(d)  The city shall, promptly, either comply with or deny a request for public records within five business days after its receipt of the request, unless the time for response is properly extended under subsection (e). 
(e)  The time for response under this section may be extended by the city for not more than five business days from the original due date for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The requested records are stored in whole or in part at other locations than the City Hall Building, 3600 Kirchoff Road, Rolling Meadows, Illinois. 
(2)  The request requires the collection of a substantial number of specified records. 
(3)  The request is couched in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records responsive to it. 
(4)  The requested records have not been located in the course of a routine search and additional efforts are being made to locate them. 
(5)  The requested records require examination and evaluation by personnel having the necessary competence and discretion to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under section 2-1022 of this article or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
(6)  The request for records cannot be complied with by the city within the time limits prescribed by subsection (d) without unduly burdening or interfering with the operations of the city. 
(7)  There is a need for consultation, which shall be conducted with all practicable speed, with another public body or among two or more components of the city having a substantial interest in the determination or in the subject matter of the request. 
(f)  When additional time is required for any of the above reasons, the city shall, within five business days after receipt of the request, notify the person making the request of the reasons for the extension and the date by which the response will be forthcoming. Failure to respond within the time permitted for extension shall be considered a denial of the request. 
(g)  Requests calling for all records falling within a category shall be complied with unless compliance with the request would be unduly burdensome for the city and there is no way to narrow the request and the burden on the city outweighs the public interest in the information. Before invoking this exemption, the city shall extend to the person making the request an opportunity to confer with it in an attempt to reduce the request to manageable proportions. If the city responds to a categorical request by stating that compliance would unduly burden its operation and the conditions described above are met, it shall do so in writing, specifying the reasons why it would be unduly burdensome and the extent to which compliance will so burden the operations of the city. Such a response shall be treated as a denial of the request for information. Repeated requests from the same person for the same records that are unchanged or identical to records previously provided or properly denied under the Act shall be deemed unduly burdensome under this provision. 
(h)  Public records will be made available for inspection and copying pursuant to this article at 3600 Kirchoff Road, Rolling Meadows, Illinois, between 9:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and between 2:00 p.m. and 4:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, except holidays. Any request to inspect or copy or for a copy of a public record pursuant to this article shall be made to the city freedom of information officer. 
(Code 1967, § 2-361; Ord. No. 09-53, § 1, 12-15-2009) 
Sec. 2-1018. - Request procedures for inspection or copying of public records for commercial purposes. 
(a)  The city shall respond to a request for records to be used for commercial purposes within 21 working days after receipt. The response shall: 
(1)  Provide to the requester an estimate of the time required by the city to provide the records requested and an estimate of the fees to be charged, which the city may require the person to pay in full before copying the requested documents; 
(2)  Deny the request pursuant to one or more of the exemptions set out in 5 ILCS 140/7; 
(3)  Notify the requester that the request is unduly burdensome and extend an opportunity to the requester to attempt to reduce the request to manageable proportions; or 
(4)  Provide the records requested. 
(b)  Unless the records are exempt from disclosure, the city shall comply with a request within a reasonable period considering the size and complexity of the request, and giving priority to records requested for noncommercial purposes. 
(c)  It is a violation of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 ILCS 140/1, et seq., for a person to knowingly obtain a public record for a commercial purpose without disclosing that it is for a commercial purpose, if requested to do so by the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-53, § 1, 12-15-2009) 
Sec. 2-1019. - Dissemination of information about city. 
    The city shall prominently display at the City Hall Building, 3600 Kirchoff Road, Rolling Meadows, Illinois; make available for inspection and copying; and send through the mail, if requested, each of the following: 
(1)  A brief description of itself, which will include but not be limited to a short summary of its purpose; a block diagram giving its functional subdivisions; the total amount of its operating budget; the number and location of all of its separate offices; the approximate number of full-time and part-time employees; and the identification and membership of any board, commission, committee, or council which operates in an advisory capacity relative to the operation of the city or which exercises control over its policies or procedures or to which the city is required to report and be answerable for its operations; and 
(2)  A brief description of the methods whereby the public may request information and public records, a directory designating the freedom of information officer or officers, the address where requests for public records should be directed, and any fees. 
(Code 1967, § 2-362; Ord. No. 09-53, § 1, 12-15-2009) 
Sec. 2-1020. - List of records available from city.
