State Law reference- State license classifications, 235 ILCS 5/5-1. 
Sec. 6-37. - Restriction on number and classification. 
(a)  The total number and classification of liquor licenses to be issued by the city shall be, unless otherwise changed by action of the city council: 
(1)  Nine class A-1 licenses. 
(2)  Eleven class A-2 licenses. 
(3)  One class A-3 licenses. 
(4)  Nine class B licenses. 
(5)  Two class B-1 licenses. 
(6)  Class C licenses as required for persons with entities meeting the requirements of subsection 6-36(d) of this Code. 
(7)  Five class D licenses. 
(8)  One class E license. 
(9)  One class P license. 
(10)  Six class D-1 licenses. 
(11)  Zero class G1 licenses. 
(b)  If any license of any class is not renewed or the license is surrendered, canceled, revoked, suspended, or otherwise terminated, such license shall be rescinded and not be restored, and the total number of liquor licenses of that class to be issued by the city shall be reduced accordingly. 
(Code 1967, § 3-9; Ord. No. 97-21, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 97-22, § 1, 4-8-1997; Ord. No. 97-30, § 1, 4-22-1997; Ord. No. 98-32, § 1, 6-23-1998; Ord. No. 98-63, § 2, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 99-22, § 1, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 99-29, § 3, 6-8-1999; Ord. No. 99-37, § 1, 7-27-1999; Ord. No. 99-53, § 1, 12-14-1999; Ord. No. 00-32, § 1, 7-25-2000; Ord. No. 01-17, § 1, 5-8-2001; Ord. No. 01-24, § 1, 7-24-2001; Ord. No. 01-08, § 1, 2-13-2001; Ord. No. 01-42, § 1, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 02-05, § 1, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 02-09, § 1, 2-26-2002; Ord. No. 02-72, § 1, 11-12-2002; Ord. No. 03-26, § 1, 3-11-2003; Ord. No. 03-40, § 1, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 04-06, § 5, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 04-18, § 1, 4-27-2004; Ord. No. 04-70, § 1, 10-26-2004; Ord. No. 07-03, § 1, 2-27-2007; Ord. No. 07-19, § 1, 6-26-2007; Ord. No. 07-26, § 2, 7-10-2007; Ord. No. 10-10, § 1, 4-6-2010; Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 5-25-2010; Ord. No. 10-25, § 2, 8-10-2010; Ord. No. 10-30, § 1, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 10-51, § 1, 12-14-2010; Ord. No. 11-25, § 1, 8-23-2011; Ord. No. 12-05, § 1, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 12-17, § 1, 4-10-2012; Ord. No. 12-40, § 1, 11-27-2012; Ord. No. 13-61, § 1, 12-3-2013; Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 1-14-2014; Ord. No. 14-13, § 3, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. 14-18, § 1, 6-10-2014; Ord. No. 14-19, § 1, 7-22-2014; Ord. No. 14-51, § 1, 12-23-2014; Ord. No. 15-60, § 1, 11-24-2015 ; Ord. No. 18-24, § 3, 6-2-2018) 
State Law reference- Authority to limit number of licenses, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 
Sec. 6-38. - Terms. 
(a)  Class A1, A2, A3, B, B-1, D, E, P and G1 licenses shall terminate one year from issuance of the license. 
(b)  Class C licenses: 
(1)  Shall be issued for a single premise, for a single event and single period or event which shall not exceed 15 days in duration. The maximum number of class C licenses that may be issued for a premise for any 12 consecutive month time period is ten with no more than seven of said licenses being available to applicants that are not the owner or lessee of the premises for which a class C license is sought. The maximum number of class C licenses that may be issued to the same licensee during any 12 consecutive month time period is seven. 
(2)  Shall be subject to the closing hours as specified in section 6-77 for class A-1 licenses, as determined by the calendar day for which the license is issued; and 
(3)  May not be renewed. 
(c)  If a license created by the city council remains unissued or is issued but the licensed premises remains unopened for a period of one continuous year, at the end of the one-year period the license shall automatically be rescinded without further action of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 3-10; Ord. No. 99-29, § 4, 6-8-1999; Ord. No. 99-30, § 3, 6-22-1999; Ord. No. 04-06, § 6, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 07-26, § 3, 7-10-2007; Ord. No. 12-04, § 4, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 14-13, § 4, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. 18-24, § 4, 6-2-2018) 
Sec. 6-39. - Fees. 
(a)  The fees for the various classes of alcoholic liquor licenses shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  Fees for all classes of licenses are payable upon application thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 3-11; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 14-13, § 5, 5-27-2014) 
Sec. 6-40. - Disposition of fees. 
    All fees required by this article shall be paid to the business relations officer and shall forthwith be turned over to the director of finance. If the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, the fee shall be deposited in the general corporate fund or in such other fund as shall have been designated by the city council by proper action. 
(Code 1967, § 3-12) 
Sec. 6-41. - Records. 
    The business relations officer shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses issued under this article and shall furnish the mayor, treasurer and chief of police, each, with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of any license or the revocation of any old license, the mayor shall give written notice of such action to each of these officers within 48 hours of such action. 
(Code 1967, § 3-13.1) 
Sec. 6-42. - Transferability. 
(a)  An alcoholic liquor license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for only the period specified therefor in section 6-38 of this article, except a nonbeverage user's license, unless sooner revoked as provided in this article, and shall not constitute property nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of the deceased licensee and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privilege of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt until the expiration of such license, but no longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. Except for a nonbeverage user's license, a refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such license in accordance with this subsection. Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose, and provided, further, that the renewal privilege provided for in this article shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the city council from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction. No retailer's license shall be renewed if the department of revenue has reported to the state liquor control commission that such retailer is delinquent in filing any required tax returns or paying any amounts owed to the state until the applicant is issued a certificate by the department of revenue stating that all delinquent returns or amounts owed have been paid by guaranteed remittance or the payment agreement to pay all amounts owed has been accepted by the department. No retailer's license issued by a local liquor control commissioner shall be renewed unless the applicant provides documentation that any tax owed to (i) the municipality in which the applicant is located (in the case of a license issued by the mayor or president of the board of trustees of a city, village or incorporated town acting as local liquor control commissioner) or (ii) the county in which the applicant is located (in the case of a license issued by the president or chairman of a county board acting as local liquor control commissioner) by the applicant has been satisfied by payment in the form of a cashier's check, certified check, money order, or cash. A negotiable instrument received as payment for a license fee, transfer fee, late fee, offer in compromise, predisciplinary conference settlement, or fine imposed by order that is dishonored on presentation shall not be considered payment and shall be cause for disciplinary action. 
(b)  The liquor commissioner in his/her sole discretion, may issue a temporary liquor license: 
(1)  If the holder of a liquor license enters into a contract for the sale of the business pending the issuance of a liquor license to the prospective new owner. 
(2)  If an application is filed for the issuance of a liquor license for premises not currently holding a liquor license, provided there is a liquor license of the class applied for available. 
The liquor commissioner must be satisfied that the proposed temporary license holder will operate the business in accordance with applicable state and city laws and is of good character. The duration of the temporary license shall be 90 days or the time required to review the new owner's application for liquor license and to complete an investigation of the applicant to enable the liquor commissioner to make a decision on the application for the liquor license, whichever time is lesser. The issuance of the temporary license creates no property right in the holder thereof nor does it increase the number of licenses available under this article nor does it predispose or require the liquor commissioner to issue the applied for liquor license. 
A temporary license shall not be issued unless the applicant has posted with the liquor commissioner proof of dram shop liability insurance as specified in section 6-34(8) of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 3-14; Ord. No. 98-09, § 24, 3-24-1998; Ord. No. 00-32, § 2, 7-25-2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-1. 
Sec. 6-43. - Responsibility of owner of premises for violations. 
    If the owner of the premises licensed pursuant to this article or any person from whom the licensee derives the right to possession of such premises or the agent of such owner or person shall knowingly permit the licensee to use such licensed premises in violation of the terms of this chapter, the owner, agent or other person shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article to the same extent as the licensee and shall be subject to the same punishment. 
(Code 1967, § 3-24) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/10-2. 
Sec. 6-44. - Liability of licensee for acts of agents, employees. 
    Every act or omission of whatever nature constituting a violation of any of the sections of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such employer or licensee, and the employer or licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by him personally. 
(Code 1967, § 3-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/10-3. 
Sec. 6-45. - Warning sign for underage drinking and driving. 
    Every alcoholic liquor licensee shall display at all times in a prominent place on the licensed premises a printed card which reads substantially as follows: 
UNDERAGE DRINKING AND DRIVING 
If you buy alcoholic liquor for or deliver alcoholic liquor to an underage person, you may be fined $1,000.00. If you are under 21, you may be fined $1,000.00 if you purchase alcoholic liquor, if you misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor, and if you drive with alcoholic liquor in your vehicle or while impaired by alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-26) 
Sec. 6-46. - Violations. 
(a)  The mayor, as city liquor control commissioner, shall have all of the authority granted to local liquor control commissioners by the Liquor Control Act of 1934 and as set forth in this section pursuant to the city's home rule authority, including but not limited to the authority to suspend, cancel, revoke, or otherwise terminate any license issued by him or impose a fine for the violation of any applicable law, ordinance, regulation, or rule. 
(b)  In lieu of or in addition to the suspension or revocation of the license, the liquor control commissioner may levy a fine on the licensee for such violations. The fine imposed shall be as provided in appendix B to this Code. Proceeds from such fines shall be paid into the general corporate fund of the city treasury. 
(c)  In addition to the suspension, revocation or imposition of a fine pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) of this section, the liquor control commissioner may require that the licensee found guilty under this section pay some or all of the city's expenses in regard to the prosecution of the liquor violation, including but not limited to attorney's fees, court reporter expenses, investigator's fees or witness fees. 
(d)  However, no revocation, suspension or fine shall be imposed on any licensee except after a public hearing by the liquor control commissioner with not less than a three-day written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend. 
(e)  An appeal of an order or action of the local liquor control commissioner shall be limited to the official record of the proceedings, as certified by a certified court reporter or certified shorthand reporter, which official record shall be filed with the state liquor control commission by the liquor control commissioner within five days after written notice from the licensee of the filing of such appeal. The appellant licensee shall pay the cost of the hearing transcript. 
(f)  In any case in which a licensee appeals to the state commission a suspension, revocation or fine by the local liquor control commissioner which is the second suspension, revocation, or fine imposed on that licensee within the preceding 12-month period, the suspension, revocation or fine shall be in effect until a reversal of the local liquor control commissioner's order has been issued by the state liquor commission or court having jurisdiction thereof, and the licensee during the appeal process shall cease all activity otherwise authorized by the license. 
(Code 1967, § 3-27; Ord. No. 97-44, § 2, 6-10-1997) 
State Law reference- General duties of local liquor control commissioners, 235 ILCS 5/4-2; revocation of local licenses, 235 ILCS 5/7-5. 
Sec. 6-47. - Financial records. 
    Each licensee that sells, gives or delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises shall, upon request of the city license officer, but at least annually, at the time or its application for renewal of its alcoholic liquor license, deliver to the city license officer a copy of its financial statement, tax returns or other evidence satisfactory to the license officer certified under oath, by the licensee or an officer of the licensee, as being true and correct, to verify what percentage of the licensee's annual gross sales from all sources is attributable to the sale or delivery of food, non-alcoholic beverages, and alcoholic liquor. 
(Ord. No. 99-29, § 7, 6-8-1999) 
Sec. 6-48. - Minors prohibited on licensed premises. 
(a)  No licensee or any officer, associate, agent or employee of a licensee shall permit a person under the age of 21 years to enter and remain in that portion of a licensed premises that sells, gives or delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. 
(b)  The prohibition under paragraph (a) above, shall not apply to any licensed premises, where selling, giving or delivering alcoholic liquor is not the principal business of the licensee on the premises. 
(c)  The prohibition under paragraph (a) above shall not prevent the licensee from employing persons who have attained the age of 18 years to serve alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises provided the licensee operates on the premises a restaurant or food shop and the selling, giving or delivering of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business of the licensee at those premises. 
(Ord. No. 04-06, § 7, 2-24-2004) 
Sec. 6-49. - Requirement for class B-1 and D-1 licenses. 
    Every class B-1 and D-1 licensee shall provide for the following: 
(1)  The hours for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be prominently posted inside of the premises. 
(2)  The cabinets or coolers containing alcoholic beverages shall be locked during hours when alcoholic beverages cannot be sold. 
(3)  Employees shall have security cameras to monitor the portion of the premises containing alcoholic beverages where those areas are not visible from the location of the cash register. 
(Ord. No. 10-27, § 4, 8-24-10) 
Secs. 6-50-6-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES 

Sec. 6-76. - Sanitation; inspections required. 
    Every person licensed under this chapter who shall sell any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises of such licensee shall keep and maintain the adequate sanitary washing facilities for the cleaning of glasses and service utensils, shall provide adequate toilet facilities for both males and females, and shall otherwise comply with all health and sanitary requirements of this Code and city ordinances applicable to the licensed business. All employees shall be clean in person and in clothing, and no person afflicted with any contagious diseases in communicable form shall be employed in or about the serving of liquor or in the washing of the glasses or other utensils. It shall be the duty of the city health officer to make periodic inspections of the licensed premises, and the period between inspections shall not exceed one year. 
(Code 1967, § 3-15) 
Sec. 6-77. - Hours and days of sale. 
(a)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under class A1 or A2 licenses alcoholic liquors in the city on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m., the following morning; on Fridays from 11:00 a.m. to 3:30 a.m. Saturday morning; and on Saturday from 11:00 a.m. to 3:30 a.m. Sunday morning. On New Year's Eve, alcoholic liquors may be sold at retail until 4:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(b)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under class G1 licenses alcoholic liquors and the use of video gaming machines in the city between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m., the following morning. On New Year's Eve, alcoholic liquors may be sold at retail until 3:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(c)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under class A3 licenses alcoholic liquors in the city between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m., the following morning. On New Year's Eve, alcoholic liquors may be sold at retail until 3:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(d)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer to sell at retail under a Class E license, alcoholic liquor in the city on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. the following morning; on Friday from 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. Saturday morning; and on Saturday from 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. Sunday morning. On New Year's Eve, alcoholic liquor may be sold at retail until 4:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(e)  (1)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under a Class B license and Class B-1 license any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m., each day of the week. 
(2)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under a Class D-1 license any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday; on Saturday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight; and on Sunday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(f)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under a class C license any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday; on Saturday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight; and on Sunday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. 
(g)  It shall be lawful to sell or offer for sale at retail under a class D license any alcoholic liquor in the city between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Sunday; and on Friday and Saturday between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail alcoholic liquor in the city other than during the hours specified in this section. During the times when alcoholic liquor may not be sold or offered for sale at retail, the premises for which a class A1, A2, A3, C, D, E, or G1 license has been issued shall be closed, provided that the premises of restaurants, hotels, and clubs may be kept open in addition to the hours referred to in this section for purposes other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-16; Ord. No. 97-21, § 4, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-29, § 6, 6-8-1999; Ord. No. 04-06, § 8, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 07-26, § 4, 7-10-2007; Ord. No. 09-19, § 2, 5-12-2009; Ord. No. 10-27, §§ 2, 3, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 14-13, §§ 6, 7, 5-27-2014; Ord. No. 17-10, § 1, 3-28-2017; Ord. No. 18-24, §§ 5, 6, 6-2-2018) 
State Law reference- Authority to limit hours of sale, 235 ILCS 5/6-14. 
Sec. 6-78. - Persons under legal disability. 
(a)  No alcoholic liquor licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee shall sell, give, or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years or to any intoxicated person, except as provided in 235 ILCS 5/6-16.1. No person, after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give, or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of 21 years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service. If a licensee or officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of the licensee is prosecuted under this subsection for selling, giving, or delivering alcoholic liquor to a person under the age of 21 years, the person under 21 years of age who attempted to buy or receive the alcoholic liquor may be prosecuted pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/6-6-20, unless the person under 21 years of age was acting under the authority of a law enforcement agency, the state liquor control commission, or a local liquor control commissioner pursuant to a plan or action to investigate, patrol, or conduct any similar enforcement action. 
(b)  If a licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee believes or has reason to believe that a sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the age of the prospective recipient, the licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee shall, before making such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification, containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties. For the purpose of preventing the violation of this subsection, any licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic liquor to any person who is unable to produce adequate written evidence of identity and of the fact that such person is age 21 years or older. Proof that the defendant-licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee demanded, was shown, and reasonably relied upon such written evidence in any transaction forbidden by this subsection is an affirmative defense in any criminal prosecution therefor or to any proceeding for the suspension or revocation of any license based thereon. It shall not, however, be an affirmative defense if the licensee or any principal, officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee accepted the written evidence knowing it to be false or fraudulent. 
(Code 1967, § 3-17) 
Sec. 6-79. - Buildings belonging to city. 
    No alcoholic liquor shall be sold or delivered in any building belonging to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-20) 
Sec. 6-80. - Underage persons. 
(a)  No licensee or any officer, associate, agent or employee of a licensee shall permit a person under the age of 21 years to enter and remain in that portion of a licensed premises that sells, gives or delivers alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises. 
(b)  The prohibition under paragraph (a) above, shall not apply to any licensed premises that operates a restaurant and where selling, giving or delivering alcoholic liquor is not the principal business of the licensee at those premises. 
(c)  No licensee or any principal officer, associate, member, representative, agent, or employee of such licensee shall permit, on the licensed premises, the drawing, pouring, or mixing of alcoholic liquor or the attending of any bar by a person under the age of 21 years. 
(d)  The prohibition under paragraph (a) above shall not prevent the licensee from employing persons who have attained the age of 18 years to serve alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises provided the licensee operates on the premises a restaurant or light food service establishment and the selling, giving or delivering of alcoholic liquor is not the principal business of the licensee at those premises. 
(Code 1967, § 3-21; Ord. No. 98-31, § 1, 6-9-1998; Ord. No. 99-29, § 8, 6-8-1999) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-29, § 8, adopted June 8, 1999, repealed former § 6-80 and set out provisions for a new § 6-80. Formerly, said section pertained to similar subject matters. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 6-81. - Card playing. 
    There shall be no card playing on the premises of any holder of a liquor license from the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-22) 
Sec. 6-82. - Pool and billiard tables. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or keep more pool or billiard tables in any premises licensed pursuant to the alcoholic liquor code than allowed by the city's zoning and business license regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 3-23; Ord. No. 98-09, § 25, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 6-83. - Required training and education for sellers and servers. 
(a)  Upon the original or renewal application for any retail liquor license issued pursuant to this chapter, other than a class C license, photocopies of the certificates of completion of all persons to be named on such license and of all persons having direct day-to-day operational responsibility of the premises to be licensed, including but not limited to all owners, managers, supervisors, and direct-serve bartenders, of a program designed to educate or train employees who sell or serve alcoholic beverages at retail to identify and address persons displaying problems with alcohol misuse or abuse, which program is licensed by the state department of alcoholism and substance abuse pursuant to 235 ILCS 5/6-27, shall be filed with the business relations officer. All alcoholic liquor sold or served in a licensee's establishment shall be under the operational supervision of a person whose certificate of completion is on file with the business relations officer. 
(b)  All new owners, managers, supervisors, and direct-serve bartenders of a licensee, within 90 days from the commencement of their ownership of or employment by such licensee, shall complete a program as required by subsection (a) of this section and, upon completion thereof, shall file a photocopy of the certificate of completion with the business relations officer. Until such completion, all alcoholic liquor sold or served in a licensee's establishment by such new owner, manager, supervisor, or direct-serve bartender shall be under the operational supervision of a person whose certificate of completion is on file with the business relations officer. 
(c)  This section applies to banquets and private functions on licensed premises. 
(d)  A photocopy of each certificate of completion required by this section to be filed with the business relations officer shall at all times be posted in clear view on the premises of the licensee. 
(e)  Each establishment covered under this section shall post in an appropriate area conspicuous to alcohol servers an intoxication awareness chart. [2] 
(f)  In addition to other penalties imposed in this chapter, a person violating this section may be required to again complete a training program. 
(g)  Any business in violation of this section shall be fined as provided in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 3-28) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The intoxication awareness chart attached to Ord. No. 90-75 is not printed herein, but is on file, together with the ordinance, in the office of the business relations officer. 

Secs. 6-84-6-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - UNDERAGE DRINKING AND DRIVING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses relating to minors, § 70-156 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106. 

Sec. 6-111. - Definitions. 
(a)  All words and phrases used in this article that are defined in the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.) or in the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.) shall have the meanings accorded to such words and phrases in such acts, except as otherwise defined in this section. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Identification card means written, printed, or photostatic evidence of age and identity. 
    Parent means a natural, biological, or adoptive parent of, a legal guardian of, or a person standing in loco parentis to the person referred to. 
    Underage person means a person under age 21 years. 
    Vicarious liability means indirect liability which is imposed as a matter of law, even though the person liable may not have directly caused an injury to another person. 
(Code 1967, § 3-51) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-112. - Prohibited acts of underage persons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an underage person in the city to: 
(1)  Consume alcoholic liquor. 
(2)  Purchase alcoholic liquor. 
(3)  Accept a gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor. 
(4)  Have alcoholic liquor in his possession. 
(5)  Present, offer, or use an identification card which is false, fraudulent, forged, or not actually his own for the purpose of ordering, purchasing, attempting to purchase, procuring, or attempting to procure alcoholic liquor. 
(6)  Have in his possession any false, fraudulent, or forged identification card. 
(7)  Alter an identification card or obtain an identification card by means of false information. 
(8)  Misrepresent his age for the purpose of ordering, purchasing, attempting to purchase, procuring, or attempting to procure alcoholic liquor. 
(9)  Transport, carry, possess, or have any alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon a street or highway in the city while a driver of such motor vehicle. 
(10)  Transport, carry, possess, or have any alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon a street or highway in the city while a passenger of such motor vehicle. 
(b)  Subsections (a)(1) and (4) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  The possession, dispensing, or consumption by an underage person of alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious service or ceremony. 
(2)  The consumption by an underage person of alcoholic liquor under the direct supervision and approval of that underage person's parent in the privacy of a home. 
(c)  Subsections (a)(4), (9), and (10) of this section shall not apply to possession of alcoholic liquor or to transporting, carrying, possessing, or having alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon a street or highway in the city by an underage person making a delivery of such alcoholic liquor in pursuance of the order of his parent or in pursuance of his employment, provided, however, that such alcoholic liquor is in its original package with its seal unbroken; nor shall subsection (a)(4) of this section apply to persons aged at least 18 years working on licensed premises in accordance with section 6-80. 
(Code 1967, § 3-52) 
Sec. 6-113. - Prohibited acts of all persons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person in the city to: 
(1)  Sell, give, deliver, or dispense alcoholic liquor to an underage person. 
(2)  Knowingly permit or knowingly or negligently fail to prevent, on premises under his control, the consumption of alcoholic liquor by an underage person. 
(3)  Knowingly permit or knowingly or negligently fail to prevent the operation of a motor vehicle in his control by an underage person, when the person knew or in the exercise of ordinary judgment should have known that the underage person had consumed any amount of alcoholic liquor within two hours prior to when the permission was granted or prior to such operation. 
(4)  Sell, give, or furnish to an underage person a false or fraudulent identification card of such underage person. 
(5)  Sell, give, or furnish to an underage person an identification card of any other person. 
(6)  Pay for or rent a hotel or motel room or facility for the purpose of or knowing that the room or facility is to be used by an underage person for the unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  Subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  The giving, delivering, or dispensing of alcoholic liquor to an underage person or permitting the consumption of alcoholic liquor by an underage person in the performance of a religious service or ceremony. 
(2)  The giving, delivering, or dispensing of alcoholic liquor to an underage person or permitting the consumption of alcoholic liquor by an underage person, under the direct supervision and approval of that underage person's parent in the privacy of a home. 
(c)  The following shall apply to subsection (b)(2) of this section: In any prosecution of a person for the commission of any state or local offense when such person was an underage person, the prosecutor, upon reasonable grounds to so believe, may request a ruling as to whether the consumption of alcoholic liquor, as permitted by the person's parent, caused the commission of the offense. If it is so determined in the affirmative, subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section shall apply and the parent shall be vicariously liable as set forth in section 6-116. 
(Code 1967, § 3-53) 
Sec. 6-114. - Driving under influence of unlawfully consumed alcoholic liquor. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of division 3 of article III of chapter 106 of this Code pertaining to reckless, negligent driving, etc., an underage person shall not drive or be in actual physical control of any vehicle within the city while the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath is greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, based on the definition of blood and breath units in section 106-203 of this Code, and the alcohol concentration is caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  An underage person requested to submit to a test as provided in subsection 106-202(a) of this Code shall be warned by the law enforcement officer requesting the test that a refusal to submit to the test may result in a fine of up to $1,000.00. The underage person shall also be warned by the law enforcement officer that if the underage person submits to the test provided in subsection 106-202(a) of this Code and the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath is greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, a fine of up to $1,000.00 may be imposed. 
(c)  Upon the trial of any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any underage person while driving or in actual physical control of a vehicle while the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath is greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, the concentration of alcohol in the underage person's blood or breath at the time alleged as shown by analysis of the underage person's blood, urine, breath, or other bodily substance shall give rise to the presumption that the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath was caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor; provided, however, that this shall not be construed as limiting the introduction of any other relevant evidence bearing upon the question of whether the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath was caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(d)  If an underage person under arrest refuses to submit to a chemical test under the provisions of section 106-202 of this Code, evidence of refusal shall be admissible in any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while the underage person was driving or in actual physical control of a vehicle while the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath was greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, and the alcohol concentration was caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(e)  An underage person requested to submit to a test as provided in subsection 106-206(a) of this Code shall be warned by the law enforcement officer requesting the test that a refusal to submit to the test or submission to the test resulting in an alcohol concentration of greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08 may result in a fine of up to $1,000.00. The results of any test administered pursuant to section 106-206 of this Code, other than a test conducted with a portable device, may be used in any civil or criminal action. Upon the trial of any civil or criminal action or proceeding arising out of acts alleged to have been committed by any underage person while driving or in actual physical control of a vehicle while the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath is greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, the concentration of alcohol in the underage person's blood or breath at the time alleged as shown by analysis of the underage person's blood, urine, breath, or other bodily substance shall give rise to the presumption that the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath was caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1967, § 3-54) 
Sec. 6-115. - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating section 6-112, 6-113, or 6-114 of this article shall in addition to any other penalty, fee, liability, or obligation imposed by this article or by a court of law be fined as provided in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 3-55) 
Sec. 6-116. - Vicarious liability. 
(a)  The following persons shall be vicariously liable to any individual who has been injured by an underage person who was under the influence of unlawfully consumed alcoholic liquor at the time alleged, when the consumption of alcoholic liquor by the underage person caused the injury: 
(1)  Any person who sold, gave, delivered, or dispensed alcoholic liquor to the underage person in violation of this article, or who supervised or approved the consumption of alcoholic liquor by the underage person in violation of this article. The person making the initial delivery to an underage person remains liable to anyone injured by the same or a different underage person, regardless of how many times the alcoholic liquor changed hands. 
(2)  Any person in control of a premises who knowingly permits or knowingly or negligently fails to prevent consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises by an underage person in violation of this chapter. 
(3)  Any person in control of a motor vehicle who knowingly permits or knowingly or negligently fails to prevent the operation of such motor vehicle by an underage person in violation of this article, when the person knew or in the exercise of ordinary judgment should have known that the underage person had consumed any amount of alcoholic liquor within two hours prior to when the permission was granted or prior to such operation. 
(4)  Any person who pays for or rents a hotel or motel room or facility for the purpose of or knowing that the room or facility is to be used by an underage person for the unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor in violation of this article. 
(b)  The vicarious liability established by this section shall not be subject to the limitations on damages as set forth in section 6-21 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/6-21). 
(Code 1967, § 3-56) 
Sec. 6-117. - Impoundment of motor vehicle. 
(a)  The following shall apply when an underage person is cited for transporting, carrying, possessing, or having alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon a street or highway in the city, while either a driver or passenger of such motor vehicle, and when an underage person is cited for operating a motor vehicle in the city while the alcohol concentration in the underage person's blood or breath is greater than 0.00 but less than 0.08, and the alcohol concentration is caused by the underage person's unlawful consumption of alcoholic liquor: 
(1)  The motor vehicle shall be subject to immediate impoundment by the police department, and the following factors shall not be considerations in determining whether to impound the motor vehicle: 
a.  The alcoholic liquor is in an opened or an unopened container; 
b.  The underage person is the owner of the alcoholic liquor; or 
c.  The underage person had knowledge of the presence of the alcoholic liquor within the passenger area of the motor vehicle. 
(2)  Upon impoundment, the motor vehicle may be released only to another person who was not a driver thereof or a passenger therein at the time alleged, showing proof of ownership of or lease rights to the motor vehicle. If the underage person is the owner or lessor of the motor vehicle, the motor vehicle may be released only to a parent or the spouse of the underage person. If the underage person has no parent or spouse, upon satisfactory proof of such fact, the motor vehicle may be released to the underage person as set forth in subsection (3) of this section. 
(3)  The motor vehicle shall not be released to a driver of or to a person who was a passenger in the motor vehicle at the time alleged unless at least 24 hours have passed from the time of the citation. 
(4)  The motor vehicle shall not be released until the person seeking the release has paid an administrative fee as provided in appendix B to this Code to the police department, not including towing and storage costs paid directly to the vendor, if any. 
(b)  The obligations and fees in this section shall be in addition to any penalties that may be assessed in a court of law for any charge incident to the stop. 
(Code 1967, § 3-57) 
Sec. 6-118. - Immunity from liability. 
    Any law enforcement officer, the police department, and the city and its officers, agents, and employees shall be absolutely immune from any liability or exposure to liability of any kind or nature for the enforcement or implementation of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 3-58) 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes:
