    If any official shall disapprove a license or permit application and the applicant for a license or permit shall be in business or shall have engaged in the occupation for which a license or permit is sought, it shall be the duty of such official to take such action as shall be necessary to compel compliance with this Code or the provisions of any ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 12-15) 
Sec. 22-17. - Procedures for filing affidavits. 
    Every applicant may be required to swear to any statement made in connection with the application for the issuance of any license or permit. When any applicant for a license or permit is required to make any statement contained in the application under oath or when the sureties on the bond to be executed in connection with the issuance of a license or permit are required to be sworn to any statement made therein or when any affidavit is required to be made in connection with the issuance of a plate or emblem by the license officer, such affidavit may be made by the applicant before a notary in the office of the city clerk, and such affidavit shall be sworn to before any officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Code 1967, § 12-16) 
Sec. 22-18. - License and permit fees established; payment. 
(a)  Fees associated with each class of license or permit, as noted in this chapter, shall be established by the city council, as set out in Appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  Every application for a license or permit shall be accompanied by a payment equivalent to total fee due for any license or permit issued under this chapter or pertinent sections of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-19; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-19. - Payment of license or permit fees in advance; receipt. 
    Whenever a license or permit cannot be issued at the time application for the license or permit is made, the department of finance shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. All such records shall have plainly indicated thereon that the receipt of payment of the license or permit fee is not to be construed as the issuance of a license or permit. 
(Code 1967, § 12-20) 
Sec. 22-20. - Effect of paying license or permit fees in advance. 
    No such receipt, as provided in section 22-19, or the payment of any license or permit fee in advance of the issuance of the license or permit in due form shall entitle or authorize any person to any of the rights or privileges conferred by the issuance of any license or permit or to the opening or maintaining of any business or establishment contrary to any of the sections of any chapter of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-21) 
Sec. 22-21. - Refund of fees for denial of license or permit. 
    If the city denies the issuance of a license or permit, one-half of the fee will be returned to the applicant, while the remaining half will be retained by the city to cover the cost of the investigation of the applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 12-22; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-22. - Liability for vending machine fees. 
    The owner, lessee or licensee of premises wherein vending machines required to be licensed pursuant to this chapter are located shall be jointly liable with the owner for the payment of license fees for the vending machines. 
(Code 1967, § 12-23) 
Sec. 22-23. - Disposition of fees. 
    All fees collected under and by virtue of this Code shall be immediately turned over to the director of finance to be deposited in the corporate fund. 
(Code 1967, § 12-24; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-24. - License and permit period. 
(a)  Except as provided below, the term for licenses and permits required under this chapter or this Code shall be from January 1 to December 31. 
(b)  The term for licenses required for cigarette and tobacco dealers, coin-operated devices, and vending machines shall be from January 1 to December 31. 
(c)  The term for licenses for building trade contractors shall be one year from date of issuance by the building official. 
(Code 1967, § 12-25; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997; Ord. No. 00-19, § 6, 6-13-2000; Ord. No. 07-45, § 1, 11-27-2007) 
Sec. 22-25. - Prorating of license or permit fees for new businesses. 
    The license officer shall prorate the license or permit fee for new businesses based on the number of months between the time that the license or permit is issued and the end of the term for the license. The total fee due to the city shall be divided by 12 and then multiplied by the whole or part of the months remaining until the business' or occupation's license or permit is scheduled to expire to determine the appropriate amount due. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997; Ord. No. 00-19, § 7, 6-13-2000) 
Sec. 22-26. - Rebates and refunds. 
    No rebate or refund shall be made of any license or permit fee or part thereof because of the death of the licensee or because of nonuse of such license or because of a change of location or occupation of such license or permit; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to prevent the city council from authorizing a refund of a license or permit fee or a portion thereof where the license or permit fee was collected through an error. 
(Code 1967, § 12-27) 
Sec. 22-27. - Delivery of licenses, permits and insignia. 
    Where all requirements provided in this chapter or applicable sections of this Code have been complied with, the license officer or building official shall be permitted to transmit by mail any license certificates, permits and license plates, tags, badges, emblems and other insignia to qualified applicants. 
(Code 1967, § 12-28; Ord. No. 00-19, § 8, 6-13-2000) 
Sec. 22-28. - Change in location. 
    If any person licensed to engage in a business or occupation at a particular place shall, before the expiration of the license or permit period, desire to change the location of such place of business, he shall forthwith notify the license officer of the fact. No business or occupation shall be engaged in under the authority of such license or permit at such new location until notice of such change has been given as provided in this section and until such licensee or permittee shall have complied with all the provisions of applicable ordinances and sections of this Code relating to the engaging in of such business or occupation at such new location, including the approval of the official who originally approved the application for the license or permit. 
(Code 1967, § 12-29) 
Sec. 22-29. - Increase in fees for change in class, location. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any licensee or permittee, by increasing the number of his employees or the amount of business done by him or the size of his plant or the number or size of his vehicles or by making any change of any kind in his business, places himself in a class where the provisions of any ordinance or sections of this Code require him to pay a higher license fee, he shall pay the additional license fee prorated for the balance of the license period and shall be entitled to receive a supplemental license and such additional license plates, badges, tags, emblems or insignia as may be required. 
(Code 1967, § 12-30) 
Sec. 22-30. - Transfer of license or permit authorized; procedure. 
    Where the transfer is not otherwise prohibited, any person to whom any license or permit shall have been issued may, with the permission of the license officer, assign and transfer the license or permit to any other person of approved character and qualifications. Such assignment shall be executed in the form prescribed by the license officer. The person to whom such license is issued or the assignee of such licensee shall surrender such assigned license or permit to the license officer and, if required to do so by the license officer, shall also surrender any license certificate, permit, tags, plates, badges, emblems or other insignia which have been issued to the licensee or permittee. A new license shall then be issued for the unexpired term of the old license, authorizing the assignee or transferee of such license to engage in the same business or occupation at such place as may be named in such new license. However, no business or occupation shall be engaged in at any new location until such assignee or transferee shall have complied with the provisions of any ordinance or section of this Code relating to the engaging in of such business or occupation at such new location. In all cases where a bond is required, the person obtaining each new license shall give a bond with sureties which shall conform as near as may be to the bond upon which such surrendered license was issued. 
(Code 1967, § 12-31) 
Sec. 22-31. - Number of transfers restricted; transfer fee. 
    No more than one transfer of ownership shall be allowed for any license or permit issued pursuant to this chapter or this Code. Except where otherwise expressly provided, the fee for the transfer shall be established by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 12-32; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-32. - Additional plates, tags, insignia. 
    When any section of this Code or any ordinance requires a license or permit to be obtained and the regulations pertaining thereto also require the licensee or permittee to obtain and exhibit a plate, tag, badge, emblem or other insignia, it shall be the duty of the license officer to deliver such insignia without additional charge to the person paying the license fee, and such fee shall be considered as including the cost of such insignia. 
(Code 1967, § 12-33) 
Sec. 22-33. - Materials, construction and contents of plates, tags, insignia. 
    Any plate, tag, badge, emblem or other insignia required by this chapter or other section of this Code shall be impervious to weather. Except for metal tags or badges, numbers shall be produced in words or figures. 
(Code 1967, § 12-34) 
Sec. 22-34. - Display of license, permit, insignia. 
(a)  When a license certificate or permit is delivered to any licensee or permittee who has designated therein a building, room, store, office or place in which the licensed or permitted business or occupation is to be conducted, it shall be the duty of the licensee or permittee to post the license certificate or permit in a conspicuous place upon the licensed or permitted premises. 
(b)  When a license emblem or other insignia is delivered to a licensee or permittee for use in connection with a business or occupation of a licensee or permittee, it shall be the duty of the licensee or permittee to affix the insignia on the inside glass part of the window of the establishment licensed or permitted which faces upon the public way or to the inside glass part of the door opening upon the public way. Such insignia shall be so placed as to be plainly visible from the public sidewalk, and the view of it shall not be obstructed by merchandise or other obstacles. When a license is issued for premises which do not have a window or door with glass opening directly upon the public way at a first-floor level, such license insignia shall be affixed to the glass in the door, window, showcase, or other prominent place in the proximity of the public or principal entrance to such establishment, except where expressly provided otherwise by any section of this chapter or other city ordinance. 
(c)  No license, certificate, plate, badge, tag, emblem or other insignia shall be permitted to remain posted or displayed after the period for which the license was issued has expired. 
(Code 1967, § 12-35; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-35. - Loss of license. 
    If any licensee or permittee who has been furnished a license in accordance with this chapter or applicable section of this Code shall lose the license, it shall be within the discretion of the license officer to authorize the issuance of a duplicate license, upon making of an affidavit of loss by such person and payment of a fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-36; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-36. - Altering, damaging or removing license certificate. 
(a)  No person shall add to, alter, deface or counterfeit any license certificate which has been or is being issued by the city. 
(b)  No person shall destroy, obliterate, take, remove, or carry away, without the consent of the owner, any license certificate which has been issued by the city. However, the certificate may be removed after the licensed business has been discontinued or the licensed premises have been abandoned. Nothing contained in this subsection shall prevent the city manager from removing any license certificate from the possession of a former licensee, his premises, or any vehicle when the license has been revoked under this chapter or any ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 12-37) 
Sec. 22-37. - Lending or giving certificate to another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or permittee to loan or give away any license certificate issued to such licensee or permittee. 
(Code 1967, § 12-38) 
Sec. 22-38. - Displaying unlawfully acquired plate, tag, insignia. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or display any license certificate or license plate, tag, badge, emblem or other insignia which has been unlawfully acquired. 
(Code 1967, § 12-39) 
Sec. 22-39. - Renewal of license or permit. 
(a)  Prior to the expiration of any license or permit or class of licenses or permits, the license officer or building official shall cause to be made an investigation or inspection as to the character or fitness of any applicant for a license or as to the proper location or condition of premises in which the business or occupation is to be conducted. 
(b)  Any business failing to properly renew their license by June 30th each year will be assessed a 100 percent late fee. If the city's finance department does not receive the payment by July 15th of each renewal year, the finance director is authorized to seek satisfaction of the outstanding obligation through the use of the services of a collection agency. The subject business will also be subject to prosecution for failure to renew their business license in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 12-40; Ord. No. 00-19, § 9, 6-13-2000; Ord. No. 01-11, § 1, 3-27-2001) 
Sec. 22-40. - Suspension, revocation of license or permit; appeal. 
(a)  When the conduct or operation of any business, occupation, activity or establishment, whether licensed or unlicensed, shall constitute a nuisance in fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general welfare or where the holder of any license or permit shall have refused to allow an inspection of his premises or has refused to furnish a sample of his goods for testing, the city manager shall be authorized to summarily order the cessation of business and the closing of the premises until the danger no longer exists. 
(b)  Within eight days after a license or permit is suspended, the city manager shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the license or permit should be revoked. 
(c)  Licenses and permits issued by the city, unless otherwise provided, may be revoked or suspended by the city manager after notice and hearing as provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the license or permit. 
(2)  Any violation by the licensee or permittee of any section of this Code or other city ordinance relating to the license or permit, the subject matter of the license or permit or the premises occupied. 
(3)  Conviction of the licensee or permittee of any felony or of a misdemeanor where such conviction indicates his inability to operate a safe, honest and legitimate business operation within the city. 
(4)  Failure of the licensee or permittee to pay any fine, penalty or charge owed to the city. 
(5)  Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling or any interference with a duly authorized city officer or employee while in the reasonable performance of his duties in making such inspections. 
    Such suspension or revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other applicable sections of this Code or other city ordinances. 
(d)  Notice of the hearing for suspension or revocation of a license or permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee or permittee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. If the licensee shall request a continuance in the date of the hearing, the ten-day suspension shall be in effect until two days after the final hearing date. 
(e)  At the hearing, the authorized city official shall present the complaint and shall represent the city. The licensee or permittee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The city manager shall preside and shall render the decision. 
    The form and technical rules of evidence shall not apply. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. 
(f)  A stenographic or electronically recorded record of the hearing shall be kept. The city shall pay the cost of attendance fees of the reporter and the cost of the transcript, if such transcript shall be ordered by the city. The licensee or permittee shall pay the cost of any transcript ordered by him. 
(g)  Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later than 30 days after such conclusion, the city manager shall file a written decision in which he has summarized the evidence and has stated the reasons for his decision. The decision and order of the city manager shall be final and binding. 
(Code 1967, § 12-41; Ord. No. 13-53, §§ 1, 2, 11-26-2013; Ord. No. 16-23, § 1, 2, 9-27-2016) 
Sec. 22-41. - Enforcement against unlicensed businesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the license officer or building official to examine or cause to be examined all persons and places of business subject to licensing or permitting for the purposes of ascertaining whether or not such license or permit has been procured. For neglect or refusal of any person to procure a license or permit as required by this chapter or this Code or any ordinance, the license officer or building official shall have authority and shall be in his/her duty to take such action as he/she deems necessary to enforce the license or permit requirement, but may not suspend or revoke the license pursuant to section 22-40. 
(Code 1967, § 12-42; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997; Ord. No. 00-19, § 10, 6-13-2000) 
Sec. 22-42. - Police powers. 
    The license officer, building official, and all license and permit investigators and inspectors shall have the right to cause to be cited any person who violates any of the license or permit provisions of any chapter of this Code and shall have the right of entry, at any time, to any place of business for which a license or permit is required for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the license or permit provisions have been complied with. 
(Code 1967, § 12-43; Ord. No. 00-19, § 11, 6-13-2000) 
Sec. 22-43. - Duty of enforcement official to assure compliance. 
    It shall be the duty of any official charged with the enforcement of any license or permit provision of this Code or any ordinance to take such action as shall be necessary to compel compliance with such provision. 
(Code 1967, § 12-44) 
Sec. 22-44. - Payment of license fees required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or engage in any business or occupation subject to regulation under this chapter without having paid a fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-45; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-45. - License required; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a commercial establishment, business and/or commercial enterprise or activities as enumerated in appendix B to this Code without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(b)  Unless otherwise expressly provided, any person convicted of violating any section of this chapter or applicable section of this Code shall be punished in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 12-47) 
Sec. 22-46. - Not-for-profit organizations. 
    Notwithstanding the other sections of this chapter, no charge shall be made for a license issued to a bona fide not-for-profit organization for a license required by this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 12-49) 
Sec. 22-47. - General licensing requirements; annual fee. 
(a)  Except for any business requiring a license as otherwise specifically provided for in this chapter or this Code or any business or occupation which is exclusively licensed and regulated by the state, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a business or occupation in the city without first having obtained a license. 
(b)  The annual license fee for any such business or occupation shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-50; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-48. - Liability insurance. 
    At the time an application for a business license is filed with the city, the proposed licensee who is engaged in the business of a contractor or subcontractor shall provide the city with evidence of liability insurance in the minimum amount of $100,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 08-20, § 1, 5-13-2008; Ord. No. 08-38, §§ 1, 2, 9-23-2008) 
Secs. 22-49-22-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MERCHANTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-76-22-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS 

Sec. 22-106. - License required; application; character of applicant. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale at retail of cigarettes, cigars or tobacco in any form or in any number without having obtained first a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made to the license officer, and no such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character or to any corporation that is not represented in the city by a person of good character. 
(Code 1967, § 12-307) 
Sec. 22-107. - Cleanliness, sanitation. 
    Premises and buildings used for the sale of cigarettes, cigars and tobacco shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. The health officer shall investigate such places sufficiently often to ensure compliance with this section. 
(Code 1967, § 12-309) 
Sec. 22-108. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. 06-06, adopted Apr. 11, 2006, repealed § 22-108 in its entirety. Former § 22-108 pertained to the selling, giving to minors and derived from the 1967 Code. 
Secs. 22-109-22-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FILLING STATIONS 

Sec. 22-136. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Filling station means any room, lot, yard, plant, building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place within the city where a container or tank, either portable or stationary, and containing ether, carbon bisulfite, gasoline, naphtha, benzol hydrocarbon (gas drips), liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene, turpentine or other flammable liquid having a flashpoint below 165 degrees Fahrenheit is kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale, or distributing any such liquids from such container or tank. However, this division shall not apply to any place where such flammable liquids are kept or sold for medicinal purposes only. 
(Code 1967, § 12-325) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-137. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating a filling station within the city without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-326) 
Sec. 22-138. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring to keep, operate or maintain a filling station shall make application in writing to the license officer for a license to so do, setting forth in such application the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual, or a member of a copartnership, and of the principal officer of the corporation. Such application shall set forth the location and legal description of the property on which it is desired or intended to keep, operate or maintain a filling station and the capacity in gallons of the container or tank described in this division and shall otherwise conform to the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. Every such application shall be investigated by the chief of police and the community development director to determine whether the applicable sections of this Code and city ordinances are being complied with, and the approval of such officer shall be noted thereon before a license shall be issued. 
(Code 1967, § 12-327) 
Sec. 22-139. - Location of tanks. 
    No tank for the storage and handling of flammable liquids shall be installed within 200 feet of a school, hospital, church or theater or within 150 feet of any residence or within 250 feet of any electrical distribution center. 
(Code 1967, § 12-328) 
Sec. 22-140. - Lockers for clothing required. 
    Lockers for workers' clothing must be provided, and they shall be of metal. 
(Code 1967, § 12-331) 
Sec. 22-141. - Compliance with building and fire regulations; inspections. 
    The construction and equipment of filling stations, including tanks, and the requirements for safety clearances around the construction, equipment and tanks shall be made and maintained in accordance with all sections contained in this Code and city ordinances regulating buildings and flammable liquids. Filling stations shall be inspected by the building official and the fire department at least once every year. 
(Code 1967, § 12-334) 
Sec. 22-142. - Self-service motor fuel for handicapped persons. 
(a)  All filling stations shall have on the premises during all hours of operation sufficient personnel to and which personnel shall, upon request, dispense motor fuel for the driver of a car that is parked at a self-service island and displays: 
(1)  Registration plates issued to a physically disabled person pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-116; 
(2)  Registration plates issued to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609; or 
(3)  A special decal or device issued pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2. 
(b)  If a vehicle described in subsection (a) of this section is parked and service is provided, the price charged to such handicapped driver shall not exceed the price as offered to the general public for motor fuel dispensed at the self-service island at such filling station. However, if such filling station offers full service and self-service, the attendant shall not be required to perform other services offered at the full-service islands unless such handicapped person specifically requests such services and agrees to pay the posted full-service price therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-335) 
Secs. 22-143-22-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LUMBERYARDS 

Sec. 22-171. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Lumberyard means any place used for the storage of lumber, wooden containers or wood in an amount exceeding 5,000 board feet. 
(Code 1967, § 12-370) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-172. - License required; application. 
    No person shall establish, conduct or maintain a lumberyard in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made to the license officer in writing and shall state thereon the location and size of the lumberyard for which the license is intended. 
(Code 1967, § 12-370) 
Sec. 22-173. - Piling lumber. 
    It shall be unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumberyard in such a way that the lumber is hanging over or in danger of falling onto any adjoining property, street, alley or public way. 
(Code 1967, § 12-374) 
Secs. 22-174-22-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OTHER BUSINESSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-201-22-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BARBERSHOPS 

Sec. 22-226. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a barbershop in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-459) 
Sec. 22-227. - Application for license. 
    Application for a barbershop license shall be made in writing to the license officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-460) 
Sec. 22-228. - General sanitation; diseased employees. 
    Premises used for a barbershop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and it shall be unlawful to permit waste material of any kind to accumulate therein. It shall be unlawful to employ in the barbershop any person infected with a venereal or contagious disease. 
(Code 1967, § 12-462) 
Sec. 22-229. - Implements. 
    It shall be unlawful to use in any establishment used as a barbershop any implements or tools upon any person having any skin or scalp disease without first sterilizing such implement or tool. It shall be unlawful to use any towel on any customer after the towel has been used before without having such towel sterilized and cleaned prior to such second usage. 
(Code 1967, § 12-463) 
Sec. 22-230. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer or some other person designated by the city manager to inspect every establishment licensed under this division as often as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division and all other ordinances relative thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 12-464) 
Secs. 22-231-22-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CARWASHES 

Sec. 22-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carwash means any building, structure or place in the city containing equipment used in the business of washing motor vehicles, whether coin-operated, automatic, manual or attendant-operated. 
(Code 1967, § 12-470) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-262. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, engage in, maintain, operate, carry on or manage a carwash, either by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, without first having obtained a license as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-471) 
Sec. 22-263. - Application. 
    An application for a license required under this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. Such application shall specify the type of carwash facility, the number of washing stalls to be used in the carwashing operation and water recovery or retention procedures used by the carwash. 
(Code 1967, § 12-472) 
Sec. 22-264. - Construction, operation and maintenance; refuse disposal. 
(a)  The construction, operation and maintenance of carwashes shall be done in accordance with the provisions of all applicable city codes and applicable state statutes. 
(b)  No building, structure or part thereof shall be used in any way as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the public. All floors or other surfaces shall be kept in good order and repair. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in this activity to permit any refuse resulting from this work to accumulate on or about the licensed premises. 
(Code 1967, § 12-473) 
Secs. 22-265-22-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CEMENT READY MIX PLANTS 

Sec. 22-291. - License required; application. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a cement ready mix plant or any place where sand, gravel and cement are mixed or prepared for mixing and loaded into vehicles for use elsewhere without first having obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall comply with applicable sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 12-480) 
Sec. 22-292. - Housing of equipment. 
    All conveyors or other equipment for mixing or raising sand, gravel or cement and all hoppers or containers for such material shall be so housed as to prevent the escape of dust or particles of such material. 
(Code 1967, § 12-482) 
Secs. 22-293-22-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DAY AND NIGHT CHILD CARE CENTERS AND HOMES 

Sec. 22-321. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved means that which is acceptable and approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
    Attendance means the total number of children present at any one time. 
    Capacity means the maximum number of children allowed to be present at the day care center at any one time as set by state department of children and family services or its successor agency. 
    Child means any person under 18 years of age. 
    Child development staff means all staff members providing direct care and services to the children in the facility. 
    Cot means a portable bed, mattress, cushion, or similar pad that a child may use for sleeping or resting which may be placed directly on the floor or elevated not more than 12 inches above the floor. 
    Day care center means any child care facility which regularly provides day care for less than 24 hours per day for (i) more than eight children in a family home, or (ii) more than three children in a facility other than a family home. The term does not include the following: 
(1)  Programs operated by public or private elementary school systems or secondary level school units or institutions of higher learning which serve children who shall have attained the age of three years. 
(2)  A program or that portion of the program which serves children who shall have attained the age of three years and that is recognized by the state board of education. 
(3)  Educational programs serving children who shall have attained the age of three years and which are operated by a school which is registered with the state board of education and which is recognized or accredited by a recognized national or multistate educational organization or association which regularly recognizes or accredits schools. 
(4)  A program which exclusively serves or that portion of the program which serves handicapped children who shall have attained the age of three years but who are less than 21 years of age and that is registered and approved as meeting standards of the state board of education and applicable fire marshal standards. 
(5)  Facilities operated in connection with a shopping center or service, religious services, or other similar facility where transient children are cared for temporarily while parents or custodians of the children are occupied on the premises and readily available. 
(6)  Any type of day care center that is conducted on federal government premises. 
(7)  Special activities programs, including athletics, crafts, instruction and similar activities, conducted on an organized and periodic basis by civic, charitable and governmental organizations. 
(8)  Part-day child care facilities, as defined in this section. 
(9)  A program or that portion of the program which: 
a.  Serves children who shall have attained the age of three years; 
b.  Is operated by a church or religious institution as described in section 501(c)(3) of the federal Internal Revenue Code; 
c.  Receives no governmental aid; 
d.  Is operated as a component of a religious, nonprofit elementary school; 
e.  Operates primarily to provide religious education; and 
f.  Meets appropriate state or local health and fire safety standards. 
For purposes of subsections (1), (2), (3), (4) and (9) of this definition, the phrase "children who shall have attained the age of three years" shall mean children who are three years of age not later than December 1 after the first day of the program term for any such program commencing after June 30; however, for programs commencing after December 31 but prior to July 1 of the next succeeding calendar year, the phrase "children who shall have attained the age of three years" shall mean children who are three years of age not later than May 1 after the first day of the program term. 
    Day care homes means family homes which receive not more than eight children for care during the day. The maximum of eight children includes the family's natural or adopted children under age 16 and those children who are in the home under full-time care. 
    Department or the department means the city health department. 
    Employee means a paid member of the child development staff. 
    Enrollment means the total number of children served by the facility on either a part-time or full-time basis. 
    Night care facilities means centers or family homes in which children are received for periodic care during the night when a single parent is or both parents are absent from home because of employment, emergency, or other reasonable circumstances and the children are in need of supervision during sleeping hours. A facility may be licensed for either day care or nighttime care or both, if circumstances permit and whether the same children are served according to the work shifts of their parents or other circumstances. The term "night care facilities" is further defined in the term "nighttime home." 
    Nighttime home means a family home which receives no more than eight children, including the family's own children under age 16, for nighttime care. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-322. - State licensing standards adopted. 
    There is adopted by reference the licensing standards of the state department of children and family services for day and night care centers (December 1, 1980), and for day and night care homes (February 20, 1977) and all subsequent amendments thereto except as provided in this division. Three copies of the licensing standards are on file with the health and human resources officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508) 
Sec. 22-323. - Physical facilities. 
    The physical facilities of child care homes that are provided both indoors and outdoors shall be designed to protect the health and safety of the occupants and shall meet or exceed the following requirements: 
(1)  The building housing a day care center shall be approved prior to occupancy by the city health, fire and building authorities. 
(2)  The portion of the building to which children from the center have access shall be used solely for a program of child care during the hours that the center is in operation; provided, however, that the facilities may be used for other purposes or by other persons when the children enrolled are not present. 
(3)  Any interior or exterior painted surface, including walls, floors, ceiling, equipment, toys, furnishings and cribs, shall be maintained in good order and free of lead paint. 
(4)  Electrical outlets within the reach of children shall be covered to render them shockproof. 
(5)  A telephone shall be on the premises, easily accessible for use in an emergency. Emergency phone numbers shall be posted next to the phone. 
(6)  Facilities operating on two or more floors shall have some means of formal communication between floors, such as telephones or an intercom system. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.2) 
Sec. 22-324. - Indoor space. 
    Indoor space of a child care home shall be provided in such a manner as to conduct the programs and activities of the center in a safe and comfortable environment and shall meet or exceed the following. 
(1)  There shall be a minimum of 35 square feet of activity area for each child in a center for normal children two years of age and over. Such area shall not include space for exit passages and fire escapes, which must be unobstructed, or administrative space, storage areas, bathroom, kitchen or other space required for equipment that is not used for direct activity with children. 
(2)  When cots are in use, there shall be at least two feet of space on at least two sides between the cots. 
(3)  Storage space shall be provided for cots, bedding and other equipment. 
(4)  All rooms or spaces shall be equipped and furnished in such a manner as to reduce and absorb noise. 
(5)  Any thermal hazards (radiators, hot water pipes, steam pipes, heaters) in the space accessible by children shall be out of reach of the children or shall be separated from the space by partitions, screens or other means. 
(6)  During the heating season and during periods of occupancy by children, the room temperature shall not be less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit and not more than 74 degrees, measured three feet above the floor. The facility shall be provided with natural or mechanical ventilation out of the reach of the children. 
(7)  Areas where children read, paint, or participate in other activities requiring close eye work shall be equipped with lighting sufficient to provide a minimum of 75 footcandles, measured two feet above the floor. Artificial light sources shall be protected from hazards of breakage by installation of covers or shields. Other areas may be provided with lighting of less intensity, depending on the usage; provided, however, the average footcandles for the entire activity area shall be at least 50 footcandles measured two feet above the floor. 
(8)  Windowsills shall be a minimum of two feet above the floor or shall be made inaccessible to children by means of screens, partitions or similar means. All windows shall be equipped with drapes, venetian blinds, or adjustable shades. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.3) 
Sec. 22-325. - Furnishings. 
    Furnishings and equipment in child care centers shall be durable, safe and scaled to the size of the children and shall meet or exceed the following: 
(1)  Child sized chairs shall be used. 
(2)  Tables shall be of appropriate heights and of a size to comfortably accommodate a small group of not more than eight to ten children. 
(3)  Lockers, cubicles, or separate hooks and shelves shall be provided for each child's personal belongings, including towels, washcloths and toothbrushes. 
(4)  Low, open shelves for play materials and books shall be provided within easy reach of the children. 
(5)  Storage for surplus toys and supplies not in use shall be provided. 
(6)  A cot shall be provided for each child in an all-day program. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.4) 
Sec. 22-326. - Outdoor space. 
    An outside play area shall be provided on the premises of the child care center and shall meet or exceed the following. 
(1)  The total play area shall accommodate at least 25 percent of the licensed capacity at one time. 
(2)  There shall be a minimum of 75 square feet of safe outdoor play area per child for the total number of children using the area at any one time. 
(3)  Play space shall be safely enclosed or otherwise protected from traffic and other hazards, with protective surfaces in areas where climbing apparatus is used and with surfaces suitable for children's wheeled vehicles and pulltoys. 
(4)  Play areas shall be well drained and maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary manner. 
(5)  There shall be opened and sheltered areas to permit children to enjoy activities in either sun or shade and to protect them from excessive exposure. 
(6)  If an area not connected with the facility, such as a public park or playground, is used for play or recreation, the children shall be closely supervised both during play and while traveling to and from the area. 
(7)  Outdoor equipment shall be so placed as to avoid collisions and accidents while still permitting freedom of action by the children. 
(8)  Supports for climbing apparatus and large equipment shall be securely fastened. 
(9)  Sandboxes, if provided, shall be covered when not in use and shall be cleaned daily of animal fecal matter if present. 
(10)  Outdoor storage shall be available for equipment not permanently secured to the ground, unless indoor storage space is available. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.5) 
Sec. 22-327. - Water, sewage disposal, plumbing. 
(a)  In a child care center, water, sewage disposal and plumbing must comply with applicable requirements of the city and the state plumbing codes. 
(b)  Drinking water shall be available to children of all ages from an approved fountain and/or individual disposable cups. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.6) 
Sec. 22-328. - Toilet and lavatory facilities. 
    In a child care center, toilets and lavatories shall be readily accessible to the children and shall meet or exceed the following: 
(1)  If toilets and lavatories are not child sized, safety steps shall be provided. 
(2)  Hot and cold running water shall be provided. 
(3)  Mild soap and individual towels shall be available and used. Commons towels and bar soap are prohibited. 
(4)  Hot water supplied to lavatories, bathing facilities, and other plumbing fixtures used by children shall be tempered or thermostatically controlled to not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(5)  The following ratio of lavatories and toilet facilities shall be provided: 
Number of 
Children In 
Day Care 
Facility Toilets Lavatories   1-10  1 1  11-25  2 2  26-50  3 3  51-75  4 4  76-100 5 5 101-125 6 6 126-150 7 7 151-175 8 9  
(6)  Bathroom door locks shall be openable from the outside. 
(7)  Toilets shall be within close proximity to the children's activity areas. If this is not possible in existing facilities, an adult shall accompany children four years of age and younger. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.7) 
Sec. 22-329. - Food services. 
    If food is served, the facilities must meet the requirements of article IV of chapter 50 governing food service establishments. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.8) 
Sec. 22-330. - Solid waste management. 
    All garbage and refuse within the child care center shall be collected daily and stored in a manner that will not permit the transmission of disease; create a nuisance or a fire hazard; or provide harborage for insects, rodents or other pests. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.9) 
Sec. 22-331. - Animal care and pest control. 
    Animal care and pest control shall be maintained at all times in a child care center and shall meet or exceed the following: 
(1)  All outside doors, operable windows, and other openings shall be screened during seasons requiring insect control. Doors with operable self-closing devices need not be screened. 
(2)  Chemicals for insect and rodent control shall not be applied and may not be present in areas accessible to children when children are present in the facility. 
(3)  There shall not be any turtles, dogs or cats or psittacine birds (birds of the parrot family) at the center. All pets shall be cared for as recommended by the state or local department of public health. 
(4)  No live animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in the kitchen. 
(5)  Animal cages shall be of an approved type with false bottoms and kept clean. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.10) 
Sec. 22-332. - Housekeeping. 
    The facilities of the child care center shall be cleaned daily and kept in a sanitary condition at all times and shall meet or exceed the following: 
(1)  The facility shall provide necessary cleaning and maintenance equipment. 
(2)  Toys, table tops, furniture, and other similar equipment used by children shall be easily cleanable and shall be washed and sanitized when they become soiled or contaminated with matter such as food, body secretions and/or excrements. 
(3)  Cleaning equipment, cleaning agents, aerosol cans and other hazardous chemicals and substances shall be stored in a space designated solely for this purpose and shall be inaccessible to children. 
(4)  For safety purposes all cleaning and sanitizing agents and the procedures for use shall be approved by the department. 
(5)  Exit areas shall be kept clear of equipment and debris at all times. 
(6)  Only equipment necessary to the operation and maintenance of the establishment shall be stored on the premises, unless stored in a clean condition in a room used only for that purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.11) 
Sec. 22-333. - Sleeping areas. 
    A child day care facility shall provide a separate crib, bed or cot for each child which shall meet or exceed the following: 
(1)  Cots, cribs or beds used by children in a day care facility may be used for other children at night if separate sets of clean sheets and other bedding are provided each user and if cots, cribs or beds have been aired and freshened. 
(2)  Clean sheets or blankets shall be provided at least once a week or as frequently as needed when wet and soiled. 
(3)  Waterproof mattress covers or undersheets for cribs, beds or canvas cots shall be provided for all children who are bedwetters. 
(4)  Each cot, bed or crib shall be identified with the name of the child. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.12) 
Sec. 22-334. - Diapering of children. 
    In a child care center, the diapering of children shall be accomplished in a safe and sanitary manner in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Diapering area. 
a.  The following equipment shall be provided for the diapering area: 
1.  If a child has his own cot and no other child uses that cot, that surface should be used to change the child's diaper. 
2.  If the child's cot is not used, a firm, safe table that can be cleaned and sanitized may be used. 
3.  A handwashing sink adjacent to the table with foot or knee control, not wrist control, shall be provided. 
4.  A covered container for soiled disposable items within reaching distance of the table shall be provided. 
5.  A covered laundry hamper shall be provided. 
6.  Solutions, toweling, etc., should be kept on a convenient shelf out of reach of children. 
b.  If a table is used, the table surface shall be clean from the previous diapering and one that has been washed with fresh solution and dried and covered with clean newspaper, examining table paper or clean cloth pads. 
c.  After diapering is completed, the table covering should be discarded and the table cleansed and sanitized and diapers disposed of as follows: 
1.  Disposable diapers should be discarded in a container close at hand. 
2.  If cloth and using a diaper service, instructions of the service should be followed. 
3.  If using own cloth diapers, fecal matter should be rinsed in the toilet and the diaper placed to soak in an approved chlorine solution. 
d.  Cleaning of the child's skin shall be accomplished as follows: 
1.  Cleanse the skin with mild soap and water. 
2.  A wash cloth used for cleaning, if not disposable, must be placed immediately with soiled linens for laundering. 
(2)  Safety precautions. 
a.  The solution (dophor, phenolic or chlorine) used for sanitizing the table surface shall be kept out of the reach of the children. 
b.  The solution shall be poured directly onto the table surface or to a clean cloth. 
c.  The safety of the child while on the changing surface must be considered at all times. Straps or rails must be provided. 
d.  Aerosol solutions are not allowed. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.13) 
Sec. 22-335. - Health and safety. 
    The following shall be required in each facility to protect the health and safety of children in the day care center: 
(1)  A first aid kit and a chart or handbook of first aid instructions shall be available for staff use. Training in Red Cross standard or multimedia first aid and CPR is required for one staff member on each shift. 
(2)  Each facility must include a designated area for children who become ill. Such space shall be adequately ventilated and heated and equipped with a bed or cot and materials that can be sanitized easily. Linens and disposable paper shall be changed after each use. If the area is not a separate room, it shall be separated from space used by other children by a partition, screen, or other suitable means. It shall be in close proximity to toilet and lavatory facilities and where health and sanitation measures can be carried out without interruption of activities of other children and staff. Sick children must not be left unattended. 
(3)  Medicines shall be administered only upon the direction of a physician. All medicines shall be stored away from the reach of children and shall be properly labeled and placed in watertight containers used solely for the storage of medicines. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.14) 
Sec. 22-336. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Whenever the health department finds a violation of any section contained in this division, it shall issue a written notice to the license holder or operator citing such violation and specifying the corrective action to be taken. The license holder or operator shall then have ten days to correct the cited violation. 
(b)  If the health department discovers a substantial hazard to the public health, the health officer for the department shall immediately inform the owner or operator of the day care center of the existing condition of the premises and order that the day care center close its operation until the condition is remedied. When the condition has been remedied, the department of health shall inspect the premises within a reasonable period of time and, upon finding that the condition of the day care center meets the standards contained in this division, shall allow the day care center to continue its operation. 
(c)  A substantial hazard to the public health may consist of the following: interruption of electrical, sewer or water service; severe infestation of insects or rodents; a confirmed food-borne illness due to the day care center's food service; confirmed communicable diseases; or severe unsanitary conditions of the premises. 
(Code 1967, § 12-508.15) 
Sec. 22-337. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall maintain or operate a day care home, night care home, day care center or night care center within the city without first having obtained a license for such facility from the state department of children and family services or its successor agency and a business license from the city. 
(b)  The health officer of the department is responsible for seeing that the standards for a license are met and maintained by all licensed child care facilities operating in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-509) 
Sec. 22-338. - Application for license. 
    An application for a license required under this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. Such application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The location of the day care center for which a license is sought; 
(2)  The number of children to be cared for; 
(3)  The name and address of the applicant if an individual and if a firm, partnership, or association of every member thereof, and if a corporation the principal address of the corporation and the names and addresses of its officers; and 
(4)  The name of the person under whose management or supervision the day care center will be conducted. 
(Code 1967, § 12-510) 
Sec. 22-339. - Compliance with standards. 
(a)  The premises and facilities used in a night or day child care home or center shall comply with all building, zoning, fire, health and sanitation regulations of the city. 
(b)  The day care home shall comply with the program standards as set forth in the state department of children and family services Licensing Standards for Day and Night Care Homes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-511) 
Secs. 22-340-22-365. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - DRY CLEANERS 

Sec. 22-366. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry cleaning means the process of cleaning fabrics by immersion and agitation or by immersion, only, in volatile solvents, including but not in way of limitation solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type, and processes incidental thereto, including but without limitation spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning and finishing. 
    Dry cleaning establishment means and includes any structure, store, building or other place where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting and/or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire or is sold, resold or offered for sale or resale. 
    Fabric means any article of wearing apparel, household furnishings, rugs, textiles, fur and leather. 
    Finishing means the process of pressing and/or reshaping any fabric, which is designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions and contour of the fabric. 
    Spotting means the process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry cleaning. 
(Code 1967, § 12-518) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-367. - License required; application. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the city without first securing a license therefor as provided in this division. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the license officer. No such license shall be issued to any person not complying with all of the sections of this division, with the provisions of the building code, and with all sections of this Code or city ordinances relating to flammable liquids. 
(Code 1967, § 12-519) 
Sec. 22-368. - Frame building prohibited. 
    No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. 
(Code 1967, § 12-521) 
Sec. 22-369. - Flammable wastes; open flames. 
    Dry cleaning establishments shall be kept free from inflammable wastes so far as possible, and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any kind in the premises. 
(Code 1967, § 12-522) 
Sec. 22-370. - Cleanliness. 
    The premises of a dry cleaning establishment must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept free of rats, mice and vermin. 
(Code 1967, § 12-523) 
Sec. 22-371. - Smoking. 
    Smoking in a dry cleaning establishment is prohibited, and appropriate signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. 
(Code 1967, § 12-524) 
Sec. 22-372. - Diseased employees. 
    No person having a contagious or venereal disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1967, § 12-525) 
Sec. 22-373. - Inspection; report of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police, health officer, fire marshal or other official designated by the city manager to inspect or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this division at least once every six months. Any violation of this division or other sections of this Code or ordinances relating to dry cleaners, premises and/or flammable liquids shall be reported to the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 12-526) 
Sec. 22-374. - Right of entry. 
    City officers shall have the right to enter any building or premises situated in the city and occupied by any dry cleaning establishment in order to examine the establishment and to determine whether or not the building and premises or any material, chemical or compound kept therein or used thereon or any article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted, or finished as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on such premises or building conforms to the fire regulations in effect in the city or constitutes a fire hazard within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-527) 
Secs. 22-375-22-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - FLAMMABLE AND HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS 

Sec. 22-401. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nitrocellulose products means any substance, material or compound having soluble cotton or similar nitrocellulose as a basis, including pyraline, celluloid, fibroid, fiscoloid, X-ray film, and similar materials and compounds by whatever name known, whether the raw or finished product, excepting motion picture films. 
    Portable generator means an acetylene generator of not more than 30 pounds carbide capacity, which has been approved for portable use by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. 
(Code 1967, § 12-556) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-402. - License required. 
    Under this division, a license shall be required for every person who shall do any of the following: 
(1)  Generate acetylene gas in any form of generator, holder, container or associated apparatus at a pressure exceeding 15 pounds per square inch. This shall not include portable generators used for lighting or plants devoted to the manufacture and compression of dissolved acetylene for sale. 
(2)  Engage in business of collecting or compressing acetylene gas at any pressure in excess of 15 pounds per square inch or of selling or distributing acetylene gas under pressure in excess of 15 pounds per square inch. 
(3)  Generate or compress oxygen or hydrogen in any form of generator, holder, container or associated apparatus. 
(4)  Keep or store calcium carbide in excess of 600 pounds. 
(5)  Manufacture, store or keep any nitrocellulose products in excess of 25 pounds. 
(Code 1967, § 12-557; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-403. - Warning cards. 
    For the purposes of this division, printed warning and instruction cards provided by the maker shall be posted in a conspicuous position near the generator so that the operator may consult them conveniently from time to time. 
(Code 1967, § 12-559) 
Sec. 22-404. - Repairs. 
    Any necessary repairs to a generator or system that is subject to this division shall be made during daylight hours by natural light or by the fixed lights in the generator room. The use of portable lights is strictly prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 12-560) 
Sec. 22-405. - Appliances. 
    Under this division, all blow torches, regulators and other appliances shall be maintained in good condition at all times. No appliance shall be installed in any line which causes or allows the mixture of air or other oxygen carrier with acetylene, except directly at the torch or burner. The use of an expansion tank in any part of the system is prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 12-561) 
Sec. 22-406. - Nitrocellulose products. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to store or manufacture nitrocellulose products in any building which is situated within 100 feet of any building occupied as a school building, hospital or any other place of public assembly or amusement. Softening or heating nitrocellulose products when not done by hot water shall be done on steam or electric heaters, dies, and so forth, with at least six inches of clearance to all combustible material. 
(b)  Stamping, perforating and similar machines shall be equipped with a metal receptacle containing water for receiving waste material. Metal receptacles with automatic or self-closing covers shall be provided for nitrocellulose scraps and clippings, and such scraps and clippings shall be removed from the premises each evening and disposed of in a manner approved by the health officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-565) 
Sec. 22-407. - Liquid acetylene. 
    The manufacture, transportation, storage, sale or use of liquefied acetylene is prohibited within the corporate limits. 
(Code 1967, § 12-567) 
Sec. 22-408. - Storage of chlorine gas. 
(a)  The sale, storage, use or handling of chlorine gas is prohibited within the city limits unless chlorine gas is stored in buildings constructed and maintained in accordance with the building requirements of this Code, in containers constructed in compliance with the Interstate Commerce Commission rules and regulations. 
(b)  No combustible material of any kind shall be placed or kept in any room or building used for the storage of chlorine gas. 
(Code 1967, § 12-568) 
Sec. 22-409. - Corrosive liquid storage. 
(a)  No corrosive liquids shall be stored in any building other than a corrosive liquids storage building constructed as required by this Code, except as otherwise provided by this section. 
(b)  It shall be permissible to store corrosive liquids in one or more fireproof vaults in any building other than a corrosive liquid storage building. 
(Code 1967, § 12-569) 
Sec. 22-410. - Portable generators of acetylene gas. 
(a)  Portable generators of acetylene gas shall not be installed or used inside of buildings unless a permit for such use in the location shall first be secured. It shall be the duty of the fire chief to inspect the premises wherein such generator is to be used before issuing such permit. If the inspection shows compliance with this section, the fire chief shall issue a permit for such installation and use. 
(b)  Before any cutting or welding process, the floor shall be swept clean and, if of wood, shall be sprinkled with water. The scene of such work shall be inspected 30 minutes after every such cutting or welding operation, and all smoldering sparks shall be extinguished. 
(c)  Extra gas cylinders shall not be stored in the same room in which a portable generator is used. 
(d)  Generators shall be cleaned and recharged and the air mixture shall be blown off outside of the building. Generators, when charged, shall not be moved by crane or derrick. When not in use they shall not be stored in any room in which open lights or fires are used unless free of carbide and thoroughly purged of gas. 
(e)  Storage rooms for portable generators shall be thoroughly ventilated. 
(f)  Cutting or welding operations shall not be carried on within ten feet of any combustible material other than the floor. 
(g)  Generators shall not be placed where water will freeze. Salt or other corrosive chemicals shall not be used as a protection against freezing. 
(h)  Not more than one cutting or welding flame shall be used with any portable generator unless permanently attached and wiped. 
(Code 1967, § 12-570) 
Secs. 22-411-22-440. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - STORAGE AND HANDLING OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS 

Sec. 22-441. - License required. 
    No person shall keep on hand or store for use in any business any flammable liquid having a flashpoint below 187 degrees Fahrenheit (86 degrees Celsius), closed cup tester, without first procuring a license for each location, place or premises where such person keeps on hand or stores for use any such flammable liquid. However, nothing contained in this section shall require any gasoline filling station; dry cleaner and spotter; drug, chemical or paint factory; drug, chemical or paint store; fuel oil dealer; fuel oil storer; wholesale gasoline dealer; retail hardware store or retail paint store, duly licensed under any other section of this Code, to obtain a license under this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-571) 
Sec. 22-442. - License application. 
    An application for license required by this division shall be made in conformance with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses, and in addition the applicant shall state the location of the place at which it is desired or intended to store flammable liquids for use in the applicant's business and the maximum aggregate quantity to be stored for use and shall give a description of the business engaged in, the location and capacity of all containers or tanks having a capacity of 50 or more for the storage of any flammable liquid, and such other information as may be required by the license officer. The license officer, upon receipt of such application shall investigate or cause to be investigated the place of business described in such application and the methods and equipment intended to be used by such applicant. 
(Code 1967, § 12-572; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-443. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  All containers, tanks and other equipment used for the storage or use of flammable liquids and all buildings and premises wherein the containers, tanks and other equipment are stored or used shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with this Code. 
(b)  Every container or tank for flammable liquids of a capacity of 50 gallons or more, either aboveground or within a building, and the premises and equipment used for the storage or handling of flammable liquids by any person subject to license under this division shall be inspected by the chief of police at least once each year. 
(c)  Rags and soiled waste shall be kept in metal containers pending removal from the premises. 
(d)  No person shall smoke in that part of any premises where flammable liquids having a flashpoint below 187 degrees Fahrenheit (86 degrees Celsius), closed cup tester, are stored or handled. 
(Code 1967, § 12-573) 
Secs. 22-444-22-470. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - FUEL OIL, WHOLESALE GASOLINE DEALERS 

Sec. 22-471. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fuel oil dealer means any person whose primary business is the storage of fuel oil, gasoline or petroleum in bulk for the purpose of sale, or whose primary business is the conveyance of fuel oil, gasoline or petroleum in any vehicle for the purpose of sale. 
    Fuel oil storer means any person who keeps on hand or stores fuel oil for use in any business, but not for resale. 
(Code 1967, § 12-575) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-472. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, operate or engage in the business of fuel oil dealer or wholesale gasoline dealer without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-574; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-473. - License application. 
(a)  An application for any license required under this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. The application shall also set forth whether the applicant engages in or proposes to engage in the business or activity of fuel oil dealer, wholesale gasoline dealer, or fuel oil storer. 
(b)  The application shall also set forth the number of vehicles, if any, to be used in connection with the business. 
(c)  The application shall also state whether the applicant uses or proposes to use storage facilities in connection with the business of fuel oil dealer and, if so, the location, place or premises where such storage facilities are located or are to be located and their capacities. 
(d)  The application for a fuel oil storer's license shall also state the location of the place at which the applicant desires or intends to store fuel oil for use in the applicant's business, the maximum aggregate quantity to be so stored or used, a description of the business engaged in, the location and capacity of all containers having a capacity of 50 gallons or more for the storage of fuel oil, and such other information as may be required by the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1967, § 12-576) 
Sec. 22-474. - Fire limits. 
    It shall be unlawful to store fuel or oil as a fuel oil dealer within the city fire limits. However, this section shall not apply to any fuel oil dealer who is storing fuel oil within the fire limits on or prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives. 
(Code 1967, § 12-577) 
Secs. 22-475-22-500. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - GUNS AND GUNSMITHS 

Sec. 22-501. - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of making, selling, or repairing firearms of any type, size or description without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-578) 
Sec. 22-502. - Permit to purchase. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person dealing in firearms to sell, barter, loan or give away to any person within the city firearms of any type, size or description, unless such person so purchasing or receiving such firearm shall have secured a gun owner's permit from the state for the purchase of such firearm. Persons dealing in firearms shall keep such records of these sales and transfers as the chief of police shall direct. 
(Code 1967, § 12-579) 
Sec. 22-503. - Age limits on sale of firearms and ammunition. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person of less than 18 years of age to sell any firearm or any firearm ammunition. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensed importer, licensed manufacturer, licensed dealer, or licensed collector to permit the sale of any firearm or any firearm ammunition by any person of less than 18 years of age. 
(Code 1967, § 12-580) 
Sec. 22-504. - Requisites for transfer of firearms or ammunition. 
(a)  No person within the city may knowingly transfer or cause to be transferred any firearm or any firearm ammunition to any person within the city unless the transferee with whom he deals displays a currently valid firearm owner's identification card which has previously been issued in his name by the department of law enforcement under the applicable provisions of state law. 
(b)  Any person within the city who transfers or causes to be transferred any firearm shall keep a record of such transfer for a period of ten years from the date of transfer. Such record shall contain the date of the transfer, the description or serial number or other information identifying the firearm if no serial number is available, and the transferee's firearm owner's identification card number. On demand of a peace officer such transferor shall produce for inspection such record of transfer. 
(c)  Any person within the city who transfers or causes to be transferred any firearm ammunition shall keep a record of such transfer for a period of ten years from the date of transfer. Such record shall contain the date of transfer; the description, serial number, lot number or other information identifying the ammunition if no serial number or lot number is available; and the transferee's firearm owner's identification card number. On demand of a peace officer such transferor shall produce for inspection such record of transfer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-581) 
Secs. 22-505-22-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - HARDWARE, PAINT AND ELECTRICAL SUPPLIES 

Sec. 22-531. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct the business of selling paint, varnish, oils, wallpapers, hardware, metal or wood specialties, and electrical supplies without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-583) 
Sec. 22-532. - License application and issuance. 
    For the purpose of this section each of the several businesses mentioned in section 22-531 shall be licensed as a paint and hardware store, and the owner shall make application to the license officer on a form furnished by him for a license as a paint and hardware store. The applicant shall state the name and address of the applicant and the place where the proposed business is to be carried on. The applicant shall file with the license officer such application properly executed, together with the full annual license fee. 
(Code 1967, § 12-584) 
Secs. 22-533-22-560. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - HEALTH AND RACQUET CLUBS 

Sec. 22-561. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Health club means a place or organization offering instruction, training or assistance in physical culture, body building, exercising, reducing, figure development, dancing or any other physical skill or offering for the use by an individual patron of the facilities of a health studio, gymnasium, or other facility used for any of such purposes. 
    Racquet club means a building which is equipped for playing tennis, squash, racquetball or handball with courts and locker room facilities. 
(Code 1967, § 12-596) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-562. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, maintain, operate, carry on or manage a health club or racquet club, either by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, without first having obtained a license as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-597) 
Sec. 22-563. - License application. 
    An application for a license required under this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. 
(Code 1967, § 12-598) 
Sec. 22-564. - Cleanliness and sanitation; washroom facilities. 
    The premises used for the activities described in this division shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and separate washroom facilities shall be provided for men and women. 
(Code 1967, § 12-599) 
Secs. 22-565-22-590. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - HOME OCCUPATIONS 

Sec. 22-591. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Home occupation means as defined in chapter 122 of this Code and shall be permitted and regulated by chapter 122 of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-606) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-592. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or engage in a home occupation in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-607) 
Sec. 22-593. - License application. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in writing to the license officer on a form provided by the officer. No such license shall be issued to any person not complying with all of the applicable sections of this Code and city ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 12-608) 
Secs. 22-594-22-620. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 14. - HOTELS AND MOTELS 

Sec. 22-621. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
