    Hotel or lodginghouse means and includes every building or structure kept, used or maintained as or held out to the public to be an inn, hotel or public lodginghouse or place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire to transient guests, whether with or without means, in which ten or more rooms are used for the accommodation of guests. 
    Motel or motor court means and includes cottages or cabins, either detached or connected, which are used by tourists, transients or other persons for sleeping or dwelling purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-613) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-622. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate any hotel, lodginghouse, motel or motor court within the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-614) 
Sec. 22-623. - Annual inspections. 
    Every hotel, lodginghouse, motel or motor court operated or maintained in the city shall be inspected under and by authority of the health officer at least once every year. Such inspections shall cover all matters pertaining to the sanitary conditions of the rooms, beds and bedding, including the ventilation of all rooms or occupied rooms, and also all rooms occupied by servants or other employees to ascertain sanitation. The investigation shall be sufficiently accurate and complete to convince the health officer whether the building and premises and parts thereof comply in all respects with this Code or city ordinances and the state laws pertaining to such establishments. 
(Code 1967, § 12-615) 
Sec. 22-624. - License application. 
    An application for a license required by this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter pertaining to applications for business licenses. 
(Code 1967, § 12-616) 
Sec. 22-625. - Operation. 
(a)  Every establishment licensed under this division and every part thereof shall be clean and free from any accumulation of dirt, filth, garbage and other matter in or on the establishment or in the yard, court, passage area or alley connected with or belonging to the establishment. 
(b)  The owner or keeper shall thoroughly cleanse all the rooms, passages, stairs, floors, windows, doors, walls, ceilings, privies, cesspools and drains of the house or part of the house of which he is the owner, lessee or keeper, to the satisfaction of the health officer, as often as shall be required by or in accordance with any regulation or order of the health officer. 
(c)  Every licensee shall have proper and suitable conveniences or receptacles for receiving garbage and other refuse matter. 
(d)  All water closets and urinals in or used in connection with any hotel or lodginghouse shall be disinfected as often as may be necessary to keep them in a sanitary condition. 
(e)  Each licensee having a public washroom shall keep therein at all times a sufficient supply of clean towels or drying machines in a place in sight of and with easy access to guests. 
(f)  All beds for the accommodation of guests shall be provided with a sufficient supply of clean bedding and with clean sheets. All beds shall be provided with clean sheets as often as the beds are assigned to different persons or at least semiweekly. 
(g)  The layout, development and facilities of the licensee shall conform to the standards and requirements of this Code, the building code and all other applicable city ordinances. 
(h)  The licensed premises shall be in the charge of a manager who shall be available and responsible at all times for maintaining the grounds, buildings, and facilities in a sanitary, safe, orderly and usable condition. 
(i)  There shall be an office or room where incoming occupants will be registered and where the registration records shall be maintained in approved form and kept available. 
(j)  Each sleeping unit shall be furnished with its own sanitary facilities, which shall consist of a minimum of one flush toilet, one lavatory and one bath or shower. 
(k)  Hot and cold running water shall be available at all times at lavatory, bath and shower fixtures. 
(l)  Plumbing fixtures and floors shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once daily or more often if necessary. 
(m)  Water supply and sewage disposal facilities shall be so maintained and operated as to perform their functions. 
(n)  Each sleeping unit shall be furnished with beds and bedding, which shall be in good condition, clean and adequate to maintain body comfort. 
(o)  Each occupant of a sleeping unit shall be furnished with soap and at least one clean, freshly laundered bath towel and hand towel daily. 
(p)  A comfortable temperature shall be maintained in sleeping units heated from a central plant. Where central heating is not provided, sleeping units shall be furnished with safe, convenient and adequate facilities for use by occupants as necessary. 
(q)  During hours of darkness, adequate lighting shall be maintained at all buildings and on the site. 
(r)  Fire extinguishers shall be maintained in a filled and workable condition. 
(s)  The manager shall comply with such other applicable health and sanitation rules and regulations as have been adopted under the powers granted state or county health departments. 
(Code 1967, § 12-617; Ord. No. 15-37, § 1, 9-8-2015 ) 
Secs. 22-626-22-655. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 15. - HOUSE MOVERS 

Sec. 22-656. - License required; application. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of house moving, raising or shoring without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the license officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-619) 
Sec. 22-657. - Compliance required. 
    Persons licensed under this division must comply with all regulations relating to the work being done and must pay the permit fee required for moving buildings and must keep lights and warnings maintained as is required. 
(Code 1967, § 12-621) 
Sec. 22-658. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-622) 
Sec. 22-659. - Bond required. 
    Every person licensed under this division shall file with the license officer a bond in the sum of $20,000.00, with sureties to be approved by the city manager, conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss, damage or expense occasioned by it, by any act or failure to act of the licensee or by any failure of the licensee to comply with this Code and city ordinances relating to the business of house moving or moving houses. 
(Code 1967, § 12-623) 
Sec. 22-660. - Deposit and insurance required. 
    In addition to compliance with the bond, no permit shall be issued for moving a building unless the mover deposits $2,500.00 in cash with the license officer, to cover the cost of repairing any damage to city property in connection with such moving, and the mover shows evidence of being covered by a public liability insurance policy in an amount of not less than $500,000.00. 
(Code 1967, § 12-624) 
Sec. 22-661. - Protection of pavement. 
    The pavement of any street, alley or sidewalk along which any house is moved shall be protected by two-inch planks along the route. 
(Code 1967, § 12-625) 
Secs. 22-662-22-690. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 16. - ITINERANT DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS AND STONES 

Sec. 22-691. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant dealer in precious metals and stones means any person engaged in the business of buying or selling tangible objects of gold, silver and any other precious metal or stone within the city who has not established a permanent place of business within the city from which such operation has been carried on for a period of at least 90 days prior to the first sale or purchase of such objects. 
(Code 1967, § 12-751) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-692. - Exemptions. 
    Any person wishing to buy or sell any objects described in section 22-691 from a permanent place of business shall not be subject to this division upon a presentation to the city manager of a bona fide lease, such lease to extend for a period of at least one year within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-751) 
Sec. 22-693. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of itinerant dealer in precious metals and stones in the city without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-752; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-694. - License application. 
    An application for a license as an itinerant dealer in precious metals and stones shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. 
(Code 1967, § 12-753) 
Sec. 22-695. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The chief of police or any other city official designated by the city manager shall make an investigation to determine whether the applicant for the license required by this division is a person of good character, reputation and integrity. No such license to be an itinerant dealer in precious metals and stones shall be issued to any applicant who is not found to be a person of good character, reputation and integrity, and no license shall be issued to any applicant who has been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary or robbery or any other felony in the federal or state courts. 
(Code 1967, § 12-754) 
Sec. 22-696. - Records required. 
(a)  Every itinerant dealer in precious metals and stones doing business within the city shall keep a record of every article received, purchased, sold or exchanged by the dealer, and setting forth the following information: 
(1)  The date of the transaction. 
(2)  The name and address of the purchaser or seller. 
(3)  A brief description of the article sold, purchased, received or exchanged, including an identification number, if any. 
(b)  Such records of the articles themselves shall, during normal business hours, be open to the inspection of any police officer. The record shall be delivered to the chief of police after the close of business for each day for which a license is issued by the city. Failure to deliver such record automatically revokes the license for the following day. Such record is required to be kept only on those sales within the city. 
(c)  All itinerant dealers in precious metals and stones shall subscribe to and participate in "leadsonline.com." All items purchased, pawned or pledged shall be entered into the leadsonline.com database within 12 hours of receipt of the item. 
(Code 1967, § 12-755; Ord. No. 12-26, § 1, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 22-697. - Stolen goods. 
    It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this division to report to the police any article received or offered to him if he shall have reason to believe that the article is stolen or lost and not, therefore, the property of the person offering it for sale or exchange. 
(Code 1967, § 12-756) 
Secs. 22-698-22-725. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 17. - KENNELS AND PET SHOPS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 

Sec. 22-726. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Boarding kennel or training kennel keeper means any person who raises, trains and boards pets belonging to another for the purpose of hire and profit but not for the purpose of sale, except that a boarding or training kennel keeper who includes the sale of pets or the operation of an animal shelter or pound on his business premises shall be considered a pet shop operator rather than a boarding or training kennel keeper. 
    Boarding or training kennel means any building or premises used for the business of a boarding or training kennel keeper. 
    Pet shop means any building or premises which is used for the business of a pet shop operator. 
    Pet shop operator means any person who sells, offers to sell or exchange or offer for adoption, with or without charge or donation, dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or other small animals (referred to as "pets") in this city. However, the following shall not be included within the meaning of the term "pet shop operator:" 
(1)  A person who sells only pets that he has produced and raised. 
(2)  A person who sells only pets that he has owned for a period of 90 days or longer. 
(3)  A boarding kennel or training kennel keeper, as defined in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 12-631) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-727. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pet shop or a boarding or training kennel anywhere in the city without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-632; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-728. - Certificate of health for premises; sanitation generally; humane treatment. 
    Every pet shop operator and boarding or training kennel keeper shall obtain a certificate of health from a licensed veterinarian approving his premises, and such premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material should be allowed to remain thereon for more than 24 hours. All animals shall be humanely treated. Certificates of rabies vaccination are required and shall be filed with the police department for all fur-bearing animals over four months of age. Any animal having a disease shall be properly isolated and treated. 
(Code 1967, § 12-633) 
Sec. 22-729. - Dispensing foodstuffs prohibited. 
    No pet shop, boarding or training kennel or any other system so intended for the housing of animals, birds, reptiles or similar creatures shall be located within the same enclosed area where food or drink is stored, prepared or served without compliance with the following: 
(1)  The primary business function is not that of a food establishment. 
(2)  A total and complete physical separation exists between the animals and the surrounding complex. This shall include physical separation of ventilation systems or any other system where the possibility of cross-contamination may occur. 
(Code 1967, § 12-634) 
Secs. 22-730-22-755. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 18. - LAUNDRIES AND LAUNDROMATS 

Sec. 22-756. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Laundry means any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof, which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching, or ironing shirts, dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs, or other wearing apparel; table, bed or other household linens; or towels, curtains, draperies or other washable fabrics, such work being done for the general public. The term "laundry" shall also be held to include the following: 
(1)  Any towel or linen supply laundry maintained or operated for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing towels, aprons, napkins, table linens, washable clothing, or other similar articles the property of such laundry, but rented or loaned for a consideration to patrons or customers of the laundry. 
(2)  Any private laundry maintained or operated in connection with any hotel, restaurant, or public institution, except a hospital or charitable institution, where no charge is made for laundry services. 
(3)  Any establishment wherein washing machine units are available for use by the general public upon the deposit of a coin or the payment of a fee to the operator of such establishment or his agent. 
(Code 1967, § 12-639) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-757. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of any laundry without first obtaining a license to do so. 
(Code 1967, § 12-640) 
Sec. 22-758. - License application. 
    An application for a license required by this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. In addition, the applicant shall state the maximum number of persons to be employed therein. The building department and health department shall cause an investigation to be made of the premises named and described in such application for the purpose of determining whether the sanitary conditions and the other requirements of this division are fully complied with. 
(Code 1967, § 12-641) 
Sec. 22-759. - Sanitary conditions. 
(a)  Every room or place used as a laundry or for the storage of unlaundered or laundered fabrics in connection therewith shall at all times be kept in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition as to floors, walls, ceilings, windows, woodwork, machinery, utensils, and fixtures, and every such room or place shall be kept free from rats, mice and vermin and all matters of an infectious or contagious nature. 
(b)  No wallpaper shall be applied upon the walls or ceilings of any room used for commercial laundry purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-642) 
Sec. 22-760. - Emission of vapors. 
    Vapors, smoke, or odors emanating from any laundry shall not be permitted at any time to become a nuisance to any portion of the premises in which such laundry is located nor to any adjoining or nearby premises. 
(Code 1967, § 12-643) 
Sec. 22-761. - Excessive heat. 
    Every machine or mechanical device in any laundry that is operated by an employee, if it emits or sends off excessive heat, shall be equipped with proper heat deflectors, hood and exhaust or other apparatus that will carry the heat from the room or place in which the device is located. 
(Code 1967, § 12-644) 
Sec. 22-762. - Separation of laundered and unlaundered articles. 
    Every person conducting or operating any laundry shall be required to provide proper facilities and equipment for the separate handling of clean and soiled articles, and no clean or laundered articles shall be allowed to come in contact with any unlaundered or soiled articles of any kind at any time. 
(Code 1967, § 12-645) 
Sec. 22-763. - Sterilization of articles. 
    No person conducting or operating any laundry in which wearing apparel, household linens, towels, bedding, or any other fabrics are received and treated through the process of washing shall remove or cause to be removed from such premises any laundered article until the article has been thoroughly sterilized by keeping it in the washing machine, vat, or other vessel provided for that purpose or maintained at a temperature of 175 degrees Fahrenheit for at least 20 minutes, by subjecting it to live steam under pressure, by keeping it in a drying house or drying tumbler in which the temperature is not less than 215 degrees Fahrenheit for a period of not less than 15 minutes, or by passing it through any ironing machine where the ironing surface is at a temperature of not less than 225 degrees Fahrenheit. However, this shall not apply for silks and woolens or other fabrics that would be injured by such processes, and silks, woolens and other fabrics shall be treated with soap, bleach, or such other standard disinfectant solutions as shall be approved by the health department. 
(Code 1967, § 12-646) 
Sec. 22-764. - Establishment of new laundries. 
    Any person establishing a new laundry shall be required to submit to the health department, for its approval, a complete set of plans and specifications of the building in which any such new laundry is to be located and a complete diagram of the floor plan of each room to be occupied by such new laundry, correctly showing the arrangement or setting of all machinery and equipment to be installed therein and provisions for the sanitary operation of the business. 
(Code 1967, § 12-647) 
Sec. 22-765. - Plans for laundromats. 
    Any person establishing a laundry of the coin-operated, self-service type shall be required to submit to the building department for its approval a complete set of plans and specifications and a complete diagram of the floor plan of each room to be occupied by such establishment, showing the arrangement or setting of all machinery and equipment to be installed therein. Each such plan shall be explicit and complete. 
(Code 1967, § 12-648) 
Secs. 22-766-22-795. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 19. - LAUNDRY VEHICLES 

Sec. 22-796. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Laundry vehicle means any wagon, automobile or other vehicle used for the purpose of delivering soiled clothes or other items to a laundry operating within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-649) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-797. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated, on any of the public ways, any laundry vehicle without first having obtained a license. 
(Code 1967, § 12-650) 
Sec. 22-798. - License application. 
(a)  An application for a license required by this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter relating to applications for licenses. In addition, the applicant shall state the character of the vehicle for which the license is applied. 
(b)  The health department shall cause such investigation to be made as is necessary for the purpose of determining whether such laundry vehicle complies with the sanitary and health regulations applicable thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 12-651) 
Sec. 22-799. - License emblem. 
    Every laundry vehicle licensee shall obtain from the city clerk, at the time that the license therefor is issued, a license emblem. Such license emblem shall have stamped thereon the words "laundry vehicle." such license emblem shall be affixed to the inside glass part of the windshield of the laundry vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 12-652) 
Sec. 22-800. - Name of laundry on vehicle. 
    No vehicle of any kind shall be used for the purpose of collecting or delivering laundry work, unless the vehicle shall carry upon two sides of the vehicle, in plain legible letters at least 11/2 inches high, the name of the laundry where the laundry work is actually done. 
(Code 1967, § 12-653) 
Sec. 22-801. - Sanitation. 
(a)  All vehicles used for the transportation of laundry shall at all times be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be properly equipped with means to separate the laundered from the unlaundered fabrics. Every such vehicle shall have separate containers for bedding, linen, and wearing apparel which may be taken from places where quarantine has been established or where persons are convalescing after a disease. 
(b)  Such vehicles shall be inspected under the direction of the health department as often and at such times as the department may deem necessary or proper in order to keep them in a proper sanitary condition, and inspectors shall make reports in writing to the department of any violation of the general city sanitary and health regulations in the operation of such vehicles or of any unsanitary or unclean conditions with respect to the transportation or delivery of laundered and unlaundered fabrics as may come to their attention. 
(Code 1967, § 12-654; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Secs. 22-802-22-830. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 20. - LAWN AND TREE CARE SPECIALISTS 

Sec. 22-831. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, remove, trim, spray, or otherwise treat lawns, trees, or shrubs for compensation within the city without a license. Application for a business license shall be made in accordance with this chapter to the license officer and shall contain the name and address of the applicant if an individual, the names and addresses of the members of a partnership, and the names and addresses of the principal officers of a corporation. Such application shall include a brief statement of the experience of such individual, firm, or corporation in such business. 
(b)  A current copy of the licensee's public liability, property damage, and workers' compensation insurance policies must be on file with the city and included with such application for the business license. 
(Ord. No. 96-46, § 2 (12-655), 9-24-1996) 
Sec. 22-832. - License fee. 
    The fee for the business license required by this division shall be as adopted by the city council and set out in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 96-46, § 2 (12-656), 9-24-1996) 
Secs. 22-833-22-860. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 21. - MACHINE SHOPS 

Sec. 22-861. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Machine shop includes every workshop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped or repaired by means of a lathe or other machinery. 
(Code 1967, § 12-658) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-862. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or manage a machine shop in the city without first having obtained a license therefor. However, this division shall not be construed as requiring an additional license for any class of machine shops specifically licensed under any other section of this Code or city ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 12-659) 
Sec. 22-863. - Cleanliness and safety generally. 
    No building, structure or part thereof used for in connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the public. The owner, lessee, occupant or manager of any such machine shop shall cause all floors or other surfaces around or beneath any machine or work bench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient and sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are intended for any other use. All cutting compounds or fluids shall be kept free from harmful or infectious matter. 
(Code 1967, § 12-661) 
Sec. 22-864. - Operation at night. 
    No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. in any place in which a majority of the buildings within a radius of 600 feet are used exclusively for residence purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-662) 
Sec. 22-865. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-663) 
Secs. 22-866-22-895. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 22. - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 22-896. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employee means any and all persons, other than a massage therapist, who renders any service for a licensee under this division and who receives compensation directly from such licensee, but who has no physical contact with customers, patrons, or clients of such licensee. 
    Massage or massage therapy means a system of structured palpation or movement of the soft tissue of the body. The system may include, but is not limited to, techniques such as effleurage or stroking and gliding, petrissage or kneading, tapotement or percussion, friction, vibration, compression, and stretching activities as they pertain to massage therapy. These techniques may be applied by a licensed massage therapist with or without the aid of lubricants, salt or herbal preparations, hydromassage, thermal massage, or a massage device that mimics or enhances the actions possible by human hands. The purpose of the practice of massage, as licensed under the Illinois Massage Licensing Act (the "Act") (225 ILCS 57/1 et seq.) is to enhance the general health and well-being of the mind and body of the recipient. "Massage" does not include those acts of physical therapy or therapeutic or corrective measures that are outside the scope of massage therapy practice as defined by the Act. 
    Massage establishment means any building or portion thereof at which massage services are provided by a massage therapist. 
    Massage therapist means a person who is licensed by the Department of Professional Regulation of the State of Illinois and administers massage for compensation. 
(Code 1967, § 12-664.1; Ord. No. 04-47, § 2, 8-24-2004) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-897. - Business license required, transferability. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct, or carry on or to permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on the operation of a massage establishment in the city without having first been issued, pursuant to this division, a city business license for each individual location within the city under which the operation of a massage establishment is conducted. 
(b)  No business license issued under this division shall be transferable or assignable to any other person or any other location. 
(Code 1967, § 12-664.2; Ord. No. 04-47, § 2, 8-24-2004) 
Sec. 22-898. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-298, which pertained to permit requirements for massage therapists and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-664.3. 
Sec. 22-899. - License and permit applications; premises; facilities required. 
(a)  An application for a license required under this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this chapter 22 relating to applications for business licenses. 
(b)  No business license shall be issued to any person without first providing documentation that all such employees or independent contractors engaging in the practice of massage or massage therapy on the licensed premises are licensed massage therapists in accord with the provisions of the Massage Licensing Act (225 ILCS 57/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1967, § 12-664.4; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997; Ord. No. 04-47, § 2, 8-24-2004) 
Sec. 22-900. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  Every portion of a massage establishment, including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated under sanitary conditions. 
(b)  Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area in a location available to all prospective customers. 
(c)  A separate dressing room for each sex shall be available on the premises, with individual lockers for each employee and massage therapist. 
(d)  Doors to dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing. 
(e)  All massage establishments shall be provided with clean laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity which shall be laundered after each use and stored in a sanitary manner. 
(f)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, baths, and any other physical facilities shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(g)  Oils, creams, lotions, and other preparations used in administering massages shall be kept in clean, closed containers or cabinets. 
(h)  Closed cabinets shall be provided for use in the storage of clean linens, towels and other materials used in administering massages. All soiled linens, towels and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets which shall be kept separate from the clean storage areas. Nondisposable instruments and materials shall be disinfected after use on each patron. 
(Code 1967, § 12-664.5; Ord. No. 04-47, § 2, 8-24-2004) 
Sec. 22-901. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-901, which pertained to advertising restrictions for massage establishments and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-664.6. 
Sec. 22-902. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-902, which pertained to out-call registration for massage therapists and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-664.7. 
Sec. 22-903. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-903, which pertained to the employment of minors at massage establishments and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-664.8. 
Sec. 22-904. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-904, which pertained to license or permit exemptions and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-664.9. 
Sec. 22-905. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-47, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 22-905, which pertained to penalties for violations and derived from the Code of 1967, § 12-665.1. 
Secs. 22-906-22-935. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 23. - NURSING HOMES 

Sec. 22-936. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nursing home means any institution, place or family used for the reception or care, for a longer period than 24 hours, of three or more children or infants apart from their parents. It is further defined to mean any institution used for the reception or care of persons who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall be understood to include homes for the aged or infirm; orphan asylums, refuges and shelters; and, also, boardinghomes caring for three or more women with their children when such children are less than 14 years of age. 
(Code 1967, § 12-667) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-937. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the city or the state, or any association or institution for the care of children which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the state pursuant to law to open, conduct, manage or maintain any nursing home, as defined in this division, within the corporate limits without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-668) 
Sec. 22-938. - License application. 
    Any person desiring a license required by this division shall make application in writing to the license officer. Such application shall conform to the general provisions of this chapter relating to applications for licenses and shall state the location or proposed location of the home; the purpose for which it is to be opened, conducted or maintained; the accommodations for the inmates thereof; the nature and kind of care, instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given therein; the names and addresses of the officials and/or board of officials conducting, managing or maintaining the home; the name of the superintendent or chief physician, surgeon, or attending physician or surgeon or the names and addresses of the board of physicians or surgeons attending therein if there is such a board. 
(Code 1967, § 12-669) 
Sec. 22-939. - Compliance with state regulations required. 
    As required by 210 ILCS 45/3-104, nursing homes shall comply with the requirements established by the state department of public health relating to such establishments. 
(Code 1967, § 12-671) 
Sec. 22-940. - Closing of homes in violation. 
    For the conviction of any person for a violation of any of the sections of this division relating to the safety and accommodation of inmates, it shall be the duty of the health officer and he is authorized and empowered to close such home and to cause its vacation pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the occupancy of its inmates and to make it comply with the terms of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-672) 
Secs. 22-941-22-970. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 24. - PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 22-971. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Outdoor parking lot means any premises, enclosure, or other place, except a public way, within the city where two or more vehicles are stored, kept or parked for hire in a condition ready for use or where rent or compensation is paid to the owner, manager or lessee of the premises for the parking, storing, keeping or maintaining of such motor vehicles. However, the term "outdoor parking lot" shall not apply to any premises or other place where vehicles are parked for hire in a condition ready for use where such premises, enclosure or other place is not used for such purpose in excess of 90 days in any calendar year and where supervision of the parked vehicles and their ingress and egress to and from such premises is furnished; nor shall such term apply to any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place where motor vehicles owned or operated for the private use of the owner or lessee of all or part of the premises upon which such structure or enclosure is located are stored or parked in a condition ready for use; nor shall it include any premises, structure, enclosure or other place within the city where two or more vehicles are stored or parked where no rent or compensation is paid for the storing, keeping or parking of such motor vehicles. 
(Code 1967, § 12-691) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-972. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of keeping, maintaining or operating an outdoor parking lot without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-692) 
Sec. 22-973. - License application. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be made in conformity with the general license requirements of this chapter. The applicant shall also specify the number of square feet of area of such parking lot. 
(Code 1967, § 12-693) 
Sec. 22-974. - Investigation of premises. 
    Prior to issuance of a license under this division, the chief of police and community development director shall investigate the premises to determine whether the applicable sections of this Code and city ordinances have been complied with. 
(Code 1967, § 12-694) 
Sec. 22-975. - Speed limit. 
    No motor vehicle going into or coming out of or being located or parked in any outdoor parking lot shall be driven at a speed in excess of ten miles per hour. 
(Code 1967, § 12-696) 
Sec. 22-976. - Manner of parking. 
    Motor vehicles parked in any outdoor parking lot shall be parked in lines not more than two deep with a lane adequate for entering or coming out of such line being provided between the vehicles so that access by the owner or driver may be had to any such motor vehicle and so that the vehicle may be removed from the parking lot at any time. No such lane or space between lines shall be at any time blocked by a motor vehicle whose operator or occupant is not located therein. Lanes leading to and from such outdoor parking lot shall be left open so that motor vehicles parked therein may be removed at any time. 
(Code 1967, § 12-697) 
Secs. 22-977-22-1005. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 25. - PUBLIC GARAGES 

Sec. 22-1006. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a public garage in the city without having first obtained a license therefor as is provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-701) 
Sec. 22-1007. - License application. 
    An application for a public garage license shall be made in writing to the license officer, and shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. 
(Code 1967, § 12-702; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-1008. - Requirements for buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building or in any building or structure used for school, church or theater purposes or in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the building code. 
(Code 1967, § 12-704) 
Sec. 22-1009. - Cleanliness. 
    The premises of every public garage shall be kept clean and free from flammable wastes. 
(Code 1967, § 12-705) 
Sec. 22-1010. - Changing vehicle identification marks, tags. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change the identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile in any public garage. It shall be unlawful to change the license tags on such cars except in accordance with the register of motor vehicles kept by the secretary of state. 
(Code 1967, § 12-707) 
Sec. 22-1011. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and fire department to make or cause to be made such inspection of public garages as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division. Any police officer shall be permitted at any reasonable time to view every car stored or kept in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any motor or motor vehicle from such inspection. 
(Code 1967, § 12-708) 
Secs. 22-1012-22-1040. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 26. - SENIOR LIVING CENTERS 

Sec. 22-1041. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Senior living center means a facility containing individual guestrooms permanently occupied by six or more competent, continent, elderly persons 62 years of age or older which provide maid, janitorial, and food service; organized social activities; and limited transportation for its guests. It does not include nursing homes, convalescent centers, or continuing care facilities. 
(Ord. No. 97-94, § 1 (12-676), 12-9-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-1042. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the city, or the state to open or conduct, manage, or maintain any facility, as defined in this division, within the corporate limits without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 97-94, § 1 (12-677), 12-9-1997) 
Sec. 22-1043. - License fee. 
    The license fee for senior living centers shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines, and penalties as adopted from time to time by the city council and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 97-94, § 1 (12-678), 12-9-1997) 
Sec. 22-1044. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  In a senior living center, each guest's floor kitchen area shall be equipped with a sink, countertop, and table and chair set that will accommodate 15 percent of the floor's occupants. 
(b)  Resident guests must have access to laundry facilities equipped with commercial-grade washing and drying equipment. 
(c)  Each occupied guestroom shall have a working telephone capable of outside calling. 
(d)  Room occupants shall have access to controls for adjusting the room's temperature. 
(e)  Weekly maid service shall be provided, including bed changes with clean linens and clean towels. 
(f)  The facility shall have sufficient staff on a 24-hour basis to address the security, supervision, and emergency needs of the occupants. 
(Ord. No. 97-94, § 1 (12-679), 12-9-1997) 
Secs. 22-1045-22-1070. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 27. - UNDERTAKERS 

Sec. 22-1071. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain an undertaking establishment or to engage in business as an undertaker or mortician within the city without having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-721; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 22-1072. - Notice to police of delivery of body. 
    It shall be the duty of every undertaker to notify the police department whenever a body is brought to him or turned over to him for his services. 
(Code 1967, § 12-722) 
Sec. 22-1073. - Compliance required. 
    Every person maintaining an undertaking establishment or engaging in business as an undertaker or mortician within the city shall maintain his establishment and conduct his business in strict compliance with all state statutes and all sections of this Code and city ordinances pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 12-723) 
Sec. 22-1074. - Exhibition of bodies. 
    It shall be unlawful for any undertaker to permit his establishment to be used for the exhibition of the body of any deceased person to the public, other than friends and relatives of the deceased. 
(Code 1967, § 12-724) 
Secs. 22-1075-22-1100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 28. - VETERINARY HOSPITALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 

Sec. 22-1101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Veterinary hospital means any building or parcel of land used for the harboring or reception for care or treatment of two or more animals. 
(Code 1967, § 12-730) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-1102. - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate, carry on, engage in or conduct a veterinary hospital in the city without obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-731) 
Sec. 22-1103. - License application. 
    The application for the license required by this division shall be made to the license officer on a form provided by him. 
(Code 1967, § 12-732) 
Sec. 22-1104. - Investigation and issuance of license. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be referred after receipt thereof by the license officer to the health officer who, upon receipt of the application, shall cause to be investigated the premises where it is proposed to conduct the veterinary hospital, the facilities thereof, the sanitary condition thereof, and such other matters as are necessary and proper to enable them to determine whether the applicant is prepared to comply with this division. The health officer shall return the application with his report to the license officer and, on the recommendation of the health officer, the license officer shall issue a license. 
(Code 1967, § 12-733) 
Sec. 22-1105. - License denial; appeal. 
    If the health officer recommends rejection of the application for the license required by this division, the license officer shall deny the application for a license. Upon receipt of notice of the denial of the application for a license, the applicant shall have the right to appeal within five days to the city council for a hearing on the application and denial thereof. 
(Code 1967, § 12-734) 
Sec. 22-1106. - License revocation; appeal. 
(a)  Any license granted under this division may be revoked by the city manager whenever a licensee violates any of the sections of this chapter or any other section of this Code or any city ordinance or any state law pertaining to the operation of veterinary hospitals. 
(b)  If a license is revoked by the city manager, the licensee may appeal such order to the city council. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the license officer within ten days of the date of the order of revocation. 
(Code 1967, § 12-736) 
Sec. 22-1107. - Duties of licensee. 
    It is the duty of every person licensed under this division to see that: 
(1)  The veterinary hospital is kept free and clean from decaying food and from filth of any kind. 
(2)  All buildings are disinfected from time to time and kept in a sanitary condition. 
(3)  No animals detained in the veterinary hospital of the licensee are allowed to in any manner disturb the peace and quiet of any person or neighborhood. 
(Code 1967, § 12-737) 
Sec. 22-1108. - Report of rabies. 
    It is the duty of every person licensed under this division who discovers any dog or other animal to be suffering with rabies to report that fact immediately to the health officer. The report shall give the name, if known, and the place of residence of the owner of the dog or other animal; the place where the dog or other animal can be found; and the license number of the dog or other animal, if known. 
(Code 1967, § 12-738) 
Sec. 22-1109. - Location; hours of operation. 
    If any part of the veterinary hospital is located within 75 feet of any building which is used for human habitation by any person other than the licensee, the licensee shall keep all dogs inside a building between 8:30 p.m. and 7:30 a.m. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit bringing into or taking away from any veterinary hospital any dog or other animal during the hours mentioned in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 12-739) 
Secs. 22-1110-22-1119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 29. - YOUNG ADULT ENTERTAINMENT FACILITIES 

Sec. 22-1120. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    City means the City of Rolling Meadows. 
    Light food service means the ability to store, prepare, sell, and service hot and cold sandwiches, snacks, and similar food items and is separately licensed by the city as a food service establishment. 
    Premises means any zoning lot, as defined in the city zoning code, where a young adult entertainment facility is operated or maintained, including, but not limited to, all hallways, bathrooms, parking areas and any other portions of the zoning lot which is accessible to the public during operating hours. 
    Person means one or more natural persons, corporations, partnerships, associations or other entities capable of having an action of law brought against such entity. 
    Special event means an activity at a young adult entertainment facility which is marketed to patrons or prospective patrons as being of a temporary or non-routine nature. 
    Young adult entertainment facility means commercial facilities which are open to the public, the primary function of which is to offer, provide, procure, make available, allow, suffer or permit entertainment to patrons between the ages of 17 and 30 years an opportunity to engage in social activities such as dancing, or the enjoyment of live or pre-recorded music, or the enjoyment of entertainment provided by dancers or other performers. A young adult entertainment facility shall provide light food service and beverages (excluding alcoholic beverages) to its patrons from the time of opening until 11:00 p.m. 
    The term "young adult entertainment facility" does not include the following: Premises which serve alcoholic beverages as defined by state and local laws; theaters which the patrons sit in parallel rows of fixed seats; full service restaurants where the only entertainment consists of background music which is incidental to the primary function of serving food; outdoor performances; a banquet, party or celebration conducted for invited guests which is not open to the public; dances or events sponsored and operated by a governmental entity, an educational institution, or a nonprofit or charitable group duly licensed with the state and having a five year operational history in the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1121. - Young adult entertainment facility license required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, operate, manage, or maintain a young adult entertainment facility in the city without first obtaining a young adult entertainment facility license from the city. The license fee shall be based on the permitted occupancy of the young adult entertainment facility as follows: 
For occupancy up to 100 $ 1,000.00 For occupancy from 101 to 200  5,000.00 For occupancy from 201 to 300 $10,000.00 For occupancy from 301 to 600 $20,000.00  
Those establishments holding a license for occupancy to 600 may after operating for a minimum of three months apply for an increased occupancy of up to 200 patrons without the payment of any additional licensing fee. The additional occupancy shall be permitted if the establishment otherwise complies with other ordinances and codes of the city and there have been no previous revocation or suspension of the licensee's license within the preceding three months. 
Those establishments holding a license for occupancy of up to 600 people who have received an increase of occupancy of up to 200 patrons may, following a period of three months after the licensee who had occupancy for up to 800 patrons has operated at such level, receive an additional increase of occupancy by applying for an increase of occupancy of up to 200 more patrons without paying any additional fee. The additional occupancy shall be permitted if the establishment otherwise complies with other ordinances and codes of the city and there have been no previous revocation or suspension of the licensee's license within the preceding six months. No further occupancy increases shall be permitted. 
All young adult entertainment facilities shall have an occupancy limit established by the applicable fire or city codes. For the purpose of this subsection, licensed premises shall not include kitchen area, storage areas, hallways, or any area used by the licensee and/or his employees and not open to the licensee's patrons. 
A license shall be effective from the date of its issue until December 31st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1122. - License application procedures. 
(a)  An application for a license shall be made in writing to the city license officer, upon forms provided, and shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, birth date, and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof, and in the case of a corporation, the date of incorporation (in the case of a foreign corporation, the state where it was incorporated and the date of its becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact business in the State of Illinois), and the objects for which it was organized. The names, dates of birth, and addresses of any partner, any officer and any director, and if a majority in interest of the stock of a corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name, date of birth, and address of such person. 
(2)  The location of the young adult entertainment facility. 
(3)  A complete statement of all convictions of the applicant as provided in this section. If the applicant is a corporation, such statement shall include applicant's officers, and directors thereof, and any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than twenty percent of the stock of such corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, such statement shall include all general partners, and any limited partner owning more than twenty percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such partnership. Such listing shall include the following: 
a.  Any offense involving sexual misconduct with children or other sex offenses as defined in Article 11 of the Illinois Criminal Code of 1961, as amended. 
b.  A felony based upon conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, within the past ten years; or 
c.  A felony unrelated to conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, but which felony involved the use of a deadly weapon, traffic in narcotic drugs, or violence against another person, including rape, within the past five years, or 
d.  A misdemeanor or licensing ordinance violation, based upon conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, within the past two years. 
(4)  A description of the proposed young adult entertainment facility, including the anticipated age and number of patrons, hours of operation and all activities and business conducted at the same location, and the physical facilities to be used. 
(5)  A written statement setting forth all measures proposed to ensure that adequate traffic control, crowd protection and security, both inside and outside the licensed premises, will be maintained, and that the ages of the patrons admitted to the young adult entertainment facility will be monitored. 
(6)  A statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager. In such case the manager's name, address, telephone number and age shall be provided, along with a statement of any convictions as set forth under subsection (3), above. 
(7)  A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a similar other license at a location other than described in this application and the disposition of such application. 
(8)  The license fee as provided in section 22-1121. 
(9)  A site plan for the licensed premises, including a floor plan showing all entrances, exits and public areas. 
(10)  The operation and training manuals to be used for the establishment, setting forth procedures for complying with this chapter, including, but not limited to, security and age verification. 
(11)  A certificate of insurance evidencing that the applicant has secured commercial general liability insurance issued by one or more companies authorized to do business in the State of Illinois providing the following minimum coverage. 
a.  One million dollars per person, per occurrence; and 
b.  One million dollars annual aggregate. 
(b)  In the event the applicant is made aware that any information or document submitted as part of this application process is inaccurate or incomplete, the applicant shall immediately notify the city and provide appropriate corrections. Failure to accurately and completely provide, or as necessary update, required information may delay the processing of such application or result in its denial. 
(c)  In addition to the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) above, the applicant and, if applicable, the manager shall submit their fingerprints to be used in completing the investigation. Applicants are required to present themselves for fingerprints to be taken by the police department as provided by the chief of police. If the applicant is a corporation, fingerprints shall be required of applicant's officers, directors, and any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, fingerprints shall be required of all general partners, and any limited partner owning more than twenty percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such partnership. The applicant shall pay the fingerprint fee for each person required to submit fingerprints. Provided, in the case of a renewal application, fingerprints and the fingerprint fee shall not be required from a renewal applicant whose fingerprints are on file, unless the chief of police determines that there may be reason to believe that the renewal applicant may have unreported convictions. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1123. - Procedures for issuance or denial of license. 
    After receiving a complete application for a young adult entertainment facility license, the city shall follow the following procedures: 
(1)  The license officer shall forward copies of the application to appropriate city officials for their comments regarding compliance with regulations under their jurisdiction. The license officer shall consider all materials and comments submitted and issue or deny the license within 30 working days after the date on which a completed application was filed unless the applicant agrees to an extension of the time period in writing. In the event that the license officer fails to act upon any application within the time period set forth herein, such inaction shall be deemed a denial of the application 
(2)  The issuance or renewal of a young adult entertainment facility license shall be denied by the license officer for any one or more of the following reasons: 
a.  The applicant has been convicted of one or more of the following offenses: 
1.  Any offense involving sexual misconduct with children or other sex offenses as defined in Article 11 of the Illinois Criminal Code of 1961, as amended. 
2.  A felony based upon conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, within the past ten years; or 
3.  A felony unrelated to conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, but which felony involved the use of a deadly weapon, traffic in narcotic drugs, or violence against another person, including rape, within the past five years; or 
4.  A misdemeanor or licensing ordinance violation, based upon conduct or involvement in such business or activity or related or similar business or activity, within the past two years. 
b.  The applicant whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause. 
c.  The applicant who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued under this chapter would not be eligible for such license upon a first application 
d.  The applicant is under the age of 18 years. 
e.  Where grounds for revocation of the license exists. 
f.  If the applicant is a partnership and any general partner, or any limited partner of owning more that 20 percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such partnership, would not be eligible to receive a license under this chapter. 
g.  If the applicant is a corporation and any officer or director, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license under this chapter. 
h.  If the applicant is a corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the "Business Corporation Act of 1983" to transact business in Illinois. 
i.  If the business of the young adult entertainment facility is to be conducted by a manager unless the manager possesses the same qualifications required by the licensee. 
j.  If the applicant is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee. 
k.  If the premises do not comply with all applicable city ordinances and state laws. 
l.  If the application is incomplete or if it contains any material misrepresentation. 
m.  If the application does not show adequate measures for the protection of persons or property, security, both inside and outside the premises, and the monitoring of the ages of patrons admitted to the young adult entertainment facility. 
(3)  If the license officer denies a license, written notice of the denial stating the reasons why shall be sent to the applicant within five working days after the denial. The applicant shall have a period of ten working days after the date of license denial to appeal to the city council. Said appeal shall be in writing and shall be scheduled for hearing within 14 days of the receipt of the appeal for a regular meeting occurring not more than 30 days after receipt of the notice and after at least five days notification of the hearing date to the appellant. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1124. - Operating rules and regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 17 years to enter or remain on the premises of a young adult entertainment facility unless accompanied by a parent or guardian; 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person 30 years of age or older to enter or remain on the premises of a young adult entertainment facility except for bona fide employees or independent contractors hired by the licensee to work in the young adult entertainment facility, a parent or guardian of a person under 21 years of age present in the young adult entertainment facility or a governmental employee in the performance of his duties. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent their age for the purpose of gaining admission to a young adult entertainment facility. 
(d)  The licensee shall require each person admitted or seeking to be admitted to display to a supervisory security person of the young adult entertainment facility an identification card showing the photo and age of the person seeking admission. In addition all patrons shall be required to pass through a metal detection device or pass a scanning by a metal detection wand. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit a person to enter or remain in a young adult entertainment facility who is under the age of 17 years or 30 years of age or older unless such person is a bona fide employee or independent contractor hired by the licensee to work in the young adult entertainment facility or a governmental employee in the performance of his duties. 
(f)  A patron once admitted to the young adult entertainment facility on the premises shall not be permitted to exit and re-enter the premises sooner than the following business day. 
(g)  In the event of an emergency, health, or safety condition occurring anywhere on the licensed premises, including the parking lot, the licensee and its employees and/or agents shall immediately contact the fire department or police department, as appropriate to the incident, and request assistance. 
(h)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to employ two off-duty city police officers who shall be present on the premises during all operating hours to maintain peace and order and to ensure compliance with all applicable laws of the state and of the city. The licensee shall pay to the city the wages and benefit costs associated with providing to the licensee the two police officers. The licensee shall also employ qualified security personnel who shall have been trained in crowd control, drug awareness, and gang awareness. The names, addressed and birth dates of all such security personnel must be on file with the chief of police at least 48 hours before their employment. 
(i)  Each licensee shall provide at least one supervising security person to monitor and verify ages of those persons seeking to gain admittance to the licensed premises. 
(j)  The licensee and its agents shall not permit or allow alcoholic beverages or controlled substances to be consumed or be present on any young adult entertainment facility premises and shall not allow or permit tobacco to be used or sold in any young adult entertainment facility. The presence of any prohibited item upon the licensed premises shall be deemed a violation of this provision. 
(k)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to refuse admittance and to remove from the young adult entertainment facility any person who is, or appears to be, under the influence of, or affected by the use of, alcohol or drugs, or whose conduct poses a physical danger to the safety of others present. It shall be the obligation of the licensee to refuse admittance and to remove from a young adult entertainment facility any person under the age of 18 years who possesses tobacco. 
(l)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to provide proper and adequate illumination of all portions of the premises which are available for public use. Such illumination shall be not less than 1.3 foot candle at floor level at all times when the premises are open to the public or when any member of the public is permitted to enter and remain on the premises. All off-street parking areas within one hundred feet of any entrance shall be illuminated during all hours of operation after sunset with a lighting system designed to provide a minimum maintained horizontal illumination of greater than one foot candle of light on the parking surface and/or walkway. 
(m)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to prevent loitering, the creation of public nuisances or disturbances of the peace by any patrons of the young adult entertainment facility on the premises or in the immediate vicinity. "Loitering" shall not include walking between the premises and a patron's vehicle, nor shall it include the act of waiting in line to gain admission to the premises. 
(n)  It shall be the obligation of the licensee to clean up all litter resulting from its operations. The cleanup shall occur within two hours after the end of each day's operation. 
(o)  It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit: (a) a greater number of patrons into the premises at any time than the permitted occupancy; or (b) any greater number of patrons to remain upon the premises than the permitted occupancy. All young adult entertainment facilities shall provide seating for not less than 30 percent of the maximum permitted occupancy. 
(p)  No licensee, his agent or employee shall allow or permit any person to perform acts of or acts which simulate: a) sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual acts which are prohibited by law; b) the actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breast, buttocks, anus or genitals; c) the actual or simulated displaying of the pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals; d) the actual or simulated displaying of the breast so as to expose the nipple of the female breast; e) the displaying of films or pictures depicting acts, a live performance of which is prohibited by a), b), c) or d) above. 
(q)  No licensee, his agent or employee shall allow or permit any person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes in public view any portion of his or her genitals or anus. 
(r)  Each licensee shall provide at least one public telephone for outgoing calls only for each 125 patrons (based upon the maximum occupancy of the premises). No licensee shall permit sound or vibration exceeding 90 decibels measured with a standard meter "A" scale within two feet of any public telephone receiver or audible at such level on the outside of any exterior wall of the premises located more than ten feet from a doorway of the licensed premises. No public telephone shall be provided on the premises for incoming calls 
(s)  The licensee shall deliver to the chief of police, no later than 72 hours before any scheduled special event occurring at a licensed premises, true and accurate copies of any and all advertisements of whatever nature therefore used to advertise or promote the event. The licensee shall also include prior to any such advertised event: 
(1)  The number of employees and/or performers to be used for the event; 
(2)  Designation of the individual who will be available prior to and during the event and who shall have authority to accept complaints, notice of violations, or take corrective action as required by proper officials of the city; 
(3)  A security plan with an acknowledgment that any changes to the security plan must be submitted to the chief of police in writing one business day before the event, and the security plan must be followed without any changes unless such change has been submitted to the chief of police in writing and he has approved it prior to the event being opened; 
(4)  Security personnel shall be required for the maximum capacity of the event as determined by the maximum occupancy of the premises under city's ordinance unless attendance is limited to a lesser number; 
(5)  Inspections may be conducted by the city to ensure compliance with its codes and ordinances; 
(6)  No members of the general public shall be allowed admittance prior to the opening of the event; 
(7)  Only one such event per evening shall be allowed; 
(8)  Automatic counters are required to be used prior to entry into the licensed premises to determine occupancy of the premises; 
(9)  Tickets may be sold before the event with the number of tickets sold limited to the occupancy limit of the premises for patrons, and after all said tickets have been sold, the licensee shall post a sign stating that the event is "Sold Out." 
(t)  The hours of operation of a young adult entertainment facility are as follows: 
Sunday through Thursday, 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight. 
Friday and Saturday, 10:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. 
New Year's Eve, 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. the following day. 
(u)  All employees and independent contractors hired by the licensee to work in the young adult entertainment facility who will be present on the premises during hours of operation shall submit to criminal background checks. No person shall be permitted to be employed who has been convicted of a felony violation of any section of the following: 
Article 8. Solicitation, Conspiracy and Attempt; 
Article 9. Homicide; 
Article 10. Kidnapping and Related Offenses; 
Article 11. Sex Offenses; 
Article 12. Bodily Harm; 
Article 18. Robbery; 
Article 19. Burglary; 
Article 33A. Armed Violence; or 
Article 33D. Contributing to the Criminal Delinquency of a Juvenile of the Illinois Criminal Code of 1961, as amended; or any section of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, as amended; or 
Chapter 51. Homicide; 
Chapter 55. Kidnapping; 
Chapter 71. Obscenity; 
Chapter 99. Rape; 
Chapter 103. Robbery and Burglary; 
Chapter 110. Sexual Exploitation of Children; 
Chapter 117. White Slave Traffic, of Title 18 of the United States Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1125. - Access by police officers. 
    All police officers of the city shall be permitted access to all young adult entertainment facilities for the purpose of inspection and to enforce compliance with the provisions of this division at all times that the premises are open to the patrons. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1126. - Suspension or revocation of licenses. 
(a)  The city manager may, at any time, suspend a young adult entertainment facility license whenever the licensee, or any manager, officer, director, agent or employee of the licensee has caused, permitted or knowingly done any of the following: 
(1)  Failed to keep the building structure or equipment of the licensed premises in compliance with the applicable health, building, fire or safety laws, regulations or ordinances in a way which relates to or affects public health or safety on the young adult entertainment facility premises. 
(2)  Failed to comply with the provisions of young adult entertainment facilities specified in this chapter. 
Such suspension shall remain in effect until the conditions causing the suspension are cured and reasonable measures are taken to ensure that the same will not reoccur as determined by the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager may, at any time, revoke or suspend a young adult entertainment facility license on any one or more of the following grounds: 
(1)  Whenever the city learns that the licenses made a material false statement or representation, or failed to disclose any material information to the city, in connection with any application for the young adult entertainment facility license or any license renewal. 
(2)  Whenever the licensee or any manager, officer, director, agent or employee of the licensee fails within a reasonable time to cure a condition that cause a license suspension. 
(3)  Whenever the licensee or any manager, officer, director, agent or employee of the licensee knowingly permits conduct on the licensed premises that violates any federal, state or village criminal or penal statute, law or ordinance. 
(4)  Whenever the operation of the young adult entertainment facility becomes the proximate cause of a significant increase in criminal activity on the premises or in the immediate vicinity in such a way as to endanger persons or property. 
(5)  Upon the cessation of business for a period in excess of 60 days. 
(c)  The suspension or revocation of a license may be appealed to the city council within five days of said suspension or revocation. The appeal shall be taken by filing with the city manager a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The city manager shall transmit a report and the entire record upon which the appeal was taken. From and after five business days after the appeal is filed any suspension or revocation shall be stayed unless the city manager from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the city council that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In this event the suspension or revocation shall not be stayed otherwise than by the city council. 
    The city council shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal and give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the appeal within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. The city council may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the suspension or revocation as in its opinion ought to be made. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1127. - License, non-transferable. 
    A license granted under the provisions of this chapter is non-transferable. The sale, lease or transfer of the substantially all of the assets of a business holding an young adult entertainment facility license or a sale or transfer of a controlling interest in a corporation or partnership holding an young adult entertainment facility license shall result in the termination of the license granted herein. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1128. - Nuisance, injunction. 
    Any violation of this chapter is declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any other relief provided by this chapter, the city attorney may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this chapter. The application for relief may including seeking a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction or permanent injunction. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Sec. 22-1129. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 99-49, § 1, 10-12-1999) 
Secs. 2-1130-22-1150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 30. - RAFFLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-04, §§ 2-12, adopted Jan. 16, 1999, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as §§ 22-1151-22-1161 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 22-1151. - Licensing of raffles. 
    A system is hereby established for the licensing of organizations to operate raffles in the city. All raffles shall be subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded by a licensee in a single raffle is $1,000,000.00. 
(2)  The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a single raffle is $1,000,000.00; 
(3)  The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issue or sold is $1,000.00; 
(4)  The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold is 120 days. 
(Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 1-26-1999) 
Sec. 22-1152. - License fee.
