2.  Temporary and/or permanent soil stabilization shall be applied to denuded areas as soon as possible. As a minimum, soil stabilization shall be provided within 15 days to denuded areas which may not be at final grade but will remain undisturbed for longer than 60 days. 
3.  Sedimentation control measures shall be installed before any significant grading or filling is initiated on the site to prevent the movement of eroded sediments off site or into the channel. Potential sediment control devices include filter fences, straw bale fences, check dams, diversion ditches and sediment basins. 
4.  A vegetated buffer strip of at least 25 feet in width shall be preserved and/or reestablished, where possible, along existing channels, per subsection (c)(2)p of this section. Construction vehicle use of channels shall be minimized. Temporary stream crossings shall be constructed, where necessary, to minimize erosion. Necessary construction in or along channels shall be restabilized immediately. 
5.  Soil erosion and sedimentation control measures shall be designed and implemented consistent with Procedures and Standards for Urban Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control in Illinois (1988), also known as the Green Book, and Standards and Specifications for Soil Erosion and Sediment Control (IEPA, 1987). 
l.  Public flood control projects. For public flood control projects, the permitting requirements of this section will be considered met if the applicant can demonstrate to the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, through hydraulic and hydrologic calculations, that the proposed project will not singularly or cumulatively result in increased flood heights outside the project right-of-way or easements for all flood events up to and including the 100-year frequency event. 
m.  General criteria for analysis of flood elevations. 
1.  The flood profiles, flows and floodway data in the regulatory floodway study, referenced in section 46-65, must be used for analysis of the base conditions. If the study data appears to be in error or conditions have changed, the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, shall be contacted for approval and concurrence on the appropriate base conditions data to use. 
2.  If the 100-year regulatory floodway elevation at the site of the proposed construction is affected by the backwater from a downstream receiving stream with a larger drainage area, the proposed construction shall be shown to meet the requirements of this section for the 100-year frequency flood elevations of the regulatory floodway conditions and conditions with the receiving stream at normal water elevations. 
3.  If the applicant learns from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, local governments, or a private owner that a downstream restrictive bridge or culvert is scheduled to be removed, reconstructed, modified, or a regional flood control project is scheduled to be built, removed, constructed or modified within the next five years, the proposed construction shall be analyzed and shown to meet the requirements of this section for both the existing conditions and the expected flood profile conditions when the bridge, culvert or flood control project is built. 
n.  Conditional letter of map revision. If the appropriate use would result in a change in the regulatory floodway location or the 100-year frequency flood elevation, the applicant shall submit to the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, and to the Federal Emergency Management Agency all the information, calculations and documents necessary to be issued a conditional regulatory floodway map revision and receive from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, a conditional approval of the regulatory floodway change before a permit is issued. However, the final regulatory floodway map will not be changed by the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, until as-built plans or record drawings are submitted and accepted by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the state department of natural resources, office of water resources. For nongovernment projects, the municipality in incorporated areas and the county in unincorporated areas shall concur with the proposed conditional regulatory floodway map revision before state department of natural resources, office of water resources, approval can be given. No filling, grading, dredging or excavating shall take place until a conditional approval is issued. No further development activities shall take place until a final letter of map revision is issued by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the state department of natural resources, office of water resources. 
o.  Professional engineer's supervision. All engineering analyses shall be performed by or under the supervision of a registered professional engineer. 
p.  Construction within 25 feet of channel. For all activities in the floodway involving construction within 25 feet of the channel, the following criteria shall be met: 
1.  A natural vegetation buffer strip shall be preserved within at least 25 feet of the ordinary high water mark of the channel. 
2.  Where it is impossible to protect this buffer strip during the construction of an appropriate use, a vegetated buffer strip shall be established upon completion of construction. 
3.  The use of native riparian vegetation is preferred in the buffer strip. Access through this buffer strip shall be provided, when necessary, for stream maintenance purposes. 
After receipt of conditional approval of the regulatory floodway change and issuance of a permit and a conditional letter of map revision, construction as necessary to change the regulatory floodway designation may proceed, but no buildings or structures or other construction that is not an appropriate use may be placed in that area until the regulatory floodway map is changed and a final letter of map revision is received. The regulatory floodway map will be revised upon acceptance and concurrence by the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency of the as-built plans. 
(d)  State review. For the projects listed in this subsection that are located in a regulatory floodway, the following information shall be submitted to the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, for its review and concurrence prior to the issuance of a permit: 
(1)  An engineer's analysis of the flood profile due to a proposed bridge pursuant to subsection (c)(2)d of this section. 
(2)  An engineer's determination that an existing bridge or culvert crossing is not a source of flood damage and the analysis indicating the proposed flood profile, pursuant to subsection (c)(2)e of this section. 
(3)  Alternative transition sections and hydraulically equivalent storage pursuant to subsections (c)(2)a, (c)(2)b and (c)(2)h of this section. 
(4)  Prior to the start of construction any department projects, dams, as defined in section 46-61, and all other state, federal or local units of government projects, including projects of the city or county. 
(e)  Other permits. In addition to the other requirements of this article, a development permit for a site located in a floodway shall not be issued unless the applicant first obtains a permit or written documentation that a permit is not required from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, issued pursuant to 615 ILCS 5/4.9 et seq. No permit from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, shall be required if the office has delegated this responsibility to the city. 
(f)  Dam safety permits. Any work involving the construction, modification or removal of a dam as defined in section 300 per 92 Ill. Adm. Code part 702 (Rules for Construction of Dams) shall require a state office of water resources dam safety permit prior to the start of construction of the dam. If the community development director finds a dam that does not have a permit, the community development director shall immediately notify dam safety section of the office of water resources. If the community development director finds a dam which is believed to be in unsafe condition, the community development director shall immediately notify the owner of the dam, the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, dam safety section, in Springfield and the state emergency services and disaster agency (ESDA). 
(g)  Activities not requiring registered professional engineer's review. The following activities may be permitted without a registered professional engineer's review. Such activities shall still meet the other requirements of this article, including the mitigation requirements: 
(1)  Underground and overhead utilities that: 
a.  Do not result in any increase in existing ground elevations; or 
b.  Do not require the placement of aboveground structures in the floodway; or 
c.  For underground stream crossings, the top of the pipe of encasement is buried a minimum of three feet below the existing streambed; and 
d.  For overhead utilities, no supporting towers are placed in the watercourse and the utilities are designed in such a fashion as not to catch debris. 
(2)  Storm sewer outfalls that: 
a.  Do not extend riverward or lakeward of the existing adjacent natural bank slope; 
b.  Do not result in an increase in ground elevation; and 
c.  Are designed so as not to cause stream erosion at the outfall location. 
(3)  Construction of sidewalks; athletic fields, excluding fences; properly anchored playground equipment; and patios at grade. 
(4)  Construction of shoreline and stream bank protection that: 
a.  Does not exceed 1,000 feet in length. 
b.  Has materials placed higher than the existing top of bank. 
c.  Has materials placed so as not to reduce the cross sectional area of the stream channel or bank of the lake. 
(5)  Temporary stream crossings in which: 
a.  The approach roads will be 0.5 foot or less above natural grade. 
b.  The crossing will allow stream flow to pass without backing up the water above the stream bank vegetation line or above any drainage tile or outfall invert. 
c.  The top of the roadway fill in the channel will be at least two feet below the top of the lowest bank. Any fill in the channel shall be nonerosive material, such as riprap or gravel. 
d.  All disturbed stream banks will be seeded or otherwise stabilized as soon as possible upon installation and again upon removal of construction. 
e.  The access road and temporary crossings will be removed within one year after authorization. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-7) 
Sec. 46-68. - Occupation and use of special flood hazard areas where floodways are not identified. 
(a)  Development prohibited. In special flood hazard areas or floodplains, including AO, AH and unnumbered A zones, where no floodways have been identified and no base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevations have been established by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and draining more than a square mile, no development shall be permitted unless the cumulative effect of the proposals, when combined with all other existing and anticipated uses and structures, shall not significantly impede or increase the flow and passage of the floodwaters or significantly increase the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation. 
(1)  Development permit. No person, not exempted by state law, shall commence any development in a special flood hazard area or floodplain without first obtaining a development permit from the community development director. Application for a development permit shall be made on a form provided by the community development director. The application shall be accompanied by drawings of the site, drawn to scale, showing property line dimensions and existing grade elevations and all changes in grade resulting from excavation or filling, sealed by a licensed engineer, architect or surveyor; the location and dimensions of all buildings and additions to buildings; and the elevation of the lowest floor, including basement, of all proposed buildings subject to the requirements of section 46-69 of this article. The application for a development permit shall also include the following information: 
a.  A detailed description of the proposed activity, its purpose and intended use. 
b.  Site location, including legal description, of the property, drawn to scale, on the regulatory floodway maps, indicating whether it is proposed to be in an incorporated or unincorporated area. 
c.  Anticipated dates of initiation and completion of the activity. 
d.  Plans of the proposed activity which shall include as a minimum the following: 
1.  A vicinity map showing the site of the activity, name of the waterway, boundary lines, names of roads in the vicinity of the site, graphic or numerical scale and north arrow; 
2.  A plan review of the project and engineering study reach showing existing and proposed conditions including principal dimensions of the structure or work, elevations in mean sea level (1929 adjustment) datum or NGVD, adjacent property lines and ownership, drainage and flood control easements, distance between the proposed activity and the navigation channel when the proposed construction is near a commercially navigable body of water, floodplain limit, location and orientation of cross sections, north arrow and a graphical or numerical scale; 
3.  Cross section views of the project and engineering study reach showing existing and proposed conditions including principal dimensions of the work as shown in plan view, existing and proposed elevations, normal water elevation, ten-year frequency flood elevation, 100-year frequency flood elevation and graphical or numerical scales (horizontal and vertical); and 
4.  A soil erosion and sedimentation control plan for disturbed areas. This plan shall include a description of the sequence of grading activities and temporary sediment and erosion control measures to be implemented to mitigate their effects. This plan shall also include a description of final stabilization and revegetation measures and the identification of a responsible party to ensure post construction maintenance. 
e.  Engineering calculations and supporting data shall be submitted showing that the proposed work will meet the criteria of subsection (b) of this section. 
f.  Any and all other local, state and federal permits or approvals that may be required for this type of development. 
(2)  Elevation comparisons. Based on the best available data according to the state water survey's floodplain repository, the community development director shall compare the elevation of the site to the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation. If no elevation information exists for the site, the developer's engineer shall calculate the elevation according to subsection 46-65(e). Any development located on land that can be shown to have been higher than the base flood elevations as of the site's first flood insurance rate map identification is not in the special flood hazard area and, therefore, not subject to the requirements of this article. The building official shall maintain documentation of the existing ground elevation at the development site and certification that this ground elevation existed prior to the date of the site's first flood insurance rate map identification. 
(3)  Other permits or approvals. The community development director shall be responsible for obtaining from the applicant copies of all other local, state and federal permits, approvals or permit-not-required letters that may be required for this type of activity. The community development director shall not issue the development permit unless all required local, state and federal permits have been obtained. 
(b)  Preventing increased damages. No development in a special flood hazard area, where a floodway has not been determined, shall create a damaging or potentially damaging increase in flood heights or velocity or threat to public health, safety and welfare or impair the natural hydrologic and hydraulic functions of the floodway or channel or impair existing water quality or aquatic habitat. Construction impacts shall be minimized by appropriate mitigation methods as called for in this article. 
(1)  Standards for riverine special flood hazard areas. Within all riverine special flood hazard areas where the floodway has not been determined, the following standards shall apply: 
a.  The developer shall have a registered professional engineer state in writing and show through supporting plans, calculations and data that the project meets the engineering requirements of subsections 46-67(c)(2)a through (c)(2)l for the entire floodplain as calculated under subsection 46-65(e) of this article. As an alternative, the developer should have an engineering study performed to determine a floodway and submit that engineering study to the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, for review and approval. After the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, approves the floodway, the developer shall then demonstrate that the project meets the requirements of section 46-67 for the regulatory floodway. The floodway shall be defined according to the definition in section 46-61 of this article. 
b.  A development permit shall not be issued unless the applicant first obtains a permit from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, or written documentation that a permit is not required from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources. 
c.  No permit from the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, shall be required if the office has delegated permit responsibility to the city per 92 Ill. Adm. Code part 708 for regulatory floodways, per the state department of natural resources, office of water resources statewide permit entitled "Construction in Floodplains with No Designated Floodways in Northeastern Illinois." 
d.  Any work involving the construction modification or removal of a dam or an on-stream structure to impound water, as defined in section 46-61, shall obtain an office of water resources dam safety permit or letter indicating a permit is not required prior to the start of construction of a dam. If the community development director finds a dam that does not have a state department of natural resources, office of water resources permit, the community development director shall immediately notify the dam safety section of the office of water resources. If the community development director finds a dam that is believed to be in unsafe condition, the community development director shall immediately notify the owner of the dam and the state emergency services and disaster agency (ESDA) and the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, dam safety section, in Springfield. 
e.  The following activities may be permitted without a registered professional engineer's review or calculation of a base flood elevation and regulatory floodway; such activities shall still meet the other requirements of this article: 
1.  Underground and overhead utilities that: 
i.  Do not result in any increase in existing ground elevations; or 
ii.  Do not require the placement of aboveground structures in the floodway; or 
iii.  For underground stream crossings, the top of the pipe or encasement is buried a minimum of three feet below the existing streambed; and 
iv.  For overhead utilities, no supporting towers are placed in the watercourse, and the utilities are designed in such a fashion as not to catch debris. 
2.  Storm sewer outfalls that: 
i.  Do not extend riverward or lakeward of the existing adjacent natural bank slope; 
ii.  Do not result in an increase in ground elevation; and 
iii.  Are designed so as not to cause stream bank erosion at the outfall location. 
3.  Construction of shoreline and streambed protection that: 
i.  Does not exceed 1,000 feet in length. 
ii.  Has materials that are not placed higher than the existing top of bank. 
iii.  Has materials placed so as not to reduce the cross sectional area of the floodplain by more than ten percent. 
4.  Temporary stream crossings in which: 
i.  The approach roads will be 0.5 foot or less above the natural grade. 
ii.  The crossing will allow stream flow to pass without backing up the water above the stream bank vegetation line or above any drainage tile or outfall invert. 
iii.  The top of the roadway fill in the channel will be at least two feet below the top of the lowest bank. Any fill in the channel shall be nonerosive material, such as riprap or gravel. 
iv.  All disturbed stream banks will be seeded or otherwise stabilized as soon as possible upon installation and again upon removal of construction. 
v.  The access road and temporary crossings will be removed within one year after authorization. 
5.  The construction of light poles, signposts and similar structures. 
6.  The construction of sidewalks; driveways; athletic fields, excluding fences; patios; and similar surfaces which are built at grade. 
7.  The construction of properly anchored, unwalled, open structures such as playground equipment, pavilions and carports built at or below the existing grade that would not obstruct the flow of floodwaters. 
8.  The placement of properly anchored buildings not exceeding 70 square feet in size or more than ten feet in any one dimension (e.g., animal shelters and tool sheds). 
9.  The construction of additions to existing buildings which do not increase the first floor area by more than 20 percent, which are located on the upstream or downstream side of the existing building and which do not extend beyond the sides of the existing building that are parallel to the flow of floodwaters. 
10.  Minor maintenance dredging of a stream channel where: 
i.  The affected length of the stream is less than 1,000 feet. 
ii.  The work is confined to reestablishing flows in natural stream channels; or 
iii.  The cross sectional area of the dredged channel conforms to that of the natural channel upstream and downstream of the site. 
iv.  Dredge material will be placed in an upland site (nonwetland or non-special flood hazard area site). 
v.  The flood-carrying capacity within any altered or relocated watercourse shall be maintained. 
(2)  Compensatory storage. Whenever any portion of a floodplain is authorized for use, the volume of space which will be occupied by the authorized fill or structure below the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation shall be compensated for and balanced by a hydraulically equivalent volume of excavation taken from below the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation. The excavation volume shall be at least equal to 1.5 times the volume of storage lost due to the fill or structure. For streams and watercourses, such excavation shall be made opposite or adjacent to the areas so filled or occupied. All floodplain storage lost below the existing ten-year flood elevation shall be replaced below the proposed ten-year flood elevation. All floodplain storage lost above the existing ten-year flood elevation shall be replaced above the existing ten-year flood elevation. All such excavations shall be constructed to drain freely and openly to the watercourse. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-8) 
Sec. 46-69. - Permitting requirements applicable to all floodplain areas. 
(a)  Generally. In addition to the requirements found in sections 46-66, 46-67 and 46-68 for development in flood fringes, regulatory floodways, and special flood hazard areas or floodplains where no floodways have been identified (zones A, AO, AH, AE, A1-A30, A99, VO, V1-30, VE, V, M, or E), the requirements in this section shall be met. 
(b)  Public health standards. Public health standards shall be as follows: 
(1)  No developments in the special flood hazard area shall include locating or storing chemicals, explosives, buoyant materials, animal wastes, fertilizers, flammable liquids, pollutants, or other hazardous or toxic materials below the flood protection elevation. 
(2)  New and replacement water supply systems, wells, sanitary sewer lines and on-site waste disposal systems may be permitted, provided all manholes or other aboveground openings located below the flood protection elevation are watertight. 
(c)  Carrying capacity and notification. For all projects involving channel modifications, fill or stream maintenance, including levees, the flood-carrying capacity of the watercourse shall be maintained. In addition, the applicant shall notify adjacent communities, by certified mail letter, 30 days prior to the issuance of a permit for the alteration or relocation of the watercourse. 
(d)  Protecting buildings generally. All buildings located within a 100-year floodplain, also known as a special flood hazard area, shall be protected from flood damage below the flood protection elevation. However, existing buildings located within a regulatory floodway shall also meet the more restrictive appropriate use standards included in section 46-67. This building protection criteria applies to the following situations: 
(1)  Construction or placement of a new building. 
(2)  A structural alteration to an existing building that either increases the first floor area by more than 20 percent or the building's market value by more than 50 percent. 
(3)  Installing a manufactured home on a new site or a new manufactured home on an existing site. 
(4)  Installing a travel trailer or mobile home on a site for more than 180 days. 
(e)  Methods of protecting buildings. The building protection requirements of subsection (d) of this section may be met by one of the following methods: 
(1)  A residential or nonresidential building, when allowed, may be constructed on permanent landfill in accordance with the following: 
a.  The lowest floor, including basement, shall be at or above the flood protection elevation. 
b.  The fill shall be placed in layers no greater than one foot deep before compaction and should extend at least ten feet beyond the foundation of the building before sloping below the flood protection elevation. The top of the fill shall be above the flood protection elevation. However, the ten-foot minimum may be waived if a registered structural engineer certifies an alternative method to protect the building from damages due to hydrostatic pressures. The fill shall be protected against erosion and scour. The fill shall not adversely affect the flow or surface drainage from or onto neighboring properties. 
(2)  A residential or nonresidential building may be elevated in accordance with the following: 
a.  The building or improvements shall be elevated on crawl space, stilts, piles, walls or other foundation that is permanently open to floodwaters and not subject to damage by hydrostatic pressures of the base flood or 100-year frequency flood. The permanent openings shall be no more than one foot abovegrade and shall consist of a minimum of two openings. The openings must have a total net area of not less than one square inch for every one square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding below the base flood elevation. 
b.  The foundation and supporting members shall be anchored and aligned in relation to flood flows and adjoining structures so as to minimize exposure to known hydrodynamic forces such as current, waves, ice and floating debris. 
c.  All areas of the building or structure below the flood protection elevation shall be constructed of materials resistant to flood damage. The lowest floor, including basement, and all electrical, heating, ventilating, plumbing and air conditioning equipment and utility meters shall be located at or above the flood protection elevation. Water and sewer pipes, electrical and telephone lines, submersible pumps and other waterproofed service facilities may be located below the flood protection elevation. 
d.  No area of a building below the flood protection elevation shall be used for storage of items or materials. 
e.  Manufactured homes and travel trailers to be installed on a site for more than 180 days shall be elevated to or above the flood protection elevation and shall be anchored to resist floatation, collapse, or lateral movement by being tied down in accordance with the Rules and Regulations for the Illinois Mobile Home Tie-Down Act issued pursuant to 77 Ill. Adm. Code 870. 
(3)  Only a nonresidential building may be structurally dry floodproofed, in lieu of elevation, provided that a registered professional engineer shall certify that the building has been structurally dry floodproofed below the flood protection elevation, the structure and attendant utility facilities are watertight and capable of resisting the effects of the base flood or 100-year frequency flood. The building design shall take into account flood velocities, duration, rate of rise, hydrostatic and hydrodynamic forces, the effects of buoyancy and impacts from debris or ice. Floodproofing measures shall be operable without human intervention and without an outside source of electricity; levees, berms, floodwalls and similar works are not considered floodproofing for the purpose of this subsection. Tool sheds and detached garages on an existing single-family platted lot may be constructed with the lowest floor below the flood protection elevation in accordance with the following: 
a.  The building is not used for human habitation. 
b.  All areas below the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation shall be constructed with waterproof material. Structures located in a regulatory floodway shall be constructed and placed on a building site so as not to block the flow of floodwaters and shall also meet the appropriate use criteria of section 46-67. In addition, all other requirements of sections 46-66, 46-67 and 46-68 must be met. 
c.  The structure shall be anchored to prevent flotation. 
d.  Service facilities such as electrical and heating equipment shall be elevated or floodproofed to the flood protection elevation. 
e.  The building shall be valued at less than $8,500.00 (1994 costs) and shall be less than 500 square feet in floor size. 
f.  The building shall be used only for the storage of vehicles or tools and may not contain other rooms, workshops, greenhouses or similar uses. 
(4)  Nonconforming structures located in a regulatory floodway may remain in use, but may not be enlarged, replaced or structurally altered. A nonconforming structure damaged by flood, fire, wind, or other natural or manmade disaster may be restored unless the damage exceeds 50 percent of its market property value before it was damaged, in which case it shall conform to this article. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-9; Ord. No. 96-14, § 1 (D), 3-12-1996) 
Sec. 46-70. - Other development requirements. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the city council shall take into account flood hazards, to the extent that they are known, in all official actions related to land management, use and development. 
(b)  New subdivision, annexation agreements, and planned unit developments within the special flood hazard area shall be reviewed to ensure that the proposed developments are consistent with sections 46-66, 46-67, 46-68 and 46-69 of this article and the need to minimize flood damage. Plats or plans for new subdivisions, planned unit developments (PUDs) and manufactured home parks shall include a signed statement by a registered professional engineer that the plat or plan accounts for changes in the drainage of surface waters in accordance with the Plat Act, 765 ILCS 205/1 et seq. 
(c)  Proposals for new subdivisions, manufactured home parks, travel trailer parks, additions to manufactured home parks, planned unit developments and additions to subdivisions shall include base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation data and floodway delineations. Where this information is not available from an existing study filed with the state water survey, the applicant's engineer shall be responsible for calculating the base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevation per subsection 46-65(e) and the floodway delineation per the definition in section 46-61 and submitting it to the state water survey and the state department of natural resources, office of water resources, for review and approval as best available regulatory data. 
(d)  Streets, blocks, lots, parks and other public grounds shall be located and laid out in such a manner as to preserve and utilize natural streams and channels. Wherever possible, the floodplains shall be included within parks or other public grounds. 
(e)  The city council shall not approve any planned unit development or plat of a subdivision located outside the corporate limits unless such agreement or plat is in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-10) 
Sec. 46-71. - Variances. 
(a)  No variances shall be granted to any development located in a regulatory floodway, as defined in section 46-61. However, when a developmental proposal is located outside of a regulatory floodway and whenever the standards of this article place undue hardship on a specific developmental proposal, the applicant may apply to the community development director for a variance. The community development director shall review the applicant's request for a variance and shall submit his recommendation to the city council. 
(b)  No variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates that: 
(1)  The development activity cannot be located outside the special flood hazard area; 
(2)  An exceptional hardship would result if the variance were not granted; 
(3)  The relief requested is the minimum necessary; 
(4)  There will be no additional threat to public health, safety, beneficial stream uses and functions, especially aquatic habitat, or creation of a nuisance; 
(5)  There will be no additional public expense for flood protection, lost environmental stream uses and functions, rescue or relief operations, policing, or repairs to streambeds and stream banks, roads, utilities or other public facilities; 
(6)  The provisions of subsections 46-66(c) and 46-68(b) of this article shall still be met; 
(7)  The activity is not in a regulatory floodway; 
(8)  The applicant's circumstances are unique and do not represent a general problem; and 
(9)  The granting of the variance will not alter the essential character of the area involved including existing stream uses. 
(c)  The community development director shall notify an applicant in writing that a variance from the requirements of section 46-69 that would lessen the degree of protection to a building will: 
(1)  Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as $25.00 for $100.00 of insurance coverage; 
(2)  Increase the risks of life and property; and 
(3)  Require that the applicant proceed with knowledge of these risks and that he will acknowledge in writing that he assumes the risk and liability. 
(d)  Variance requested in connection with restoration of a site or building listed on the National Register of Historical Places or documented as worthy of preservation by the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency may be granted using criteria more permissive than the requirements of subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-11) 
Sec. 46-72. - Disclaimer of liability. 
    The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does not imply that development, either inside or outside of the special flood hazard area, will be free from flooding or damage. This article does not create liability on the part of the city or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from reliance on this article or any administrative decision made lawfully under this article. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-12) 
Sec. 46-73. - Penalty. 
(a)  Under this article, failure to comply with the requirements of a permit or conditions of a variance resolution shall be deemed to be a violation of this article. Upon due investigation, the community development director may determine that a violation of the minimum standards of this article exist. The community development director shall notify the owner, in writing, of such violation. 
(b)  If such owner fails, after ten days' notice, to correct the violation: 
(1)  The city may make application to the circuit court for an injunction requiring conformance with this article or make such other order as the court deems necessary to secure compliance with this article. 
(2)  Any person who violates this article shall, upon conviction, be fined in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(3)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(4)  The city may record a notice of violation on the title to the property. 
(c)  The community development director shall inform the owner that any such violation is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and, therefore, may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violation. All costs connected therewith shall accrue to the person responsible. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-13; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 46-74. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
    This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. Where this article and other sections of this Code, ordinances, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. This article is intended to repeal the original ordinance or resolution which was adopted pursuant to the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, but is not intended to repeal the resolution which the city passed in order to establish initial eligibility for the program. 
(Code 1967, § 81/2-14)

ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-26. - Health department created. 
    There is created an executive department of the city which shall be known as the department of health. 
(Code 1967, § 10-1) 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-551 et seq. 
Sec. 50-27. - Composition of health department. 
    The department of health shall consist of the health officer and such other personnel as the city council shall from time to time prescribe. 
(Code 1967, § 10-2) 
Sec. 50-28. - Health officer's qualifications, appointment, term, duties. 
(a)  The health officer shall be a duly qualified physician, dentist, public health nurse, licensed environmental health practitioner or other person in an allied health care speciality appointed by the city manager. He shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(b)  The health officer shall carry out duties assigned to him by the city manager. The health officer shall be advisory to the board of health. 
(Code 1967, § 10-3) 
Sec. 50-29. - Salary of health officer; additional employees. 
    The city health officer's salary and additional personnel of the department of health, their classifications and their salaries shall be determined by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 10-4) 
Sec. 50-30. - General duties of health officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to: 
(1)  Exercise a general supervision over the sanitary conditions of the city, including all persons and establishments handling, selling, manufacturing or processing any type of food products. 
(2)  Investigate any reports of the existence of any contagious disease and adopt measures to arrest its progress. 
(3)  Furnish the mayor and officers in charge of executive city departments all such professional advice and information as they may require, with a view to preservation of the public health. 
(4)  Attend all board of health meetings. 
(Code 1967, § 10-5) 
Sec. 50-31. - Duties of health officer and health department. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer, by and with the aid of his assistants in the department of health, to: 
(1)  Enforce and observe all rules, regulations and orders of the city, the state department of public health, the county department of public health, and all state and county laws pertaining to the preservation of the health of the people of the city. 
(2)  Investigate the existence of any contagious or infectious diseases within the city and to report the diseases promptly to the departments of health of the state and county as prescribed by law and to act without delay in carrying out such measures for arresting the progress of the diseases as either or both bodies may adopt or as may be adopted by the city council upon recommendation of the city board of health. 
(3)  Execute and enforce all sections of this Code and other city ordinances relating to the conduct of all dairies, milk depots, creameries, food storage houses, bakeries, restaurants, taverns, fruit stores, soda fountains, ice cream parlors or stands, and all other places in the city where drugs or foodstuffs of any kind are either prepared, manufactured, packaged, stored, sold or otherwise handled and to enforce all rules and regulations for the conduct thereof. 
(4)  Make or cause to be made all necessary sanitary and health investigations and inspections within the city, as required by law, pursuant to recommendations by the board of health, the city manager, or by other city departments. 
(5)  Call upon the police and upon such other authorities, state or municipal, as may be deemed by him to be necessary in the performance of his duties, and cause the arrest and prosecution of the offenders against any of the sections of this Code or city ordinances relating to nuisances, public health and sanitation. 
(Code 1967, § 10-6) 
Sec. 50-32. - Right of entry. 
    For the purpose of carrying out this chapter, the health officer shall be permitted at all reasonable hours, during the day or night, to enter into or upon any premises wherein there is the handling, selling, manufacturing or processing of any type of food or dairy product. This section shall not apply to dwelling units. 
(Code 1967, § 10-8) 
Sec. 50-33. - Assistance by other city officers. 
    It shall be the duty of all city officers to assist the health officer and the board of health in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1967, § 10-9) 
Sec. 50-34. - Arrest powers of health department employees. 
    Employees of the department of health shall have the right to cause to be arrested and prosecuted any person who violates any section of this Code or regulations adopted under this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 10-10) 
Sec. 50-35. - Protection from epidemics. 
    If an epidemic disease occurs or if danger from an anticipated or impending epidemic disease occurs or if the sanitary condition of the city should be of such character to warrant, it shall be the duty of the health officer, with the approval of the board of health, to take such measures and to do, order and cause to be done such acts for the preservation of the public health, though not specifically authorized in this chapter or elsewhere in this Code or otherwise, as he may in good faith declare the public safety and health to demand. 
(Code 1967, § 10-12) 
Sec. 50-36. - Prevention of spread of contagious, infectious or epidemic disease. 
    The health officer shall have the power to cause any house or any premises to be cleaned, disinfected or closed to visitors while any person is suffering from any contagious or infectious disease, as may be required by state law. He may, by an order in writing, direct any nuisance affecting the sanitary condition of the city or the public health to be abated or direct unwholesome matter or substances, dirt or filth to be removed from any house or premises and may prescribe the time and mode of doing so and may take any other reasonable measures he may deem necessary and proper to prevent the spread of any contagious, infectious or epidemic disease. 
(Code 1967, § 10-13) 
Sec. 50-37. - Records of health officer. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to cause to be kept a record of all transactions of the department of health, all reportable diseases, and such other statistical information as may be required by law or necessary to the efficient operation of the department. 
(Code 1967, § 10-14) 
Sec. 50-38. - Information to physicians of epidemics. 
    The health officer shall keep the physicians of the city informed of any epidemic or impending epidemic and any information which may be necessary or prudent for the preservation of the public health. 
(Code 1967, § 10-15) 
Sec. 50-39. - Reports of health officer. 
    The health officer shall submit written reports at least quarterly or more often, if directed by the city manager, to the city manager and to the board of health, which may endorse but not alter the original report. This report shall contain the activities of the health department, including but not limited to the inspections made, conditions found, recommendations made, communicable diseases reported, with the number of each, and any recommendations for the improvement of the health and sanitation of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 10-16) 
Sec. 50-40. - Interfering with health officer. 
    Any person who shall interfere with the health officer or his deputy in the regular performance of his duties shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 10-17) 
Secs. 50-41-50-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF HEALTH[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-661 et seq. 

Sec. 50-71. - Board created. 
    There is hereby created a board of health. The board of health shall be a subcommittee of the urban affairs committee. The urban affairs committee shall administer and perform the functions and duties of the board of health. 
    There is created a board of health. 
(Code 1967, § 10-28; Ord. No. 04-48, § 2, 8-24-2004) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-48, § 3, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed §§ 50-72, 50-73, which pertained to the composition and qualifications of the board of health. For complete derivation, see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
Sec. 50-74. - Duties. 
    The board of health shall have general supervision of the interests of the health of the people of the city. The board shall cooperate with the state department of health in enforcing the rules and regulations promulgated by the department for control of communicable diseases and such other rules and regulations of the state and county and city as may be related to the sanitation and health of the city. The board of health shall have authority to make recommendations to the mayor and city council for the passage of ordinances pertaining to reasonable rules, regulations and orders, as it may from time to time deem necessary for the preservation and improvement of the public health and for the suppressing of disease. The board of health shall also give to the city authorities such professional advice and information as may be required or requested to preserve the public health. 
(a)  The board of health shall additionally conduct blood drives within the City of Rolling Meadows for life source center or any similar organization whose purpose is to provide blood to area hospitals. 
(Code 1967, § 10-31; Ord. No. 02-07, § 3, 2-26-2002) 
Sec. 50-75. - Tobacco information prevention subcommittee. 
    There is hereby created the tobacco information prevention subcommittee, a subcommittee of the board of health, which shall consist of membership not to exceed nine persons appointed by the board of health. The subcommittee shall annually elect from among its members a chairman to serve a term of one year or until a successor has been appointed. The terms of all members of the subcommittee shall correspond with the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 99-36, § 1, 7-27-1999) 
Sec. 50-76. - Duties. 
    The subcommittee shall be responsible for the development of programs to educate of persons within the city in regard to health problems associated with the use of tobacco. The subcommittee shall implement programs directed at curtailing or preventing the use of tobacco programs, particularly for children and young adults. The city council shall review, and at its sole discretion, may approve annual appropriations for use by the subcommittee to carry out its duties. 
(Ord. No. 99-36, § 1, 7-27-1999) 
Sec. 50-77. - Reports. 
    The subcommittee shall, not less than quarterly, submit a written report to the board of health and the city manager on its activities. Further, the chairman shall submit an annual report to the city manager and chairman of the board of health summarizing its accomplishments for the past calendar year; said report shall be filed not less than 90 days following the end of the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 99-36, § 1, 7-27-1999) 
Secs. 50-78-50-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BEAUTY CULTURE SHOPS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 50-101. - Sanitation rules. 
    The following sanitation rules shall apply to beauty culture shops: 
(1)  All persons practicing beauty culture must provide quarters that have been either designed or altered to accommodate these services, that are equipped to give adequate service to patrons and that are subject to inspection by the constituted authorities. 
(2)  The use of the beauty culture shop as living quarters is prohibited. If a beauty culture shop is located in a private residence or in connection with some business, a separate room and an adequate entrance must be provided for the beauty culture shop. 
(3)  The location of a beauty culture shop in a building occupied or frequented by persons of an immoral character is prohibited. The use of a beauty culture shop for immoral purposes shall be sufficient cause for automatic revocation of the certificate of registration. 
(4)  Floors, walls, furniture and other fixtures must be kept clean at all times. All basins, containers, etc., must be sanitized immediately after using. 
(5)  Every owner of a beauty culture shop must provide an adequate supply of hot and cold water in such quantities as may be necessary to conduct the beauty culture shop in a sanitary manner. 
(6)  No owner or manager of a beauty culture shop shall knowingly permit any person suffering from a communicable disease or from any venereal disease in a communicable form to work in the beauty culture shop. 
(7)  Male and female beauticians must wear clean professional, washable uniforms at all times. 
(8)  Clean towels shall be stored in a sanitary manner. Persons employed in a beauty culture shop shall use separate and clean towels for each patron. After a towel has been used once, it must be discarded in a separate container until properly laundered. 
(9)  The headrest of any facial chair shall be covered in a sanitary manner and changed after each patron. 
(10)  Combs and brushes must be cleansed thoroughly after each use, with soap and hot water, and immersed in an approved germicidal solution for the required time as per the manufacturer's instructions, removed and rinsed in hot water, dried and placed in a closed container. 
(11)  Glass or metal articles that cannot be boiled must be cleansed in soap and water, wiped in a 70-percent alcohol solution and kept in a closed container. 
(12)  No employee of any beauty culture shop shall massage any person when the surface to be massaged is inflamed or broken out or contains pus. 
(13)  Every person engaged in a beauty culture shop must thoroughly cleanse his hands immediately before serving each patron. 
(14)  All powders, lotions, creams, and other cosmetics used for patrons must be kept in clean and closed containers. 
(15)  Powder must be in shakers or similar receptacles. Open powder boxes must not be used for patrons. 
(16)  Lotions or fluids must be poured into sterile containers and applied to patrons by means of sanitary applicators. 
(17)  Creams and other semisolid substances must be removed from the container with a sterile article or spatula. Removing such substances with the fingers is prohibited. 
(18)  Cosmetics must be removed by means of absorbent soft paper or other disposable material. 
(19)  Every person engaged in a beauty culture shop must display the certificate of registration in a conspicuous place, preferably at the station where such person is employed. 
(20)  No animals or pets shall be kept in or allowed to enter a beauty culture shop, other than dogs aiding the blind, hearing impaired and physically handicapped, per 720 ILCS 630/1. 
(Code 1967, § 10-65) 
Sec. 50-102. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the rules and regulations of this article shall pay a fine in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 10-66; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Secs. 50-103-50-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FOOD AND FOOD DEALERS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 50-131-50-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND RETAIL FOOD DEALERS 

Sec. 50-161. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certified food service manager or supervisor means a person who has successfully completed 16 hours of a food service sanitation class and who has successfully passed the examination required by the state department of public health. 
    Food service establishment means any place where food is prepared and intended for individual portion service and includes the site at which individual portions are provided. The term includes any such place, regardless of whether consumption is on or off the premises and regardless of whether there is a charge for the food. The term includes delicatessens that offer prepared food in individual service portions. It also includes bakeries and ice cream parlors. The term does not include private homes where food is prepared or served for individual family consumption, retail foodstores, the location of food vending machines, and supply vehicles. 
    Health authority means that person designated by the city to enforce this division. 
    Nonserious violation means a violation of the adopted codes of this division that is not a serious threat to public health. A nonserious violation is one that would not cause or create a situation in which illness, injury or possible death could occur. Nonserious violations are a one- or two-point weighted item on the inspection report form. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, company, corporation, trustee, association or public or private entity. 
    Repeated violations means violations that have been cited on previous inspection report forms and have not been corrected. 
    Retail foodstore means any establishment or section of an establishment where food and food products are offered to the consumer and intended for off-premises consumption. The term includes delicatessens that offer prepared food in bulk quantities, only. It also includes meat markets and automobile service station minimarts. The term does not include establishments that handle only prepackaged spirits, roadside markets that offer only fresh fruits and fresh vegetables for sale, food service establishments, or food and beverage vending machines. 
    Serious violation or critical violation means a violation of the adopted codes of this division that is a serious threat to public health. A serious violation is one that would cause or create a situation in which illness, injury or possible death could occur. Serious violations are four- or five-point weighted items on the inspection report form. Serious violations that may affect public health include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Extended loss of water supply. 
(2)  Extended power outage. 
(3)  A sewage backup into the establishment. 
(4)  Inadequate refrigeration. 
(5)  Damage to the establishment by fire, smoke, or flooding. 
(6)  Rating score of the establishment of 60 points or less. 
    Valid business license means one that is not suspended, revoked or expired. 
(Code 1967, § 12-156) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-162. - Enforcement; adoption of rules, regulations and standards. 
(a)  This division shall be enforced by the health authority in accordance with the 1996 Food Service Sanitation Code, as established by the state department of public health, and pursuant to any subsequent revisions or amendments to such rules and regulations, except that sections 750.1600 through 750.1700, pertaining to temporary food service, of such rules and regulations are not adopted. Copies of the rules and regulations are on file in the city clerk's office and the offices of the health authority. 
(b)  This division shall be enforced by the health authority in accordance with the 1992 Retail Foodstore Sanitation Rules and Regulations, as established by the state department of public health, and any subsequent revisions. Copies of the rules and regulations shall be on file in the city clerk's office and in the offices of the health authority. 
(c)  This division shall be enforced by the health authority in accordance with the national sanitation foundation standards for food service establishment equipment, including construction and installation standards for new and replacement equipment, and any subsequent revisions. 
(d)  The rules, regulations and standards, including code books, listed in subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section are adopted by reference. 
(Code 1967, § 12-157) 
Sec. 50-163. - License required; posting. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to operate a retail foodstore or food service establishment within the city without first obtaining a business license from the city. 
(b)  A valid business license shall be posted in every food service establishment and retail foodstore in a manner consistent with the general provisions of article I of chapter 22. 
(Code 1967, § 12-158) 
Sec. 50-164. - License application; inspection; issuance. 
(a)  Any person desiring a business license to operate a food service establishment or retail foodstore or any person desiring to renew such a business license shall make written application on forms provided by the license officer. The applicant shall provide, in addition to the information generally required under article I of chapter 22, the following information: 
(1)  The type of the proposed food service establishment or retail foodstore. 
(2)  The signature of the applicant. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such application and the fee by the license officer, the health authority shall make an inspection of the food service establishment or retail foodstore to determine compliance with this division. 
(c)  If the inspection reveals that the applicable requirements of this division have been met, a business license shall be approved by the health authority and forwarded to the license officer. 
(d)  Only a person who complies with the requirements of this division shall be entitled to receive and retain such a business license. 
(e)  The business license shall be issued to the person named in the application for the premises, and shall not be transferable except in compliance with section 22-30. 
(Code 1967, § 12-159) 
Sec. 50-165. - License fees. 
    The annual license fees to be paid for licenses for food dealers, subject to regulation under this division, shall be based on the assignment of the particular food dealer to one of three categories: high risk, medium risk, or low risk. 
(Code 1967, § 12-160; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 50-166. - Renewal of annual licenses. 
(a)  Upon receipt by the license officer of an application to renew an annual business license issued pursuant to this division, the health authority shall reinspect the establishment, as provided in subsection 50-164(b), to determine compliance with this division. 
(b)  If the inspection reveals that the applicable requirements of this division have been met, a new business license shall be approved by the health authority and forwarded to the license officer. 
(c)  Whenever an inspection of the establishment reveals a serious or repeated violation of this division, the business license may not be approved and the health authority shall, within a reasonable time, so notify the applicant in writing, stating the basis for denial. Such notice shall state that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided in accordance with section 22-40 if the applicant for the renewal license requests a hearing, in writing, within ten days of receipt of the notice provided in this subsection. 
(Code 1967, § 12-161) 
Sec. 50-167. - Conditional license. 
    If, during the course of the annual business license renewal inspection conducted pursuant to this division, the health authority finds any structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation or other defects that are contributing to sanitary defects, which defects are nonserious violations, a conditional business license may be approved by the health authority and forwarded to the license officer for issuance of a conditional business license. The conditional business license will be valid for 30 days. At that time, another licensing inspection will be conducted to determine compliance with this Code. If the violations are still in existence, procedures for suspension or revocation of the business license will be initiated. Only the health authority can approve issuance of a conditional business license. 
(Code 1967, § 12-162) 
Sec. 50-168. - Inspection of establishments. 
    The health director shall assign each food service business regulated under this division into one of three risk categories for the purpose of determining the fee owed for a license and the frequency of inspection. High-risk establishments shall be inspected at least four times annually; medium-risk establishments shall be inspected at least three times annually; and low-risk establishments shall be inspected at least two times annually. The following factors shall be used by the health director in determining the appropriate risk category for a particular food dealer: 
(1)  High-risk criteria: 
a.  Extensive handling of raw meat products. 
b.  Potentially hazardous food items go through several handling procedures. 
c.  Potentially hazardous food items are prepared more than 12 hours prior to service. 
d.  Establishment serves an immuno-compromised population. 
(2)  Medium-risk criteria: 
a.  Minimum handling of raw meat products; 
b.  Potentially hazardous food products go through few food handling procedures; 
c.  Potentially hazardous food items prepared less than 12 hours prior to service; and 
d.  Establishment does not serve an immuno-compromised population. 
(3)  Low-risk criteria: sells only prepackaged potentially hazardous foods. 
(Code 1967, § 12-163; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 50-169. - Examination and condemnation of food. 
(a)  Under this division, food may be examined or sampled by the health authority as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from adulteration or misbranding. The health authority may, upon written notice to the licensee or person in charge, place a hold order on any food that he determines or has probable cause to believe to be unwholesome or otherwise adulterated or misbranded. 
(b)  Under a hold order, food shall be permitted to be suitably stored, but not sold. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or alter a hold order, notice, or tag placed on food by the health authority, and neither the food nor the containers thereof shall be relabeled, repacked, reprocessed, altered, disposed of, or destroyed without permission of the health authority, except on order by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1967, § 12-164) 
Sec. 50-170. - Suspension of license. 
(a)  Failure to comply with any notice issued in accordance with this division may result in suspension of the business license. The licensee or person in charge shall then be advised, in writing, of the intended suspension, the reason therefor, and the effective date of such suspension. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other section of this division, whenever the health authority finds any condition in the operation of a food service establishment or retail foodstore which, in his judgment, constitutes serious violations or a substantial hazard to the public health, he shall immediately and without warning or hearing notify the licensee or person in charge of such condition and order the business license suspended and cause notification of such suspension to be mailed to or personally served to the licensee or his agent. All food service operations shall then be immediately discontinued. Substantial hazards to public health or serious violations include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Extended loss of water supply. 
(2)  Extended power outage. 
(3)  A sewage backup into the establishment. 
(4)  Inadequate refrigeration. 
(5)  Damage to the establishment by fire, smoke or flooding. 
(6)  Rating score of the establishment of 60 points or less. 
(c)  The licensee shall have ten days from the date of receipt of any notice of intent to suspend under subsection (a) of this section or from the date of delivery to the licensee or person in charge or the mailing of the notice of suspension under subsection (b) of this section, as the case may be, to request a hearing before the city manager to contest the action of the health authority. Such operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 12-165) 
Sec. 50-171. - Reinstatement of suspended license. 
    Any person whose business license has been suspended pursuant to this division may, at any time, make application for a reinspection for the purpose of reinstatement of the business license. Within five days following receipt of a written request, including a statement signed by the applicant that, in his opinion, the conditions causing suspension of the business license have been corrected, the city shall cause a reinspection. If the applicant is complying with the requirements of this division, the business license shall be reinstated. Reinstatement will be determined by the health authority or city manager. 
(Code 1967, § 12-166) 
Sec. 50-172. - License revocation. 
(a)  For serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this division or for the interference with the health authority in the performance of his duties, the business license may be permanently revoked after an opportunity for a hearing before the city manager. Prior to such action, the city manager shall notify the licensee, in writing, stating the reasons for which the business license is subject to revocation and advising that the business license shall be permanently revoked at the end of ten days following service of such notice, unless a request for a hearing is filed with the city manager by the licensee within such ten-day period. 
(b)  A business license may be suspended for cause pending its revocation or a hearing relative thereto. 
(Code 1967, § 12-167) 
Sec. 50-173. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  The hearings provided for in this division shall be conducted for the following reasons: 
(1)  Nonrenewal of the annual business license. 
(2)  Appeal from an inspection report. 
(3)  Suspension of a business license. 
(4)  Revocation of a business license. 
(5)  Imposition of a hold order under section 50-169. 
(6)  A fourth offense for violation of this division. 
(b)  The hearings shall be conducted by the city manager at a time and place designated by him. Appropriate notice and the conduct of such hearings shall be in accordance with those provisions generally applicable to license suspension or revocation in subsections 22-40(d) through (g). During the hearing, the city must prove by a preponderance of evidence that the violation exists and/or that suspension or revocation is justified, as the case may be. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager may appeal to the corporate authorities pursuant to section 22-40. 
(Code 1967, § 12-168) 
Sec. 50-174. - Posting of health violation signs. 
(a)  Whenever a food service establishment or retail foodstore has had its business license suspended or revoked for the reasons set forth in this division, a health violation sign shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the establishment or store. 
(b)  The sign must be signed by the officer who authorized its posting and cite the Code sections violated. 
(c)  The sign cannot be removed by anyone except the officer who authorized its posting. 
(Code 1967, § 12-169) 
Sec. 50-175. - Food brought in from other jurisdictions. 
(a)  Food from food service establishments and/or retail foodstores outside the city's jurisdiction may be sold within the city if such facilities conform to this division. Examples of such operations include but are not limited to catering establishments and mobile food vendors which prepare food in another jurisdiction but serve the food within the city. 
(b)  To determine the extent of the establishment's compliance with this division, the health authority may accept reports from the responsible authority in other jurisdictions where such facilities are located. If the inspection reports from the other jurisdictions indicate unsanitary conditions, the establishment will not be allowed to sell food within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-170) 
Sec. 50-176. - Review of construction or remodeling plans. 
(a)  When a food service establishment or retail foodstore is to be constructed or remodeled or when an existing structure is to be converted for use as a food service establishment or retail foodstore, properly prepared plans and specifications shall be submitted to the health authority and approved in writing before such work begins. 
(b)  Such plans shall be drawn to scale and shall show locations of all fixed equipment. Specifications shall describe construction materials and equipment by manufacturer and model number. 
(c)  Food service establishments and retail foodstores must abide by the current health department food service construction requirements. 
(Code 1967, § 12-171) 
Sec. 50-177. - New or replacement equipment. 
    New or replacement equipment, which includes equipment new to the food service establishment or retail foodstore, shall meet or be equivalent to the standards of the National Sanitation Foundation as to construction and installation, which standards have been adopted by reference in section 50-162 of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 12-172) 
Sec. 50-178. - Preoperational inspection. 
    Whenever plans and specifications are required by this division to be submitted to the health authority, the health authority shall inspect the food service establishment and/or retail foodstore prior to the start of operations to determine compliance with the approved plans and specifications and with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-173) 
Sec. 50-179. - Procedure for suspected infection. 
    When the health authority has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease transmission by an employee of a food service establishment and/or retail foodstore, he may secure a morbidity history of the suspected employee or make any other investigation, as indicated, and shall take appropriate action. The health authority may require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of the employee from the employment of the facility. 
(2)  The immediate closing of the facility concerned until, in the opinion of the health authority, no further danger of disease outbreak exists. 
(3)  Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the facility where there would be no danger of transmitting disease. 
(4)  Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of other employees and of his and their body discharges. 
(Code 1967, § 12-174) 
Sec. 50-180. - Conflict with other provisions. 
    If a section of this division is found to be in conflict with a provision of any building, fire, safety or health ordinance or section of this Code or of any other code existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division derives, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. 
(Code 1967, § 12-175(a)) 
Sec. 50-181. - Certified food service managers. 
(a)  All food service establishments, as defined in section 50-161, shall be under the operational supervision of a certified manager or supervisor who is employed at the establishment no less than 40 hours per week. A minimum of one certified person at each establishment is required; provided, however: 
(1)  New food service establishments shall have six months from the initial day of operation to comply. 
(2)  Food service establishments that are not in compliance because of employee turnover or other loss of certified personnel shall have three months from the date of the loss of certified personnel to comply. 
(b)  Certification shall be achieved by successfully completing an examination offered by the state department of public health or other approved examination monitored by the state department of public health or its designated representative. A certificate of certification will be issued to candidates attaining the passing point as determined by the state department of public health. 
(c)  Names and certificate numbers of certified personnel shall be maintained at the place of business and shall be made available for inspection. 
(d)  Certificate holders are required to notify the state department of public health of any change of address or status. 
(Code 1967, § 12-176) 
Sec. 50-182. - Service of notices. 
    Notices provided for under this division shall be deemed to have been properly served when a copy of the notice has been delivered personally or has been sent by registered or certified mail to the licensee or person in charge at the address of the business affected. A copy of such notice shall be filed with the records of the health authority. 
(Code 1967, § 12-177) 
Sec. 50-183. - Penalties. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other section of article I of chapter 22, any person who violates any of the sections of this division or who refuses to comply with any lawful order or requirement of the health authority duly made in writing as provided in this division shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor, and each day after the expiration of the time limit for abating unsanitary conditions and completing improvements to abate such conditions as ordered by the health authority shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1967, § 12-178; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Secs. 50-184-50-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TEMPORARY FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND RETAIL FOODSTORES 

Sec. 50-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Health authority means that person designated by the city to enforce this division. 
    Restricted establishment means any person, group, or business desiring to operate a temporary food service establishment or temporary retail foodstore and who does not hold a valid business license from the city and does not meet the requirements of division 2 of this article. 
    Temporary food service operation means a food service establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than 14 consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. 
    Temporary retail foodstore means a retail foodstore that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than 14 consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. 
    Unrestricted establishment means a food service establishment or retail foodstore which holds a current business license from the city and meets the requirements of division 2 of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 12-185) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-212. - Compliance with division. 
    A temporary food service establishment shall comply with all sections of this division that are applicable to its operation, provided that the health authority may augment food, may prohibit the sale of certain potentially hazardous food, and may modify specific requirements for physical facilities when, in his opinion, no imminent health hazard will result. 
(Code 1967, § 12-186) 
Sec. 50-213. - Permit required; application; inspection of premises. 
(a)  Required. Any person, group, or business desiring to operate a temporary food service or temporary retail foodstore must apply for a temporary food service operation permit from the health authority. 
(b)  Application. The applicant must apply for a temporary food operation permit at the office of the health authority and provide the following: 
(1)  The type of the proposed temporary food service establishment or retail foodstore. 
(2)  The date and time of the event when operation will be set up. 
(3)  The signature and phone number of the applicant. 
(c)  Inspection of premises. After a temporary food operation permit is issued, the health authority will conduct an inspection of the premises to determine compliance. 
(d)  Duration. The temporary food operation permit is valid up to 14 days. After 14 days another permit must be taken out to continue the temporary food operation; however, no more than two consecutive permits can be issued. If the applicant desires to operate longer than 28 days, application for a business license must be made. 
(e)  Fee. The fee that would normally be due for a temporary food operation may be waived by the license officer for events being sponsored and operated by not-for-profit groups located within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-187; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 50-214. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
(a)  Noncompliance. Failure to comply with this division will result in immediate suspension or revocation of the permit, and all operations must cease.
