(b)  Violations causing suspension or revocation. Serious violations that may affect public health and that may cause immediate suspension or revocation of the permit include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Repeated violations of food not being maintained at the proper temperature. 
(2)  Unsanitary water supply used for cooking, cleaning and handwashing. 
(3)  Presence of excessive insects and/or rodents. 
(4)  Unwholesome food used. 
(5)  Inadequate sewage disposal. 
(Code 1967, § 12-188) 
Sec. 50-215. - Sanitation requirements for operation. 
    Compliance with this division shall be deemed to have been satisfied when the following requirements are met: 
(1)  All food, including meat, milk, vegetables, etc., shall be obtained from sources complying with applicable state laws and regulations, and only food that is clean, wholesome and free from adulteration and misbranding shall be sold or served. All fruits and vegetables shall be washed before being used. Home-canned foods shall not be used. All stands that freeze dairy products must have a certificate of approval from the state division of food and drugs. 
(2)  The preparation of potentially hazardous food, such as cream filled pastries, custards and similar products, and meat, poultry and fish in the form of salads or sandwiches shall be prohibited, provided that this prohibition shall not apply to hamburgers, frankfurters and other food which, prior to service, requires only limited preparation such as seasoning and cooking. All poultry must be fried or boiled. Food items prepared with or from poultry products are prohibited. All hamburger intended for use shall be purchased in patty form only. All hams including precooked hams shall be thoroughly cooked prior to serving. 
(3)  All food prepared one day shall not be retained and served the following day or thereafter. 
(4)  Potentially hazardous food shall be stored and displayed at 41 degrees Fahrenheit or below or 140 degrees Fahrenheit or above, whichever is applicable. 
(5)  Ice which will be consumed or which will come in contact with food shall be obtained from an approved source in chipped, crushed or cubed form, packaged in single-service, sealed container bags. Necessary precautions shall be taken to prevent the contamination of the ice during storage or serving. Ice scoops are required. Hand dipping is prohibited. 
(6)  The handling of all food shall be accomplished by the appropriate use of utensils such as scoops, tongs, spoons and forks or approved food paper wraps. 
(7)  All food on display, such as cotton candy, candied apples, candy and other foods shall be adequately covered or shall be individually packaged to prevent contamination from dust and other elements. Effective shielding must be provided consisting of glass or other suitable materials where necessary to prevent contamination of food and food preparation equipment from dust, rain, flies, insects, consumer handling and other elements. 
(8)  There shall be no wet storage of packaged foods and beverages. However, bottled or canned beverages may be stored in water, providing the top of the bottle or can is not submerged and a chlorine residual of at least 50 parts per million is maintained and ice water is changed frequently enough to keep both the water and container clean. 
(9)  Sugar, mustard, ketchup and other condiments shall be individually packaged or dispensed from an approved dispenser. Open, common serving containers are strictly prohibited. 
(10)  All equipment and facilities must be kept clean and in a sanitary condition. Only equipment which is safe, in good repair and cleanable shall be used. Food contact surfaces in food preparation areas shall be smooth. Counters and shelving are to be kept clean and presentable at all times. 
(11)  Approved utensil washing and sanitizing facilities shall be provided. All multiuse utensils following washing and rinsing must be sanitized by immersion in hot water at 180 degrees for at least one minute or immersed in an approved chemical sanitizing solution of 50 parts per million (ppm) chlorine bleach or 12 ppm iodine for at least one minute. 
(12)  Only the use of single-service paper plates, cups and plastic or wooden knives, forks or spoons by the public is permitted. Multiuse eating utensils are prohibited. 
(13)  An adequate supply of safe sanitary quality water for drinking, food preparation, handwashing, and manual dishwashing of utensils must be maintained in the establishment if a pressure water supply is not available in the establishment. Auxiliary heating facilities, capable of producing an ample supply of hot water for such purposes, shall be provided. Water storage containers for storage of water used in drinks and food preparation must be of an approved type and material and shall have tightfitting covers. There shall be no dipping of water. All water must be dispensed through an approved type of dispensing valve. 
(14)  All liquid waste shall be disposed into public sewers or approved private facilities. Two chemical restrooms shall be provided, one for women and one for men, for each group of concessions, booths or rides totaling 20 or a fraction thereof, and they shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary way at all times. 
(15)  All garbage shall be kept in tightly covered watertight washable containers until removed. All rubbish, paper and boxes must be stored in a manner that does not cause an unsightly or unsanitary situation. The grounds immediately surrounding the establishment shall be kept free of food scraps, paper and similar refuse. An adequate number of garbage containers shall be provided. All garbage and refuse shall be collected, transported and disposed of in an approved way. 
(16)  Strict attention shall be given to personal hygiene. Persons with boils, cuts, respiratory infections and communicable diseases shall not work in the stand at any phase of food handling. Fingernails shall be trimmed; hands and arms shall be clean and washed before starting work, after using the toilet and at other times as necessary. Clean outer garments shall be worn. The hair must be kept restrained (hair nets and caps are recommended). The use of tobacco in the stand in any form shall not be permitted. 
(17)  Handwashing facilities shall be provided in each stand or establishment. Such facilities shall consist of water for washing and rinsing of hands, soap and single-service paper towels. 
(18)  All food stands shall be located at a safe and reasonable distance from toilet facilities, animals or their enclosures and other potential fly-breeding areas. 
(19)  Floors shall be of tight woods, asphalt or other cleanable material, provided that the health authority may accept dirt or gravel covered floors when graded to preclude the accumulation of liquids and when covered with movable, cleanable wooden platforms or duckboards. Walls and ceilings shall be so constructed as to minimize the entrance of flies and dust. Temporary construction may be accepted. Ceilings may be of wood, canvas, or other materials or of 16-mesh screening or equivalent. When flies are prevalent, counter service openings shall either be equipped with self-closing, flytight doors, or the opening shall be protected by effective fans. Where fans are used for this purpose, the size of the opening shall be limited so the fans employed will effectively prevent the entrance of flies. 
(20)  A copy of the temporary food operation permit shall be posted in a conspicuous location within the area of food preparation and serving. 
(21)  Only packaged ice cream or other frozen milk products can be served except from an approved dispenser. 
(22)  Only bottled drinks, milk included, or those drawn from an approved container with a tap can be served. 
(23)  Only authorized personnel are allowed in the food preparation area. No children under age 16 shall be allowed, unless supervised by a person at least 18 years of age. 
(24)  Any other requirement deemed necessary by the health authority to protect the public health in view of the particular nature of the food service operation shall be met. 
(Code 1967, § 12-189) 
Sec. 50-216. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the sections of this division or who refuses to comply with any lawful order or requirement of the health authority duly made in writing as provided in this division shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor, and each day after the expiration of the time limit for abating unsanitary conditions and completing improvements to abate such conditions as ordered by the health authority shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1967, § 12-190; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Secs. 50-217-50-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FOOD MANUFACTURERS 

Sec. 50-246. - License required; application. 
    It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of manufacturing any food, candy, ice cream or confectionery other than baking goods without having first secured a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the license officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-194) 
Sec. 50-247. - Sanitation. 
(a)  All premises used for food manufacturers shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any flammable waste to accumulate. All employees of such places must keep themselves clean both as to person and clothing, and it shall be unlawful to employ any person in any such place who has a contagious disease of any kind. 
(b)  All places used for such purposes must be kept free from flies, mice, and vermin of all kinds. 
(Code 1967, § 12-196) 
Sec. 50-248. - Materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for a food manufacturer to use in such business any materials that might be harmful to human health or adulterated in a manner contrary to the state or federal statutes. All milk used in the manufacture of food or ice cream shall be milk, which is of the standard required by division 6 of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 12-197) 
Sec. 50-249. - Inspections. 
    The health officer shall make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division, and he shall make at least one such inspection every six months. 
(Code 1967, § 12-198) 
Secs. 50-250-50-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLES 

Sec. 50-276. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Caterer or catering food service establishment means any food service establishment which meets the requirements of division 2 of this article who prepares food and then transports the food to various locations within and outside the city limits. 
    Food delivery vehicle means any vehicle which carries or stores food, whether prepackaged, in bulk, or nonpackaged prepared food, for delivery of such food items to any place in the city for use and consumption or for resale in the city. Delivery trucks used by caterers or catering food service establishments are considered food delivery vehicles. The driver of a food delivery vehicle is not permitted to stop the vehicle and vend food from the vehicle on any city street. 
(Code 1967, § 12-203) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-277. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons and motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by manpower, for the storage or carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, bread or bakery goods or any other provisions intended for human consumption, including beverages and milk, in the city for the purpose of delivering any such foodstuffs to any place in the city for use and consumption or for resale in the city for such purposes, unless a license for such vehicle is first secured and unless there is full compliance with this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-204) 
Sec. 50-278. - License application; issuance. 
    Application for a food delivery vehicle license shall be made to the license officer and shall recite the name of the person from whom such deliveries are made and the nature of the goods carried. The license officer shall issue such licenses and shall give the city manager a list of all such licenses issued. 
(Code 1967, § 12-205) 
Sec. 50-279. - Exemption from license fee. 
    No fee for the license required by this division shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a food dealing establishment in the city, but all sections of this division shall be complied with in connection with such vehicles. 
(Code 1967, § 12-207) 
Sec. 50-280. - General cleanliness. 
    All food delivery vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. It shall be unlawful to permit stale food, decaying matter, or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used. 
(Code 1967, § 12-208) 
Sec. 50-281. - Transporting unwrapped foodstuffs. 
    If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any food delivery vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle that is screened and protected against dust and insects. 
(Code 1967, § 12-209) 
Sec. 50-282. - Food storage. 
    Potentially hazardous food items delivered by caterers and prepared in bulk must be stored in food holding containers approved by the National Sanitation Foundation (N.S.F.) and shall be capable of holding the temperature of 45 degrees Fahrenheit or 140 degrees Fahrenheit until such food is delivered to its destination. 
(Code 1967, § 12-210) 
Sec. 50-283. - Mechanical refrigeration required. 
    Food delivery vehicles must be equipped with mechanical refrigeration which shall maintain the temperature at 41 degrees Fahrenheit or below if the truck is delivering potentially hazardous food (bulk, raw materials), as defined by the state department of public health rules and regulations. 
(Code 1967, § 12-211) 
Sec. 50-284. - Inspections required. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-212) 
Sec. 50-285. - Revocation of license for violation. 
    Any license issued under this division may be revoked by the city manager for any violation of any section or regulation of this division, and such revocation shall be in addition to any fine imposed. 
(Code 1967, § 12-213) 
Sec. 50-286. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the sections of this division or who refuses to comply with any lawful order or requirement of the health authority duly made in writing as provided in this division shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor, and each day after the expiration of the time limit for abating unsanitary conditions and completing improvements to abate such conditions as ordered by the health authority shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1967, § 12-214; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Secs. 50-287-50-315. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - FOOD VENDING VEHICLES 

Sec. 50-316. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Health department means the city health department. 
    Health official means the city health officer or his duly authorized representative. 
    Prepared food vending vehicle means a food vending vehicle from which any prepared food or beverage product is sold, given away, displayed or offered for sale at retail or wholesale. 
(Code 1967, § 12-215) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-317. - Parking and stopping. 
    No person shall stop or park a food vending vehicle on a public thoroughfare for the purpose of selling, giving away, displaying or offering for sale any food or beverage product except for a period of time sufficient to consummate an immediate sale. No person shall stop, park or cause any food vending vehicle to remain on any public property except pursuant to the order of a lawful authority or for the purpose of making emergency repairs to the vehicle; in no event shall any person sell or give away any food beverage product from a food vending vehicle while on public property other than a public thoroughfare. No person shall stop, park or cause a food vending vehicle to remain on any property for the purpose of selling, giving away, displaying or offering for sale any food or beverage product to any person other than the owner of such property or his agents, customers or employees, and then only for a period of time sufficient to consummate immediate sales. 
(Code 1967, § 12-216) 
Sec. 50-318. - Application of other laws. 
    This division and other sections of this Code and city ordinances and state laws and regulations relative to health and sanitation shall apply to food vending vehicles. 
(Code 1967, § 12-217) 
Sec. 50-319. - Refrigeration. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated a food vending vehicle unless it is furnished with mechanical refrigeration equipment in good working order sufficient to maintain potentially hazardous food and beverage products at a temperature not in excess of 45 degrees Fahrenheit. Refrigeration units must be approved by the health authority. Refrigeration compartments shall be kept clean; shall be constructed of tile, metal or other approved materials; and shall have no seams or cracks. Wet refrigeration is prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 12-218) 
Sec. 50-320. - Certificate of inspection; identification. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated a food vending vehicle that does not display a valid certificate of inspection and that does not display on each exterior side of the vehicle, in letters not less than four inches high, the name of the owner or the assumed name under which he operates, the business address and telephone number of the owner, and the distinctive identifying number or symbol assigned to that vehicle. Such lettering shall be permanently affixed to the vehicle by painting, decal or other method approved by the health officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-219) 
Sec. 50-321. - Cleanliness. 
    The interior and the exterior of every food vending vehicle and all equipment therein shall have smooth washable surfaces and shall be maintained in good repair and in a sanitary manner. 
(Code 1967, § 12-220) 
Sec. 50-322. - Prepared food vending vehicles. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated a prepared food vending vehicle without complying with all of the following: 
(1)  Such person shall establish, within the state, a commissary which meets all of the requirements of this Code or city ordinances applicable to food establishments. The commissary shall be used for the preparation and/or temporary storage, at temperatures as required by this article, of food and beverage products prior to the delivery thereof to a food vending vehicle. Unless written authorization from the health officer to do otherwise is first obtained, food vending vehicles shall be stocked only with food and beverage products which shall be sold or otherwise distributed from a prepared food vending vehicle, unless such products were prepared in a commissary or in a food establishment, for either of which a valid permit is held, or in some other sanitary location appropriate for such preparation which is regularly inspected by some recognized health department inspection service or as approved by the director of the state department of public health. Food and beverage products not prepared in such a commissary or establishment shall be stored at a commissary prior to delivery to the prepared food vending vehicle. 
(2)  Potentially hazardous food items must be maintained at all times at 41 degrees Fahrenheit or 140 degrees Fahrenheit. Mechanical refrigeration and National Sanitation Foundation (N.S.F.) approved heating/holding units must be used for all mobile vendors. 
(3)  The source (name and address) of all food items must be on all individual packages. Food acquired from sources other than the commissary must include ingredients on the label. 
(4)  Thermometers must be provided in hot food holding units and refrigeration units. 
(5)  All food items must be individually packaged. 
(6)  Bulk items such as relish, onions, tomatoes, peppers, salsa, etc., are not permitted on vehicles. 
(7)  Only single-service utensils, plates, cups, etc., can be used. 
(8)  Adequate garbage containers must be provided on the vehicle. 
(Code 1967, § 12-221) 
Sec. 50-323. - Inspection required. 
    Every prepared food vending vehicle shall be inspected on dates scheduled by the health officer as often as he deems such inspections to be necessary. The vending vehicle shall be fully loaded and ready for operation at the time of such inspection. 
(Code 1967, § 12-222) 
Sec. 50-324. - Restriction on use. 
    Food vending vehicles shall be used for no purpose other than those purposes permitted by this division. 
(Code 1967, § 12-223) 
Sec. 50-325. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any food delivery vehicle unless a business license is first secured and the provisions of this division and all other applicable sections of this Code and city ordinances are fully complied with. Application shall be made to the license officer and shall recite the name and address of the owner and such information that is required. 
(Code 1967, § 12-223.1; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 50-326. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the sections of this division or who refuses to comply with any lawful order or requirement of the health authority duly made in writing as provided in this division shall be guilty of a class B misdemeanor, and each day after the expiration of the time limit for abating unsanitary conditions and completing improvements to abate such conditions as ordered by the health authority shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(b)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1967, § 12-223.2; Ord. No. 97-26, § 1, 4-22-1997) 
Secs. 50-327-50-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 50-356. - License required. 
    No person who owns, leases or has a possessory interest in any premises within the city shall install, keep, maintain, use or permit the maintenance or use upon such premises of any vending machine, automatic vending machine, coin-operated machine or other mechanical device requiring more than $0.01 for the activation thereof, which is used or intended to be used for the sale or distribution of any product, unless the machine or device shall have been first licensed under this division, and no owner of any vending machine, automatic vending machine, coin-operated machine or other mechanical device requiring more than $0.01 for the activation thereof, which is used or intended to be used for the sale or distribution of any product, shall install the machine or device on any premises located within the city without first obtaining a license therefor pursuant to this division. This division shall not apply, however, to cigarette vending machines, jukeboxes, amusement machines or laundry machines. 
(Code 1967, § 12-247) 
Sec. 50-357. - License application. 
    Application for the license required by this division shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of article I of chapter 22 relating to applications for licenses. Such application shall include the following: 
(1)  The name of the owner of the premises upon which the machine is located for use; and 
(2)  The product to be sold or distributed by the machine. 
(Code 1967, § 12-248) 
Sec. 50-358. - Adulterated or misbranded food or beverages. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to sell, to offer or to expose for sale, through vending machines, or to have in his possession with intent to sell from vending machines any food, beverage or ingredient that is adulterated or misbranded. 
(b)  Samples of food, beverages or ingredients may be taken and examined by the city as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from adulteration or misbranding. The city may, on written notice to the operator, impound and forbid the sale of any food or beverage that is adulterated or misbranded or that the city has probable cause to believe to be adulterated or misbranded. After the operator has been given an opportunity for a hearing, the city may cause to be removed or destroyed any food or beverage that is adulterated or misbranded. However, if misbranding can be corrected by proper labeling, such food or beverage may be released to the operator for correct labeling under the city's supervision. 
(Code 1967, § 12-249) 
Sec. 50-359. - Inspection; notice of violation. 
(a)  The appropriate city officials shall inspect the servicing, maintenance and operation of vending machines dispensing readily perishable foods at least once every six months. Vending machines dispensing other than readily perishable foods may be inspected as often as deemed necessary. 
(b)  City officers or employees, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter at any reasonable time, upon any private or public property within the city where vending machines are operated, for the purpose of determining compliance with this division. The operator shall make provision for the city to have access to the interior of all vending machines operated by him. 
(c)  Whenever the city discovers a violation of any section of this division the operator concerned shall be notified. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Describe the condition found and state which section of this division is violated by such condition; 
(2)  Provide a specific and reasonable period of time for the correction of the condition; and 
(3)  State that an opportunity for a hearing on inspection findings will be provided, if a written request for such hearing is filed with the license officer. Such hearing shall be in the form prescribed in article I of chapter 22 for suspension or revocation of licenses. 
(Code 1967, § 12-250) 
Sec. 50-360. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Foods, beverages and ingredients. Under this division, foods, beverages and ingredients shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Foods, beverages and ingredients intended for sale through vending machines shall be obtained from sources complying with the regulations of the city and with other applicable state and federal laws and regulations. Such products shall be clean and wholesome, free from spoilage, and shall be processed, prepared, handled and stored in such a manner as to be protected against contamination and adulteration. All product contact surfaces of containers and equipment shall be protected from contamination. 
(2)  All foods, beverages and ingredients shall be stored or packaged in clean protective containers and shall be handled, transported and vended in a sanitary manner. Wet storage of packaged products is prohibited. 
(3)  Readily perishable foods offered for sale through vending machines shall be dispensed to the consumer in the individual original container or wrapper into which it was placed at the commissary or at the manufacturer's or processor's plant, or such products shall be dispensed into single-service containers. 
(4)  In those vending machines dispensing readily perishable foods, beverages, or ingredients in bulk, the bulk supplies of such foods, beverages or ingredients shall be transferred only to a bulk vending machine container and appurtenances that are clean and that have been subjected to an approved bactericidal process. 
(5)  Readily perishable foods or ingredients within the vending machine shall be maintained at a temperature not lower than 33 degrees Fahrenheit or not higher than 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Vending machines dispensing readily perishable foods shall be provided with controls which ensure the maintenance of these temperatures at all times, provided that an exception may be made for the actual time required to fill or otherwise service the machine and for a maximum recovery period of 30 minutes following completion of filling or servicing operations. Such controls shall also place the machine in an inoperative condition until serviced by the operator, if a power condition occurs which permits the food storage compartment to attain a temperature above 50 degrees Fahrenheit or below 33 degrees Fahrenheit, whichever is applicable. Vending machines dispensing readily perishable food shall be provided with a thermometer which, to an accuracy of plus or minus two degrees Fahrenheit, indicates the air temperature of the food storage compartment. 
(6)  The temperature for hot liquid foods or beverages shall be not less than 150 degrees Fahrenheit, and for frozen foods not more than 32 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(7)  Milk offered for sale through vending machines shall be dispensed only in individual containers or from bulk containers into which the milk was placed at the plant. 
(b)  Machine location. The vending machine location shall be such as to minimize the potential for contamination of the product, shall be easily cleanable and shall be kept clean. Service connections shall be such as to protect against unintentional or accidental interruption of service to the machine. Unless the vending machine is so sealed to the floor as to prevent seepage underneath or unless the machine can be manually moved with ease, one or more of the following shall be utilized to facilitate cleaning operations: 
(1)  The machine shall be mounted on legs six inches or more in height; 
(2)  The machine shall be mounted on casters or rollers; or 
(3)  The machine shall be mounted on gliders which permit it to be easily moved. 
(c)  Interior construction and maintenance. All interior surfaces and component parts of the vending machine shall be so designed and constructed as to permit easy cleaning and shall be kept clean. All product contact surfaces of the machine shall be of smooth, nontoxic, corrosion-resistant, and relatively nonabsorbent material and shall be capable of withstanding repeated cleaning and bactericidal treatment by normal procedures. Such surfaces shall be protected against contamination. 
(d)  Water supply. Water used in vending machines shall be from an approved source and shall be of safe and sanitary quality. 
(e)  Waste disposal. All wastes shall be properly disposed of and pending disposition shall be so kept in suitable containers as to prevent creating a nuisance. This subsection shall be deemed to have been satisfied when the following are met: 
(1)  All trash and other waste material shall be removed from the machine location as frequently as may be necessary to prevent nuisance and unsightliness and shall be disposed of in a manner approved by the health officer. 
(2)  A self-closing, leakproof, readily cleanable, plainly labeled and designated waste container shall be provided in the vicinity of each machine to receive used cups, cartons, wrappers, straws, closures and other single-service items. Such waste containers shall not be located within the vending machine, provided that an exception may be made for those machines dispensing only packaged products with crown closures, in which case the closure receptacle may be located within the machine. Suitable racks or cases shall be provided for multiuse containers or bottles. 
(3)  Containers shall be provided within all machines dispensing liquid products in bulk for the collection of drip, spillage, overflow, or other liquid wastes. An automatic shutoff device shall be provided which will place the vending machine out of operation before such container overflows. Containers or surfaces on which such wastes may accumulate shall be readily removable for cleaning, shall be easily cleanable, and shall be corrosion resistant. If liquid wastes from drip, spillage or overflow which originate within the machine are discharged into a sewer system, the connection to the sewer shall be through an air gap. 
(f)  Delivery of foods, ingredients, equipment and supplies to machine location. Foods, beverages and ingredients and product contact surfaces of containers, equipment and supplies shall be protected from contamination while in transit to the vending machine location. Readily perishable foods and beverages while in transit shall be maintained at a temperature not higher than 50 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1967, § 12-251) 
Sec. 50-361. - Failure to obtain license. 
(a)  If a vending machine required to be licensed under this division shall be operated within the city without a license having been procured for the machine or if such license is not displayed as provided in this Code, the license officer may: 
(1)  Render the machine inoperable by removing any electrical or other utility connection to the machine, by turning the machine with its face to a wall, or by installing some lock or other device to render the machine inoperable. Where such an action is taken, the officer shall place upon the machine a notice indicating that the operation of the machine constitutes a violation of city ordinances. 
(2)  Render such machine inoperable by covering it with some material which must be broken or torn in order to operate the machine. After rendering the machine inoperable in this manner, he shall place a notice indicating that the operation of the machine constitutes a violation of city ordinances. 
(3)  Impound the machine and remove it to any place within the city. If the machine is moved in this manner, the person who was required to procure a license for the machine under this division shall, in addition to procuring a license, be responsible for the payment of the expenses incurred by the city in the impoundment process. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to interfere with a city official who is carrying out his responsibilities to render inoperable or impound a vending or similar machine pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1967, § 12-252) 
Secs. 50-362-50-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RODENT CONTROL[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 

Sec. 50-391. - Elimination of rodent harborages. 
    All premises, improved or unimproved, and all open lots, areas, streets, sidewalks and alleys shall be kept clean and free of all refuse and/or material that might serve as harborage for rodents. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-23), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 50-392. - Elimination of food for rodents. 
(a)  All food products for human or domestic consumption shall be so protected as to prevent rats from gaining access thereto or coming into contact therewith. 
(b)  All garbage or other material unfit for human or domestic animal consumption, but edible to rodents, shall be stored in closed garbage containers. 
(c)  Garbage containers shall be tightly closed at all times, except when momentarily opened to receive or remove the contents thereof. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-24), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 50-393. - Notice of violation. 
    Whenever premises are suspected to be infested with rodents or to be maintained in violation of section 50-391 or 50-392, a notice, in writing, signed by the health officer or a member of the police department or the director of public works or an inspector from the building department, shall be served upon the owner personally or posted in a conspicuous place on the property. The notice shall state wherein such premises violate this article and the requirements and time allowed for correction. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-25), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 50-394. - Failure to comply with notice. 
    Failure to comply with notice provided for in section 50-393, within the time specified in the notice, shall constitute a violation. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-26), 5-27-1997) 
Secs. 50-395-50-420. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TOXIC SUBSTANCES DISCLOSURE TO EMPLOYEES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 50-421. - Definitions. 
    The words used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Toxic Substances Disclosure to Employees Act, 820 ILCS 255/1 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 10-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-422. - Report to department of labor. 
    The city shall submit to the director of the state department of labor an alphabetized list of substances, compounds or mixtures for which the city has acquired material safety data sheets on or before July 1 and annually thereafter, pursuant to 820 ILCS 255/5. Such sheets are to be provided by the supplier, importer, manufacturer, or seller of the toxic substance to the city pursuant to 820 ILCS 255/11. 
(Code 1967, § 10-72) 
Sec. 50-423. - Posting signs in workplace. 
    The city shall post in each department, in the place where notices to employees are usually posted, a sign informing the employees of their rights under this article and the state statute, 820 ILCS 255/1 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 10-73) 
Sec. 50-424. - Labeling of toxic substances. 
    The city shall label, with the chemical name and appropriate hazard warnings, each container of a toxic substance in the workplace, except that such label is not required if the container is ten gallons or less in volume and is a temporary container into which the toxic substance is transferred by the employee for immediate use. If the container is fixed (pipe, piping systems, reaction vessel or storage tank), a sign posted nearby shall convey the name and hazard warning. 
(Code 1967, § 10-74) 
Sec. 50-425. - Toxic substance labels. 
    The city shall ensure that each label, sign, placard, or set of operating instructions is prominently displayed so that employees can easily identify the toxic substances present. New labels need not be added, pursuant to this article, if existing labels already convey the necessary information required, nor does this article apply to containers into which products registered pursuant to the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act are transferred to form/use solutions at a mixing/loading site to use within a 12-hour period. All labeling information required for such products by the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act must be posted in a prominent location at the mixing/loading site. 
(Code 1967, § 10-75) 
Sec. 50-426. - Material safety data sheets. 
(a)  The city shall obtain a material safety data sheet for each toxic substance used, produced or stored in the workplace to which employees may be exposed. 
(b)  If the city becomes aware of new, significant information regarding the health hazard of a toxic substance, the new information must be added to the material safety data sheet within three months. 
(c)  The city shall maintain copies of the required material safety data sheets for each toxic substance in the workplace and shall make such sheet accessible to employees for at least ten years after the substance is no longer used or stored. 
(d)  The city shall provide, within ten days of a written request by an employee or a treating health care professional, the material safety data sheet. If the city does not possess the material safety data sheet, notice, in writing, shall be given of that fact within ten days to the requesting party. 
(e)  If the city does not possess the requested material safety data sheet, it shall request the sheet, in writing, from the seller of the toxic substance within ten days of the employee's request. If the seller fails to provide the city with the sheet within 30 days, the city shall file a complaint within ten days of such refusal, pursuant to 820 ILCS 255/9, with the state department of labor. 
(f)  The city must then mail a copy of the written request and the filed complaint to the seller and a copy of the filed complaint to the employee who requested the sheet within ten days of filing the complaint. 
(g)  Upon receipt of the material safety data sheet, the city shall mail it to the requesting employee or party within ten days. 
(Code 1967, § 10-76) 
Sec. 50-427. - Employees' rights. 
(a)  If an employee has requested information in writing about a toxic substance to which he is entitled under this article and 820 ILCS 255/1 et seq., and has not received it within the time required, the employee may refuse to work with the toxic substance, unless the city has made a good faith effort, pursuant to 820 ILCS 255/9(d), to acquire the material safety data sheet and has failed to do so, in which case, the employee may not refuse to work. 
(b)  Any employee refusing to work pursuant to this section or who files a complaint or claim against the city with the department of labor for the city's failure to comply with this article may not be discharged, disciplined or discriminated against. 
(c)  Employees may neither be requested nor required to waive their rights under this article. 
(Code 1967, § 10-77) 
Sec. 50-428. - Fire safety. 
    The city must arrange with the fire department to familiarize the fire department with all toxic substances used in every other department, their hazards, locations, places where employees are regularly stationed, entrance roads and evacuation routes. 
(Code 1967, § 10-78) 
Sec. 50-429. - Employee information and training. 
(a)  The city shall provide all employees with an education and training program with respect to all toxic substances to which the employees are routinely exposed in the course of employment. 
(b)  An employee is routinely exposed to any toxic substance that he ingests, inhales, absorbs through the skin or otherwise contacts on a regular basis during the course of his employment in concentrations for which there is substantial scientific evidence that a significant risk to human health may occur or that exceeds the limits established by the state department of labor. 
(c)  To inform and train employees, the city shall provide, before an employee is assigned to work with a toxic substance and annually thereafter: 
(1)  Personal instruction with respect to methods of material handling for each toxic substance to which the employee will be exposed; 
(2)  A material safety data sheet for each toxic substance; and 
(3)  A summary provided by the state department of labor. 
(Code 1967, § 10-79) 
Sec. 50-430. - Complaints. 
    Any employee alleging denial of rights under this article may, within 180 days of the alleged denial, file a complaint with the state department of labor, pursuant to 820 ILCS 255/17. 
(Code 1967, § 10-80) 
Sec. 50-431. - Exceptions to article. 
    This article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Use of toxic substances, compounds or mixtures regulated by this article which are: 
a.  Intended for personal consumption by employees in the workplace. 
b.  Consumer goods used, stored or sold by an employer, manufacturer, importer, retailer or supplier in the same form, approximate amount, concentration and manner as they are sold to consumers, provided that employee exposure to such consumer goods is not significantly greater than consumer exposure occurring during the principal consumer uses of the consumer goods. For purposes of this article, the term "consumer goods" shall be defined as in section 9-109.1 of the Uniform Commercial Code, 810 ILCS 5/9-109. 
c.  Present in a concentration of less than one percent. For carcinogens, mutagens or teratogens, only those substances shall be exempt which are present in a concentration of 0.1 percent or less. No substance shall be exempt under this subsection which is present in concentrations exceeding threshold concentrations established by regulation of the state department of labor. 
(2)  Laboratories in which a toxic substance, compound or mixture regulated by this article is used by or under the direct supervision of a technically qualified individual, provided that the toxic substance or mixture is not produced in the laboratories for commercial sale. The department shall promulgate rules prescribing the standards used in determining whether a laboratory is under the direct supervision of a technically qualified individual. 
(3)  All retail trade establishments as listed in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Division G, Retail Trade, published by the U.S. Government Printing Office, except this article shall apply to those retail trade establishments listed within Major Groups: 52-Building Materials, Hardware, Garden Supply, and Mobile Home Dealers; and 55-Automotive Dealers and Gasoline Service Stations, except for those activities involving the retail sales of gasoline motor fuels or lubricants, or if the retail trade establishments are engaged in any of the following specific activities, this article shall apply only to the retail trade establishments' involvement in such specific activities: paint mixing, other than the tinting of consumer sized containers of paint; finishing or refinishing operations using paint or paint-related products; automobile battery servicing; photo finishing operations; and dry cleaning operations. 
(Code 1967, § 10-81) 
Chapter 54 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
