Sec. 86-98. - Records. 
    Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which records shall be, together with the articles themselves, open to inspection by any member of the police department at all reasonable hours. 
    A secondhand store doing business as a pawnbroker shall comply with the provisions set forth in chapter 86, "secondhand goods", article III, "pawnbrokers." 
(Code 1967, § 12-411; Ord. No. 12-26, § 3, 6-26-2012) 
Sec. 86-99. - Additional license required for pawnbrokers. 
    No person operating a secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker without first securing a pawnbroker's license in addition to a secondhand dealer's license. 
(Code 1967, § 12-412) 
Secs. 86-100-86-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SCAVENGERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 90. 

Sec. 86-126. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger or the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse or offal or scrap metal or plastic without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-711; Ord. No. 97-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-22-1997) 
Sec. 86-127. - Application for license. 
    Application for a license required by this article shall be made to the license officer. 
(Code 1967, § 12-712) 
Sec. 86-128. - Vehicles. 
    Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of refuse. 
(Code 1967, § 12-713) 
Sec. 86-129. - Permission required for disposal or storage of refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place within the city limits or within one mile thereof, without the permission of the city manager and city council. 
(Code 1967, § 12-715) 
Sec. 86-130. - Agreements to deliver multifamily waste. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized to enter into agreements, approved as to form by the city attorney and authorized for use by the city council through the adoption of a resolution, with licensed scavengers to provide for the delivery of waste generated from multifamily complexes and other system waste located within the corporate limits of the city to facilities operated by the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County, consistent with the city's obligations under the March 25, 1992 Project Use Agreement between the City of Rolling Meadows and the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County. The agreement shall specify the minimum amount of waste to be delivered by each multifamily complex in the city limits. 
(b)  As a condition of receiving a scavenger's license in the city, applicants must enter into agreements with the city, as provided in subsection (a) of this section to deliver all system waste, as defined in chapter 90, Solid waste to facilities operated by the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County, pursuant to the city's obligations under the March 25, 1992 Project Use Agreement between the City of Rolling Meadows and the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County. 
(Ord. No. 00-31, § 1, 7-25-2000) 
Chapter 90 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulation, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 50; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 66; scavengers, § 86-126 et seq.; utilities, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for collection and removal, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apartment house means a dwelling containing two or more dwelling units designed with more than one dwelling unit connecting to a common corridor or entranceway, originally constructed for such purpose, and not including converted dwellings or attached row dwellings (party wall type) and defined in this section. 
    Building means a structure enclosed within exterior walls, party walls or firewalls built, erected and framed of component structural parts; designed for the housing, shelter, enclosure and support of individuals, animals or property of any kind. When separated by firewalls or party walls or from the ground up and without openings, each portion of such building shall be deemed a separate building. 
    Construction material means all materials used for the construction, remodeling or repair of a building. Such materials include but are not limited to concrete, brick, plaster, tile, lumber, roofing materials, drywall, sawdust, paneling, exterior siding, windows and doors. Such materials are not considered garbage for purposes of this chapter. 
    Disposal contractor means any proper company providing garbage collection and disposal, by agreement, to occupied units in multifamily dwelling units. 
    Dwelling means a building or a portion thereof, but not including a house trailer or mobile home, designed or used exclusively for residential and multiple-family dwelling units, two-family dwelling units, but not including hotels, boardinghouses or lodginghouses. 
    Garbage means any rejected waste or food, offal, swill or carrion, manure, and every accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter discarded by the preparation, use, cooking, distribution or storage of meats, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables, and any other matter of any nature which is subject to decay, putrefaction and the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors or which, during or after decay, may serve as a breeding or feeding material for rodents, flies or other insects or animals. 
    Garbage container means as follows: 
(1)  Residential means, with the exception of certain multiple-family dwellings, a refuse sack for use on residential properties shall be 30 gallons in capacity, constructed of waterproof material, adhesive, and commonly known as "biodegradable kraft paper refuse bags," or a plastic bag not exceeding 30 gallons in capacity of sufficient construction and strength to avoid breakage during handling. 
(2)  Commercial means any garbage container designed for business or commercial use which may exceed 55 gallons in capacity. 
(3)  Recycling container means an upright top-loading container on wheels designed for automated collection which is owned by the city and supplied to all residences for the specific purpose of collection of recyclable materials. Recycling containers do not include the rectangular plastic container used previously for the purpose of collecting recyclable materials. 
The recyclable plastic bins previously used for recycling may be retained by residents for whatever other purpose they may desire or may be disposed of as a recyclable material. 
"Recycling containers" are further defined to include non-municipally owned containers which may be owned privately by residents provided they are similar in design to the city's containers and are capable of automated collection. Any such privately owned containers shall be maintained, repaired and replaced by the resident who purchases or owns the container. 
    Health officer means the duly appointed health officer of the city or his duly authorized representative. 
    Multiple-family dwelling unit means a structure containing three or more dwelling units designed with more than one dwelling unit connecting to a common corridor or entranceway, with each individual unit designed and intended for occupancy by one family for living purposes and having its own permanently installed cooking and sanitary facilities, including but not limited to apartment buildings and condominium and townhouse developments. 
    Occupied unit means a unit that is considered occupied in any month during which the owner thereof uses such unit as his primary residence or in which the unit is leased and a rental paid for a period not less than 21 days. 
    Owner means any person or group of persons who shall have legal or equitable title to property, or the agent of such person, lessee or the agent of a lessee or any person having care, management or control of property. 
    Owner, occupant or other person in a multiple-family dwelling means any individual, agent, employee, including corporations, associations of owners, occupants or individuals (e.g., condominiums or homeowner associations) contracting and responsible for the payment for garbage collection and disposal services for occupied units in multifamily dwelling units. 
    Person means owner, occupant, or lessee of any dwelling or any individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership or organization. 
    Recyclable material means any refuse, as may be designated from time to time by the director of public works, which is to be segregated from other refuse and collected by the city for recycling. 
    Refuse means waste, recyclable materials and garbage, as defined, or any other material item or thing which the owner wishes to throw away or discard. 
    Special pickup means the pickup and disposal by the city of any items other than garbage, as defined in this section, including but not limited to construction material or garbage, as defined in this section in a quantity other than normal, as described in sections 90-73 and 90-74. Such special pickup is made by the city for an extra charge to be determined in the sole discretion of the director of public works. 
    System waste means garbage and general household waste generated by single-family, attached and detached, and multifamily developments within the corporate limits of the city. System waste does not include institutional waste, commercial and office waste, industrial lunchroom waste, or construction and demolition waste. 
    Waste stream means all recyclable material, garbage, construction material, yard waste and refuse, as defined in this section. 
    Yard waste means grass clippings, leaves, twigs, small branches, garden debris, weeds, sod, fruit from trees or plants, seeds, stalks, vines, bark, wood chips, compost and manure. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-1), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 00-31, § 2, 7-25-2000; Ord. No. 08-09, § 1, 3-11-2008; Ord. No. 09-11, § 1, 3-10-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-2. - Violations and penalties. 
    If any person violates any section of this chapter or article V of chapter 50, the city shall have authority to issue a warning or P ticket with a penalty in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-27), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 97-53, § 2, 7-8-1997) 
Secs. 90-3-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ACCUMULATION, STORAGE, DISPOSAL AND OWNERSHIP OF REFUSE 

Sec. 90-31. - Disposal required. 
    The occupancy of any premises within the city shall be prima facie evidence that refuse is being generated and accumulated on such premises. All refuse shall be called for and disposed of by the city's refuse department or by a disposal firm or contractor duly licensed by the city, except that building or other construction contractors may remove construction, remodeling and demolition debris; tree trunks; bushes; and shrubs. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-2), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-32. - Accumulation prohibited. 
    Accumulation of refuse on any premises within the city shall be prohibited, except that refuse being stored until the next pickup shall be enclosed in covered waste containers or sacks. The waste so stored shall be removed from the premises on the next pickup. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-3), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-33. - Failure to dispose. 
    If refuse accumulates on any premises within the city, in violation of this chapter, the city's health officer, any member of the police department, the director of public works, any member of the department of public works, or any inspector from the building department designated by the director shall post a notice on the property that, if the refuse accumulated in violation of this chapter is not removed within 24 hours of the time of the notice, which must be set forth on the notice, the city shall cause removal of the refuse from the premises. The reasonable cost of such removal shall become a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens, provided that within 60 days after such cost is incurred, the city or the entity performing the service by authority of the city, in his own name, records a notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county or in the office of the registrar of titles if the affected real estate is registered in the torrens office. Such remedy is in addition to all other actions by the city set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-4), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-34. - Disposal on city property. 
    Except as set forth in this chapter, it is unlawful to dispose of or place any refuse or yard waste material in any public place in the city or on any public way or publicly owned land, except refuse properly contained, placed on the public parkway, in containers, as provided in this chapter, awaiting pickup. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-5), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-35. - Burning, dumping or scattering. 
    No refuse shall be burned, dumped, scattered or buried within the city limits, either on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-6), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-36. - Refuse containers required. 
    Every person in possession of any premises in the city shall provide for and shall at all times maintain in clean and good repair a sufficient number of refuse containers for a weekly accumulation of normal refuse. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-7), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-37. - Use of containers. 
    Every customer in possession of any premises shall cause to be deposited in refuse containers all refuse produced in or on such premises as soon as practicable after the refuse is produced. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-8), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-38. - Commercial refuse containers. 
(a)  Waste from all premises other than residential and refuse containers not mounted on wheels shall be stored on durable racks, above ground level, which shall be, in turn, placed on an easily cleaned and impervious surface. 
(b)  Such racks shall raise the waste and/or garbage containers at least two inches above the surface on which the racks are placed to provide a suitable cleaning area. 
(c)  Containers mounted on wheels shall be specifically designed for use with collection vehicles. 
(d)  The base of each container must also be elevated a distance of at least six inches from the storage surface, and the storage surface must be impervious and easily cleaned. 
(e)  Compactor box and refuse containers which are mechanically raised or dumped are also permitted for all premises other than residential. 
(f)  All containers in which refuse is stored shall have a lid which shall be kept closed and maintained in a clean condition. 
(g)  All dumpsters, drop boxes or other containers used for the storage and/or removal of refuse shall have the name and phone number of the owner/contractor plainly displayed on the container. 
(h)  Collection of refuse prior to 6:00 a.m. is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-9), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 08-09, § 4, 3-11-2008; Ord. No. 09-11, § 2, 3-10-2009) 
Sec. 90-39. - Containers. 
(a)  All refuse containers shall be as defined in this chapter, and no other type of container shall be acceptable. 
(b)  Dirty, leaking or defective containers shall be cleaned, repaired or replaced by the person in possession of the premises, at his expense, as directed in writing by the city's health officer, police department or public works director. 
(c)  Containers in violation of this chapter must be replaced, cleaned and repaired after such notice, within 48 hours of the notice, and failure to do so shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-10), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-40. - Inspection of containers. 
    All refuse containers and/or dumpsters, whether owned by the city, an individual, or private refuse hauler, shall be subject to inspection by the city health officer, the city police department, the director of public works, or any personnel of the public works department designated, in writing, by the director. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-11), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-41. - Waste stream ownership. 
    The entire waste stream within the city boundaries shall be the property of the city, including waste originating in the city, picked up by contract haulers. It shall be unlawful for anyone other than the original owner of the refuse who placed it for pickup, the city's refuse workers, or a properly licensed contracted waste hauler, to remove any article from the waste stream without permission of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-13), 5-27-1997) 
Secs. 90-42-90-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY REFUSE SERVICE 

Sec. 90-71. - Residential service available, conditions and premises excluded from service. 
(a)  Curb service pickup of refuse shall be provided to all residences of the city that: 
(1)  Individually handle, store and control their refuse. 
(2)  Individually place their refuse at the curb for pickup. 
(3)  Have a private area for the sanitary storage of refuse, such as a garage, utility room or screened yard. 
(b)  Residential structures that have common refuse handling, storage, or removal for more than one dwelling unit are specifically excluded from city refuse service as it relates to having said waste removed by city forces. Owners of multifamily residential properties are obligated to deliver system waste as designated by the city as provided by section 86-130 of the Code, and paying debt service costs that may be charged to the city by the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County. 
(c)  In addition to garbage pickup, the city will also pick up recyclable material and yard waste on a schedule to be established by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-14), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 00-31, § 3, 7-25-2000) 
Sec. 90-72. - Removal of certain refuse. 
    All refuse from preparation, cooking and use of foods; tin cans; glass; bottles; ashes; metalware; paper boxes; rags; excelsior and scrap will be picked up by the city. No construction material or concrete, bricks, tile, dirt, other earthy materials or trees will be removed by regular curb service. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-15), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-73. - Construction material. 
    Construction material will be picked up by the city on a fee basis only as determined by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-16), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-74. - Regulations. 
    The following regulations shall govern city refuse service: 
(1)  Only paper bags, plastic bags, or biodegradable 30 gallon paper bags may be used for disposal of refuse at curbside. Only 30 gallon biodegradable Kraft paper bags designated for yard waste collection may be used for disposal of yard waste at curbside. All paper or plastic bags used for refuse shall not exceed 30 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in weight when full. All bags must be of sufficient strength and construction to avoid breakage during handling. 
(2)  All paper sacks shall be properly folded, and plastic bags shall be tied and securely closed in order to prevent entrance of insects and rodents. 
(3)  No open bags shall be placed for collection. 
(4)  All carpeting or padding must be cut to lengths of no more than six feet and rolled and tied securely. 
(5)  Cardboard boxes placed outside the refuse sack at the curb must be flattened, bundled and tied securely. 
(6)  Any items with doors which latch, such as refrigerators, must have doors removed when put at the curb. 
(7)  An item over four feet in length or other than a normal household item, including but not limited to, such as automotive parts, gutters, downspouts, garage doors, swing sets, windows, shall require a special pickup. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of every person in possession of a premises within the city to cause all refuse produced on the premises to be thoroughly drained of all surplus liquid and placed in the refuse sack as soon as practicable after the refuse is produced. 
(9)  From April 1 to October 31 refuse shall not be placed at the curb before 6:00 p.m. of the day before pickup and should be placed at the curb no later than 6:00 a.m. of the day of pickup. From November 1 to March 31 refuse shall not be placed at the curb earlier than 3:00 p.m. on the day preceding pickup. Refuse set out too late for collection shall be removed from curbside no later than 7:00 p.m. of the pickup day missed. 
(10)  Scrap wood must be cut into four-foot lengths, tied in bundles, and total bundles shall not exceed more than one cubic yard in capacity. Scrap wood in excess of one cubic yard will only be collected by the city as a special pickup. 
(11)  Dirt, concrete or materials used for construction, remodeling or repair of buildings will be picked up only as a special pickup. 
(12)  Branches (brush) placed for pickup by the yard waste truck must be no more than four feet in length and tied securely with twine, in bundles, not to exceed two feet in diameter. 
(13)  When the refuse/recycling collection day falls on an observed city holiday, the collection day will be moved to the following day, for the holiday week only. Each successive collection day after a holiday will also be moved to the following day. 
(14)  Curbside recycling collection will be once a week. From April 1 to October 31 recyclables are to be put in containers and placed at the curb no later than 6:00 a.m. on the day of pickup and no earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the day preceding pickup. From November 1 to March 31 recycling material may be placed at the curb no earlier than 3:00 p.m. on the day preceding pickup. All recycling containers shall be removed from the curbside by the end of the collection day. 
(15)  One recycling container will be supplied by the city to each single-family home and to designated multi-family homes to be determined by the city Council. Containers are the property of the city and shall remain with the dwelling unit. Any person removing the recycling container from the premises to which it was originally delivered will be billed by the city for such. Residents will be allowed one free replacement for a lost, stolen or damaged container. Additional containers will be provided to residences at cost. 
(16)  Yard waste is to be put in 30-gallon Kraft paper bags only. Bags must be rolled down, crimped, and not exceed 50 pounds in weight. All 30-gallon paper refuse sacks for yard waste pickup shall be clearly differentiated, marked with an "X" or other means to be clearly identified as yard waste, and separated, when placed at the curb, from household refuse. Any yard waste mixed with regular household garbage will not be picked up. Residents are responsible for all separation of yard waste and household garbage. Yard waste will be picked up by the refuse department with a separate truck. Larger branches will be picked up in accordance with the chipper program, as set forth in division 2 of article II of chapter 114 of this Code pertaining to vegetation collection service, or as a special collection fee. 
(17)  The director of public works may authorize backdoor refuse pickup for the elderly, ill and disabled if there is sufficient evidence to determine that there is an undue hardship for the resident to get the refuse to the curb for pickup. 
(18)  The city shall be divided into areas and assigned specific days of collection, which schedule may be changed from time to time by the director of public works. 
(19)  Recycling containers are to be cleaned and disinfected as often as necessary to maintain the containers in a clean condition. 
(20)  Recycling containers shall be maintained and repaired by the city. 
(21)  City-owned recycling containers shall be replaced by the city only once, in the event it is lost, damaged other than in its normal use or vandalized. Thereafter, the owner of the residence shall be required to pay for the city's cost of the container together with the city's cost for delivery. 
(22)  New residents of the city who request a larger or smaller recycling container shall receive the requested container at no cost to the resident. 
(23)  Any resident may purchase a second recycling cart from the city at the city's cost together with the city's cost to deliver the container. 
(24)  All refuse containers and bags, yard waste bags, and recycling containers stored outside shall be in a side or rear yard and screened so as not to be visible from any street. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-17), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 04-05, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 08-09, §§ 2, 3, 3-11-2008; Ord. No. 09-11, § 3, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. 12-35, § 1, 10-9-2012) 
Sec. 90-75. - Violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for refuse to be treated in any way contrary to the terms of this chapter. Each day that the unlawful treatment continues shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-18), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-76. - Rates for system waste. 
(a)  The city shall charge each owner, occupant, or lessee of a single-family residence eligible for city refuse service an amount in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as established by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B. 
(b)  The city shall charge each owner of multifamily properties in the city a share of debt service associated with the city's membership in and in accordance with obligations set forth in the March 25, 1992, project use agreement between the city of Rolling Meadows and the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County. The charge shall be on a per dwelling unit basis, and shall be in an amount set forth in the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as established by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B. 
(c)  The refuse charge shall be included in the city's billing to the eligible residence for water and sewer service, as defined in section 90-71 and shall be subject to the collection and penalty provisions provided for water and sewer charges. All monies received by the city in payment of the consolidated garbage, water and sewer bill shall be applied first toward the payment of the garbage bill, second to the sewer bill, and the balance to the water bill. 
(Ord. No. 97-25, § 1 (9-19), 4-8-1997; Ord. No. 97-34, § 2, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 97-53, § 2, 7-8-1997; Ord. No. 00-31, § 4, 7-25-2000; Ord. No. 09-11, § 4, 3-10-2009) 
Sec. 90-77. - Billing and collection of charges. 
(a)  Each residence shall be sent a bill for refuse disposal service monthly, which bill shall be due and payable on or before 20 days after its date. If any bill is paid after such period, there shall be added thereto a late charge of ten percent of the water bill. 
(b)  The refuse bill shall be consolidated with the water bill for each residence, and all monies received by the city in payment of the consolidated bill shall be applied first toward the payment of the refuse bill and the balance, if any, toward the payment of the sewer bill and water bill. 
(c)  Bills for refuse service shall be rendered on or about the first day of the month immediately following the expiration of the monthly period for which refuse service was provided. 
(d)  For a violation of any of the sections of this article or for the nonpayment of refuse bills for a period of 20 days and for refuse service accounts with a past due greater than $100.00, the director of public works shall discontinue refuse service. 
(e)  The city shall impose a refuse reinstatement fee of $50.00 for refuse billing accounts which are past due on their City of Rolling Meadows' Refuse Billing Accounts and the city has reinstated the refuse service. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-20), 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 13-24, § 1, 7-9-2013) 
Sec. 90-78. - Lien for delinquent charges. 
(a)  Charges for refuse service shall be a lien upon the premises. Whenever a bill for refuse service remains unpaid 30 days after it has become due, the director of public works shall direct the city attorney to file with the recorder of deeds of the county or the torrens office a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for the amount then due plus any and all charges for refuse service subsequent to the period covered by the then-due bill. 
(b)  If the person to whom refuse service has been provided is not the owner of the premises and the director of public works has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to the director of public works, whenever such bills remain unpaid for a period of 20 days after it has become due. 
(c)  The failure of the city to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid refuse bills as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid refuse charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the charges, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the refuse charges, after deducting costs, as for the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be a bill in equity in the name of the city. The city attorney is authorized to institute such proceedings in the name of the city and in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which a refuse bill has remained unpaid, a statement of lien claim has been filed, as set forth in this section, and a period of 30 days has elapsed since the filing. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-21), 5-27-1997) 
Sec. 90-79. - Hauling prohibited. 
    Except for a person hauling recyclable materials from his own residence to a recycling center, it shall be unlawful for any person to transport refuse through the city unless such refuse is being transported in a leakproof, compaction-type body commonly referred to as a "packer refuse body" or a vehicle licensed by the city. Such hauling equipment shall be cleaned at sufficient frequency to prevent nuisance and insect breeding and must be maintained in good condition and repair. 
(Ord. No. 97-34, § 2 (9-22), 5-27-1997) 
Chapter 94 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, accepting the dedication of, naming, establishing, locating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street, alley, public way or public park in the city saved from repeal, § 1-12(4); any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-12(8); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-12(9); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; library, ch. 62; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 66; peddlers, solicitors and canvassers, ch. 74; planning, ch. 78; right-of-way management, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 98; traffic and vehicles, ch. 106; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; vehicles for hire, ch. 118; zoning, ch. 122. 
State Law reference- Authority over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Obstructions prohibited. 
    Anyone obstructing any street or sidewalk without permission from the mayor, city council or chief of police shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and each day or part of a day such obstruction or encumbrance shall continue shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(Code 1967, § 17-1) 
Sec. 94-2. - Duty to remove obstructions on notice. 
(a)  Whenever the owner of any building, fence, or other obstruction, article, or other thing upon any street, sidewalk, alley or public ground in the city shall refuse or neglect to remove the building, fence, obstruction, article or thing after notice, or without notice, if the owner cannot be readily found for the purpose of such notice, the building, fence, obstruction, article or thing shall be deemed a nuisance, and it shall be lawful for public works department employees, as authorized by the public works director or designee, or any police officer to summarily remove or take down such, and the expense therefrom shall be recoverable from the owner in addition to any fine thereof. 
(b)  All mailboxes in the right-of-way shall be constructed in a manner which conforms to the city's standard for proper installation of curb-side mailboxes and all other provisions contained therein. Any mailbox which does not conform to the city's standard on the effective date of this amended section shall be allowed to remain in the right-of-way provided that if the nonconforming mailbox is substantially destroyed or removed, any replacement must meet the city's standards. 
(Code 1967, § 17-2; Ord. No. 98-09, § 43, 3-24-1998; Ord. No. 08-43, § 1, 11-25-2008) 
Sec. 94-3. - Legal defense for actions resulting from snow removal. 
    The city is authorized through the city attorney or its liability insurance carrier, if applicable, to provide legal defense for any person arising directly out of snow removal from a public street or sidewalk upon a determination by the city manager that the legal action arose from such removal. This authorization shall not apply to civil liability resulting from acts or omissions amounting to willful or wanton conduct in such snow or ice removal or from the removal of snow or ice from a private sidewalk, driveway or other portion of private property. 
(Code 1967, § 17-4) 
Sec. 94-4. - Snow obstruction of public street. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Plow, shovel, or otherwise remove snow from private property, and inclusive of privately serving driveways ("aprons") located within public rights-of-way or easement, by a motor vehicle or other apparatus such as a truck, backhoe, excavator or grader equipped with a snow plow or other device designed to plow or remove snow or ice and to deposit the removed snow or ice: 
a.  On that portion of a public right-of-way which is paved and used or designed for use by motor vehicles ("public street") in such a manner so as to obstruct or decrease the drivable width of any public street; or 
b.  In such a manner so as to obstruct or decrease the width of any public sidewalk or bike path. 
(2)  Deposit snow or ice on designated handicapped parking spaces located on private or public property. 
(3)  Obstruct, harass, prevent, or otherwise interfere with any employee of the city engaged in snow removal operations or to obstruct, cause damage to, or otherwise interfere with any city vehicle used in snow removal operations. 
(4)  The director of public works, or his designated representative, is authorized, in addition to other persons having enforcement powers pursuant to state law of local ordinance, to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-03, § 1, 2-22-2000; Ord. No. 15-66, § 1, 12-22-2015) 
Secs. 94-5-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 94-31. - Permit required. 
    No excavation or trench shall be made in any street, avenue, alley or public ground in the city for any sewer, drain, water, gas, steam or heating pipe or for any other purpose not otherwise provided for without a permit issued by the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 17-12) 
Sec. 94-32. - Permit fee. 
    For all permits required under this article the fee shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 17-13; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 94-33. - Bond required; amount, conditions. 
    Permits to make excavations or trenches shall be issued by the public works department, for utility companies, or the building department, for all others, only to such persons or entities as have executed a franchise agreement with the city or delivered to the city a bond with sureties to be approved by the community development director and a cash deposit as provided in the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties in appendix B of this Code. Such bond shall be in the penal sum as provided in the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties in appendix B of this Code and shall indemnify and save harmless the city from any liability on account of accident or damage caused by making any excavation or trench in any street, avenue or alley or public place of the city and to provide for the replacing of the ground removed in making such excavation or trench in any unimproved street in as good condition as it was before being removed for the space of 12 months thereafter and to provide that the person so opening any unimproved alley, avenue or public ground, if it settles, shall replace it in such manner as may be directed. 
(Code 1967, § 17-14; Ord. No. 98-09, § 44, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 94-34. - Notice of refilling and repairing; duty of city. 
    When any trench or excavation is ready to be refilled or repaired, the applicant shall notify the city department that issued the permit to allow for an inspection of the prefill conditions and the refill work itself. The city departments shall establish at the time the permit is issued the amount of time the applicant must contact the appropriate official prior to commencing refill work. It shall then be the duty of the applicant to refill and repair such street. Such repairs shall be made in good and workmanlike manner and to the satisfaction of the city engineer. If the applicant fails to properly refill and repair the excavation, the public works director or the community development director may authorize the completion of the work and recover such costs through the applicant's cash deposit, the surety bond or by legal action. 
(Code 1967, § 17-16; Ord. No. 98-09, § 45, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 94-35. - Protection of openings. 
    All openings made by any applicant or his agent in any improved street under this article shall be protected at his risk until the work passes inspection from the appropriate official of the city department that issued the permit. The applicant is responsible for following the United States Occupational Health and Safety Act regulations pertaining to excavated spaces, that may be in effect at the time of issuance of the permit, at all times. 
(Code 1967, § 17-17; Ord. No. 98-09, § 46, 3-24-1998) 
Chapter 98 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city saved from repeal, § 1-12(10); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 66; planning, ch. 78; right-of-way management, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 110; vegetation, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 122. 
State Law reference- Plat Act, 765 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be referred to officially as "The Subdivision Regulations of the City of Rolling Meadows, Illinois." 
(Code 1967, § 18-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a narrow public way within a block generally giving access to the rear of lots or buildings and upon which service entrances of buildings abut and which is not generally used as a thoroughfare by pedestrians and vehicles or which is not used for general traffic circulation or which is not less than 30 feet in right-of-way width or which is not in excess of 40 feet in right-of-way width at its intersection with a street. 
    Approved means as acceptable to the city engineer. 
    Bicycle path or bikeway means a pathway usually separated from the roadway, designed specifically to satisfy the physical requirements of bicycling. 
    Buffer planting strip means a strip of land planted with trees and landscaping plants for the purpose of screening one use from another. 
    Building line means a line within a lot or other parcel of land, so designated on the plat of the proposed subdivision, between which and any street line upon which the lot abuts the erection of a building is prohibited. 
    City engineer means such person or firm as may be designated by the city manager to serve as the city's engineering representative. 
    Conditional approval means an approval, with or without recommended alterations, given to a preliminary plat by the planning and zoning commission and providing the necessary authority to proceed with the preparation and presentation of the final plat. 
    Cul-de-sac means a short street having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the general public, a corporation, or a certain person for a specific purpose. 
    Final plat means the drawings and documents described in division 3 of article III of this chapter. 
    Improvement means any manmade, immovable item which becomes part of, placed upon or is affixed to, real estate including grading, but not including buildings. Public improvements are considered an improvement. 
    Improvement, public means any sanitary sewer, storm sewer, drainage ditch, water main, roadway, parkway strip, sidewalk, buffer planting strip, pedestrian easement, off-street parking areas, or other facility for which the city may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation. 
    Intersection, street means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines or, if none, the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two streets which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining at any other angle may come in conflict. Where a street includes two roadways, 30 feet or more apart, every crossing of each roadway of such divided street by an intersecting street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. If such intersecting street also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, every crossing of two roadways of such streets shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Limited access highway means a trafficway, including expressways and toll roads for through traffic, in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting property or lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from, except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such trafficway. 
    Lot means a parcel of land in a subdivision separated from other parcels or portions by virtue of a plat of subdivision recorded with the appropriate county office and identifiable by reference to such plat of subdivision and not dependent for such identification by metes and bounds. 
    Major street plan means a part of the official plan showing the location and dimensions of principal thoroughfares. 
    Official map means the official map and standards ordinance of the city which is used to regulate the use of private property. It is an expression of public commitment for certain public improvements based on the official plan. 
    Official plan means the comprehensive plan or any portion thereof made and adopted by the planning and zoning commission in accordance with the laws of the state and the city ordinances indicating the general or specific locations recommended for streets, parks, public buildings, zoning districts and all other public improvements. 
    Owner may mean either a natural person, firm, association, partnership, private corporation, public or quasipublic corporation, or combination of any of them. 
    Parkway strip means a strip of land between the roadway and the sidewalk or sidewalk site. 
    Pedestrian easement means a public right-of-way, ten feet or more in width between property lines, to be used by pedestrians. 
    Planning and zoning commission means the city planning and zoning commission. 
    Planned development means a tract of land which is developed as a single unit under single ownership or control pursuant to the requirements of article IV of chapter 122 of this Code. 
    Plat means a map, drawing, or chart on which the subdivider's plans of the subdivision are presented and which he submits for approval and intends to record in final form. 
    Preliminary plan means the drawings and documents described in division 3 of article III of this chapter. 
    Preliminary plat means the drawings and documents described in division 3 of article III of this chapter. 
    Roadway or road means that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. Wherever the word "road" or "roadway" is used in this chapter, it shall be deemed to be the paved area existing on the street right-of-way and shall not be deemed the street right-of-way width. 
    Sidewalk means the portion of a street or pedestrian easement, paved or otherwise surfaced, intended for pedestrian use only. 
    Street means an area between property lines which primarily serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and pedestrian access to abutting lands or to other streets. The word "street" refers to the width of the street right-of-way or easement, whether public or private, and shall not be considered as the width of the roadway or paving or other improvement on the street right-of-way. 
    Street, collector means a street which is used to carry traffic from minor streets to major streets. 
    Street, major means a street designed to serve as a thoroughfare traffic artery and as shown on the official plan of the city. 
    Street, marginal access (frontage road) means a minor street which is parallel and adjacent to major streets and limited access highways and which provides access to abutting properties and protection to local traffic from fast, through-moving traffic on the major streets and limited access highways. 
    Street, minor means a street intended primarily as access to abutting properties. 
    Street, private means any street not dedicated to public use. 
    Subdivider means any person dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as defined in this section. 
    Subdivision means the division of land into two or more parts, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of the transfer of ownership of land or buildings or for building development, including all tracts, parcels, lots, blocks, public streets, alleys, ways for public service facilities, parks, playgrounds, school grounds or other public grounds. Included shall be the dedication or establishment of any new public or private street. Also included is a planned development whether such planned development is divided into parcels for separate sale or is developed on a leased basis. Also included is the consolidation or combining of two or more lots or parcels for the purpose of creating a larger lot or parcel. The following shall not be considered a subdivision and shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter: 
(1)  The division of land into parcels or tracts of five acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
(2)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining and contiguous land, where such sale or exchange does not create additional lots. 
(3)  The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
(4)  The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
(5)  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use. 
(6)  Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances. 
(7)  The division of lots or blocks of less than one acre in any recorded subdivision which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
(8)  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the division into no more than two parts of a particular parcel or tract of land existing on July 17, 1959, and not involving any new streets or easements of access. 
(9)  The sale of a single lot of less than five acres from a larger tract when a survey is made by a registered surveyor, provided that this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from the same larger tract of land, as determined by the dimensions and configuration of the larger tract on October 1, 1973, and provided, also, that this exemption does not invalidate any local requirements applicable to the subdivision of land. 
(Code 1967, § 18-18; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 1-4, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 04-28, § 1, 6-8-2004; Ord. No. 17-19, § 2, 6-13-2017) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-3. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  As used in this chapter, the word "lot" shall include the words "plot," "piece," and "parcel." 
(b)  The word "person" includes a firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company, or corporation as well as an individual. 
(Code 1967, § 18-17) 
Sec. 98-4. - Intent and purpose. 
    This chapter is adopted to: 
(1)  Ensure sound, harmonious subdivision development and community growth which will become a permanent asset by establishing minimum standards for design and construction. 
(2)  Ensure the development of land for the highest possible use with all the necessary protection against deterioration and obsolescence which would adversely affect the living environment or tax base. 
(3)  Provide common grounds of understanding and a sound working relationship between the city and the developer and to safeguard the interests of the homeowner, the subdivider, the investor and the city. 
(4)  Prevent scattered platting of lots beyond the existing public utilities and improvements. 
(5)  Cause the cost of design and installation of improvements in new, platted subdivisions to be borne by the persons purchasing the lots, rather than by any direct or indirect burden upon the existing property owners beyond the limits of the subdivision who have already paid for the improvements servicing their property. 
(6)  Bring about compact development of both the homes and the public improvements without the delay often experienced through future use of special assessment methods. 
(7)  Bring about the indirect effect of having dwellings erected on lots soon after the time of platting due to the investment of the developer in the public utilities and street facilities or within a short period of time thereafter as a result of posting of bond. 
(8)  Coordinate new subdivision design with the design of the city as a whole to allow for the proper capacity of all types of improvements on the basis of an orderly sequence of subdivisions as a part of neighborhoods and neighborhoods as a part of the community. 
(9)  Secure the rights of the public with respect to public lands and waters. 
(10)  Improve land records by establishing standards for surveys and plats. 
(11)  Ensure compatibility and uniformity of lots within established subdivisions. 
(Code 1967, § 18-2; Ord. No. 04-28, § 2, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 98-5. - Geographic jurisdiction. 
(a)  This chapter shall be applicable to all subdivisions and resubdivisions of unimproved land and areas subject to redevelopment within the corporate limits and contiguous unincorporated territory not more than 11/2 miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any other municipality. 
(b)  This chapter shall also apply to all planned developments, whether residential, commercial, or otherwise in nature, and to any other developments whether a subdivision is required or not under the law, statutes, ordinances or regulations of the governmental body or agency having jurisdiction or control, and regardless of whether such is labeled a subdivision or not, it being the intent of this chapter to apply to all types of development, both within the city and to areas lying within 11/2 miles of the corporate limits. 
(Code 1967, § 18-3) 
Sec. 98-6. - Scope. 
(a)  Whenever any subdivision of land shall be laid out, the subdivider thereof or his agent shall submit a preliminary and a final subdivision plat to the planning and zoning commission. Such plats and plans of proposed improvements and all procedures relating thereto shall in all respects be in full compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Until plats and plans for the subdivision are approved, properly signed and recorded: 
(1)  No land shall be subdivided nor shall any street be laid out nor shall any improvements be made to the natural land. 
(2)  No lot, tract, or parcel of land within any subdivision shall be offered for sale nor shall any sale, contract for sale or option be made or given. 
(3)  No improvements such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage, sanitary sewer facilities, gas service, electric service or lighting, grading, paving or surfacing of streets shall be made by any owner or his agent or by any public service corporation at the request of such owner or his agent. 
(c)  All lands offered to the city for use as streets, alleys, schools, parks, and other public uses shall be referred to the planning and zoning commission for review and recommendation before being accepted by the city council or by any other governing authority of the city. 
(d)  No plat will be approved for a subdivision which is subject to periodic flooding or which contains poor drainage facilities and which would make adequate drainage of the lots and streets impossible. However, if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which will, in the opinion of the city engineer, make the area safe for residential occupancy, and provide adequate lot and street drainage, the plat of the subdivision may be approved. See subsection 98-132(a)(14). 
(e)  In all subdivisions due regard shall be given to the preservation of historical sites and natural features such as large trees, watercourses and scenic views. 
(f)  For preliminary plats for parts of tracts, where it appears necessary to the planning and zoning commission for the satisfactory overall development of an area, an owner may be required to prepare at least a street plan of his entire tract based upon proper topographic surveys before approval of any portion of such plan. 
(g)  Whenever an area is subdivided into lots of 40,000 square feet or more which may at a later date be resubdivided, consideration shall be given to the street and lot arrangement of the original subdivision so that additional minor streets can be located which will permit a logical arrangement of smaller lots. 
(Code 1967, § 18-4; Ord. No. 17-19, § 3, 22, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 98-7. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the sections of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements. 
(b)  Where the conditions imposed by any section of this chapter upon the use of land are either more restrictive or less restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other section of this chapter or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(c)  This chapter is not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement, provided that where the regulations of this chapter are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than such easements, covenants, or other private agreements, the requirements of this chapter shall govern. 
(Code 1967, § 18-5) 
Sec. 98-8. - Applicability. 
    The rules and definitions contained in this article shall be observed and applied in the interpretation of all other articles of this chapter, except when the context indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1967, § 18-16) 
Secs. 98-9-98-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 98-36. - Administering and enforcing officers. 
    This chapter shall be administered by the planning and zoning commission acting in lieu of the city council except as specifically provided in this chapter. The public works director or his designee is designated and authorized to enforce of this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 18-125; Ord. No. 17-19, § 4, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 98-37. - Community development director to maintain specifications. 
    The community development director shall maintain sets of specifications available for public sale at all times as a guide in preparing project specifications pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1967, § 18-126; Ord. No. 00-14, § 5, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-38. - Criteria for issuance of building permits. 
    No building permit shall be issued providing for the improvement of a lot or parcel regulated by this chapter until the plat of subdivision is approved by the city council and the plans and specifications have been approved by the community development director and the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 18-127; Ord. No. 00-14, § 6, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-39. - Occupancy permits. 
    No certificate of occupancy permit shall be granted by any governing official for the use of any structure within any subdivision approved for platting or replatting until required utility facilities have been installed and made ready to service the property and until roadways providing access to the subject lot have been constructed. 
(Code 1967, § 18-128) 
Sec. 98-40. - Variations and exceptions. 
(a)  When the subdivider can show that a section of this chapter, if strictly adhered to, would cause unnecessary hardship and when, in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, because of topographical or other conditions peculiar to the site a departure may be made without destroying the intent of such section, the planning and zoning commission may recommend a variance or modification to the city council. The subdivider shall apply in writing for such variance or modification of the action. Any variance or modification thus authorized shall be attached to and made a part of the final plat. 
(b)  Planned development and resubdivision of a single lot of a platted block of an old subdivision shall be considered as an exceptional condition meriting departure from the strict letter of this chapter. No variation or exception shall be made that will be detrimental to the public welfare or that will affect adversely the official plan. 
(Code 1967, § 18-129; Ord. No. 17-19, § 5, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 98-41. - Appeals. 
(a)  Procedure. Any party aggrieved by a decision of the city engineer, public works director or his designee or planning and zoning commission may, within 45 days thereafter, appeal therefrom to the city council, and he shall file with the commission a written notice of appeal specifying the decision from which such appeal is taken. 
(b)  Transcript of proceedings. Upon receiving notice of appeal, the planning and zoning commission shall transmit to the city council a certified copy of the proceedings in the case upon which the appeal is taken. 
(Code 1967, § 18-130; Ord. No. 17-19, § 6, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 98-42. - Forms. 
(a)  Survey certification. For the purpose of this chapter the survey certification shall be in the following form:
