ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 98-196-98-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL 

Sec. 98-226. - Initial steps and detailed engineering plans. 
(a)  Required plans and specifications. Prior to the time of approval of the final plat of subdivision by the community development director and city engineer, final working drawings and specifications for improvements shall be submitted to the community development director in a prescribed number and format. The community development director may require funds to be deposited in escrow sufficient to cover the estimated review expenses and such funds shall be forfeited to the city should the subdivider fail to pay the review fees. 
(1)  Detailed drawings of the required improvements listed in division 3 of this article including a cover sheet, grading plan with one foot contour intervals, roadway improvement (plan and profile), roadway cross sections, utility improvements (plan and profile), street lighting plan (if applicable), summary of quantities, standard details and other such specialty information as may be required by the city engineer. 
(2)  Plans and profiles drawn at a scale not to exceed one inch equals 100 feet horizontally and one inch to ten feet vertically indicating horizontal and vertical location of streets, sewers, appurtenances, and the existing grade. 
(3)  Detailed material and construction specifications with cost estimates concerning the work to be performed including general conditions of the contract acceptable by the city. 
All engineering plans shall be submitted on 24 inch by 36 inch sheets and shall bear the signature and seal of the state-registered professional engineer under whose directions they were prepared. 
(b)  Submission. Upon receipt of the final plans, the community development director shall cause their review by the city engineer and director of public works to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter. The city engineer may, at his discretion, confer with the design engineer concerning correction or clarification of the final plans. In addition to the paper copies of final plans, the subdivider shall submit final approved plans on an electronic file media prescribed by the community development director. 
(c)  Permission to proceed required. Specific permission of the community development director, via permit, shall be secured before commencement of construction of any improvement. No substantial deviations from the approved plans and specifications will be allowed without the written permission of the city engineer. Field changes may be allowed by the city engineer. The subdivider shall also secure any permission or permits required by law of state; county or other applicable governmental officials and permission extended by the city council shall not relieve the subdivider of responsibility to secure such other approvals. If the subdivider elects to construct an improvement prior to approval of the final plat, the city council may extend permission to proceed upon recommendation of the city engineer and community development director together with certification by the community development director that working drawings and specifications have been approved and that engineering fees have been paid and that the inspection bond and performance guarantees have been posted. 
(d)  Qualification of contractors. The developer shall make available to the community development director a list of all contractors and subcontractors who are to participate in construction of public improvements. Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to the appropriate licensing provisions of this Code and shall be subject to disqualification because of faulty performance upon past construction work done in the city. 
(e)  Notification and required inspections. The subdivider or his contractor shall notify the community development department at least 48 hours in advance of initial work on an improvement and shall schedule required inspections at least 24 hours in advance of the inspection. Required inspections include, but are not necessarily limited to the following: proof roll of street subgrade, underground utility installation, placing of concrete and laying of bituminous concrete pavement courses. 
(Code 1967, § 18-72; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 29-31, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-227. - Guarantee of completion and maintenance. 
    The final plat of subdivision shall not be recorded until the subdivider has completed all required public improvements or guarantee the completion of all required improvements and has guaranteed to maintain the improvement for a period of one year following satisfactory installation of the improvement. This guarantee shall be by either one or a combination of the following methods; only one method shall be applied to a specific improvement: 
(1)  Surety bond. The subdivider may post a surety bond or other security as provided by this article or as authorized by state statute in a form approved by the city attorney. The amount of the bond or other security shall be not less than 115 percent of the final estimate of cost of the improvement, as estimated by the city engineer under section 98-229. There shall be no reduction in the amount of that portion of the bond applying to a particular improvement unless and until that improvement is complete and accepted or approved by the city engineer and the community development director. Each such bond is deemed to contain the following provisions, whether such provisions are inserted in such bond or not: 
The principal and sureties on this bond agree that all the undertakings, covenants, terms, conditions and agreements of the contract or contracts entered into between the principal and the city will be performed and fulfilled, and to pay all persons, firms and corporations having contracts with the principal or with subcontractors, all just claims due them under the provisions of such contracts for labor performed or materials furnished in the performance of the contract on account of which this bond is given, if such claims are not satisfied out of the contract price of the contract on account of which this bond is given, after final settlement between the city and the principal has been made. 
(2)  Irrevocable letter of credit. The subdivider may post an irrevocable letter of credit in a form approved by the city attorney. The amount of the letter of credit shall be not less than 115 percent of the final estimate of cost of the improvement as estimated by the city engineer under section 98-229. Reductions in the amount of a letter of credit shall only be by approval of the city attorney conditioned upon the following: 
a.  The installation of an improvement or improvements for which a reduction is requested must be approved by the city engineer and community development director. 
b.  For full improvement installation the amount of the reduction shall not exceed 85 percent of the guarantee's value assigned to that improvement. 
c.  For partial improvement installation the amount of the reduction shall not exceed 75 percent of the guarantee value assigned to the installed improvement. A partial reduction request may be rejected if it is determined by the city engineer that damage or unreasonable wear will result to the improvement or other improvements as a result of the partial completion. 
(3)  Cash bond. The subdivider may deposit a cash bond with the city in accordance with a specific escrow agreement approved by the city attorney and community development director and in an amount not less than 115 percent of the final estimate of cost of the improvements as estimated by the city engineer under section 98-229. The deposit shall be held in a special account by the city, and the agreement may provide for partial payouts as work progresses in amounts recommended by the city engineer and approved by the community development director as corresponding to the original estimate of unit costs. Partial payouts shall be contingent upon favorable inspection reports, and the sum of partial payouts for a single improvement shall not exceed 85 percent of the original deposit for the improvement until and unless the improvement is complete and accepted or approved by the city council. 
(4)  Cash deposit. The subdivider shall deposit cash with the city to guarantee the repair, correction or replacement of any improvement not properly completed or destroyed or damaged after installation and prior to acceptance of the subdivision improvements by the city proposed in section 98-228. The cash deposit shall pertain to the following but is not limited thereto: cleanup; buffalo box repair or adjustment to proper level; sidewalk, curb or street damage repair; tree plantings and water, sanitary sewer and storm sewer extension. The cash deposit required by this subsection is as follows: (i) $50.00 per lot for a single-family dwelling, (ii) $20.00 per unit for a multifamily dwelling, (iii) $50.00 per acre for commercial and industrial property. The maximum cash deposit for each classification shall be $5,000.00. The cash deposit shall be held in a special account by the city. After the area is complete, the city engineer shall present the subdivider with a written list of necessary repairs and corrections. If this work is not done within 30 days of notice by the city engineer to the subdivider, the city will make the correction and repairs and the cost thereof will be deducted from the cash deposit. 
(5)  Alternate improvement method. The subdivider may, for subdivisions of not to exceed ten acres for residential subdivisions and not to exceed 20 acres for industrial subdivisions that are contiguous and adjacent to a previously improved subdivision, provide the following materials as proof of intent to install and maintain required improvements: 
a.  Proof of ownership of the land to be subdivided, approved by the city attorney. 
b.  A photographic copy of the contract between the subdivider and his subcontractors in which the city is named as the beneficiary of the public improvements, as specified, plus the requirements of subsection (5)f. of this section. 
c.  A letter of guarantee from the owner of the subject land to the subcontractors of the subdivider that the owner will pay for all public improvements of the entire subdivision if the subdivider defaults. 
d.  A letter from the owner and the subdivider of the subject land guaranteeing maintenance of the properly completed public improvements for the period of one year from the date of completion thereof. 
e.  A performance bond, letter of credit or other security from the subcontractor or contractor installing the public improvements, subject to the approval of the city attorney. 
f.  The contract between the subdivider and his subcontractors shall provide that the subcontractors shall maintain the public improvements for one year from the date of completion, as provided in this section, and that the subcontractors shall provide a maintenance bond for that period equal to 100 percent of the value of the improvements, or the subdivider shall turn over to the city a sum equal to 15 percent of the total value of the improvements to be used by the city for maintenance or paid to the subcontractors if, on certification of the city engineer, the improvements have been properly maintained for one year by the subcontractors. 
(6)  Project completion. The city shall refund a cash bond to the subdivider or release the irrevocable letter of credit or surety bond within 60 days after the subdivider notifies the city in writing of the completion of the project improvements for which the security was required. For this purpose, "completion" means that the city has determined that the project improvement for which the security was required is complete or a licensed engineer or licensed architect has certified to the subdivider and the city that the project improvement has been completed in compliance with the applicable codes and ordinances of the city. The city shall pay interest to the subdivider, beginning 60 days after the subdivider notifies the city in writing of the completion of the project improvement, on any security not refunded to the subdivider, at the rate of one percent per month. 
(Code 1967, § 18-73; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 32-37, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 01-50, § 1, 12-18-2001) 
Sec. 98-228. - Inspection. 
(a)  Required. All improvements in a subdivision shall be subject to inspection by the city engineer both during the course of construction and after construction is complete. The city engineer shall have authority over materials of construction, methods of construction and workmanship to ensure compliance with work drawings and specifications. The contractor shall provide for reasonable field and laboratory tests and proof of quality of materials as requested by the city engineer. Upon due cause the city engineer may require that work be suspended, and due cause shall include weather conditions, questionable materials of construction, methods of construction, workmanship or nonadherence to specifications and drawings. Required inspections shall include but are not necessarily limited to the following: proof rolling of roadway, subgrade, underground utilities, placement of concrete, laying of bituminous concrete pavement, grading and street lighting. 
(b)  Inspection reports. The city engineer shall prepare and submit to the community development director each month a report stating the progress of the work and giving his findings as to quality and quantity of materials used and quality of methods and workmanship. He shall in particular call attention to any circumstances that entail departures from working drawings and specifications such as unforeseen difficulties of drainage, groundwater, poor subsoil, unstable fill material, unconventional or faulty practices of contractors or other circumstances. Whenever, in his opinion, such departures are likely to cause either a lower ultimate standard of performance or a higher construction cost than could reasonably be anticipated, he shall immediately notify the community development director. When an improvement has been completed he shall prepare a summary report. The summary report shall be dated, signed and one copy each prepared for the subdivider, community development director and the city council. 
(c)  Subdivider responsibility. Approval by the city engineer or absence of inspection shall in no way relieve the subdivider of full responsibility for adherence by his contractors to specifications and working drawings nor for high standard of materials, methods and workmanship. The subdivider shall be responsible for providing, at his expense, any third party inspection reports as requested by the city engineer. 
(d)  Approval not acceptance. Approval by the city engineer shall not be deemed acceptance of the public improvement by the city. Acceptance shall be only by action of the city manager, and acceptance shall be contingent upon a favorable inspection report. 
(Code 1967, § 18-74; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 38-41, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-229. - Fees. 
(a)  Engineering review and inspection fees. To offset the engineering and inspection expenses incurred by the city engineer for review of plans and specifications, final cost estimates, improvement installation, inspections and reporting, the subdivider shall pay fees in accordance with the fee schedule set forth in appendix B of this Code. 
(b)  Administrative and permit fees. To offset the administrative cost associated with administration of this chapter by the community development department, the subdivider shall pay fees in accordance with the fee schedule set forth in appendix B of this Code. 
(c)  Recapture fees. The subdivider shall pay any applicable recapture fees as required by ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 18-75; Ord. No. 00-14, § 42, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-230. - Maintenance and final acceptance. 
(a)  Subdivider's responsibility for maintenance of improvements. As further assurance of serviceable construction and to provide for repair of damage resulting from subsequent construction operations of the subdivider or his contractors, the subdivider shall be responsible for all maintenance of an improvement for a period of 12 months from the satisfactory completion of an entire improvement as determined by the city engineer or community development director. The guarantee of completion and maintenance shall recognize the possibility of maintenance costs, and the terms of the guarantee shall provide for reimbursement to the city for any maintenance expenses incurred by the city in performing maintenance work after failure of the subdivider to perform such work upon due notice. Sale of a parcel or lot does not relieve the subdivider of the responsibility to maintain the improvements adjacent to the lot in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Guarantee for maintenance of improvements. The contract between the subdivider and his subcontractors shall provide that the subcontractor shall maintain their installed improvement for a period of one year from the date of completion as determined by the city engineer. The subdivider shall provide a maintenance guarantee to the city in a form approved by the city attorney and equal to at least 15 percent of the improvement cost. Said guarantee shall be used by the city for maintenance failed to be performed by the subdivider of his contractor. 
(c)  Protection and repair of existing improvements. The subdivider, his contractors and suppliers shall be jointly and severally responsible that existing improvements and the property of the city are not damaged or rendered less useful or unsightly by the operations of the subdivider, his contractors or suppliers. This subsection is intended to include damage or nuisance with respect to the land, improvements or landscaping of the city; damage to existing streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter, parkways by passage thereover of equipment or trucks or by excavation for any purpose; the spillage or tracking of earth, sand or rock onto existing streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter or parkways; the washing by stormwater of earth or sand onto streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter or parkways or into catchbasins; damage to water mains, sanitary sewers, culverts or storm sewers. To reduce or localize the possibility of damage to streets by heavy trucking, the director of public works, with approval of the city engineer, shall instruct the subdivider as to the streets to be used for access to the subdivision by equipment and trucks, and the subdivider shall be responsible for enforcement of this instruction upon his contractors and their suppliers. The subdivider shall make provision to prevent damaging or washing of earth or sand onto sidewalks, streets, curb and gutter and into catchbasins by stormwater. When deemed advisable, the director of public works shall have the power to require, either prior to commencement of construction or after construction is in process, that the subdivider post surety to guarantee repair of damages or abatement of nuisances. Where need for surety becomes apparent after construction is in progress, the director of public works shall have the power to order construction discontinued until surety has been posted. Expenses incurred by the city in repairing damages and in cleaning streets, catchbasins and sewers shall be deducted from the surety. 
(d)  Acceptance. Acceptance of an improvement shall be by approval of the city manager upon recommendation of the city engineer and community development director. Acceptance of an improvement shall constitute release of the applicable portion of the performance bond or of the applicable portion of the balance of cash deposit. Recommendation shall be contingent upon the following: 
(1)  Fulfillment of the requirements of subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section. 
(2)  An opinion of the city attorney that satisfactory and proper conveyances have been made by the subdivider to the city. 
(3)  Improvement being complete and in good repair in accordance with city standards and requirements. 
(4)  Inspection reports, including but not limited to television inspection of all sanitary and storm sewers as required by sections 98-269 and 98-270, indicating compliance with working drawings and specifications. 
(5)  Submission of a set of improvement plans showing the "as built" condition. The submittal shall be on a reproducible mylar or vellum with four paper copies and must be sealed by an engineer or surveyor licensed in the State of Illinois and also be placed on an electronic media in DXF file format. The drawings shall include one foot contours, first floor elevations, all rim and invert elevations of all underground structures, actual pipe lengths, location of water and sanitary service lines and any field changes approved by the city engineer. 
(6)  Completion of a single improvement throughout the subdivision as indicated in the final plat and working drawings. A single improvement shall not be accepted in part. The subgrade, base course and surface course of a street, alley or parking area shall be considered as a single improvement. 
(e)  Effect of other regulations. None of the sections of this chapter pertaining to permission, surety, fees, acceptance and approval shall be construed as exempting subdividers, general contractors, subcontractors or any other contractor or craftsman from any other section of this Code or city ordinance or regulation with respect to licenses, fees, surety, inspection or other control. 
(Code 1967, § 18-76; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 43-46, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 03-46, § 2, 7-8-2003) 
Secs. 98-231-98-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 98-261. - Types required. 
(a)  All improvements listed in this section shall be provided in a subdivision, except the city council shall have the power to modify the number of the improvements depending upon the nature and scope of the subdivision. The design, layout and carrying capacities of streets, stormwater, sanitary sewer, and water facilities shall recognize the future requirements of adjacent undeveloped areas. The improvements required shall be as follows: 
(1)  Survey monuments. 
(2)  Street and alley construction. 
(3)  Driveways. 
(4)  Curb and gutter. 
(5)  Sidewalks and bicycle paths, within streets and pedestrian easements. 
(6)  Water mains and hydrants. 
(7)  Sanitary sewer facilities. 
(8)  Stormwater drainage facilities, including grade with rights-of-way and drainage easements. 
(9)  Street signs. 
(10)  Streetlights. 
(11)  Seeding of planting strips. 
(12)  Street trees. 
(b)  All improvements shall be in accordance with the city standards and requirements listed in this chapter or given in ordinances and regulations in effect at the time of submission of the final plat. 
(c)  Improvements shall include but are not necessarily limited to public improvements. 
(Code 1967, § 18-87; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 47, 48, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-262. - Monuments. 
(a)  Permanent monuments shall be placed at all street corners and at points of tangency of curve lines in the subdivision. Permanent monuments shall be of concrete with minimum dimensions of four inches by four inches at the top, six inches by six inches at the bottom, and 36 inches long, with a copper dowel three-eighths inch in diameter, at least 21/2 inches in length, imbedded so that the top of the dowel shall be flush with the surface and at the center of the monument. 
(b)  All lot corners not marked by concrete monuments shall be marked by galvanized or wrought iron pipe or iron or steel bars at least 18 inches in length and not less than one-half inch in diameter. The top of the pipe or bar is to be set two inches above the established grade of the ground. 
(c)  In addition a minimum of one permanent benchmark shall be established for each 20 acres or fraction thereof subdivided and at a location designated by the city engineer. This monument shall be of concrete with a minimum dimension of four inches by four inches at the top, six inches by six inches at the bottom, and 48 inches long, with a brass plate securely fastened to the surface. On the brass plate shall be inscribed the number and elevation of the benchmark. 
(Code 1967, § 18-88) 
Sec. 98-263. - Grading. 
(a)  Stormwater. Subdivision lots and blocks shall be so graded as to eliminate depressions that would accumulate stormwater. In addition, grading of all lots and streets shall be accomplished in such a manner as to prevent ponding in excess of eight inches if a complete failure of the storm sewer system occurs. Except in special cases, grading on all lots will be kept within the range of one percent and five percent. Grades at building sites shall bear such relationships to roadway and curb grades as to prevent flooding during heavy storms of basement windows, garages, or of entryways either to basements or to first floor levels in the absence of basements. Drainage easements will be provided when surface waters from more than one lot are conveyed down a property line. 
(b)  Streets. All surfaces to receive street or alley surfacing shall first be graded to the line as approved by the city engineer. All major street rights-of-way shall be graded to full width. Fill areas shall be built up in layers not exceeding six inches at one time and each layer thoroughly compacted by rolling with a self-propelled roller weighing not less than ten tons. 
(c)  Erosion control. All grading work shall be in conformance with article III of chapter 38 of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 18-89; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 49-51, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-264. - Street construction. 
(a)  All streets, public and private, shall be designed and constructed in conformance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction as adopted by said department on January 1, 1997, and as subsequently amended. Pavement widths and structures shall be as listed in the table found in section 98-162(m). 
(b)  Existing streets. The city engineer shall have the authority to require improvements of existing roadways serving the subdivision after having determined such improvement is necessary to accommodate the increased use of said street. 
(Code 1967, § 18-90; Ord. No. 00-14, § 52, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-265. - Driveway construction. 
    That portion of a driveway located upon a dedicated public right-of-way or easement for public road purpose shall be constructed in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Residential property. Driveways on residential property shall be constructed of either Portland Cement Concrete (350 PSI, minimum), six inches thick with two inches of aggregate base course or bituminous concrete surface course, IDOT Class I, two inches thick with six inches of aggregate base course. The minimum and maximum width of the driveway at the property line shall be ten feet and 20 feet respectively. The minimum and maximum width of the driveway at the back of curb shall be 14 feet and 24 feet, respectively. 
(2)  Commercial property. Commercial driveways shall be constructed of Portland Cement Concrete (3,500 PSI, minimum), seven inches thick with two inches aggregate base course or bituminous surface course, Class I, two inches thick with bituminous aggregate mixture (BAM) six inches thick with a two inches aggregate base course. Welded wire fabric shall be used in all Portland Cement Concrete aprons. The maximum width of the driveway at the property and curb line is 25 feet and 35 feet, respectively, unless the geometrics for additional driveway lanes require a greater width and then by specific approval of the city engineer. 
(3)  Industrial property. Industrial driveways shall be constructed of Portland Cement Concrete (3,500 PSI, minimum), eight inches thick with four inches aggregate base course or bituminous concrete surface course, Class I, two inches thick, with bituminous binder course two inches thick, with bituminous aggregate mixture (BAM) six inches thick with a four inches aggregate base course. Welded wire fabric shall be used in all Portland Cement Concrete aprons. The minimum and maximum width of the driveway at the property line and curb line is 35 feet and 45 feet, respectively, unless the geometrics for additional driveway lanes requires a greater width and then by specific approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1967, § 18-91; Ord. No. 00-14, § 53, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-266. - Curb and gutters. 
    Every street shall have curb and gutter built in accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, adopted January 1, 1997, and as subsequently amended. The shape of the curb and gutter shall be as stated in the table found in section 98-162(m). 
The minimum thickness of the road face of the gutter slab shall be nine inches. 
(Code 1967, § 18-92; Ord. No. 00-14, § 54, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-267. - Sidewalks and bicycle paths and bikeways. 
    Every subdivision shall have sidewalks and/or bicycle paths constructed in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be located on both sides of a public street and be constructed in conformance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction as adopted on January 1, 1997 and as subsequent amended. The minimum width of sidewalk shall be five feet, and the minimum thickness shall be five inches, except through driveways where it will be six inches thick. 
(2)  Separate bicycle paths and bicycle ways shall be required only if they have been specified as part of the adopted Master Bicycle Path Plan and such path may serve in lieu of a required sidewalk if approved by the city engineer. Bicycle paths shall be constructed in accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction as adopted on January 1, 1997 and as subsequently amended except that the minimum width shall be ten feet. 
(Code 1967, § 18-93; Ord. No. 00-14, § 55, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-268. - Sidewalks in pedestrian easements. 
    Sidewalks in pedestrian easements in a subdivision shall be placed where needed as determined by the planning and zoning commission. Materials used and methods of construction shall be the same as for sidewalks generally. 
(Code 1967, § 18-94; Ord. No. 17-19, § 17, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 98-269. - Water supply, fire hydrants, sanitary sewers. 
(a)  Required public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities shall be designed and constructed as approved by the city engineer and in accordance with all the applicable Illinois Environmental Protection Agency regulations and the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois (May 1996 Edition) as jointly published by the Illinois Municipal League, Illinois Association of General Contractors, Illinois Society of Professional Engineers and Illinois Underground Contractors Association except that the following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  Water mains shall comply with the following: 
a.  Must serve all lots and provide for reasonable expansion of the system. 
b.  Must be ductile iron pipe, cement lined, slip joint, centrifically cast, electrically conductive, manufactured in accordance with American Water Works Association Standard 151-65, minimum of class 52 and designed for the laying conditions and depths as shown on the approved development plans. 
c.  Must be a minimum of eight inches in diameter and have a minimum earth cover of six feet. Dead end mains shall not exceed 150 feet in length and must have a fire hydrant within ten feet of the end. 
d.  Valves are to open counterclockwise and, except for fire hydrant auxiliary valves and service valves under three inches, shall be enclosed in precast concrete valve vaults of a minimum diameter of four feet for valves greater than three inches but less than ten inches, and a minimum diameter of five feet six inches for valves ten inches and larger. Valve vaults shall have approved cast iron frames and lids and imprinted with the word "water." Valve spacing shall be as approved but in no case shall exceed 1,000 feet. 
e.  Water services shall extend from the main to a point at least eight feet beyond the outside curb lines of the proposed roadway pavement or sidewalk and be sized to meet the anticipated water usage of the property served, but in no case is it to be less than one and one-half inches in diameter type K Copper. Corporation stops, curb stops and curb stop valve boxes shall be of model and manufacturer stipulated by the department of public works and placed at locations as approved by the city engineer. Water service stub locations shall be marked with a wooden marker, two by four inches, six feet long, projecting two feet above ground with the top painted blue. 
f.  Fire hydrants shall be so located as to be within 250 feet of all homes and each other in single-family developments. In every commercial, manufacturing, governmental or multifamily developments, no portion of a building shall be further than 300 feet from a fire hydrant, as the hose lie, and not be further than 250 feet apart. Fire hydrants shall be of Waterous manufacture as approved by the city engineer and have auxiliary valves and boxes with a minimum valve opening of five inches. The hydrant shall have two and one-half inches and one four-inch fire department connections with threads compatible with those used by the fire department's equipment and hoses. 
g.  Newly installed water mains shall not be activated unless approved by the city engineer after required pressure testing, disinfection and lab analysis has been performed. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer mains shall comply with the following: 
a.  They must serve all lots and provide reasonable expansion of the system. 
b.  In addition to the aforementioned standard, it shall be designed and constructed in compliance with the rules and regulations of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
c.  The developer shall deposit with the city the sum as set forth in appendix B to this Code, to cover the cost of televising and cleaning the sanitary sewer by the city's public works department prior to final testing and approval by the city. The developer may be charged for additional television inspecting resulting from repairs performed following the first television inspection. 
d.  Sewer service stubs shall extend from the main to a point at least eight feet beyond the outside curbline of the proposed roadway pavement or sidewalk and be sized to meet the anticipated flow rates, but in no case shall it be less than six inches in diameter. The sewer stub end shall be plugged in an approved manner and the location marked by a wooden marker, two by four inches, six feet long, projecting two feet above ground with the top painted red. 
(b)  All lots and developments shall be served by public water and sewer facilities. If the public sewer is not within 300 feet of a development that has lot sizes exceeding one acre (43,560 square feet) the city council may, at its discretion, allow private sewage disposal systems to serve each lot provided they comply with the requirements found in chapter 18, Buildings and building regulations, of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 18-95; Ord. No. 00-14, § 56, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-270. - Storm sewer drainage facilities. 
(a)  Every subdivision planned development or zoning lot shall have a storm sewer system separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system, with an adequate outlet to the existing storm sewer system or connection with the existing natural drainage channels leading from the subdivision. The storm sewers and drainage channels shall be designed to accept and convey all stormwaters entering upon the subdivision. They shall be designed on the basis of rainstorms of ten years' frequency and shall be of such sizes as to adequately carry the runoff from all tributary areas at such time as they are developed to the density shown on the city's comprehensive plan. Inlets shall be provided at all low points and at all points where the design of intensity of flow reaches one cubic foot per second. Retention of stormwater in accordance with the requirements of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation (formerly "Sanitary") District and city engineer shall be required for all residential subdivisions exceeding five acres and for all other projects exceeding 2.5 acres or in special areas where the city engineer determines that the existing storm sewer system or natural drainageway does not have sufficient capacity to adequately handle the additional stormwater runoff. 
(b)  Storm sewers shall be designed and installed in accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction adopted January 1, 1997 and as subsequently amended. Manholes shall not be placed more than 300 feet apart. Catch basins and gutter inlets shall be located in the gutter line at suitable intervals so as to provide adequate surface drainage. Pipe connections and change of direction of piping shall be made at a structure unless otherwise approved by the city engineer. No stormwater detention facility shall have a release (outlet) pipe restrictor of less than four inches in diameter. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  When required by the city engineer, rear yard inlets shall be provided with catchbasin bottoms having a depth of at least two feet, and the outlet pipes shall be installed in such a manner as to preclude the entrance of floating matter into the storm sewer. Rear yard inlets shall be subject to the specifications provided by the city engineer. The minimum cover for storm sewers shall be three feet, unless specially approved precautions are taken to protect the pipe. Storm sewers shall be designed to flow full with a minimum velocity of three feet per second and a maximum velocity of ten feet per second. Stormwater detention storage in public parking lots, a maximum depth of six inches from the lowest measurable elevation is allowed. 
(e)  Tile drains constructed around the outer edges of buildings may be connected to a storm sewer system in a manner that will prevent backflow as approved by the city engineer or plumbing inspector. It shall be unlawful to connect the tile drains to a combined sewer system. 
(f)  Storm sewers and services of approved design and capacity with a minimum earth cover of four feet shall be provided to serve all lots and to provide for reasonable expansions of the system. Storm sewers shall be designed using the criteria of the city, the Metropolitan Sanitary District, and the state environmental protection agency. The developer shall deposit with the city the sum as set forth in appendix B to this Code, to cover the cost of televising and cleaning the storm sewer by the city's public works department prior to final testing and acceptance by the city. The developer may be charged for additional television inspecting if the storm sewer installation is in such a condition as to require additional inspection after repairs. 
(Code 1967, § 18-96; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 57-61, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 05-40, §§ 1-3, 10-11-2005) 
Sec. 98-271. - Street signs. 
    Street name, traffic control, and bicycle path signage shall be installed in an approved manner at the expense of the subdivider. Such signs shall conform to the Illinois Department of Transportation Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The developer may, at his option, contract the purchase and placement of signage with the department of public works. A subdivider or developer shall be responsible for preserving existing signage and, if they are damaged or removed as a result of development activity, their repair and replacement cost shall be borne by the developer. 
(Code 1967, § 18-97; Ord. No. 00-14, § 62, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-272. - Street lighting. 
    Street lights shall be installed in accordance with the standards and specifications on file with the community development department. Minimally, street lights shall be located at all intersections, at all ends of streets or culs-de-sac and at roadway curves as deemed necessary by the city engineer. Poles must have a fixture mounting height of 20 feet except for culs-de-sac which shall have a 15 foot mounting height. Luminaries shall be 150 watt high pressure sodium. The installation shall conform to the electrical code of the city. The electric utility company may be contracted for installation provided it is approved by the city engineer and community development director. 
(Code 1967, § 18-98; Ord. No. 00-14, § 63, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-273. - Landscaping. 
(a)  General. All developments, whether public or private, shall provide for the landscaping of parkways, parks, open space areas, areas to be dedicated to the public and other areas in accordance with this section and other Code sections of the city. 
(b)  Parkways shall be finished graded with a minimum of six inches of topsoil and seeded or sodded in an approved manner. 
(c)  Parkway trees shall be planted in conformance with the requirements contained in chapter 114 of this Code. Existing trees located entirely or partially upon the right-of-way shall be surveyed by the city forester to determine necessary trimming or removal. Such trimming or removal is the developer's responsibility until the trees are accepted by the city. Deciduous tree branches shall be no lower than eight feet above the ground. If approved by the city forester, evergreen trees may remain. 
(d)  Site protection shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Topsoil preservation. Topsoil moved during the course of construction shall be redistributed on all regarded surfaces so as to provide at least four inches of even cover to all disturbed areas of the development and shall be stabilized by seeding or planting. 
(2)  Removal of debris. All stumps and other tree parts, litter, brush, weeds, excess or scrap building materials or other debris shall be removed from the site and disposed of in accordance with the law. No tree stumps, or portion of tree trunks or limbs shall be buried anywhere in the development. All dead or dying trees, standing or fallen, shall be removed from the site. If trees and limbs are reduced to chips, they may be used as mulch in landscaped areas, subject to approval by the city engineer. 
(3)  Protection of existing plantings. Maximum effort should be made to save fine specimens. No material or temporary soil deposits shall be placed within four feet of shrubs or ten feet of trees intended to remain. Protective barriers or tree wells shall be installed around each plant and/or group of plants that are to remain on the site. Barriers shall not be supported by the plants they are protecting, but shall be self-supporting. They shall be a minimum of four-feet high and constructed of a durable material that will last until construction is completed. Snow fences and silt fences are examples of acceptable barriers. 
(4)  Slope plantings. Landscaping of all cuts and fills and/or terraces shall be sufficient to prevent erosion and all roadway slops steeper than one foot vertically to three feet horizontally shall be planted with ground cover appropriate for the purpose and for soil conditions, water availability and environment. 
(5)  Additional landscaping. In nonresidential developments, all areas of the site not occupied by buildings and required improvements shall be landscaped by the planting of grass or other ground cover, shrubs and trees. 
(Code 1967, § 18-99; Ord. No. 00-14, § 64, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-274. - Public utilities. 
(a)  All public utility lines for telephone and electric services shall be placed entirely throughout the subdivision, planned development or zoned lot in easements. Electric service to streetlights shall extend along side lots from rear lot easements or as approved by the city engineer. 
(b)  Telephone and electric service lines are to be placed underground entirely throughout a subdivided area. The conduits or cables shall be placed within easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. 
(c)  Any telephone and/or electric service lines provided for any subdivision on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection derives shall be placed underground entirely throughout any such subdivided area. The telephone and/or electric service lines shall be placed in accord with the requirements of subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  Cable television lines may be installed throughout the city overhead on existing utility poles in those areas where such poles have been erected and are currently in existence at the time of the cable television installation. In those areas of the city where all utilities are underground at the time of the cable television construction, the cable television lines must be placed underground. In those areas of the city where some utility lines are overhead and some utility lines are underground at the commencement of the cable television construction, the cable company may choose whether it will install the lines above the ground on the existing utility poles or beneath the ground. This subsection does not relieve the cable television installer from obtaining necessary permits or approvals from the owners, lessees or grantees of easements or utility poles proposed to be used by the cable television installer. 
(Code 1967, § 18-100) 
Sec. 98-275. - Development within floodplains. 
(a)  Purpose and effect of restrictions. Every tract of land situated within the corporate limits or in the contiguous territory not more than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits and not included within any other municipality shall be subject to the floodplain regulations as set forth in this section or other applicable section of this Code or other city ordinance and the regulations of the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources. Such regulations shall provide for the orderly use of land secured as nearly as possible, safety from the hazard of floods, and to ensure adequate provisions for the control of underground, surface, and runoff water. 
(b)  Minimum building elevation above recorded flood level. No new or existing building or structure shall be erected upon or moved within an area which has been designated as a regulatory floodplain in the Report on the Regulation of Construction within the Flood Plains of Upper Salt Creek and Tributaries, Palatine, Schaumburg, Elk Grove Townships, Cook County, by the Illinois Department of Transportation, Division of Water Resources, dated December, 1975, unless the lowest floor is two feet above the base flood elevation. Basements, cellars or crawl spaces shall be structurally adequate, poured-in-place concrete with no openings below the regulatory flood protection elevation, all in accordance with the existing city building code. 
(c)  Drainage easements. Where the drainage plan for a site with an area designated as a floodplain area requires rear or side lot drainage easements, such easements shall be centered on lot lines and shall be a minimum of 100 feet in width on the Arlington Heights branch of Salt Creek, or as determined by the city engineer in other areas. The minimum width shall be determined on the basis of the area drained, the channel cross section, a rainfall intensity of 100 years, and a minimum width for ingress and egress for maintenance, and, with the exception of utility facilities, no structures shall be placed in these drainage easements. 
(d)  Elevation of streets above recorded flood stage. The elevation of the finished surface at the centerline of any new street, access drives and driveways, lying within an area designated as a floodplain area, shall not be less than the regulatory flood stage as shown in the report mentioned in subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)  Use of fill. Fill within the floodplain is permitted provided filling is in accordance with the requirements of chapter 45 of this Code. 
(f)  Sanitary sewer construction. All sanitary sewer manholes constructed within an area designated as a floodplain area must have rim elevations above the regulatory flood elevation as shown in the report mentioned in subsection (b) of this section, or they must be provided with watertight covers. Groundwater or surface water connections are prohibited from being connected into the sanitary sewer system. 
(g)  Overhead sewers required. When a building wall encloses open space that is below the curb grade or street grade at the site or as determined by the city engineer, low level gravity building drain connections are prohibited and overhead sewers are required. 
(Code 1967, § 18-101; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 00-14, §§ 65-68, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-276. - Public improvement completion timing. 
(a)  General. Public improvements are to be installed in a timely manner to assure adequate service to developed property. Minimally, prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, a building must be served by water main, sanitary sewer, storm drainage facilities and street, including signage, completed through base course and if dead-end with the turnaround installed. 
(b)  Notwithstanding (a) above, improvements shall be installed and approved within the time prescribed as follows from the date of recordation of the final plat: 
Water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers 6 months Curb and gutter, street base and binder course 6 months Street lighting and street signs 12 months Parkway trees and grading and seeding 18 months Sidewalks and bicycle paths 24 months Rough grading and seeding of vacant lots 12 months  
(c)  Failure on the developer's part to cause the installation of the improvements within the prescribed timeframes will constitute grounds for activation of the performance guarantee and completion of the improvements by the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-14, § 70, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-277. - Deposit in lieu of public improvements. 
    In the event the city council determines to grant a variance from the requirements for the installation of the public improvements required by this chapter, the property owner shall deposit with the city an amount equal to the city engineer's estimate of cost for the public improvements. The deposit with the city shall be made prior to the issuance of any building permits. At such time as the city determines to install the public improvements, the city shall use the funds deposited by the owner for the installation of the public improvements for which the deposit was made by the owners. If the city has not installed the public improvements within ten years of the date of the deposit and the installation of the public improvements are not at that time included within the city's five-year capital improvement plan, the owner may request a refund of the deposit. The owner shall be required to request the refund within one year of the expiration of the ten-year period or the five-year capital improvement plan, whichever is longer. Any interest earned by the city on the deposit shall be retained by the city to offset the increased cost of construction and as an administrative charge of the city. 
( Ord. No. 15-04, § 1, 1-27-2015 ) 
Secs. 98-278-98-279. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RECAPTURE 

Sec. 98-280. - General. 
    Wherever: 
(1)  A municipal ordinance of the city requires the installation of any water mains, sanitary sewers or storm drains; and 
(2)  In the opinion of the city council such facilities may be used for the benefit of additional property not controlled by the person of whom an installation is required; and 
(3)  Such water mains, sanitary sewers and storm drains are to be dedicated to the public. 
The corporate authorities may, by ordinance, require that additional property benefitted by such facilities not be permitted to develop or connect to the facilities unless a fair and reasonable portion of certified costs of installation are reimbursed to the installing party. Installation cost, as determined by the city engineer, shall include the following and no others; actual construction costs (material, labor, equipment and overhead associated with the contract to install) and engineering fees equaling not more than three percent of the installation cost applicable to the recapture. 
A property is considered benefitted if the improvement fronts the property, otherwise serves the property, or is oversized and/or deepened beyond what would be required to serve just the developed property. 
The installing party has a maximum of one years' time, from the time of the placement of the public utility that was installed into operation, to make a formal written request to the city council to establish a recapture agreement, by ordinance. Recapture agreements shall have a term of ten years. Upon the completion of said ten-year term, the installing party may request one extension, up to five years, if justification can be provided that additional development or utility connections are likely to occur within the time frame of said extension. 
(Ord. No. 00-14, § 71, 5-9-2000; Ord. No. 16-05, § 1, 2-23-2016) 
Sec. 98-281. - Determining benefitted areas and apportionment costs. 
    The city council shall have the sole authority to determine the following: 
(1)  The benefitted properties. 
(2)  The costs eligible for the recapture. 
(3)  The method by which the costs are to be determined and certified. 
(4)  The amount of interest, if any, which may be charged to a benefitted property owner (not to exceed ten percent simple interest per annum). 
(Ord. No. 00-14, § 71, 5-9-2000) 
Sec. 98-282. - Methodology. 
    The city engineer will use the following methodology when determining benefitted areas and costs to be allocated for recommendation to the city council. 
(1)  Sanitary sewer. 
a.  Properties that will or can be served by an extension of the system are determined. 
b.  The size (square footage) of a property in relation to the total area served is used to establish its pro-rated share. 
c.  The actual cost for the sanitary sewer installation is used. Up to three percent of such cost for engineering may be included. The gross cost of installation is divided by the total square footage of the benefitting properties; the factor is multiplied by the square footage of the benefitted properties outside the subdivision to determine a gross amount due from each property. 
d.  While the developer's sanitary sewer installation allows outside property owners to connect to the sanitary sewer in the future, the future customers will still have to extend the sewer mains additional distances to account for their needs. The value of this additional work is subtracted from the gross installation cost to develop a net eligible cost for each parcel. 
(2)  Water main. 
a.  Property that will or can be served by an extension of the water main system is determined. 
b.  The total front footage of all of the benefitted properties is determined. 
c.  The actual cost for the installation is used. Up to three percent of such costs may be included for engineering. The cost for installation is divided by the total front footage for the benefitting properties. 
d.  The factor is applied to the benefitted properties outside the subdivision. 
(3)  Storm sewer. 
a.  Property that will or can be served by an extension of the storm sewer system is determined. 
b.  The size (square footage) of a property in relation to the total area served is used to establish its pro-rated share. 
c.  The actual cost for the storm water sewer installation is used. Up to three percent of such costs may be included for engineering. 
d.  The gross cost of installation is divided by the total square footage of the benefitting properties. The factor is multiplied by the square footage of the benefitted property outside the subdivision. Only those costs that are attributable to benefitted properties outside the subdivision are included in the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 00-14, § 71, 5-9-2000) 
Chapter 102 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 102-1-102-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAXES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 102-26. - Imposed. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail in this city at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this section is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this city in the business of making sales of service, at the rate of one percent of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. 
(b)  Such "Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax" and the "Home Rule Municipal Service Occupation Tax" shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and non-prescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics. 
(c)  The imposition of these taxes is in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-1 and 5/8-11-2, respectively. 
(Code 1967, § 19-1; Ord. No. 03-59, § 1, 9-23-2003) 
Sec. 102-27. - Collection and enforcement. 
    The taxes imposed in this division and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto shall be collected and enforced by the state department of revenue. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce this article. 
(Code 1967, § 19-2) 
Sec. 102-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-56, adopted Nov. 25, 2008, repealed § 102-28 which pertained to sunset clause and derived from Ord. No. 02-21, adopted May 21, 2002; and Ord. No. 03-82, adopted Dec. 16, 2003. 
Secs. 102-29-102-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HOTEL OPERATOR'S TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Hotel tax not preempted, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6a(3). 

Sec. 102-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hotel means any building in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodginghomes, roominghouses and apartment houses. 
    Person includes any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, public or private corporation or a receiver, executor, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
(Code 1967, § 19-57) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-57. - Imposed. 
    A tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel at the rate of eight percent of the gross rental receipts from such renting, leasing or letting, excluding, however, gross receipts obtained from the renting, leasing or letting to permanent residents of a hotel. 
(Code 1967, § 19-56; Ord. No. 01-36, § 1, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 07-61, § 1, 12-4-2007) 
Sec. 102-58. - Reimbursement. 
    Persons subject to the tax imposed by this division may reimburse themselves for their tax liability for such tax by separately stating such tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination with the state tax imposed under The Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 145/1 et seq., or in a single amount. 
(Code 1967, § 19-58) 
Sec. 102-59. - Construction of division. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed to authorize the city to impose a tax upon the privilege of engaging in any business which under the United States Constitution may not be made the subject of taxation by the state. 
(Code 1967, § 19-59) 
Sec. 102-60. - Report required; payment. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel within the city shall file with the city clerk, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by section six of the Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 145/6, approved July 6, 1961, as amended. Every person subject to the tax imposed by this division that does not file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by section six of the Hotel Operators' Occupation Tax Act, 35 ILCS 145/6, approved July 6, 1961, as amended, shall file with the city clerk, on or before the last day of each calendar month, a report of the gross rental receipts from the renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel within the city, excluding, however, gross receipts obtained from the renting, leasing or letting to permanent residents of the hotel in the city. 
(b)  At the time a copy of the report is filed with the city clerk, the person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel shall pay the amount of the tax required by this division. 
(Code 1967, § 19-60; Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 9-10-2013) 
Sec. 102-61. - Disposition of fees. 
(a)  All revenue derived under this division, except for the collection of fees, shall be deposited into the general fund of the city and used for the purpose of promoting tourism, conventions, economic development, public relations and to encourage nonresidents to visit the city. 
(b)  No funds received pursuant to this division shall be used to advertise or otherwise promote new competition in the hotel business. 
(Code 1967, § 19-61) 
Sec. 102-62. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 6 of Ord. No. 07-07, adopted March 27, 2007, repealed § 102-62, which pertained to interest in relation to taxation and derived from Code 1967, § 19-62. 
Sec. 102-63. - Administration and collection rebate. 
    For the purpose of assisting each hotel in defraying the cost of administration and collection of the hotel operators' occupation tax, the city shall rebate to the hotel two percent of the taxes actually collected from the hotel by the city. Payments by the city to the collecting hotels shall be made at least quarterly. 
(Code 1967, § 19-63) 
Sec. 102-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-42, § 1, adopted November 15, 2011, repealed § 102-64, which pertained to a sunset clause and derived from Ord. No. 02-21, adopted May, 14, 2002 and Ord. No. 05-69, adopted December 20, 2005. 
Sec. 102-65. - Late payment penalty. 
    If any tax imposed by this article is not paid when due, penalties and interest payments shall be imposed as described in article VI of this chapter, local tax rights and responsibilities. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 5, 3-27-2007) 
Secs. 102-66-102-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REAL PROPERTY TRANSFER TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Real property transfer tax not preempted, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-6a(4). 

Sec. 102-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Beneficial interest in real property includes but is not limited to: 
(1)  The beneficial interest in a land trust in this state; 
(2)  The lessee interest in a ground lease, including any interest of the lessee in the related improvements, that provides for a term of 30 or more years when all options to renew or extend are included, whether or not any portion of the term has expired; or 
(3)  The indirect interest in real property, as reflected by a controlling interest in a real estate entity. 
    Controlling interest means: 
(1)  Fifty percent or more of the combined voting power or fair market value of all ownership interests or beneficial interests in a real estate entity, whether the interests are owned by one or by several persons; or 
(2)  The right of one or of several persons to receive, at the time of any distribution, 50 percent or more of the income or profits of a real estate entity. 
    Department of finance means the city department of finance. 
    Director of finance means the city director of finance. 
    Person means any individual, receiver, administrator, executor, conservator, assignee, trust, estate, partnership, joint venture, club, joint stock company, business trust, political subdivision of the state, corporation, association, limited liability company, syndicate, society, or any group of persons acting as a unit, whether mutual, cooperative, fraternal, nonprofit, or otherwise. 
    Real estate entity means any person, other than an Illinois land trust, including but not limited to any partnership, corporation, trust, or single or multitiered entity that exists or acts substantially for the purpose of holding, directly or indirectly, title to or beneficial interest in real property located in the city, whether for personal use, the production of rental income, or investment. It shall be presumed, unless proved otherwise, that an entity is a real estate entity if it owns, directly or indirectly, real property located in the city having a fair market value greater than 75 percent of the total fair market value of all of the entity's assets, determined without deduction for any mortgage, lien, or encumbrance. 
    Transfer price means the consideration furnished for the transfer of title to or beneficial interest in real property, valued in money, whether paid in money or otherwise, including cash, credits, and property, determined without any deduction for mortgages, liens, or encumbrances, and specifically including the amount of any indebtedness or obligation cancelled or discharged in connection with the transfer. When the controlling interest in a real estate entity is transferred and the real estate entity holds assets in addition to title to or beneficial interest in real property located in the city, the term "transfer price" means only that portion of the consideration attributable to the transfer of such real property or such beneficial interest. 
(Code 1967, § 19-101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 102-92. - Imposed. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, a tax is imposed upon the privilege of transferring title to or beneficial interest in real property located in the city, whether or not the agreement or contract providing for the transfer is entered into in the city. The tax shall be at the rate of $3.00 per $1,000.00 of the transfer price, rounded to the next highest thousand, of the real property or the beneficial interest in real property. 
(b)  The tax imposed by this article is due upon the earlier of the delivery or recording of the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer. 
(1)  For an assignment of a beneficial interest in a trust, delivery shall be deemed to occur when the trustee receives possession of a valid assignment of the beneficial interest. For other transfers, delivery shall be deemed to occur when the transferee or the transferee's representative or agent receives, or becomes entitled to receive possession of the instrument of transfer. 
(c)  The primary incidence of the tax and the obligation to pay the tax are on the seller, grantor, assignor, or other transferor; provided, however, that if the transferor is exempt from the tax solely by operation of state law, the incidence of the tax and obligation to pay the tax shall be upon the transferee. 
(d)  The tax imposed by this article shall be due whether the transfer of a controlling interest in a real estate entity is effected by one transaction or by a series of related transactions. For purposes of this subsection, it shall be presumed, unless proved otherwise, that transactions are related if they occur within the same 24-month period. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to impose a tax upon any transaction or privilege which, under the Constitution of the United States or the constitution of the state, may not be made the subject of taxation by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 19-102) 
Sec. 102-93. - Payment. 
(a)  Except for a tax paid pursuant to section 102-99, the tax imposed by this article shall be paid by the purchase of a tax stamp issued by the finance department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the person liable for the tax to affix or to cause to be affixed the appropriate amount of the stamp to the face of the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer. 
(c)  The finance department shall not issue a transfer tax stamp in connection with a parcel of real property located in the city if there are unpaid sewer, water, garbage charges or other debts due the city. 
(d)  The city manager is authorized to enter into agreements with agents to provide for off-site collections of the city's real estate transfer tax and recover the cost of providing such a service through the imposition of a fee, with such fee being added onto the amount due to the city. The fee shall be determined by the city council through the adoption of an ordinance, and detailed in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1967, § 19-103; Ord. No. 98-63, § 5, 12-15-1998; Ord. No. 11-18, §§ 3, 4, 7-12-2011) 
Sec. 102-94. - Contingent liability of transferees. 
    If a real property transfer declaration is not filed, as provided by section 102-96, the transferee shall be liable for any unpaid tax imposed by this article, together with interest at the rate of one percent per month and a penalty of ten percent of the transfer tax. 
(Code 1967, § 19-104) 
Sec. 102-95. - Exempt transfers and transactions; refunds for certain transfers. 
(a)  Subject to the requirement contained in subsection 102-96(c) of this article, the following transactions are exempt from the tax imposed by this article: 
(1)  Transfers of real property made prior to July 1, 1988, where the deed was recorded after that date, or assignments of beneficial interest in real property dated prior to July 1, 1988, where the assignment was delivered on or after July 1, 1988. 
(2)  Transfers involving real property acquired by or from any governmental body. 
(3)  Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer secures debt or other obligations. 
(4)  Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer, without additional consideration, confirms, corrects, modifies, or supplements a deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer previously recorded or delivered. 
(5)  Transfers in which the transfer price is less than $500.00. 
(6)  Transfers in which the deed is a tax deed. 
(7)  Transfers in which the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer releases property which secures debt or other obligations. 
(8)  Transfers in which the deed is pursuant to a court decree. 
(9)  Transfers between a subsidiary corporation and its parent or between subsidiary corporations of a common parent either pursuant to a plan of merger or consolidation or pursuant to a plan of reorganization providing for the sale of substantially all of the seller's assets. 
(10)  Transfers from a subsidiary corporation to its parent for no consideration other than the cancellation or surrender of the subsidiary's stock and transfers from a parent corporation to its subsidiary for no consideration other than the issuance or delivery to the parent of the subsidiary's stock. 
(11)  Transfers made pursuant to a confirmed plan of reorganization as provided under section 1146(c) of chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code of 1978, as amended. 
(12)  Transfers in which the deed or other instrument of transfer is issued to the mortgagee or secured creditor pursuant to a mortgage or security interest foreclosure proceeding or sale or pursuant to a transfer in lieu of foreclosure. 
(b)  The taxes imposed by this article shall not be imposed on a transfer by an executor or administrator to a legatee, heir, or distributee where the transfer is being made pursuant to will or by intestacy. The tax imposed by this article shall further be exempt where the transaction is effected by operation of law or upon delivery or transfer in the following instances; provided, however, that a declaration form is filed: 
(1)  From a decedent to his executor or administrator. 
(2)  From a minor to his guardian, or from a guardian to his ward upon attaining majority. 
(3)  From an incompetent to his conservator or similar legal representative, or from a conservator or similar legal representative to a former incompetent upon removal of disability. 
(4)  From a bank, trust company, financial institution, insurance company or other similar entity or nominee, custodian or trustee therefor to a public officer or commission or person designated by such officer or commission or by a court in the taking over of its assets, in whole or in part, under state or federal law regulating or supervising such institutions or upon redelivery or retransfer by any such transferee or successor thereto. 
(5)  From a bankrupt or person in receivership due to insolvency to the trustee in bankruptcy or receiver, from such receiver to such trustee, or from such trustee to such receiver, or upon redelivery or retransfer by any such transferee or successor thereto. 
(6)  From a transferee under subsections (b)(1) through (5) of this section, inclusive, to his successor acting in the same capacity, or from one such successor to another. 
(7)  From trustee to surviving, substitute, succeeding, or additional trustees of the same trust. 
(8)  Upon the death of a joint tenant or tenant by the entirety to the survivor. 
(c)  Any person who pays the tax imposed by this article may apply for a refund of the tax so paid, less the sum of $20.00, if within 12 months of the closing of the sale of their principal residence the person closes the purchase of a new residence within the city and each of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The person owned and occupied the property which was sold as his principal residence for a period of one year prior to the closing of the sale; 
(2)  The person did not rent or lease any portion of the property sold; 
(3)  The person buys or builds a new residence within the city; 
(4)  The person owns and occupies the newly acquired property as their principal residence; 
(5)  The person shows proof that a water deposit has been paid on the new residence; 
(6)  The person shows proof that all current wheel taxes due the city are paid. 
(Code 1967, § 19-105; Ord. No. 00-57, § 1, 12-19-2000) 
Sec. 102-96. - Filing of declaration. 
(a)  At or before the time that the tax imposed by this article is due or, for an exempt transfer, at or before the time that the deed, assignment, or other instrument of transfer is delivered, there shall be filed with the finance department a real property transfer declaration signed by at least one of the transferors and also signed by at least one of the transferees or by their respective attorneys or agents. The declaration shall be on a form prescribed by the director of finance and shall contain such information as the director may reasonably require. 
(b)  If the declaration is signed by an attorney or agent on behalf of transferors or transferees who have the power of direction to deal with the title to the real property under a land trust agreement, the trustee being the mere repository of record legal title with a duty of conveying the real property only when and if directed, in writing, by the beneficiary having the power of direction, the attorney or agent executing the declaration on behalf of the transferors or transferees shall not be required to identify the beneficiary having the power of direction under the land trust agreement. 
(c)  No transfer shall be exempt from the tax imposed by this article unless the declaration describes the facts supporting the exemption and is accompanied by such supporting documentation as the director of finance may reasonably require, which may include a sworn statement; provided, however, that the director of finance shall, prior to issuing an exempt stamp, collect a processing fee as set forth in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 19-106) 
Sec. 102-97. - Obligations of trustees. 
    No trustee of a trust which holds title to or beneficial interest in real property located in the city shall accept or acknowledge an assignment of a beneficial interest in the trust unless the trustee has received from the assignor and assignee a complete and fully executed real estate transfer declaration as provided in section 102-96 and unless the amount of tax stamp required by this article has been affixed to the assignment. 
(Code 1967, § 19-107) 
Sec. 102-98. - Stamp. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the director of finance shall cause to be made a rubber stamp, which impression shall be placed either directly on the face of the deed or assignment or on an adhesive stamp denoting the amount of tax paid and the date the stamp was issued. If the transfer is exempt, the finance department shall note that the transfer is exempt and shall place the section number applicable to the exemption and the date the stamp was issued. 
(b)  In every case where a tax stamp is used to pay the tax imposed by this article, the person affixing the stamp shall write or stamp thereupon the person's name or initials and the date upon which the stamp is affixed; provided, however, that no stamp shall be defaced in such a manner as to prevent its authenticity and denomination from being determined. 
(Code 1967, § 19-108) 
Sec. 102-99. - Open transactions. 
    Under this article, for a transfer where any part of the transfer price is contingent upon the occurrence of a future event or the attainment of a future level of financial performance, additional tax shall be due at the time each additional amount of consideration is furnished and shall be paid directly to the department of revenue. A supplemental real estate transfer declaration shall be filed with the department at the time each tax payment is due. 
(Code 1967, § 19-109) 
Sec. 102-100. - Penalty for violation. 
    In addition to the other sections of this article, any person found guilty of violating this article shall be fined as set forth in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 19-110) 
Sec. 102-101. - Liens. 
(a)  If the tax imposed by this article is not paid when due, the city shall have a lien against the related real property in an amount equal to the tax, together with all applicable interest and penalties. The lien shall expire only at such time as the outstanding tax, interest, and penalties are paid in full; the lien is foreclosed; or the period for bringing a foreclosure action described in subsection (c) of this section expires.
