Sec. 106-19. - Parking during snow removal. 
    It is unlawful to park any vehicle for a period of time longer than three minutes for loading and unloading of passengers or 30 minutes for loading and unloading of property in any place, whether designated as a loading zone or not so designated, at any time after snow begins to fall and for a period of eight hours after snow stops falling, if the snow on the street exceeds one inch in depth (two inches in depth on Arbor Drive), provided that the eight-hour parking restriction shall continue during snow removal operations until completed. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-470), 9-9-2008; Ord. No. 10-21, § 3, 7-13-10) 
Sec. 106-20. - Permits for special no parking areas. 
(a)  Special no parking spaces in front of shipping entrances and the entrances to churches, hotels, theaters, office buildings or other buildings where a large number of people are accustomed to gather may be provided and established by compliance with this section. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant of such building adjacent to a street or alley desiring a certain no parking space immediately in front of the entrance to such building shall make application to the city council, setting forth all relevant information and stating the number of feet and the time desired for such purposes. The city council shall have authority to grant the application with such restrictions or limitations as it may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-471), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-21. - Other vehicles parking in bus stops, taxicab stands. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle other than a bus to stand or park in an officially designated bus stop or for any vehicle other than a taxicab to stand or park in an officially designated taxicab stand, except that the driver of any passenger vehicle may temporarily stop in such stop or stand for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-472), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-22. - Parking on premises other than driveways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle or for the owner of premises to allow the parking of a motor vehicle, except those vehicles defined in article II of chapter 66 pertaining to trailers, recreational vehicles and trailer camps, on premises within the city unless the parking area complies with the provisions of article VII of chapter 18, pertaining to driveways, of the comprehensive building code and all amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-473), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-23. - Parking of second division vehicles. 
(a)  No vehicle of the second division, exceeding 8,000 pounds or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, shall be parked or stored on any residential or retail premises classified in a residential or commercial district pursuant to chapter 122 except as follows: 
(1)  Vehicles parked pursuant to authority contained in article II of chapter 66 pertaining to trailers, recreational vehicles and trailer camps. 
(2)  Vehicles parked on church or school premises used for the transportation of persons for school or church purposes. Such vehicles may be parked on residentially zoned premises, other than church and school premises, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and sunset, or any time if less than 12 feet in height, eight and one-half feet in width, and 20 feet in length, and parked behind the front building line. 
(3)  Vehicles making a delivery or pickup of merchandise or material, providing a service for the premises or engaged in the transporting of household possessions of the persons moving into or out of a dwelling unit shall be permitted to stand and park for a period not to exceed 24 hours. 
(4)  Vehicles granted a special permit issued by the police department for nonrecurring work or service, such as construction. 
(b)  No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, roadwork or for use on a farm, including but not limited to bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane or roller, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residence district unless the equipment or machinery is engaged in work in the subject premises. 
(c)  Recognizing there may be circumstances that exist which create an economic hardship for an owner to comply with the requirements of the Code of Ordinances prohibiting the parking of a business or commercial, the police chief may issue a special permit allowing a variance from the requirements set forth by this section. If the police chief grants a request for a special permit, it shall be issued to the owner, and shall not be transferable to other parties or properties and may be revoked at any time the criteria are no longer met. In the granting of the variance for the special permit, the police chief shall find that the following criteria have been met: 
(1)  The vehicles do not violate any other sections of the Code of Ordinances; 
(2)  Vehicles are appropriately licensed, operable and in good repair. "Good repair" means that the vehicle is in a clean and reasonable well maintained condition; 
(3)  Vehicles are registered to the employer of the owner; 
(4)  An economic hardship exists relating to the owner's employment requiring the owner to park the vehicle on the owner's residential property; 
(5)  The grant of the special permit does not impair the health, welfare, character, or safety of the neighborhood; and 
(6)  Each request for a variance shall be made to the police chief with a written application on a form approved by the police chief. Each special permit shall expire at the end of the calendar year in which it is issued. Applications for a special permit for the next calendar year may be filed with the police chief not more than 60 days prior to the end of that calendar year. In the event that the police chief denies a request for a special permit, the applicant may appeal the police chief's decision to the city manager. Any appeal to the city manager shall be made no later than 14 days after the denial of the application by the police chief. The city manager shall either affirm the police chief's denial of the special permit or grant the special permit within 14 days of the date the appeal is filed with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-474), 9-9-2008; Ord. No. 15-06, § 1, 2-10-2015 )

(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-475), 9-9-2008; Ord. No. 10-18, §§ 1, 2, 5-25-2010; Ord. No. 10-19, §§ 1, 2, 6-22-2010; Ord. No. 12-03, § 1, 1-24-2012; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 3-13-2012; Ord. No. 18-27, § 1, 7-10-2018) 
Sec. 106-25. - Parking at night. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or owner of any vehicle to park such vehicle or allow such vehicle to remain parked on any street between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day, except as follows: perpendicular parking on the west side of Algonquin Parkway adjacent to Coach Light Condominiums, beginning 477 feet north of the northerly line of Algonquin Road as measured along the westerly line of dedicated Algonquin Parkway to a point 878 feet north of the northerly line of Algonquin Road in the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-476), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-26. - High school parking plan. 
(a)  Parking prohibition. It shall be unlawful for the driver or owner of any vehicle to park such vehicle or allow such vehicle to be parked in the following locations between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m., on days when Rolling Meadows High School is in session: 
Birch Lane North Side from Linden Lane to Cedar Street. Brookmeade Drive Both sides from Magnolia Drive to Plum Grove Drive. Cedar Street South side from Linden Lane to Weber Drive. Central Road South side from the intersection of Peacock Drive and Central Road to a point 300 feet west of the west right-of-way line of Peacock Drive. Eagle Lane East side from Fulle Street to Grouse Lane. Jay Lane East side from Fulle Street to Grouse Lane. Linden Lane West side from Central Road to Birch. Maple Lane South side from Linden Lane to Maple Court. Oak Lane Both sides of the street from Linden Lane to Weber Drive. Peacock Drive East side from Central to end and all of the cul-de-sac. Peacock Lane North of Central Road on the east and west sides of the street from Peacock Court to Central Road. Raven Lane East side from Fulle Street to Grouse Lane. Willow Lane North side from Linden Lane to Cedar Street.  
Permit parking only: 
Barker Avenue: East side from Salt Creek Bridge to 75' south of Central Road (within parking spaces). 
(b)  Permit parking. Annual parking permits shall be issued by Rolling Meadows High School for parking within marked spaces on the east side of Barker Avenue from Salt Creek Bridge north to 75 feet south of the Central Road right-of-way and for parking spaces located on the city garage property, 3200 Central Road, as designated by the director of public works. 
The parking permit fee is $60.00 and is nonrefundable. The parking permit fees shall be paid by the high school to the city. 
(c)  Signs. The director of public works is directed to erect and maintain signs or devices and pavement striping consistent with the provisions of this section. The director of public works shall remove any existing signs that are not consistent with the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Penalty. The penalty for violation of the provisions of this section shall be the same as the penalty for parking violations as set forth in appendix B in the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-477), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-26.1. - Arbor Drive permit parking. 
    Permit parking only shall be permitted on Arbor Drive. The penalty for a violation of this section should be the same as the penalty for parking violations as set forth in Appendix B in the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 2, 12-13-10) 
Sec. 106-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bumper means every device or system of devices protruding from and attached to the front and rear of a motor vehicle which has been designed to be used to absorb the impact of a collision. 
    Headset receiver means any device, other than a hearing aid, designed to be worn on a person's head which enables the wearer to hear or receive electronic communications. 
    Muffler means every device consisting of a series of chambers or baffle plates or other mechanical design for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from an internal combustion engine or turbine wheels for the purpose of receiving exhaust gas from a diesel engine, both of which are effective in reducing noise. 
    Safety glazing materials means any glazing materials so constructed, treated or combined with other materials as to reduce, substantially, in comparison with ordinary sheet glass or plate glass, the likelihood of injury to persons by objects from exterior sources or by these safety glazing materials when they may be cracked or broken. 
    Suspension system means the system of devices consisting of but not limited to springs, spring shackles, shock absorbers, torsion bars, frame or any other supporting members used to attach the body of a motor vehicle to its axles. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-506, 106-636, 106-666), 9-9-2008) 
State Law reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-28. - Violation of permit. 
(a)  Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit issued under sections 106-30 through 106-35 of this chapter by operating under a fraudulent permit or under a permit not specifically covering the move, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a business offense, and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. When any person is convicted of such violation, the permit shall be null and void and such person shall be fined in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  Penalties for violations of this section shall be in addition to any penalties imposed for violation of subsection 106-739(i) of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-735), 9-9-2008) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/15-113.1. 
Sec. 106-29. - Special weight limitations on certain streets. 
(a)  The city council prohibits the operation of any vehicle whose gross weight, loaded or unloaded, exceeds the maximum of ten tons per vehicle on any street under its jurisdiction with the exception of the following streets where the weight limit will be 40 tons: 
(1)  Apollo Drive; 
(2)  Berdnick Street; 
(3)  Carnegie Street; 
(4)  Edison Place; 
(5)  Golf Place; 
(6)  Hicks Road; 
(7)  Industrial Avenue; 
(8)  Keystone Court; 
(9)  Kirchoff Road; 
(10)  Lois Drive; 
(11)  Meacham/Plum Grove Road - South of Emerson; 
(12)  Meadowbrook Drive and Meadowbrook Industrial Court; 
(13)  Meijer Drive Industrial Use/Truck Route; 
(14)  New Wilke Road - Algonquin Road to Golf Road; 
(15)  Newport Drive; 
(16)  Plum Grove Road; 
(17)  Rohlwing Road; 
(18)  Squibb Avenue; 
(19)  Tollview Drive; 
(20)  Weber Drive - Southbound; 
(21)  Wilke Road from Euclid Avenue to Kirchoff Road. 
    The weight limits set forth above shall not apply to fire and emergency vehicles, city owned trucks or trucks engaged in city business within the city, public passenger vehicles (buses), public utility vehicle, refuse and recycling trucks engaged in the collection of material, and delivery vehicles for a distance of one highway mile to or from a class II highway on any street or highway, unless there is a sign prohibiting the access or five highway miles on a street or highway in the system of state highways, and upon any street or highway designated by the city council or road district commissioners, to points of loading and unloading and facilities for food, fuel, repairs and rest. 
(b)  The city shall erect or shall cause to be erected and maintained the signs designating the provisions of the ordinance of special weight limitations at all streets that intersect any street affected, and the ordinance shall not be effective unless and until such signs are erected and maintained. 
(Ord. No. 11-16, § 2, 6-28-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-16, § 1, adopted June 28, 2011, repealed the former § 106-29, and § 2 of Ord. No. 11-16 enacted a new § 106-29 as set out herein. The former § 106-29 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 08-37, adopted September 9, 2008. 
Sec. 106-30. - Fees for house trailer combinations. 
    A fee for special permits to move a house trailer or modular home section in combination with a towing vehicle for limited continuous operation shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-742), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-31. - Fees for special permits to move certain overdimension vehicles, combinations and loads. 
(a)  A fee for special permits to move overdimension vehicles, combinations, and loads, other than house trailer combinations, shall be paid by the applicant to the city clerk. Such fee shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  Permits issued under this section shall be for a vehicle or vehicle combination and load not exceeding legal weights and, for the limited continuous operation, shall be for the same vehicle, vehicle combination or like load. Escort requirements shall be as prescribed in the police department's rules and regulations. Fees for the police vehicle escort, when required, shall be in addition to the permit fees. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-743), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-32. - Fees for overweight axle loads. 
    Fees for special permits to move legal gross weight vehicles, combinations of vehicles and loads with overweight axle loads shall be paid by the applicant to the city clerk as follows: for each overweight single axle or tandem axle group the flat rate fees scheduled in this article including the issuance fee is predicated upon an 18,000-pound single-axle equivalency. Single trip permits only shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-744), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-33. - Fees for overweight gross loads. 
    Fees for special permits to move vehicles, combinations of vehicles and loads with overweight gross loads shall be paid at the rates in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-745), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-34. - Fees for police escort. 
    When police escorts are required for safety of the motoring public, a fee shall be paid by the applicant requesting such escort in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. The estimate of time of the movement shall be agreed upon between chief of police and the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-746), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-35. - Operation of motor driven scooters, minibikes and pocket bikes. 
(a)  Restricted. No person shall operate a motor driven scooter, minibike or pocket bike upon any public street, sidewalk, parking lot, bike path, park or on any other public property. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following shall be exempt from the prohibitions contained in this section: 
(1)  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, municipal vehicle, special district vehicle, county vehicle or forest preserve district vehicle driven by an employee in the course of his or her duties. 
(2)  Motorized wheelchairs. For purposes of this section, a motorized wheelchair means any motorized vehicle designated for and used by a person with disabilities. 
(3)  Electric personal assistance mobility devices, as defined in Section 5/1-117.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5-1-100 et seq.). 
(c)  Applicability of this section. Without limitation, this section applies to all public property in the City of Rolling Meadows. 
(d)  Violations. Any person 18 years of age or older who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00 for the first offense, $100.00 for the second offense and $500.00 for the third offense. Any offenses after the third offense shall be subject to a fine of not less than $750.00. The police shall have the authority to impound the motor driven scooter, mini bike or pocket bike, subject to the code hearing unit adjudication provisions of chapter 3 of the City Code of Ordinances of the City of Rolling Meadows, Cook County, Illinois. An offense committed by a minor under the direct control or with the consent of a parent or guardian may subject the parent or guardian to the penalties provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-776), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-36. - Pedestrian control signals. 
    Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the words "walk" or "don't walk" or the illuminated symbols of a walking person or an upraised palm are in place, such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  Walk signal or walking person symbol. Pedestrians facing a walk signal or walking person symbol may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal or symbol and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles. 
(2)  Don't walk signal or upraised palm symbol. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of a don't walk signal or upraised palm symbol, but any pedestrian who has partly completed his crossing on the walk signal or walking person symbol shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the don't walk signal or upraised palm symbol is illuminated, steady, or flashing. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-885), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-37. - Riding bicycles or motorized pedalcycles on roadways. 
    A person riding a bicycle or motorized pedalcycle upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of the roadways set aside for its exclusive use. Persons riding two abreast shall not impede the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, and on a laned roadway persons shall ride within a single lane. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-956), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-38. - Registration. 
    Every owner of a bicycle, except dealers in bicycles, who resides within the city, shall register such bicycle with the city traffic division on forms to be furnished by the chief of police. Such form shall state the name of the owner, the make of the bicycle being registered, the serial number if any, and a brief description of any features of the bicycle that will serve to identify it. Any bicycle so registered need not be reregistered as long as it is owned by the person who registered it. A charge in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code shall be made by the city clerk for registering any bicycle. The city clerk shall issue a suitable identification tag or card to the owner of the bicycle so registered. The city clerk shall not issue a license for any bicycle when he knows or has reasonable grounds to believe that the applicant is not the owner of or entitled to the possession of such bicycle. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-967), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-39. - Trick riding and racing. 
(a)  No bicycle rider shall practice or perform any stunt, trick, fancy or acrobatic riding on any street, except under permit from the chief of police. 
(b)  No bicycle rider shall participate in any race for speed or in any endurance contest with any bicycle or vehicle upon the street, except under permit from the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-968), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-40. - Requirements for rental bicycles. 
    A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the bicycle is licensed and a license plate is attached thereto as provided in this article and such bicycle is equipped with the lamps and other equipment required in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-969), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-41. - Bicycle safety program and court. 
(a)  Program established; composition. There is established a bicycle safety program. Such program shall consist of a bicycle safety court and bicycle safety officers. A bicycle court hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor. Such appointment shall be made without benefit of salary to the appointee. 
(b)  Bicycle safety court. The court shall be held at least two Saturdays per month at city hall, bicycle safety court, from June through August, at the discretion of the mayor. Such court and operational procedures shall be educational in nature to promote bicycle safety and compliance with existing law. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-970), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-42. - Bicycle safety officer patrol. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to appoint bicycle safety officers from the police department or employ additional bicycle safety officers. This position shall concern the enforcement of sections of this chapter. Such bicycle safety officer shall have at his disposal all equipment, training and methods deemed necessary by the chief of police. 
(b)  Bicycle safety officers shall have the authority to issue a warning notice or a citation for violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-971), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-43. - [Tag] required. 
    No resident owner of a bicycle having wheels 19 inches or more in diameter with tires inflated shall ride such bicycle or permit it to be ridden by others on any street or part of the street unless such bicycle has been provided with the proper permit tag as provided in this division, and provided, further, that, upon request of the owner and payment of the registration fee, a bicycle having a wheel diameter of less than 19 inches may be licensed, but need not be. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1001), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-44. - [Same-]Issuance. 
    The city clerk, upon issuing a bicycle license, shall also issue a license tag bearing the license number assigned to the bicycle and the name of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1002), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-45. - [Same-]Removal. 
    No person shall remove a license tag from a bicycle during the period for which issued except upon a transfer of ownership or if the bicycle is dismantled and no longer operated upon any street in this city. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1003), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-46. - [Same-]Replacement. 
    Any bicycle license lost, stolen, or mutilated must be replaced within two weeks and the fee for issuance of the replacement license shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1004), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-47. - Effect of sale or transfer. 
    Upon the sale or transfer of a licensed bicycle, the holder of a license shall surrender to the city clerk the license or may have such license tag assigned to another bicycle owned by him. A fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code shall be charged for any such transfer. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1005), 9-9-2008) 
Sec. 106-48. - Clerk to supply licensee with copy of chapter. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk, with the issuance of a bicycle license, to supply a copy of this chapter pertaining to bicycles to every purchase of such license. 
(Ord. No. 08-37, § 2(106-1006), 9-9-2008)
