Secs. 110-1-110-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UTILITY AND STORMWATER MANAGEMENT REVIEW BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. 02-07, adopted Feb. 26, 2002, amended the title of art. II, utility review board, to read as herein set out. Sections 110-27 and 110-28 have been changed to reflect the new board title, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-661 et seq. 

Sec. 110-26. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a utility stormwater review board, which is an administrative body made up of the city manager, director of public works, and director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 97-45, § 1 (23-30), 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 02-07, §§ 4, 5, 2-26-2002; Ord. No. 09-17, § 1, 4-28-2009) 
Sec. 110-27. - Purpose. 
    The utility[and stormwater management] review board shall hear appeals for adjustments to utility bills from customers of the city's water system who have experienced extraordinary utility bills from the city due to high water usage, where the customer asserts that the circumstances associated with the high water usage were beyond his reasonable control. 
(Ord. No. 97-45, § 1 (23-31), 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-28. - Authority and power. 
    The utility [and stormwater management] review board is authorized to make adjustments to water and sanitary sewer charges in accordance with the following guidelines: 
(1)  The ability of staff to adjust bills is limited to those changes under $2,500.00; any request to adjust a bill in excess of $2,500.00 shall be made to the city council. 
(2)  The adjustment can only be for a single month's bill or for the time period associated with a single event. 
(3)  The water charges may be adjusted by applying the rate paid by the city for the purchase of water through the Northwest Suburban Municipal Joint Action Water Agency to the amount of water usage registered on the customer's meter instead of using the normal rate paid by city water customers. 
(4)  The sanitary sewer charges may be adjusted by using the average monthly charge paid by the customer for the 12 months previous to the monthly sanitary sewer charge at issue or by establishing the sanitary sewer charge for the monthly charge at issue at 30 percent of the customer's water service charge for the same month as the sanitary sewer charge at issue. 
(5)  As a condition of receiving consideration for a utility bill adjustment, the customer must demonstrate to the utility [and stormwater management] review board members that he has taken affirmative actions to correct the conditions which lead to the extraordinary bill, and pay a 15 percent administrative fee on the adjusted amount. 
(6)  In addition to the authority and powers enumerated herein, the utility and stormwater management review board shall review fees associated with stormwater management. 
(Ord. No. 97-45, § 1 (23-31), 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 02-20, § 1, 4-23-2002; Ord. No. 06-50, §§ 1, 2, 11-14-2006; Ord. No. 02-07, § 6, 2-26-2002) 
Secs. 110-29-110-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-56. - Department created. 
    There is created the department of sewers, an executive department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-1), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-57. - Head of department and executive duties. 
    The director of public works shall be the head of the sewer department and all officers and employees assigned thereto. All such officers and employees shall perform their duties subject to the supervision of the director. The director shall be charged with the responsibility of the operation, repair, and maintenance of the sewer system, and he shall have the right to hire and discharge personnel for the sewer department subject to the city's personnel rules. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-2), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-58. - Functions of department. 
    The sewer department shall have charge and supervision over the care, maintenance and construction of all sanitary sewers, drains and appurtenances thereto. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-3), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-59. - Rates and charges established. 
(a)  There are established rates or charges for the use and for the service supplied by the sewer system of the city. 
(b)  All users within the city shall pay a usage rate and an access-to-sewer fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(c)  All sewer service only users shall pay a per month charge in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(d)  All sewer users located partially or completely outside of the corporate limits shall pay a surcharge based on 50 percent of their monthly bill to enable the recovery of indirect expenses associated with the public works department, such as building rent, overhead, etc., which support the sewer system, which are otherwise paid by property owners subject to real estate property taxation located within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-4), 8-27-1996; Ord. No. 07-47, § 1, 11-27-2007) 
Sec. 110-60. - Due date of bills; delinquency penalty. 
    All sewer bills shall be due and payable during a period of 20 days from the date of any billing, and the date of the 20th day after billing shall appear on all bills. If any bill is paid after such period, there shall be added thereto a late charge of ten percent of the sewer bill to be paid by any sewer user making a late payment. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-5), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-61. - Right to change rates and regulations. 
    The city reserves the right to make such reasonable changes in rates and in conditions established in this article and to establish further rules and regulations from time to time as may be found expeditious or necessary. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-6), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-62. - Lien for unpaid charges. 
(a)  Charges for sewer service shall be upon the premises serviced as provided by state statute. Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid 30 days after it has become due, the director of finance may direct the city attorney to file with the recorder of deeds of the county a statement of lien claim or take other appropriate action, including but not limited to the use of a collection agency. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for the amount when due plus any and all charges for the sewer service subsequent to the period covered by the then-due bill. 
(b)  If the sewer user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the director of finance has notice of this, the notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known, whenever such bills remain unpaid for a period of 20 days after it has become due. 
(c)  The failure of the city to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid sewer bills. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid sewer charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the charges, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to the sewer charges, after deducting costs, as the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosures shall be a bill in equity in the name of the city. The city attorney is authorized to institute such proceedings in the name of the city and in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which a sewer charge has remained unpaid, a statement of lien claim has been filed as set forth in this section and a period of 30 days has lapsed since such filing. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-7), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-63. - Use of revenues; depreciation fund. 
(a)  All revenues derived from the operation of the sewer department shall first be applied to defray the cost of operation of the department. 
Any revenues accumulated over and above the cost of operation of the sewer department shall be deposited to the depreciation fund. 
(b)  The depreciation fund shall be used for such replacements and repairs as may be necessary from time to time for the continued effective and efficient operation of the sewer system. The depreciation fund shall not be allowed to accumulate beyond a reasonable amount necessary for that purpose and shall not be used for extension of the system. 
(c)  The city council by ordinance may transfer funds from the depreciation fund to a surplus fund which has accumulated in excess of an amount reasonably necessary for the effective and efficient operation of the sewer system. The surplus fund account shall be used for the construction, acquisition, improvement, extension, operation or improvement of the sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-8), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-64. - Sewage facilities near water wells. 
    No sewage facilities (i.e., septic tanks) shall be allowed within a distance of 1,000 feet radially from any city water supply well in compliance with standards established in the state environmental protection agency groundwater protection program. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-9), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-65. - Discharge of sanitary or industrial wastewater prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall permit or cause the discharge of sanitary or industrial wastewater into any storm sewer constructed within the corporate limits. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be fined in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-10), 8-27-1996; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-66. - Other ordinances adopted; penalty for violation. 
(a)  There is adopted by reference the ordinance passed by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago July 10, 1969, as amended, regulating the issuance of permits for construction, operation and maintenance of sewers, sewer systems, treatment facilities and sewer connections designed to discharge directly or indirectly into collection and treatment facilities of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. 
(b)  There is adopted by reference the most recent edition of the Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance Adopted by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, published as of the date of adoption of this Code of Ordinance. Three copies of the manual are on file with the city clerk. 
(c)  There is adopted by reference the ordinance for the Industrial Waste Surcharge, which was passed by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and which became effective on October 1, 1970. 
(d)  Any building owner constructing a sewer or connecting to a sewer which discharges directly or indirectly into a sewer which discharges directly or indirectly into collection and treatment facilities of the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago shall be aware of the requirements this article, specifically sections 110-165-110-168, and any and all requirements established by the city, the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and any other governmental body having jurisdiction. 
(e)  Any person failing to obtain the necessary permits, failing to follow the conditions of the permits or violating any provision of the Manual of Procedures for the Administration of the Sewer Permit Ordinance, as amended from time to time, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-11), 8-27-1996; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-67. - Authority to investigate. 
    The city shall have the authority to enter upon any property at any reasonable hour to test for and determine the source of outflow of sewage or any questionable discharge. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-12), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-68. - Notice of violation and penalty. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of a violation of any portion of this article shall be fined in accordance with section 110-66 of this article. 
(b)  The city may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-74), 8-27-1996) 
Secs. 110-69-110-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF BUILDING SEWERS 

Sec. 110-96. - Responsibility to install. 
    All sewer lines and pipes running from the main to the premises served, referred to as "building sewers," shall be installed by and at the cost of the owner or occupant of the property to be served. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-21), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-97. - Inspections authorized. 
    The repair and maintenance of all building sewers, after initial installation, shall be subject to the inspection of the director of public works. Initial installation of all building sewers shall be inspected by the community development director. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-22), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-98. - Compliance required. 
    No building sewer shall be installed unless it conforms to the requirements of the city building and subdivision regulations, the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, and the Environmental Protection Agency of the United States and of the state. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-23), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-99. - Repair. 
(a)  All repairs of building sewers located on or under the public right-of-way, serving single-family detached dwellings, only, shall be repaired by the city. As used in this subsection, the term "repaired" shall mean the reconstruction of all or a portion of a building sewer located on or under the public right-of-way to an extent that requires excavation of all or a portion of the building sewer located on or under city property. Other maintenance shall be the owner's responsibility. 
(b)  That portion of the building sewer located under private property shall be maintained and repaired at the expense of the owner or occupant of the premises served. 
(c)  All repairs and maintenance to building sewers to premises other than single-family detached dwellings shall be made by and at the expense of the owners or occupants of the premises served. The city may, in an emergency, repair any building sewer, and the reasonable cost of such work shall be repaid to the city by the owner of the premises served. If the owner of the premises served does not repay to the city the expense of any emergency repair on the owner's or occupant's premises, the city shall have a lien against the property for the amount of the repairs or maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-24), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-100. - Excavation permits. 
    Excavations for installing building sewers require a permit from the city and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, and the excavations shall be made in compliance with this Code and the ordinances governing the excavations and shall be subject to original installation inspected by the community development director, with subsequent excavations for repairs subject to inspection by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-25), 8-27-1996) 
Secs. 110-101-110-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OBSTRUCTIONS OF STORMWATER CONVEYANCE SYSTEMS 

Sec. 110-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Floodplain means the area adjacent to a watercourse which has been or may be intermittently included in the regulatory floodplain maps prepared by the state department of transportation, division of water resource, for the administration of floodplain regulations for the Upper Salt Creek Watershed or, in lieu of these maps, the flood insurance maps prepared by the Federal Insurance Administration. 
    Manmade and natural watercourse means a natural or artificial channel of perceptible extent, with definite bed and banks to confine and conduct continuously or periodically flowing water. 
    Storm sewer means an enclosed pipe which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial waste. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-41), 8-27-1996) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-127. - Prohibited acts. 
    The keeping or disposal of grass clippings, trash, debris, obstructions or unwanted materials into storm sewers or within or along banks of manmade or natural watercourses or in adjacent floodplain areas which may wash into streams or sewers is unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-42), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-128. - Power and authority of inspectors. 
    The duly appointed city engineer and the director of public works and Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and their duly authorized agents or employees, upon proper identification to the owner of the property or his tenant, shall be permitted to enter upon properties within the city for the purpose of inspection, observation and measurement, in accordance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-43), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-129. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating a section of this division shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing ten days for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. If the offender fails to take the required corrective action within the time specified in the notice, the city may take corrective action, and the offender shall be responsible to reimburse the city for its reasonable and necessary cost in regard thereto. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-44), 8-27-1996; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Secs. 110-130-110-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 110-156. - Sewer permit required. 
    No person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into; use; alter; or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance or change the composition or industrial waste thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city, the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and any other governmental body having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-61), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-157. - Sewer permit application. 
    Application for a sanitary sewer permit shall be made on forms furnished by the building department or the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago (section 5-4.4 art. E, sewer permit fees). 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-62), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-158. - Downstream capacity required. 
    Prior to the issuance of building sewer permit under this division, it shall be the obligation of the applicant to provide to the city reasonable satisfaction that the downstream sewer facilities have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste loads. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-63), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-159. - Abandonment. 
    When a building sewer is abandoned, all existing sanitary sewer service connections shall be abandoned and removed, and the city sewer shall be repaired at the expense of the property owner to the reasonable satisfaction of the building department. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-64), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-160. - Connection requirements and prohibitions. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of all building and plumbing and all other applicable rules and regulations of the city. Upon approval of the city engineer the connection may conform to the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. In addition, the following shall apply: 
(1)  Overhead plumbing. All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below grade level at the building site shall have overhead plumbing for both storm and sanitary systems. 
(2)  Footing drains. Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps for further discharge via an overhead system into a storm sewer or drainage swale. No footing drain or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system. All sump basins shall be vented. No wastewater from the building may be connected to a footing drain or footing drain sump basin. 
(3)  Pipe bedding. Bedding, other than concrete embedment, shall consist of crushed gravel or crushed stone, one-fourth inch to one inch in size. As a minimum, the material shall conform to the requirements in article 704.01 of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction of the state or ASTM C-33. The graduation shall conform to the graduation CA7, CA8, CA11 or CA13 2 of the state standard specification or to ASTM graduation no. 67. The pipe shall be laid so that it will be uniformly supported, and the entire length of the pipe barrel will bear on the bedding. No blocking of any kind shall be used to adjust the pipe to grade except when blocked with embedment concrete and the remainder of the pipe is in full contact with the bedding. Bedding shall be required for all sewer construction and shall be a minimum thickness equal to one-fourth of the outside diameter of the sewer pipe, but shall not be less than four inches deep, and shall extend to the spring line and be fully tamped into place. When PVC, ABS or other flexible or composite sewer pipe or service is utilized, the bedding material shall extend to 12 inches over the top of the pipe and shall be fully tamped into place. Added flexible pipe shall be tested with a mandrel as described in the Standard Specifications of Sewer and Water Main Construction of the state. 
(4)  Connection of other sources of runoff. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(5)  Floor drains. Floor drains in basements shall be connected to sump pumps and discharged to the sanitary sewers. 
(6)  Sump pumps. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge groundwaters or other stormwaters shall be connected to a storm sewer or shall discharge into a drainage ditch. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge floor drain flow or other sanitary sewage shall be connected to the sanitary sewers. A sump pump shall be used for one function, only, either the discharge of stormwaters or the discharge of sanitary sewage. 
(7)  Window well and areaway drains. No window well or areaway drains carrying surface runoff or groundwater shall be connected to the sanitary sewer. 
(8)  Construction standards. In addition to meeting all other applicable requirements, sanitary sewers shall be SDR26 PVC or CL52DIP. Public sanitary sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of eight inches. Sanitary building sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of four inches. Joints for sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer services shall be of the compression type in conformance with the specifications of the American Society for Testing Materials, designation D3212 (PVC) or (DIP). Sidewalls and bases of manholes on sanitary sewers shall be of reinforced precast concrete ring construction which shall have a five-inch minimum thickness. Manhole frames and covers shall be Neenah R-1015 or equivalent, with a concealed pick-hole, gasket seal and the word "sanitary" cast on top. Precast flexible rubber sleeves shall be provided for all manhole connections. Manhole covers to be used in the floodplains or adjacent to ditches or streets which could cause stormwater to enter the sanitary sewer shall be a bolt-down type (R-1077) or (R-1916-F). 
(9)  Applicability of water reclamation district requirements. Current Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago requirements shall apply, including but not limited to requirements for pipe slope and manhole spacing. All PVC pipe shall be deflection tested. All pipe shall be tested for infiltration. 
(10)  Connections to manholes. When a connection is within 12 inches of the manhole, sanitary services shall be connected directly to the manhole. All other connections shall be by wye connection and shall attach to the pipe with a gasket or glue and bonding. Maximum infiltration shall be 100 gal./in dia./mile/day, tested after building sewer connections are installed. 
(11)  Crushed stone bed. All sanitary sewer lines shall be placed in a prepared (shaped and compacted) bed of crushed stone. The ratio of the thickness of the crushed stone bed to the outside diameter of the pipe shall be not more than 1:4. Under no circumstances shall the bed be less than four inches. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-65), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-161. - Inspection notification. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit required under this division shall notify the building department when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-66), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-162. - Construction protection. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, trees, bushes, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner acceptable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-67), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-163. - Discharge of stormwater and unpolluted drainage. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the city engineer. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of the city engineer, to a storm or a natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-68), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-164. - Prohibited or restricted discharges. 
    For purposes of determining those materials or substances, the discharge of which into the public sewer are prohibited or restricted, and any required permits, referenced material published by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago or any other governmental body having jurisdiction are adopted by reference as though fully set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-69), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-165. - Industrial control manhole. 
    All commercial or industrial buildings shall be required to install an inspection manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole shall be accessible and safely located. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-70), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-166. - Industrial lab tests required. 
    The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes will be required to have a permit from the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago and may be required to provide laboratory measurements and analyses of waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this article and any special conditions for discharge established by the city or regulatory agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge. The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the owner shall be as stipulated by the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. The industry must supply a complete chemical and biological analysis of the components of the wastewater discharge to ensure the compliance with the federal, state, local and the other regulatory standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of measurements and laboratory analyses to the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago. The owner shall bear the expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting if required. At such times as deemed necessary, the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago reserves the right to take measurements and samples for analysis by an outside laboratory service. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-71), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-167. - Test standards. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of IEPA Division of Laboratories Manual of Laboratory Methods and shall be determined at the inspection manhole provided or upon suitable samples taken at the inspection manhole. If no special manhole has been provided, the inspection manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by scientifically accepted methods to reflect the effect on the sewer works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, health and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample should be taken. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-72), 8-27-1996) 
Sec. 110-168. - Access to premises. 
    The city engineer, the director of public works or any duly authorized employee of the city, the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago, the state or the United States Environmental Protection Agency bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurements, sampling, repair, maintenance and testing in accordance with this article. All premises lying within the corporate limits of the city, will pay $2.63 per ERU. The ERU is defined as 3,604 square feet of impervious surface area. 
(Ord. No. 96-43, § 2 (16-73), 8-27-1996; Ord. No. 03-80, § 1, 12-16-2003; Ord. No. 05-06, § 1, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 06-56, § 1, 11-28-2006) 
Secs. 110-169-110-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DRAINAGE IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, adopted March 23, 1999, set out provisions pertaining to the single family residential drainage improvement program. To maintain the numeric sequence of this chapter, these provisions have been included as §§ 110-181-110-185 at the discretion of the editor to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 110-181. - Program adopted. 
    The city hereby adopts a single-family residential property drainage improvement program to assist residential property owners in alleviating certain flooding conditions caused by deficient grading. The program is estimated to be available to approximately three to five improvements per year. 
(Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
Sec. 110-182. - Eligibility requirements. 
    Single-family residential properties in the single-family zoning districts shall be eligible for participation in the program if one or more inches of standing water remain on the property for a period of at least 48 hours of dry conditions following one-half or more inches of rain. Flooding caused by storm sewer obstruction, landscape improvements, sump pump discharge, misdirected downspouts or frost conditions shall not be a basis for eligibility. 
(Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
Sec. 110-183. - Work cost; city, owner contribution. 
    The city will contribute an amount equal to one-half of the direct costs associated with the work, not to in any event, exceed the amount appropriated by city council for any single drainage improvement in any fiscal year. The owner shall contribute the balance of any and all costs. 
(Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
Sec. 110-184. - Easement required. 
    As a condition to the city's participation, the city shall receive a ten-foot easement from the owner of record for future maintenance, repair and replacement of the drainage system. The easement area shall not be obstructed, improved or planted with bushes or trees. 
(Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
Sec. 110-185. - Contractor approval required by city. 
    The drainage work shall be bid by either the city, or the owners may contract for the work directly with a contractor, provided however, that the contractor is approved by the city. Final payment of the city's portion of the costs shall be paid only after inspection and approval of the work by the city. The city's responsibility for maintenance, repair or replacement is conditioned upon such inspection and approval by the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-13, § 1, 3-23-1999) 
DIVISION 6. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT FEE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-19, § 2, adopted June 12, 2001, states that this division shall be of no further force and effect on January 1, 2002 unless extended by the city council prior to January 1, 2002. The user of this Code is directed to section 110-191. 

Sec. 110-186. - Stormwater management fee. 
(a)  The base billing unit for the stormwater management fee is defined as the runoff generated by the "typical" single-family residence. The runoff will be measured in terms of mean or median square feet of impervious area defined as the "equivalent residential unit" (ERU). The ERU is the measure that will serve as an index to compare runoff generated by different types and uses of properties with different stormwater generation characteristics. The ERU is defined as 3,604 square feet of impervious surface area. The stormwater management fee per ERU is in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  There is hereby established a stormwater management fee for single-family detached residences and single-family attached residences (townhomes) at the rate set in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(c)  Properties other than single-family detached residences and single-family attached residences (townhomes) will be charged a stormwater management fee at the rate set in appendix B for each ERU, or fraction thereof, of impervious surface area of the property. (Example: a property consisting of 50,000 square feet of which 25,000 square feet is impervious would pay a stormwater management fee computed as follows: 25,000 square feet of impervious surface divided by the ERU (3,604 square feet) equals 6.9; the 6.9 ERU multiplied by the rate set in appendix B.) 
(d)  All premises lying within the corporate limits of the City of Rolling Meadows, will pay a rate set in appendix B per ERU. The ERU is defined as 3,604 square feet of impervious surface area. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 6-12-2001; Ord. No. 01-40, § 1, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 02-27, § 1, 5-28-2002; Ord. No. 02-90 § 1, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 04-84, § 1, 12-14-2004; Ord. No. 05-65, § 1, 12-6-2005; Ord. No. 07-49, § 1, 11-27-2007) 
Sec. 110-187. - Surcharge for users partially or completely outside of city limits. 
    All stormwater sewer users located partially or completely outside of the corporate limits shall pay a surcharge based on 50 percent of their monthly bill to enable the recovery of indirect expenses associated with the public works department, such as building, overhead, etc., which support the stormwater sewer system, which would otherwise be paid by property owners subject to real estate property taxation located within the corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 6-12-2001) 
Sec. 110-188. - Due date and delinquency penalty. 
    All stormwater management fee bills shall be due and payable during a period of 20 days from the date of any billing, and the date of the 20th day after billing shall appear on all bills. If any bill is paid after such period, there shall be added thereto a late charge of ten percent of the storm sewer management fee to be paid by any sewer user making a late payment. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 6-12-2001) 
Sec. 110-189. - Right to change rates and regulations. 
    The city reserves the right to make such reasonable changes in rates and in conditions established in this provision and to establish further rules and regulations from time to time as may be found expeditious or necessary. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 6-12-2001) 
Sec. 110-190. - Lien for unpaid charges. 
(a)  Charges for stormwater sewer service shall be upon the premises serviced. Whenever a bill for storm sewer service remains unpaid 30 days after it has become due, the director of finance may direct the city attorney to file with the recorder of deeds of the county a statement of lien claim or take other appropriate action, including but not limited to the use of a collection agency. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for the amount when due plus any and all charges for the storm sewer service subsequent to the period covered by the then-due bill. 
(b)  If the storm sewer user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the director of finance has notice of this, the notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known, whenever such bills remain unpaid for a period of 20 days after it has become due. 
(c)  The failure of the city to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid storm sewer maintenance fees. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid storm sewer management fee charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the charges, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to the stormwater management fee, after deducting costs, as the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosures shall be a bill in equity in the name of 
the city. The city attorney is authorized to institute such proceedings in the name of the city and in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which a stormwater management fee charge has remained unpaid and a statement of lien claim has been filed as set forth in this section and a period of 30 days has lapsed since such filing. 
(Ord. No. 01-19, § 1, 6-12-2001) 
Sec. 110-191. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-41, § 2, adopted November 25, 2014, repealed § 110-191, which pertained to a sunset clause and derived from Ord. No. 02-21, adopted May 14, 2002 and Ord. No. 06-56, adopted November 28, 2006. 
Secs. 110-192-110-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-196. - Hindering, obstructing, interfering with water system generally. 
    No person shall, in any manner, obstruct the access to any stopcock, hydrant or valve or any public faucet or opening for taking water in any street, alley, public ground or place connected with or part of the water system or pile or place any lumber, brick or building material or other article, thing or hindrance whatsoever within 12 feet of such or so as to in any manner hinder, delay or obstruct access to the water system. It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with or obstruct the flow, retention, storage or authorized use of water in the water system, reservoir or plant or any part thereof or to injure, deface, remove or displace any water main, hydrant, service pipe, shutoff box, public fountain, valve, engine or building connected with the water system or plant or to cause, suffer or permit any of the things to be done or to fail to allow the reading, repairing or replacement of meters at any and all reasonable times. Any person who shall perform any act in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, in addition to the penalties set forth in section 110-209, be liable for the actual damage done or caused. 
(Code 1967, § 23-8) 
Sec. 110-197. - Turning on hydrant or service cock without authority. 
    No person not duly authorized shall turn the water on at any fire hydrant or service cock or use water therefrom when so turned on, and the person so using or wasting water in such unlawful manner shall be liable to pay for the use. Any person who shall perform any act in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, in addition, be liable for the actual damage done or caused. 
(Code 1967, § 23-9) 
Sec. 110-198. - Furnishing water to others prohibited; permit required to change plumbing. 
    No water consumer may supply water to other families or allow them to take it, except for use on the premises and for the purposes specified in the application. After water is introduced into any building or upon any premises, no person shall make or employ any other person to make any tap or connection with the work upon the premises for alterations, repairs, extensions or attachments without a written permit therefor to be issued by the community development director. 
(Code 1967, § 23-10) 
Sec. 110-199. - Separate stopcocks required; crossing premises to adjoining premises. 
    No owner or plumber shall be permitted to conduct water pipes into any two distinct premises or tenements unless separate and distinct stopcocks shall be placed on the outside of such premises along the sidewalk opposite the premises, nor shall any pipe be allowed to cross lots or buildings to adjoining premises. 
(Code 1967, § 23-11) 
Sec. 110-200. - Valve vaults required. 
(a)  All valves on water mains having an internal diameter of four inches or more shall be enclosed within a valve vault. The vaults shall be constructed of Portland-type cement concrete, brick or concrete blocks, and the internal diameter of the vault shall be not less than 48 inches in diameter. Each such vault shall contain a cast iron frame and cover similar and equal to James B. Clow & Sons Suburban Standard No. F-3245. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of any premises containing a vault as required in this section to at all times maintain the vault and premises to allow for accessibility to the vault and ease of reading the meter therein. 
(c)  The owner shall be responsible for maintaining, repairing or replacing any damaged pipes or connection thereto located on the premises. 
(Code 1967, § 23-12) 
Sec. 110-201. - Ban on outdoor water use. 
(a)  The director of public works shall have the responsibility to implement a temporary or permanent water ban restricting any or all outdoor use due to a disruption or shortage of adequate water flow or major mechanical failure. The water ban restriction on outdoor water use shall include, but not be limited to lawn and garden watering or sprinkling; vehicle washing; washing of pavement, outside walls, walks, driveways or windows; or filling of swimming pools. 
(b)  From and after May 15 of each year, to and including September 15 of each year, no lawn sprinkling or irrigation, including but not limited to the use of automatic sprinklers or handheld hoses, attended or unattended of city water shall be permitted during the six-hour period in the middle of the day from 12:00 p.m. through 6:00 p.m. nor shall any such sprinkling or irrigation be permitted on any two consecutive days. New lawns (less than three months old) may be exempted from this provision. 
(c)  Landscapers, contractors and other persons with approved tank trucks or trailers for the transportation of water, with the intended use of lawn or landscape maintenance, cleanup or watering, shall fill their trucks or trailers at the department of public works or other location designated by the director of public works, only after issuance of a permit by the director of public works and payment of applicable fees. 
(d)  The restrictions contained in this section apply only to the city's public water supply system and not to private wells or water systems. 
(e)  Sections 110-207 and 110-209 of this article are applicable to violations of this section. 
(Code 1967, § 23-19; Ord. No. 15-47, § 1, 10-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 110-202. - Ownership of meters; meter maintenance. 
    The water meter shall at all times remain the sole property of the city, and the city shall furnish maintenance upon the meter. 
(Code 1967, § 23-20) 
Sec. 110-203. - Liability of city. 
    All connections and water applied for under this article and all the water used under this article shall be upon the express condition that the city shall not be liable nor shall any claim be made against it for damages or injury caused because of the breaking of any main, branches, service pipes, apparatus or appurtenances connected with the system or plant, any part or portion of the plant, or for any interruption of the supply because of the breakage of machinery or because of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals. 
(Code 1967, § 23-24) 
Sec. 110-204. - City's right to shut off water or concentrate or restrict use of water. 
    The city reserves the right to shut off water at any time in the mains for the purpose of repairing, cleaning, making connections with or extensions to the mains or for the concentrating of water in any part of the city in case of fire and for restricting the use of water for a deficiency in supply. No claim shall be made against the city for increasing the water pressure at any time or from concentration or restricted use of water as provided in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 23-25) 
Sec. 110-205. - Installation of new wells for use of groundwater as a potable water supply prohibited. 
(a)  Except for such uses or methods in existence before the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, the use or attempted use of groundwater as a potable water supply well by installation of wells, by use of existing wells as potable water supply wells, or by any other method is hereby prohibited, expressly including points of withdrawal by the city, within the area described in Exhibit A* and depicted in Exhibit B*, both of which are incorporated herein and made part hereof. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person violating the provision of this section shall be subject to a fine of up to $500.00 for each violation. 
(c)  Definitions. 
    Person is any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    Potable water is any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes, or preparing foods. 
(Ord. No. 01-52, §§ 1-3, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 08-39, § 1, 10-14-2008; Ord. No. 12-11, §§ 1-3, 2-28-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 01-52, §§ 1-3, adopted Dec. 18, 2001, which set out provisions pertaining to the prohibition of the installation of potable water supply wells did not specifically amend this Code. Hence, inclusion of said provisions as § 110-205 was at the discretion of the editor to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
 *Exhibits A and B were not included in the codification of this section and can be found in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 110-206. - Meter required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to connect any building, structure or premises or any part or addition thereto to the city water distribution system unless the connection supply or service is controlled by a water meter purchased from or approved by the city. 
(Code 1967, § 23-27) 
Sec. 110-207. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any member of the police department, fire department or public works department observing a violation of this article may issue a warning or citation to the violator on a form designated by the city manager. The citation shall: 
(1)  Advise the person that he has violated a specified section of this article. 
(2)  Request him to make payment to the city within seven days of the date of citation in an amount applicable to the alleged violation as set forth in this article. 
(3)  Inform him that, upon failure to so settle, a complaint will be filed in the circuit court charging him with such violation. 
(b)  The citation may be delivered to the violator personally or may be delivered to a member of the violator's household of the age of ten years or upwards or may be affixed to the main entrance to any building located upon the premises where the violation occurred. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge the power of a police officer to arrest any violator and take him into custody. 
(d)  If the person to whom the citation is issued fails to settle and pay the citation within the time prescribed, a complaint may be filed in the circuit court of the county for the alleged violation. 
(e)  The person appearing on the city's records for billing purposes shall be considered prima facie responsible for any violation occurring on the premises. 
(Code 1967, § 23-28) 
Sec. 110-208. - Restoration of service. 
    If the water to a metered premises is turned of for unpaid water charges, the fee for restoration of service shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 97-39, § 1 (23-30), 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-209. - Penalty. 
(a)  Schedule. The citation issued pursuant to this article may be paid in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(b)  Double penalty for delinquent payment. If payment has not been made on or before seven days of the date a citation is issued, the amounts for each offense shall be double. 
(c)  Court proceedings. Every person convicted of a violation of any of the sections of this article shall, on first conviction thereof, be punished in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. A separate and distinct offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1967, § 23-29; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-210. - Water use refund. 
    The city will consider a request to refund water use charges which were billed by the city and paid by the water user for a one year period immediately prior to receipt by the city finance department of a written request for refund setting forth the basis of the claimed refund and the amount requested to be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 05-04, § 1, 1-25-2005) 
Secs. 110-211-110-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 110-236. - Division established. 
    There is established a division of the public works department, an executive department of the city, to be known as the water division. 
(Code 1967, § 23-1; Ord. No. 98-09, § 57, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 110-237. - Supervision of division. 
    The water division shall be under the supervision of the public works director, who shall be charged with the responsibility for the operation, repair, and maintenance of the waterworks system. 
(Code 1967, § 23-2; Ord. No. 98-09, § 58, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 110-238. - Account required for service. 
    No water shall be turned on for use or in any premises until an account is established with the city finance department. 
(Code 1967, § 23-5; Ord. No. 98-09, § 59, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 110-239. - Deposit required. 
(a)  Every applicant desiring water service shall deposit with the city at the time application for water service is made a deposit to secure the payment in a timely manner of water used on the premises. If a default occurs in the payment of water charges, the deposit shall be applied to such default. The application by the city of the deposit to payment of past due water charges shall not prevent the city from using other remedies available to it in regard to delinquent accounts, including but not limited to termination of water services. The cash deposit for water users served by a five-eighths, three-fourths or one-inch meter shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. All other water users shall deposit cash, a letter of credit or other security for the payment of water charges as determined by the director of finance. It is the intent of the city that each water user deposit with the city an amount representing the highest monthly billing to the user on an annual basis. 
(b)  The deposit required at the time of application shall be determined by the director of finance based upon estimated consumption of water by similar type users. Thereafter, the director of finance shall annually review the deposit requirements to determine if the user's amount of deposit shall be increased or decreased to reflect the highest monthly water charge during the past year. 
(c)  The deposit requirements shall apply to new applicants and to existing users of the city's water service, except that existing residential users need not increase their present deposit even if they move from one residence to another within the city. All residential users shall be required to pay a deposit in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. As used in this subsection, the term "residential user" is defined as one dwelling unit being served by one meter. 
(Code 1967, § 23-6; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-240. - Disposition, investment of water deposits. 
(a)  All water deposits, as required in section 110-239, shall be maintained by the city director of finance in a fund to be known as the water fund. The city director of finance shall from time to time invest all or a portion of the fund in accordance with the investment policy adopted by the city council. 
(b)  A deposit must be released to the applicant at the earliest reasonable time, but in no case exceeding 45 days, after the applicant becomes entitled thereto. All earnings accruing on any investments on deposits made pursuant to this section shall be credited to the water division. 
(Code 1967, § 23-7; Ord. No. 98-09, § 60, 3-24-1998) 
Sec. 110-241. - Right to change rates and regulations. 
    The city reserves the right to make such reasonable changes in rates and in conditions established in this article and to establish further rules and regulations from time to time as may be found expeditious or necessary. 
(Code 1967, § 23-13) 
Sec. 110-242. - Rates within city. 
    There will be and there are hereby established rates or charges for the use of and for the service supplied by the waterworks system of the city to users whose premises lie entirely within the city, based on the amount of water consumed, as follows: 
    A two-tiered water rate structure and an access-to-water fee will apply to all water users in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 23-14; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 01-38, § 1, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 02-89, § 1, 12-18-2002; Ord. No. 03-79, § 1, 12-16-2003; Ord. No. 04-82, § 1, 12-14-2004; Ord. No. 05-62, § 1, 12-6-2005; Ord. No. 06-59, § 1, 11-28-2006; Ord. No. 07-46, § 1, 11-27-2007) 
Sec. 110-243. - Charges for consumers outside city. 
    All users of the waterworks system whose premises lie partially or completely outside the corporate limits shall be charged 50 percent additional to all rates listed and set forth in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 23-15) 
Sec. 110-244. - Due date of bills; delinquency penalty. 
    All water bills shall be due and payable during a period of 20 days from the date of any billing, and the date of the 20th day after billing shall appear on all bills. If any bill is paid after such period, there shall be added thereto a late charge of ten percent of the water bill to be paid by any water consumer making a late payment. 
(Code 1967, § 23-16) 
Sec. 110-245. - Billing periods established. 
(a)  Billing for the waterworks system shall be on a monthly basis. Bills for water service shall be rendered on or about the first day of the month immediately following the expiration of the monthly period for which service has been supplied or was available. 
(b)  Every other monthly bill may be based upon an estimated amount of water used by each owner/occupant, which estimate shall be made by the city. The amount of the bills for other periods shall be based upon an actual reading of the meter. 
(Code 1967, § 23-17) 
Sec. 110-246. - Connection fee required. 
    Any person intending to purchase city water must pay the city a connection fee as set by ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 23-18) 
Sec. 110-247. - Temporary use of water for building and construction purposes. 
(a)  A person desiring to use city water for building or construction shall make application therefor in writing and shall file the application in the office of the director of public works on a form prescribed for that purpose. 
(b)  The director of public works shall be responsible for the issuance of temporary use of water permits upon the following conditions: 
(1)  New developments. Installation of a temporary line into the development and a meter attached thereto. 
(2)  Other purposes. Installation at the dispensing point of the meter and/or satisfactory proof of tank truck capacity. 
(3)  Meter charges. The applicant shall be responsible for a deposit of the cost of the meter upon issuance of the temporary use of water permit. Upon return of the meter to the city, in good condition, the applicant shall be refunded his deposit less the amount of water used. Upon a permit being granted, the applicant shall pay 11/2 times the standard water rates as set by ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 23-21) 
Sec. 110-248. - Discontinuing service for nonpayment or violation. 
(a)  For a violation of any of the sections of this article or for the nonpayment of water bills for a period of 20 days, and for accounts with a past due amount greater than $250.00 for a period greater than 10 days after the bill is due, the director of public works has the right to turn off the water and to forfeit any payments made. Individuals or businesses owing the city money under this section shall have the right to a hearing with the city manager, or their designee, prior to water shut-off, who shall have the authority to negotiate payment terms. After the water has been turned off from any service pipe because of nonpayment of water bills or a violation of rules, the water will not be turned on until a current deposit is paid according to section 110-239, all delinquent bills and penalties are paid, together with any cost incurred by the city incident to the collection of the delinquent bill, including but not limited to charges for checks drawn against insufficient funds and certified letter costs, together with the labor cost for turning the water on and off, which shall not be less than $5.00. No water will be furnished to any person who is indebted to the city because of a required deposit, water consumed, materials or repair. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or prevent the city from turning off the water to any premises for the nonpayment of a water bill. 
(c)  The city shall impose a late notice posting fee of $20.00 for water disconnection notices posted on city utility billing account holders property which and are past due on their city of water billing accounts. 
(Code 1967, § 23-22; Ord. No. 08-34, § 2, 8-26-2008; Ord. No. 13-12, § 1, 3-26-2013) 
Sec. 110-249. - Lien for delinquent charges. 
(a)  Charges for water shall be a lien upon the premises served as provided by state statute. Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid 30 days after it has become due, the director of public works shall direct the city attorney to file with the recorder of deeds of the county a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for the amount then due plus any and all charges for water served subsequent to the period covered by the then-due bill. 
(b)  If the consumer of water whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the director of public works has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises, if his address is known to the director of public works, whenever such bill remains unpaid for a period of 20 days after it has become due. 
(c)  The failure of the city to record such lien claim or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid water bills as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Property subject to a lien for unpaid water charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the charges, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the water charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be a bill in equity in the name of the city. The city attorney is authorized to institute such proceedings, in the name of the city and in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which a water bill has remained unpaid, a statement of lien claim has been filed as set forth in this section and a period of 30 days has elapsed since the filing. 
(Code 1967, § 23-23) 
Secs. 110-250-110-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 110-276. - Plumbing installation. 
    All plumbing installed within the city shall be installed in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, 77 Ill. Adm. Code 890. 
(Code 1967, § 23-51) 
Sec. 110-277. - Surveys and investigations. 
    The public works director shall cause surveys and investigations to be made of properties served by the public water supply to determine whether any customers use water in a manner that creates an above-average potential for backflow or backsiphonage of contaminants into the water system. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years or as often as the public works director shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(Code 1967, § 23-52) 
Sec. 110-278. - Inspections. 
    For the purposes of this division, the public works director, in his sole discretion, may require that the water customer arrange and pay for an inspection to be conducted by a plumbing inspector licensed, as such, by the state, certified by the state environmental protection agency as a cross connection control device inspector and bonded to perform inspections in the city. The report of the inspector shall determine whether or not a backflow prevention device must be installed. The public works director shall immediately notify the water customer of the need for such device. 
(Code 1967, § 23-53) 
Sec. 110-279. - Installation of backflow prevention device. 
    The water customer shall, within 30 days of the notice given according to section 110-278, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location, in a manner and in accordance with the state plumbing code, the state environmental protection agency, and all applicable local regulations and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved device upon installation and annually thereafter by an inspector approved by the environmental protection agency and public works director at the customer's sole expense. The customer of the premises shall maintain records to document that testing, servicing, and repairs are conducted as required. 
(Code 1967, § 23-54) 
Sec. 110-280. - Connection of private water supply prohibited. 
    No person shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply, other than the regular public water supply of the city, enters the supply or distribution system of the city unless such private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved, in writing, by the public works director and the state environmental protection agency. 
(Code 1967, § 23-55) 
Sec. 110-281. - Rights of inspection. 
    The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter, at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the city for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections, and the public works director shall have the right to enter, at any reasonable time, any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the city for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessee, or occupant of any property so served shall furnish to the public works director any information which he may request regarding the piping system or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the public works director, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 23-56) 
Sec. 110-282. - Discontinuance of water service. 
    The public works director is authorized to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, water service to any property where a connection in violation of this division exists and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with this division and until a reconnection fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code is paid to the city. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected if imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of the reason for disconnection. 
(Code 1967, § 23-57; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 110-283. - Liability. 
    Neither the city nor its agents or assignees shall be liable to any water customer for any injuries, damages, or lost revenues which may result from termination of the customer's water supply in accordance with this division, whether or not the termination was with or without notice. 
(Code 1967, § 23-58) 
Sec. 110-284. - Contamination of water supply. 
    If contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an unlawful cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained, or repaired cross connection control device or a device that has been bypassed, the customer, from whose premises the contamination came, must bear the cost of cleanup and other costs resulting from contamination of the potable water supply system. 
(Code 1967, § 23-59) 
Sec. 110-285. - Adoption of rules by reference. 
    The city rules and regulations on cross connection control, as amended, shall be incorporated in this division by reference and shall be considered part of this division. 
(Code 1967, § 23-60) 
Sec. 110-286. - Permit required. 
    A permit is to be required for the installation of an approved cross connection control device. This permit shall be issued by the community development department, subject to fees applicable. 
(Code 1967, § 23-61) 
Sec. 110-287. - Records. 
    The public works director shall cause to be maintained a record system which shall contain all records of each property to which water is supplied, including but not limited to data on inspections, reinspections, repairs, alterations, tests. 
(Code 1967, § 23-62) 
Sec. 110-288. - Violations. 
(a)  The public works director shall deny or discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any premises wherein any cross connection control device required by this division is not tested, maintained and repaired in a manner acceptable to the public works director or it is found that the cross connection control device has been removed or bypassed or an unprotected cross connection exists on the premises. 
(b)  Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer has corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in compliance with this division and to the satisfaction of the public works director and until all applicable fees are paid. 
(Code 1967, § 23-63) 
Sec. 110-289. - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any section or provision of this division or who shall fail to comply after proper notice shall be punishable by a fine in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B to this Code. Each day the failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1967, § 23-64; Ord. No. 97-39, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Secs. 110-290-110-299. - Reserved.

Sec. 110-301. - Exemptions to payment of water installation connection fee. 
(1)  Where application is made for connection to the city water system by the owner or user of property located in a city approved recorded plat of subdivision or plan unit development and the owner of the subject property caused the extension of the public water main, no connection fee shall be required provided the actual connection to the water system for an individual lot takes place within three years of the date of recording the plat of subdivision or planned unit development. 
(2)  Where there is an existing contract, such as an annexation agreement or development agreement with the city, the annexation agreement, development agreement or other contractual arrangement with the city shall determine whether a water availability fee is required to be paid to the city for water service during the time the agreement is in effect. If the agreement is silent on the subject of water availability fees, the fee shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 04-07, § 2, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 05-16, §§ 1, 2, 4-12-2005) 
Sec. 110-302. - Properties subject to a recapture fee. 
    Any property which is subject to a recapture fee payable to the party installing the water main shall pay the city the installation connection fee as provided in section 110-300 less the recapture fee due the party installing the water main. 
(Ord. No. 05-16, § 2, 4-12-2005)

ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 00-36, § 1, adopted Aug. 8, 2000, repealed and replaced this div. 1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 114-26. - Statement of purpose. 
    The primary objective of the city government is to provide the citizens of Rolling Meadows a safe, prosperous, and healthy community in which to live and work. To consistently meet this objective requires the coordinated efforts of many individuals and municipal departments including those responsible for maintaining the infrastructure of the city. Components of this infrastructure include streets, sidewalks, sewers, buildings and trees. Healthy trees are unique in that they appreciate in value as they mature, unlike other components of the infrastructure that continually depreciate over time. 
    Trees provide a wide range of benefits to the city. Healthy trees reduce air and noise pollution, slow stormwater runoff, contribute to energy conservation through shade and protection from the wind, and significantly increase property values. Trees need sufficient soil, water, and air to survive. Protecting existing natural resources and planning for the establishment and care of new trees will enhance the economic and environmental health of the city. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote and protect public health and safety by providing for the proper establishment of new trees, the protection and maintenance of existing trees and the timely removal of hazardous or undesirable trees. 
(Ord. No. 00-36, § 1, 8-8-2000) 
Sec. 114-27. - Goals. 
    The provisions contained in the City Code are designed to yield specific goals when properly implemented. These goals include: 
(1)  Maintain a healthy urban forest. The urban forest of the city is a dynamic ecosystem comprised of trees, soil, water, air, wildlife and humans. Proper stewardship of the ecosystem is the most efficient and economical method of ensuring a safe and relatively hazard-free environment for the citizens of Rolling Meadows. 
(2)  Promote age and species diversity of the tree population. The long-term health of city' urban forest depends on a proper distribution of young, middle-aged and mature trees. Adequate stocking of variously aged trees ensures that as mature trees decline and are removed, younger trees are available to fill in the canopy. Species diversity is also important to guard against substantial losses to a species-specific pest or disease, such as Dutch elm disease. 
(3)  Improve species and site selection for new tree plantings. Increasing species diversity will only improve the urban forest if the species are matched with the site in which they are growing. Large trees provide the greatest benefits relative to energy conservation; air quality and storm water retention, but require sufficient space to reach their full size at maturity. Small trees can be used in a variety of places that are size restricted, however, if a space will accommodate a tree that achieves a larger size at maturity, the larger-growing species should be considered. The proper tree should be located according to the conditions of the site with consideration given to increasing canopy closure, maximizing environmental benefits and achieving consistency in the landscape design. 
(4)  Establish optimum canopy closure. Trees help to conserve energy by providing shade to buildings during the summer. Additional cooling can be realized by shading roads and parking lots that would otherwise absorb sunlight and radiate heat. Since the city is located in a climate where considerably more energy is spent on heating than cooling, consideration must also be given to the effect of shade on heating costs in the winter. Careful consideration of the establishment of new trees will result in the optimum canopy closure relative to energy conservation. 
(5)  Resolution and prevention of tree/hardscape conflicts through coordinated planning. Trees require space for roots, trunk, and branches. Frequently the space occupied by portions of trees is needed for other elements of the infrastructure such as roads, sewers, utility lines and buildings. Conflicts between trees and other infrastructure components can be minimized through cooperation of the various city departments, local utility companies and citizens. The provisions of this article are intended to facilitate communication and cooperation between those individuals and agencies charged with maintaining the city's infrastructure. 
(6)  Provide attractive and aesthetically pleasing transportation routes and open space. The city recognizes the benefits associated with the development of shade provided by trees along motor vehicle and bicycle routes in the community. The shade provides a cooling effect, which encourages physical activity, manifested by walking, jogging and bicycle riding. In addition, the beauty of a tree canopy adds charm and attractiveness to residential and commercial settings. 
(7)  Promote public education and support. The primary reason to care for trees and natural resources in the city is to improve the community for its citizens. The urban forest management program must be based on the informed support of the citizens. A goal of this article is to provide proper tree care through informed, professional management based on knowledge. Those city employees responsible for the management of natural resources in Rolling Meadows are also responsible for sharing their knowledge and sources of information with the public. 
(8)  Facilitate the resolution of tree-related conflicts. A goal of this article is to make available reasonable and fair guidelines for maintaining healthy, structurally sound and safe trees, and providing a comprehensive standards manual for planting, pruning and removing trees. By providing these guidelines in a clear and understandable format, equal and fair treatment is guaranteed for all residents. 
(Ord. No. 00-36, § 1, 8-8-2000) 
Sec. 114-28. - Home rule authority and severability. 
    It is the intent of this article to help coordinate the efforts of those responsible for the care of natural resources within the city by promoting ideas consistent with existing state and federal laws that may also be applicable. In the event that the provisions of this article conflict with the provisions of other existing codes or ordinances, the guidelines put forward in this document shall prevail within the borders of the city. 
    Should any part or provision of this chapter be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the chapter as a whole or any part other than the part held to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 00-36, § 1, 8-8-2000) 
Sec. 114-29. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
