Open terraces not over four feet above the average level of the adjoining ground, but not including a roofed-over terrace or permanently affixed awnings or canopies; steps, four feet or less abovegrade, which are necessary for access to a permitted building or for access to a zoning lot from a street or alley; chimneys projecting 24 inches or less into the yard; and flagpoles. Fences shall be permitted obstructions only when constructed in accordance with the requirements of the city's fence regulations. Open off-street parking spaces and driveways shall be permitted obstructions only when constructed in accordance with the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 of this Code relating to parking areas and driveways and when not specifically restricted by the regulations of a zoning district. 
(2)  Front yards. One-story bay windows projecting three feet or less into the yard; overhanging cornices, eaves, sills, gutters or similar architectural features projecting not more than 42 inches into the required yards; basketball backboards and standards that are ten feet from the side lot line. 
Covered attached porches per the following: 
a.  Encroachment is not to exceed six feet into the required front yard; 
b.  The encroachment portion is to be single story within 18 inches of grade; 
c.  May not be enclosed in any manner except by a railing not exceeding 42 inches in height; 
d.  The porch roof's architecture is to substantially conform to the house roof design and may not be metal canopy, awning, corrugated panel or similar materials; 
e.  Not to exceed more than 13 percent of the required front yard area. 
(3)  Rear yards. Accessory buildings, as defined in section 122-3 and subject to the limitations stipulated in section 122-10; balconies; breezeways and open porches; one-story bay windows projecting not more than 21/2 feet into the required yard; and overhanging cornices, eaves, sills, gutters or similar architectural features projecting not more than 42 inches into the required yards. 
(4)  Side yards. Overhanging cornices, eaves, sills, gutters or other similar architectural features projecting not more than 42 inches into the required yards. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 12), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 85-47, § 7, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 90-71, § 1, 11-27-1990; Ord. No. 03-39, § 1, 6-10-2003) 
Sec. 122-16. - Buildings on a zoning lot. 
    Every building erected or structurally altered to provide a single-family dwelling unit shall be located on the zoning lot, as defined in this chapter, and in no case shall there be more than one such building on one zoning lot. This section shall not apply to approved planned developments. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 13), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-17. - Moving of structures. 
(a)  No residential building or structure shall be moved into other territory already improved with residences to the extent of 75 percent of the land area contained within a radius of 300 feet of a new proposed location, unless such residential structure proposed to be moved shall be of approximately the same age, type of architecture and materials as the residential buildings and structures of at least 50 percent of the then-existing residential structures within such area, unless such building proposed to be moved shall be so repaired, altered and improved that it will conform to the majority of the other residential buildings within such area with respect to its general appearance, quality and value and with the provisions of the city building code so far as practicable, provided that the requirements of this subsection may be waived if there is obtained the consent of the owners of 75 percent of the area of all the lots either wholly or partially located within a radius of 300 feet of the outside lot lines of the property on to which such building is to be moved. 
(b)  No residential building or structure shall be moved into other territory not already improved with residences to the extent of 75 percent of the land area contained within a radius of 300 feet of the new proposed location, if such structure proposed to be moved is over 40 years old. Any proposed residential structure 40 years old or less may be moved into such territory if it shall be of approximately the same age, type of architecture and materials as the majority of the residential structures within such territory and if such building shall be so repaired, altered and improved that it will conform to a majority of the other buildings in such territory with respect to its general appearance, quality and value and shall comply in all respects with the city building code, provided that the requirements of this subsection may be waived if there is obtained the consent of the owners of 75 percent of the area of all the lots whether wholly or partially located within a radius of 300 feet of the outside lot lines of the property on to which such building is to be moved. 
(c)  No permit shall be issued for the moving of any building in accordance with the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section unless the applicant for such permit shall first have filed with the community development director complete plans and specifications covering the repairs, alterations and improvements to be made to such building for the purpose of making it conform to the applicable requirements of subsection (a) or (b) of this section, and unless such plans and specifications shall show compliance with such requirements. Before any permit shall be issued the applicant or owner of the premises onto which such building is proposed to be moved shall furnish cash bond in the sum of $10,000.00 or a surety bond in the sum of $10,000.00 indemnifying the city with surety approved by the mayor and city council, guaranteeing the completion of all repairs, alterations and improvements on such building according to such plans and specifications as approved within one year after the placing of such building in its new location, and providing, in case of failure to complete as state, for the removal of such structure from such premises. If such owner or applicant shall fail to remove such structure, the city shall have the right to remove the structure and to recover on such bond. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for the premises until all requirements of this subsection have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 14), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-18. - Agricultural exemptions. 
    This chapter shall not be exercised so as to impose regulations or require permits with respect to land used or to be used for agricultural purposes or with respect to the erection, maintenance, repair, alteration, remodeling or extension of buildings or structures used or to be used for agricultural purposes upon such land, except that such buildings or structures for agricultural purposes may be required to conform to building or setback lines. If the land ceases to be used solely for agricultural purposes, then and only then shall this chapter apply. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 15), 12-14-1972) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 122-19. - Floodplain reservation areas. 
    All development shall be constructed in compliance with the floodplain regulations in chapter 46 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 16), 12-14-1972) 
Cross reference- Floods, ch. 46. 
Sec. 122-20. - Building lines established by master plan and subdivision chapter. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this chapter, no building or structure shall be erected, constructed, structurally altered or enlarged closer to the centerline of an existing primary, major, secondary street or expressway than the distance specified in the city's master plan or chapter 98 of this Code pertaining to subdivision control in effect at the time of application for a building permit. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 17), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-21. - Nonconforming buildings and uses. 
(a)  Nonconforming buildings. 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  If a nonconforming use of any building or premises is discontinued or its normal operation stopped for a period of one year, the use of the building or premises shall thereafter conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(4)  No existing building or premises devoted to a use not permitted by this chapter in the district in which such building or premises is located, except when required to do so by law or ordinance, shall be enlarged, extended, reconstructed or structurally altered, unless such use is changed to one permitted in the district in which such building or premises is located. 
a.  Large retail and commercial buildings (not including office space). 
1.  Existing commercial and retail buildings in excess of 20,000 square feet and tenant spaces greater than 10,000 square feet within commercial or retail buildings shall be considered legal nonconforming uses and structures provided it is leased and occupied. 
2.  Existing legal nonconforming spaces that are vacant or without a commercial occupant for in excess of one year shall forfeit its legal nonconforming status and any future occupancy of the space must be pursuant to a special use in accordance with article V of this chapter. 
(b)  Nonconforming uses. The lawful use of land for junkyards, storage purposes and for advertising signs and billboards, which does not conform to this chapter, shall be discontinued within two years from the date of the approval of this chapter, and the same uses of land which become nonconforming by reason of subsequent change in this chapter shall also be discontinued within two years from the date of this change. 
(c)  Amortization. All other nonconforming uses, other than residential uses, shall be removed or the uses altered to eliminate, as applicable, the nonconformity within one year from the date of written notice from the community development department to the property owner or lessee that a nonconformity exists. 
(d)  Certificate of nonconformance. A certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule shall be required for the continuation of all nonconformities created by this chapter or any amendment thereto. 
(1)  When the community development director determines that a property has any nonconformity, the owner or lessee thereof shall be notified, in writing, of such nonconformity and of the regulations applicable thereto. 
(2)  Following receipt of the notice, the owner or lessee shall file with the community development director, within 60 days of the date thereof, either evidence that the property is not nonconforming or a completed application for a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule. 
(3)  The application shall require the applicant to submit information as required by the community development director to determine the applicable amortization period for the nonconformity. Upon timely receipt of a complete and accurate application therefore, the community development director shall, within ten working days, issue a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule for the nonconforming property. 
(4)  Failure to apply for a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule within 60 days of the notice provided for in this subsection will require the amortization of the nonconformance within six months of the notice provided for herein. 
(5)  Nonconforming uses that have obtained a certificate of nonconformance and amortization schedule from the community development director shall be discontinued within the amortization period specified therein for said use. 
(e)  Extended amortization periods. An owner or lessee of a nonconforming use may, within 60 days of the notice provided for herein, apply for an extended amortization schedule of up to five additional years. The owner or lessee shall state on the application that it is for an extended amortization schedule and shall set forth the reasons for pursuing the extended period. 
(1)  Upon receipt of a complete and accurate application for an extended amortization schedule, the zoning board of appeals shall schedule and hold not less than 15 days nor more than 45 days thereafter, a public hearing. At least 15 days in advance of the hearing, notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published at the applicant's expense in a newspaper of general circulation in Cook County and shall be posted on the road or street frontage of the property for which an application for a extended amortization schedule has been requested. In addition, notice of the hearing shall be sent to each civic or property owners' organization requesting notices of hearings on nonconformances; however, failure to notify a civic or property owners' organization so requesting such shall not place any liability whatsoever upon the city, nor shall such failure invalidate the legality of said hearing. 
(f)  Standards for extended amortization schedule. Approval and/or establishment of extended amortization schedules and instructions for issuance of extended amortization schedules based on applications therefore shall be granted by the zoning board of appeals only in accordance with the following standards. 
(1)  The degree of nuisance or other adverse effects each type of nonconformity creates; 
(2)  The size of the investment in the feature that creates the nonconformity and the relative ease and expense with which the nonconformity may be eliminated; 
(3)  The accelerated cost recovery system adopted in 1981 by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, which provides for a 15-year period during which investors in real property may recover the costs of their investment. 
(4)  No extended amortization schedule shall be approved or established unless the zoning board of appeals shall find: 
a.  The conditions upon which the application for the extended amortization schedule are based are unique to the property for which the extended amortization schedule is sought and are not applicable, generally, to other property within the same zoning classification. 
b.  That the period of amortization of the nonconformance will not be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort or general welfare. 
c.  That the nonconformance during the period of amortization will be not injurious to the use and enjoyment of other property in the immediate vicinity for the purposes already permitted, nor substantially diminish and impair property values within the adjacent neighborhood. 
d.  That the nonconformance during the period of amortization will not impede the normal and orderly development and improvement of surrounding property for uses permitted in the district. 
e.  That adequate utilities, access roads, drainage, and/or other necessary facilities have been or are being provided. 
f.  That adequate measures have been or will be taken to provide ingress and egress so designed as to minimize traffic congestion in the public streets. 
g.  That the nonconformance will conform to all other applicable regulations of the district in which it is located except those specific requirements directly relating to the nonconformance status of the property. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 18), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 00-04, § 2, 3-14-2000; Ord. No. 05-27, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 12-31, § 1, 9-11-2012) 
Sec. 122-22. - Signs. 
(a)  Specific prohibitions. The following signs are specifically prohibited by this chapter: 
(1)  Off-premises signs, except located in a business area, as defined in this chapter or if located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.), which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this chapter, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city. 
(2)  Attention-getting devices, unless they are specifically permitted by another section of this chapter. 
(3)  Flashing signs except time/temperature and electronic message boards, as specifically provided for in this Code. 
(4)  Projecting signs. 
(5)  Portable signs. 
(6)  Vehicle signs, including trailer-mounted signs. 
(7)  Painted wall signs. 
(8)  Any sign or sign structure which constitutes a hazard to public health or safety. 
(9)  Any sign which obstructs free ingress to or egress from a fire escape, door, window, or other required exitway. 
(10)  Signs which, because of size, location, content, coloring, or manner of illumination, obstruct the vision of drivers or obstruct or detract from the visibility or effectiveness of any traffic sign or control device on public streets and roads. 
(11)  Signs which make use of words such as "stop," "look," "one way," "danger," "yield," or any similar words or phrases, symbols, lights, or characters in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
(12)  Any sign which advertises a business no longer conducted or a product no longer sold on the premises where such signs are located, except if the sign is an approved off-premise sign located in a business area as defined by this Code. 
(13)  Signs on fences, trees, utility poles, or walls, which are not part of a building structure unless specifically permitted by the community development director for identification. 
(14)  Attention-getting devices, including searchlights, pennants, banners, propellers, spinners, streamers, balloons and similar devices, except for certain special occasions such as grand openings, first, fifth, tenth, 15th, etc., anniversaries, or as provided in the specific zoning district regulations, and then only after having obtained a permit from the director of building and zoning. Unless otherwise stated, the attention-getting device shall be limited to a 30-day maximum period. 
(b)  Signs not subject to permits or fees. The following types of signs shall not be subject to permit or fee requirements unless illuminated: 
(1)  Flags. Flags, symbols or crests of nations or an organization of nations, states, cities, fraternal, religious and civic organizations. Flags of corporations and businesses are exempt from permit if displayed from a ground mounted flag pole and the flag is not larger than 50 square feet in area. 
(2)  Informational signs. Signs directing and guiding automotive or pedestrian traffic on private property, but bearing no advertising matter. 
(3)  Institutional signs. Signs for public, charitable, religious institutions, where such are located on the premises of the institutions. 
(4)  Nameplates. Signs not exceeding two square feet in area bearing only names of occupants and or addresses of premises or other identification of premises not having commercial connotations. 
(5)  Public signs. Traffic, legal notices, identifications, informational, or directional signs erected or required by governmental bodies or authorized for a public purpose by any law, statute, or ordinance. 
(6)  Real estate signs. Signs for the sale, rental, or leasing of property when they are nine square feet or less in area. 
(7)  Open house, garage, or rummage sale signs. Open house, garage, or rummage sale signs are permitted subject to the terms and conditions of section 122-122(s). 
(8)  Window displays. Merchandise fixtures or models of products or services incorporated in a window display. 
(9)  Political campaign signs. Signs or posters announcing the candidates seeking public, political office and/or political issues, and data pertinent thereto up to an area of 12 square feet. Signs shall be displayed for no more than 60 days. Signs shall be removed within 48 hours after an election. Political signs shall not be permitted on public property. 
(10)  Window promotional signs. Signs not to exceed 50 percent of the total surface area of each window, for a period not to exceed 30 days. 
All other signs not listed in this subsection shall be subject to a permit fee. 
(c)  Permits required. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, alter, or locate any sign within the city without first obtaining a permit from the community development department and paying the fee required. The routine maintenance or changing of parts is permissible, provided that such change does not alter the surface area, height, copy, or otherwise make the sign nonconforming. 
(2)  Fees as prescribed by this code are hereby waived for organizations and entities that are chartered as not-for-profit and have been determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be exempt from taxation pursuant to Sections 501(c)(3) or 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(d)  Application for sign permit. Application for a sign permit shall be made upon forms provided by the community development department, shall be signed by the applicant, and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  Location of the building structure or lot to which or upon which it is to be attached or erected. 
(3)  Location of the sign upon the lot, and the copy of the sign. 
(4)  The size and height of the sign. 
(5)  Two blueprints or ink drawings of the plans and specifications, and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground. 
(6)  If required by the community development director, a copy of stress sheets and calculations showing that the structure is designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction, in the amount required by this chapter and all other city laws and ordinances. 
(7)  The name of the person erecting the sign. 
(8)  Written consent of the owner of the building structure or land on which the sign is to be erected. 
(9)  Any electrical permit required for this sign. 
(10)  Insurance policy or bond as required by this chapter and the community development director. 
(11)  Such other information that the community development director shall require to show full compliance with this chapter and all other city ordinances. 
(e)  Issuance of sign permit. It shall be the responsibility of the community development director, upon the filing of an application for a sign permit, to examine such plans and specifications and other data related to the erection of the sign and sign structure. If it shall appear that the proposed sign and sign structure is in compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and all other city ordinances, the permit will then be issued. If the work authorized under the permit has not been completed after six months after the date of issuance, the permit will become null and void. 
(f)  Sign permit and inspection fees. The fees for a permit to install and for inspection, annual inspection and a permit to alter a sign shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. 
(g)  Revocation of sign permits. All permits acquired under this section or any amendment thereto are mere permits, revocable at any time by the community development director. All such permits shall be subject to this subsection. 
(h)  Identification. Every sign erected, which requires a permit, shall have a permanent identification number either painted or attached in a conspicuous place thereon. The identification number shall be the same as the sign permit number. 
(i)  Illuminated signs. 
(1)  All illuminated signs shall be wired in accordance with regulations as prescribed by the city electrical code. 
(2)  Gooseneck reflectors and lights shall be permitted on ground signs and wall signs; provided, however, that any such light installed shall only be in such manner that direct rays of such light shall be concentrated on the sign and shall be prevented from causing a glare on or striking the streets or nearby property, or the reflector shall be provided with proper glass lenses concentrating the illumination upon the area of the sign so as to prevent a glare on the street or nearby highway. 
(3)  In no case shall the lighting intensity of any sign exceed the limit of 75 footcandles, with a standard light-meter, perpendicular to the face of the sign, at a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of the sign. 
(4)  Illuminated signs with revolving or rotating beams or beacons are not permitted. 
(5)  Illuminated signs, with the exception of residential identification signs, located on a lot adjacent to, across the street from, or in the next use district to any residential districts shall be turned off and not operated between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., unless the premises on which or for which the sign is specifically operating is engaged in the operation of its business, in which event the sign shall not be operated past the hour of 1:00 a.m. 
(6)  No illumination shall be permitted which will increase the surrounding brightness at any residential property line more than one footcandle. 
(7)  Signs which are illuminated shall have lamps, tubes and other light Emitting devices that are in good working order. Signs with partially working lights shall not be illuminated. 
(j)  Construction requirements. All signs shall be constructed to withstand a wind pressure of 30 pounds per square foot and shall be in compliance with the BOCA National Building Code. 
(k)  Required maintenance. The permittee or owner of any sign, other advertising structure, canopy, or awning, as defined in this chapter, shall maintain in good condition all parts and supports of such sign. In order to prevent rust, rotting, or other deterioration, it shall never be the function of maintenance to reinstall a sign or change the size, height, or copy of a sign. 
(l)  Permit to alter sign. Whenever a holder of a permit desires to enlarge or alter the display surface of a sign, he shall be required to submit an application for a new permit and pay the full fee therefor. No refund or credit shall be given for fees previously paid, and the existing permit will be canceled and a new permit issued. 
(m)  Nonconforming signs. Any sign lawfully existing or under construction on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives which does not conform to this section may be continued or maintained, but may not be replaced, structurally altered, reestablished if discontinued, or continued if destroyed or damaged to the extent of 50 percent or more of its own replacement value at the time the damage occurred. 
(n)  Public hearing for variance requests. 
(1)  As part of the required notification process, all petitioners shall be required to post a sign, three feet by three feet in size, with a white background and black lettering, on each frontage of the subject property. Such sign shall be mounted and provided by the department of public works for a $100.00 fee per sign, refundable upon return of the sign in reasonable condition. All signs regarding public hearings shall be posted no more than 30 days and no less than 15 days before the requested hearing. 
(2)  After the close of the public hearing, the planning and zoning commission, by a majority vote of a quorum, may affirm, annul, or modify the order or action of the public works director or his designee, and the planning and zoning commission shall recommend to the city council that it grant or deny the variance requested together with any recommendations or conditions it may wish the city council to impose. 
(3)  The city council may accept, reject, or modify the findings and recommendations of the planning and zoning commission and may grant or deny a variance to this section as it may determine. The decision of the city council shall be final and binding on all parties. 
(o)  Variances. 
(1)  The corporate authorities may vary the application of this section in harmony with its general purpose and intent, in accordance with the procedure set forth in this subsection, where there are practical difficulties or particular hardship in the way of carrying out the strict letter of any of the subsections of this section. Any such variance shall be granted only by the adoption of an ordinance by the corporate authorities after a public hearing before the planning and zoning commission as provided in this section. 
(2)  A variance may be granted only when special circumstances involving size, shape, topography, location or surroundings affect the property referred to in the application and the sign would not cause substantial injury to the value of other property in the vicinity or be detrimental to the public safety or welfare in the neighborhood in which it is located. 
(3)  Variances may be granted only by ordinance passed by at least a majority vote of the city council after an application for a variance has been submitted to the planning and zoning commission and after publication a hearing is scheduled and held by the planning and zoning commission and its findings and recommendations are reported to the city council as provided in this section. 
(4)  The planning and zoning commission may recommend and the city council may provide such conditions and restrictions upon the construction, location and use of any sign for which a variance is granted as may be deemed necessary to promote the general objectives of this chapter, and to minimize any injury to persons or property in the neighborhood. Failure to maintain such conditions or restrictions as may have been imposed shall constitute grounds for revocation of the authorizations for such variance, whereupon the permittee or owner shall promptly bring the sign into compliance with this chapter or remove the sign. 
(5)  All requests for variances in the requirements set forth in this section or appeals from any rulings of the public works director or his designee shall be directed to the planning and zoning commission by serving written notice on the public works director or his designee who, in turn, shall immediately transmit the notice to the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission shall set a public hearing date for the appeal or request for variance within 30 days thereafter. The public works director or his designee shall take no further action on the matter pending the commission's decision, except for unsafe signs which present an immediate and serious danger to the public. 
(6)  The filing fee for each application for sign variance shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. 
(7)  All actions of the city council taken under this section shall be construed as administrative actions for the purpose of ensuring that inequities in specific situations may be avoided by granting a variance and shall not be construed as amendments to this chapter unless otherwise provided by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 19), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 78-11, § 2, 7-25-1978; Ord. No. 81-18, § 2, 4-28-1981; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 8, 9, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 87-12, § 2, 4-14-1987; Ord. No. 88-35, § 3, 5-10-1988; Ord. No. 88-42, § 3, 6-28-1988; Ord. No. 90-77, §§ 3-6, 12-26-1990; Ord. No. 92-13, § 10, 2-25-92; Ord. No. 93-07, §§ 6, 7, 2-23-1993; Ord. No. 97-40, § 1, 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 97-66, § 1, 8-12-1997; Ord. No. 99-09, §§ 2-9, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 17-19, § 23, 6-13-2017; Ord. 18-02, §§ 1, 2, 1-9-2018) 
Sec. 122-23. - Screening and landscaping. 
(a)  In all zoning districts, except R-1, R-2, R-5 and R-6, off-street parking facilities shall be screened on each side and rear lot by a fence or wall of planted shrubbery not less than six feet in height, plus a planted strip of shrubbery not less than four feet in width in accordance with this subsection or according to an alternate arrangement approved by the planning and zoning commission. Landscaping and ground cover of grass or shrubs shall be provided and maintained on a continuing basis within the planted strip. At least one tree of not less than three-inch diameter size class shall be provided for every 1,500 square feet of pavement area up to 6,000 square feet. At least one tree of not less than three-inch diameter size class shall be provided for every 3,000 square feet of pavement area over 6,000 square feet. These trees shall be planted in islands of sufficient size, in paved areas, to maintain the trees' growth. 
(b)  The selection of trees, hedges, shrubs, ground cover, and other planting materials shall be approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 20), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 778, § 1, 8-10-1976; Ord. No. 91-71, §§ 5, 6, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 03-62, § 1, 10-14-2003; Ord. No. 17-19, § 24, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 122-24. - Walls, fences and screens. 
(a)  Height restrictions for vehicular movement across pedestrian ways. Planted screens or hedges shall not exceed three feet in height where location is such that sight lines are necessary for vehicular movement across pedestrian ways. 
(b)  Permitted materials for fences and walls. Fences or walls may be constructed with any of the following materials and shall be made of the same material on both sides; materials other than those that follow shall be subject to the approval by the community development director: 
(1)  Fences: 
a.  Wood (board, panel or picket). 
b.  Concrete (panel). 
c.  Metal (wrought iron or panel). 
(2)  Walls: 
a.  Concrete (plain or textured). 
b.  Brick (plain or glazed). 
c.  Tile or architectural block. 
d.  Stone (natural, block stone or rubble stone). 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. V, § 21), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 778, § 1, 8-10-1976) 
Sec. 122-25. - Screening of receptacles for garbage, refuse and grease. 
(a)  Any property which is located in any zoning district (except detached dwellings or townhouses were the refuse container serves only one dwelling unit), shall screen all garbage, refuse and grease receptacles where the receptacle is located adjacent to or across a right-of-way from R-1, R-2, R-4 or R-5 zoning district. 
(b)  A garbage, refuse or grease receptacle required to be screened as provided in subsection (a) shall be considered screened if one of the following apply: 
(1)  The receptacle is located within an enclosure complying with subsection (c), or 
(2)  The receptacle is not visible from, or is set back at least 150 feet from a public right-of-way and a screening fence at least six feet in height is erected adjacent to adjoining residential property and such fence screens the receptacle from view from adjoining residential property, or 
(3)  The community development director determines that the property owner has demonstrated that the receptacle's placement results in meeting this section's intent. 
(c)  The screening enclosure for a receptacle shall comply with the following and requires the approval of the community development director. 
(1)  The screening shall be compatible with the color, material and texture of the building. 
(2)  The screening shall be one or more of the following types of materials: 
a.  Solid stockade or solid decorative wooden fencing; 
b.  Face brick wall; 
c.  Decorative concrete block wall; 
d.  Reinforced wall with applied decorative finish; or 
e.  Dense evergreen living shrubs. 
(3)  The height shall be sufficient to screen the entire receptacle from view, but not to exceed eight feet in height. 
(4)  The enclosure shall have at least three sides unless the receptacle remains visible from adjoining property or the street in which case is shall have a gate that is architecturally compatible with the enclosure and provide a sufficient screen. The gate shall remain closed when not in use. 
(d)  All garbage, refuse or grease receptacles existing at the time of the adoption of these provisions shall comply with the provisions hereof, within two years, except as extended by the planning and zoning commission upon appeal. 
(e)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the public works director or his designee may appeal that decision to the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission, after a public hearing, may affirm or reverse the decision of the public works director or his designee. If the decision of the planning and zoning commission is to affirm the decision of the public works director or his designee, an appeal may be made to the city council. Any appeal of a decision of the public works director or his designee or planning and zoning commission shall be filed with the public works director or his designee within 30 days of the date of the decision of the public works director or his designee or planning and zoning commission. Upon receipt of an appeal the public works director or his designee shall notify the planning and zoning commission or the city council of the appeal and cause the appeal to be placed upon the agenda of the planning and zoning commission or city council at their next available meeting. 
(Ord. No. 99-16, § 1, 3-23-1999; Ord. No. 17-19, § 25, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 122-26. - Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. 
(a)  Any property required by the applicable use district or planned development provisions of this Code to have pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall provide such facilities in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Already developed zoned lots and parcels five acres or more in size and not designated as a planned development or special use which are reconfiguring or altering more than 50 percent of the site and/or parking areas shall provide pedestrian and bicycle facilities in as much to meet the intent of this section as approved by the community development director. 
(c)  Pedestrian walkways and bicycle paths shall be either combined or separate. 
(1)  Combined walkway paths shall be a minimum eight feet in width with a center stripe. 
(2)  Separate walkway/paths shall be a minimum of five feet in width. 
(3)  Walkways and paths shall connect the public way (public street, sidewalk or both) and the main access to the building(s) or use. Developments five acres or more in size and bounded by more than one public street shall have walkways and paths from each street. 
(4)  Walkways and paths shall be separated from parking areas by a barrier except at driveways and aisle intersections. Barriers are defined as an approved object or approved method, which prohibits access of a motor vehicle, such as curbs, bumpers, posts, trees, planters or fence. 
(5)  Walkways and paths shall be accessible to the disabled as required by applicable law. 
(6)  Design and construction of walkways and paths and related appurtenances shall be approved by the community development director and city engineer and shall substantially conform to the Guide for the Development of Bicycle Facilities, 1999 Edition, as published by the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials or other standard as specifically approved by the community development director and the city engineer. 
(d)  Bicycle parking facilities shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  The number of bicycle parking spaces provided shall be in accordance with the following: 
Type of Use Minimum No. of Spaces (at least one) Primary and Secondary School 10% of the number of students Shopping Centers, Restaurants and Office Buildings 3% of the number of automobile spaces Sports and Recreation Center 10% of the number of automobile spaces Manufacturing 1% of the number of automobile spaces Multifamily Dwellings One space per four dwelling units Other Uses As determined by the community development director  
(2)  Bicycle parking facilities shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the following: 
a.  Class III facilities shall be provided and have at least a 24 inch clearance from the centerline of each adjacent bicycle and at least 18 inches from walls or other obstructions. 
b.  An aisle or other space shall be provided to bicycles to enter and leave the facility. This aisle shall have a width of at least five feet to the front or the rear of a standard six-foot bicycle parking in the facility. 
c.  Parking facilities shall support bicycles in a stable position without damage to wheels, frame or components. Facilities designed for hanging or vertical storage of bicycles shall not satisfy the requirements of this chapter. 
d.  Bicycle parking should be situated at least as conveniently as the most convenient parking area. Bicycle and vehicle parking areas shall be separated by a physical barrier or sufficient distance to protect parking bicycles from damage by vehicles. 
e.  Paving of bicycle parking areas is required. 
f.  Convenient access to bicycle parking facilities shall be provided. Where access is via a sidewalk or pathway, curb ramps shall be installed where appropriate. 
g.  The community development director shall have the authority to review and approve the design of all bicycle parking facilities required by this chapter with respect to safety, security and convenience. 
(e)  Appeals. Any person may appeal the provisions of the Code related to pedestrian and bicycle facilities or decision about same by the public works director or his designee. Such appeal shall be before the planning and zoning commission and after public hearing the commission shall accept, reject or accept with modifications the appellant's request or affirm or reverse the decision of the public works director or his designee. If the appellant is aggrieved by the planning and zoning commission's decision, an appeal may be made to the city council and such appeal must be filed with the public works director or his designee within 30 days of the planning and zoning commission decision. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 1, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 17-19, § 26, 6-13-2017) 
Editor's note- Section 14 of Ord. No. 02-04, adopted Feb. 12, 2002, states that the provisions pertaining to pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall be of no further force and effect from and after 18 months from the effective date thereof, unless extended by action of the city council prior to the expiration of the 18 months. 
Sec. 122-27. - Outdoor business activities. 
(a)  Any property conducting an outdoor business activity permitted by the applicable use district shall do so in accordance with this section and other applicable sections of this Code. Outdoor business activities include the sale, display, and/or storage of material or product not within a wholly enclosed building. 
(b)  Outdoor business activity shall be designated as permanent or temporary. 
(c)  A permanent outdoor activity is that which remains in effect beyond the allowable maximum duration designated for temporary business activities. Permanent outdoor activities include the following: 
Material storage 
Product storage 
Landscaping material and plants display and storage 
Equipment and machinery parking and storage 
Farm stands 
Construction material storage 
(1)  Approval shall be by the city council in accordance with the requirements of Article V, Special Use or Article IV, Planned Developments. 
(2)  Permanently placed vending machines, refrigeration and storage cabinets and ice machines, each not exceeding a volume of 120 cubic feet shall not require city council approval provided the following: 
a.  The maximum number permitted is one per 5,000 square feet of lot area but not more than six total. 
b.  Placement must be adjusted to the wall of the principal structure. 
(3)  A zoning permit issued by the community development department is required for each activity. The fee for said permit shall be as prescribed by appendix B of this Code. 
(4)  The use of permanently parked vehicles, semi-trailers, truck bodies and drop storage containers is prohibited. 
(d)  A temporary outdoor business activity is that use described hereafter and is for a duration within the time limits prescribed. Conditions applicable to all temporary outdoor business activities are as follows: 
(1)  A product or use not specifically listed or those that are proposed for a duration exceeding the allowed maximum shall only be by specific approval of the city council. 
(2)  A permit issued by the community development department is required for each structure, activity or event. The fee for said permit shall be as prescribed by Appendix B of this Code. 
(3)  All material or product stored and displayed must be maintained in a neat, orderly and clean manner. 
(4)  Seasonal sales and displays not within a temporary shelter or tent and open to the sky are allowed only for potted plants, bagged landscape material, arts and crafts and retail products normally found within the premises' building, and holiday trees and decorations with the following conditions: 
a.  Must not occupy more than two percent of the lot area or 3,000 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  Packaged material shall be stacked in a safe manner and be not higher than five ft. 
c.  The duration shall be for not more than 120 days per calendar year. With any one storage or display period not exceeding 90 days. 
d.  Shall not occupy more than 20 percent of the required parking area and not obstruct any parking designated for the disabled. 
e.  The location and arrangement is subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(5)  Seasonal sales and displays within a temporary tent or structure or under a fixed canopy are allowed for the following: potted plants, bagged landscape material, arts and crafts and other retail products normally found within the premises' building, holiday tree and decorations with the following conditions: 
a.  Must not occupy more than 1% of the lot area or 1,500 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  Packaged material shall be stacked in a clean, safe and orderly manner and be not higher than five ft. 
c.  The duration shall not be more than 120 days per calendar year with any one storage or display period not exceeding 90 days. 
d.  Shall not occupy more than ten percent of the required parking and not obstruct parking for the disabled. 
e.  The location and arrangement is subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(6)  Sidewalk sales are allowed as follows: 
a.  Must be operated by the business such sale is fronting. 
b.  The square foot area occupied by the sale (tables, racks, etc.) is not to exceed two times the width of the store or business fronting the sidewalk. 
c.  Location and arrangement is subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
d.  The duration is not to exceed eight days per month and 32 days per calendar year. 
(7)  Temporary automobile or boat sales are allowed as follows: 
a.  Such sale must have specific approval of the city council. 
b.  The area occupied is not to exceed two percent of the lot area or 5,000 square feet, whichever is less. 
c.  Occupy not more than ten percent of the required parking and not obstruct parking designated for the disabled. 
d.  Location and arrangement is subject to the review and approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
e.  The duration shall not exceed ten days per event not more than 30 days total per calendar year. 
f.  Two signs not exceeding 100 square feet in area each shall be permitted subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(8)  Festivals, parties, entertainment and promotional events are allowed subject to the following: 
a.  Not to exceed more than three percent of the lot area or 10,000 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  Not to occupy more than ten percent of the required parking and not obstruct parking designated for the disabled. 
c.  The location and arrangement is subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
d.  The hours of operation are subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
e.  The duration is not to exceed four consecutive days or a total of eight days per calendar year. 
f.  One sign not exceeding 100-square feet in area shall be permitted to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
g.  Must be sponsored and/or operated by a business permanently located on the premises. 
(9)  Amusements such as carnivals and circuses are allowed subject to following: 
a.  The area occupied shall not be more than 15 percent of the lot area or 65,000 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  Shall not occupy more than 30 percent of the required parking or obstruct parking designated for the disabled. 
c.  The duration shall not exceed 11 consecutive days or a total of 22 days per calendar year. 
d.  Two signs not exceeding 100 square feet each shall be permitted subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(10)  The following special activities are allowed in residential districts: church festivals, church seasonal sales, festivals and fundraisers in public parks, subject to the following: 
a.  The location, arrangement and duration are subject to the approval of the community development director and his/her designee. 
b.  Two signs not exceeding 100 square feet each shall be permitted subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(11)  Temporary storage trailers and drop storage containers are allowed only as follows: 
a.  Maximum number allowed is one per acre of land or fraction thereof with a maximum of six each not to exceed 4,160 cubic feet in volume. 
b.  Duration is limited to 60 consecutive days not to exceed 120 days per calendar year. Exception, in residential districts where the maximum is 11 consecutive days per calendar year. 
c.  The location, arrangement and contents of the storage trailer or container are subject to the approval of the community development director or his/her designee. 
(12)  Temporary seasonal outdoor seating. 
a.  Temporary seasonal outdoor seating areas not requiring a special use. A special use shall not be required for temporary seasonal outdoor seating if the following conditions are satisfied: 
1.  Does not require the construction of a patio or other similar structure to accommodate the outdoor seating area; 
2.  Does not exceed seating for 12; 
3.  Does not serve alcohol; 
4.  Will not require additional parking; and/or 
5.  Meets the proposed general regulations for outdoor seating as set forth below. 
All requests for a permit for temporary seasonal outdoor seating not requiring a special use shall be reviewed annually by the community development director or his or her designee. The fee for said permit shall be as prescribed by appendix B of this Code. 
b.  Temporary seasonal outdoor seating area requiring a special use. A special use shall be required for temporary seasonal outdoor seating if the following conditions apply: 
1.  Requires the construction of a patio or other similar structure to accommodate the outdoor seating area; 
2.  Allows for seating in excess of 12; 
3.  Serves alcohol; and/or 
4.  Does not meet the proposed general regulations for all temporary seasonal outdoor seating as set forth below. 
c.  General regulations for all temporary seasonal outdoor seating areas. The following regulations shall apply to all outdoor seating areas: 
1.  All requests for outdoor seating shall be submitted to the community development department for review. A plot plan shall be submitted that clearly identifies the area to be used for outdoor seating in relation to the existing restaurant and all tables, chairs, waste containers and other items shall be clearly marked and to scale. 
2.  An annual permit shall be obtained for all outdoor seating areas. 
3.  The outdoor seating area shall be incidental to the operation of a restaurant, appropriately located on the premises and adequately landscaped as determined necessary by the director of community development or his/her authorized designee. 
4.  All outdoor seating areas shall be placed on an all-weather hard surface area. 
5.  The outdoor seating area shall be immediately abutting the principal building and the space which is occupied by the restaurant. 
6.  All outdoor seating areas shall comply with current life, safety, health and exit code requirements adopted by the city as now existing or hereafter amended. 
7.  Seating may be located on sidewalks or pedestrian walkways (public or private) provided that five feet of the sidewalk or walkway remains unobstructed. 
8.  If seating is provided on public property, the following shall apply: 
i.  The applicant shall submit a hold harmless agreement which indemnifies the city from any and all liability that may arise relating to the outdoor seating activity. 
ii.  The applicant shall submit evidence of general liability and dram shop insurance (if required), in an amount acceptable to the city. The policy shall include the city as a named insured and insuring the city against any liability resulting from the operation of the outdoor seating. The minimum coverage shall be at least $1,000,000.00 for general liability insurance and $300,000.00 dram shop insurance and shall have no less than an "A" rating by the most recent AM Best Insurance Guide. 
iii.  All maintenance of the public right-of-way associated with the operation of the outdoor seating area shall be the responsibility of the owner of the restaurant (upkeep includes the replacement of damaged public property, etc). 
9.  All seating shall be a minimum of five feet from any drive aisle or point of vehicular access. 
10.  The seating shall not occupy or interfere with the use of required parking spaces, aisles, driveways, fire lanes and fire exits. 
11.  The seating shall not occupy or interfere with the use of building entrances, exits and pedestrian walkways. 
12.  Music shall remain at a conversational level and be discontinued by 10:00 p.m. 
13.  Exterior lighting shall be inwardly directed so that no direct lighting is cast off-premises. 
14.  Hours shall be limited to 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. on Friday and Saturday. 
15.  Outdoor seating areas shall be permitted from April 1 to November 1. 
16.  All tables, chairs and other items are to be removed at the end of the permitted time period and not stored outside. 
17.  All furnishings shall be durable, kept in a neat, orderly and clean condition. 
18.  Outdoor furnishings and their color should be selected for harmony and aesthetic quality with the adjoining buildings and streetscape and be capable of withstanding a wind force of 30 mph. Materials shall be of durable quality such as wrought iron and not plastic, aluminum or other light gauge material. 
19.  Outdoor seating which does not exceed seating for 12 and/or include the construction of a patio or other similar structure for placement of seating shall not require additional parking. 
20.  Any other conditions deemed necessary by the city manager to protect the public health, safety and welfare may be imposed. 
d.  Regulations for outdoor seating areas serving alcohol. The following regulations shall apply to all temporary seasonal outdoor seating serving alcohol: 
1.  All outdoor seating areas where alcohol is served shall require a special use. 
2.  All outdoor seating areas where alcohol is served shall meet the general regulations for all temporary seasonal outdoor seating areas as set forth in this section. 
3.  Access to the outdoor seating area shall be directly from the restaurant or through an outdoor entry which must be staffed by an employee at all times. 
4.  A fence or similar barrier shall be provided around any outdoor seating area where alcohol is served. The fence shall include a self latching gate with a sign stating "NO ALCOHOL BEYOND THIS POINT." 
5.  Sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be restricted by the liquor license governing the restaurant. 
6.  Liquor license ordinance violations occurring on the premises, including the outdoor seating area, shall be considered sufficient basis for the city manager to revoke the outdoor seating area permit. 
(Ord. No. 04-08, § 1, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 09-38, §§ 1, 2, 11-10-2009) 
Secs. 122-28-122-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 122-51. - Enforcing officer. 
    The community development director of the city is designated to enforce this chapter and, in furtherance of this authority and in addition to the duties designated to him under the building code and other ordinances, he shall: 
(1)  Receive applications for building or erection permits for the construction, erection, alteration, enlargement and removal of buildings, structures and signs; receive applications for occupancy permits for the development or improvement of any premises for a parking lot, open sales lot, or other purposes where a building permit is not required; issue permits applied for as soon as practicable where the plans are found to comply with this chapter and all other laws and ordinances applicable thereto; make and maintain records thereon; 
(2)  Receive applications for certificates of use and occupancy for buildings, structures and signs for which building or erection permits have been issued and which have been constructed, erected, altered, enlarged or moved in accordance with such permits and are developed or improved as a parking lot, open sales lot, certificates of use and occupancy for any premises developed or improved as a parking lot, open sales lot, or other purposes where a building permit is not required; issue certificates of use and occupancy applied for within ten days after written application is filed; 
(3)  Receive affidavits and applications for certificates of use and occupancy for buildings, structures and land which become nonconforming as to use under this chapter; issue certificates of use and occupancy within ten days after written applications are filed where the use and occupancy of the buildings, structures and land are subject to elimination or, if found subject to elimination, certificates shall be issued only for such periods of time as are authorized by this chapter; 
(4)  Conduct inspections of buildings, structures, signs and uses of any premises to determine compliance with the terms of this chapter; 
(5)  Maintain permanent and current records of this chapter, including but not limited to official actions on all amendments, special uses, variations, appeals, and applications therefor; 
(6)  Provide such clerical and technical assistance as may be required by the zoning board of appeals in exercise of its duties; and 
(7)  Make an annual report to the city council on the work of the building department on the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § A), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-52. - Zoning board of appeals. 
(a)  Appeal and review. 
(1)  An appeal may be taken to the planning and zoning commission by any person or by an officer, department, board or bureau of the city aggrieved by a decision of the public works director or his designee. Such appeal shall be taken within such time as shall be prescribed by the commission by general rule, by filing with the public works director or his designee and with the commission a notice of appeal, specifying the grounds thereof. The public works director or his designee shall forthwith transmit to the commission all of the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(2)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the public works director or his designee certifies to the planning and zoning commission, after the notice of appeal has been filed with him, that because of facts stated in the certificate the stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed, otherwise than by a restraining order, granted by the commission or by a court of record on application and on notice to the public works director or his designee and on due cause shown. 
(3)  The commission shall select a reasonable time and place for the hearing of the appeal and shall give due notice thereof to the parties and shall render a decision on the appeal without unreasonable delay. Any person may appeal and testify at the hearing, either in person or by duly authorized agent or attorney. A fee shall be collected in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. The public works director or his designee shall collect the fee at the time the notice of appeal is filed and prior to each subsequent hearing and shall forthwith transmit the fee to the city treasurer to the credit of the general revenue fund of the city. 
(b)  Jurisdiction. 
(1)  The planning and zoning commission shall have the following powers and it shall be its duty to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in law in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the public works director or his designee in the enforcement of this chapter and articles II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, and VIII of chapter 18. 
(2)  In hearing and deciding appeals the commission shall have the authority to grant such variations therefrom as may be in harmony with its general purpose and intent so that the function of this chapter be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done, including the following: 
a.  Interpret the sections of this chapter in such a way as to carry out the intent and purposes of the plan, as shown upon the zoning map accompanying and made part of this chapter, where street layout actually on the ground varies from the street layout as shown on such map. 
b.  Permit the erection and use of a building or the use of premises for public utility purposes. 
c.  Permit the modification of the automobile parking space or loading space requirements where, in the particular instance, such modification will not be inconsistent with the purpose and intent of such requirements. 
d.  Permit the modification of the height and area regulations as may be necessary to secure an appropriate improvement of a lot which is of such shape or is so located with relation to surrounding development or physical characteristics that it cannot otherwise be appropriately improved without such modification. 
e.  Permit temporary buildings and uses for periods not to exceed two years in undeveloped sections of the city and for periods not to exceed six months in developed sections. 
f.  Permit a limited increase in the number of employees permitted in processing activities in the commercial districts, but only when such increase will not adversely affect the character of the establishment, will not be detrimental to or affect the character of surrounding residential development and will not increase traffic or parking congestion. 
(3)  In consideration of all appeals and all proposed variations to this chapter, the commission shall, before making any variations from this chapter in a specific case, first determine that the proposed variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property or unreasonably increase the congestion in public streets or increase the danger of fire or endanger the public safety or unreasonably diminish or impair established property values within the surrounding area, or in any other respect impair the public health, safety, comfort, morals or welfare of the inhabitants of the city. The attendance of five members shall constitute a quorum. The concurring vote of a majority of the quorum shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of the public works director or his designee or to decide in favor of the applicant any matter upon which it is authorized by this chapter to render a decision. 
(4)  Nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed to give or grant to the commission the power or authority to alter or change this chapter, articles II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, and VIII of chapter 18 or the zoning map, such power and authority being reserved to the mayor and city council in the manner provided by law. 
(c)  Notice. The commission shall make no decisions except in a specific case and after a public hearing conducted by the commission. A notice of the time and place of such public hearing shall be published in a paper of general circulation in the city at least 15 days prior to the hearing. Such notice shall contain the address or location of the property for which the variation or other ruling by the commission is sought, as well as a brief description of the nature of the appeal. The applicant shall make notification, in writing and by certified mail, to the property owners within 250 feet of the subject property, excluding public rights-of-way, within seven days of the hearing date, advising the owners of the date, time and place and nature of the request. 
(d)  Time limits of commission orders. No order of the commission permitting the erection or alteration of a building shall be valid for a period longer than one year, unless a building permit for such erection or alteration is obtained within such period and such erection or alteration is started and proceeds to completion in accordance with the terms of such permit. No order of the commission permitting a use of a building or premises shall be valid for a period longer than one year unless such use is established within such period; provided, however, that where such use permitted is dependent upon the erection or alteration of a building, such order shall continue in force and effect if a building permit for the erection or alteration is started and proceeds to completion in accordance with the terms of such permit. 
(e)  Finality of decisions. In exercising the powers in this section, the commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have all the powers of the public works director or his designee from whom the appeal is taken. All decisions and findings of the planning and zoning commission, on appeal or upon application for a variation after a hearing, shall in all instances be final administrative determinations and shall be subject to review by court as provided by law, including application of the provisions of the Administrative Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § B), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 84-41, §§ 7, 8, 8-14-1984; Ord. No. 85-47, § 73, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 88-42, § 5, 6-28-1988; Ord. No. 91-71, §§ 12, 13, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 92-03, § 9, 1-28-1992; Ord. No. 92-44, §§ 1, 2, 7-14-1992; Ord. No. 97-40, § 1, 6-10-1997; Ord. No. 10-36, §§ 1, 2, 11-2-2010; Ord. No. 16-08, § 1, 4-1-2016; Ord. No. 17-19, § 48, 6-13-2017) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-661 et seq. 
Sec. 122-53. - Zoning changes and amendments. 
(a)  Zoning commission. The regulations imposed and the districts created by this chapter may be amended from time to time, but no amendment to this chapter shall be made by the city council without prior public hearing before the zoning commission appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council, nor without a report of recommendations first having been made by the commission to the city council, and every such report shall be accompanied by findings of fact specifying the reasons for the recommendations. The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall appoint a chairman of the commission. 
(b)  Procedure for amending chapter. 
(1)  The zoning commission shall consider from time to time any amendment to regulations imposed and districts created under this chapter which may be presented to the commission by the city council, either upon the council's initiative or in response to a properly prepared petition to the council signed by a majority of the property owners in the area proposed to be affected. The commission shall conduct public hearings with respect to any and all such proposed amendments, and all hearings conducted by the commission shall be open to the public. Notice shall be given of the time and place of the public hearing not more than 30 days nor less than 15 days before the hearing, by publishing a notice in a newspaper having a general circulation within the city. 
(2)  As part of the required notification process, all petitioners shall be required to post a sign, three feet by three feet in size, with a white background and black lettering, on each frontage of the subject property. Such sign shall be mounted and provided by the department of public works for a $100.00 fee per sign, refundable upon return of the sign in reasonable condition. All signs regarding public hearings shall be posted no more than 30 days and no less than 15 days before the requested hearing. 
(c)  Recommendations to city council. Upon the completion of the public hearing relating to any proposed amendment, the zoning commission shall report its recommendations to the city council. In considering such recommendations, due allowance shall be made by the commission for existing conditions, for the conservation of property values, for the direction of building development to the best advantage of the entire city, and for the uses to which the property affected is being devoted at the time, and no change shall be recommended unless it is required for the public good. 
(d)  Opposition to amendment. If a written protest against any proposed amendment of the regulations or districts, signed and acknowledged by the owners of 20 percent of the frontage proposed to be altered or by the owners of 20 percent of the frontage immediately adjoining or across an alley therefrom or by the owners of 20 percent of the frontage directly opposite the frontage proposed to be altered, is filed with the city clerk, the amendment shall not be passed except upon a favorable vote of two-thirds of all the members of the city council then holding office. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § C), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 85-47, § 74, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 89-68, § 9, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 91-71, §§ 14, 15, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 92-03, § 10, 1-28-1992; Ord. No. 92-13, §§ 9, 10, 2-25-1992; Ord. No. 17-19, § 27, 6-13-2017; Ord. No. 18-02, §§ 1, 2, 1-9-2018) 
Sec. 122-54. - Filing fees for zoning amendments. 
    Any petition for an amendment to this chapter, including rezoning requests, by and on behalf of the owner of the property affected, shall be filed with the community development director and accompanied by a fee in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § D), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 84-41, §§ 9, 10, 8-14-1984; Ord. No. 91-71, §§ 16, 17, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 97-40, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Sec. 122-55. - Required permits and certificates. 
(a)  Building or erection permits. It shall be unlawful to start the construction of a new building, structure, parking lot or sign or the enlargement, alteration or removal of a building or structure which involves a change in use without first filing written application for and obtaining a building, development, removal or erection permit from the community development director. Each application for a building permit shall be accompanied by a plat in duplicate or duplicate prints thereof drawn to scale; showing the actual dimensions of the lot to be built upon; the size, shape and location of any existing building; and such other information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of this chapter. A record of applications and plats shall be kept in the office of the community development director. No building, development, removal or erection permit shall be issued unless the community development director has certified after examination of the plot plan and construction plans that such plans show compliance with all sections of this chapter. 
(b)  Certificate of use and occupancy. 
(1)  No parking lot or land shall be used or occupied and no building or structure erected or structurally altered, enlarged or moved shall be used or occupied in whole or in part for any purpose whatsoever until a certificate of use and occupancy has been issued by the community development director, stating that the building and the proposed use of the building and land comply with all ordinances, including this chapter. Any use or occupancy without the issuance of such a certificate by the community development director shall be considered a violation of this chapter. 
(2)  No change of use shall be made in any building, parking lot or part thereof erected or structurally altered or enlarged that does not comply with this chapter, and a certificate of use and occupancy shall be required for any such change of use. 
(3)  Any person claiming a lawful nonconforming use of any premises, building or structure, under the terms of this chapter, shall, within 360 days from the effective date of this chapter, file an affidavit, together with an application for a certificate of use and occupancy of the premises, building or structure, with the community development director on forms prescribed by the community development director. The community development director shall cause an inspection to be made to ascertain whether the use is in fact nonconforming and lawful, and if so he shall issue a certificate for use and occupancy which use shall be subject to all of the terms and conditions of this chapter and all other city ordinances. 
(4)  No certificate of use and occupancy or an affidavit shall be required for any building or structure which exists lawfully on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives and which is nonconforming solely with respect to one or more of the following minimum requirements for new buildings and structures erected: 
a.  Bulk; 
b.  Ground floor area per dwelling; 
c.  Yards; 
d.  Gross floor area; or 
e.  Off-street parking or loading spaces. 
(5)  Any person failing to file the required affidavit and application for a certificate of use and occupancy as a lawful nonconforming use in accordance with this subsection and within the period of time specified shall be deemed to have renounced, waived and abandoned any claim as a lawful nonconforming use of the premises, building or structure and shall be barred from asserting any such claim thereafter. 
(6)  When any building, structure or use of land or a building is entitled thereto, the community development director shall issue a certificate of use and occupancy within ten days after written application therefor, on request, to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building affected. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § E), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-56. - Interpretation, purpose and conflict. 
    In interpreting and applying the sections of this chapter, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public safety, health, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and general welfare. It is not intended by this chapter to interfere with or abrogate or annul any ordinance or rules, regulations or permits previously adopted or issued and not in conflict with any of the sections of this chapter or which shall be adopted or issued pursuant to law relating to the use of buildings or premises and likewise not in conflict with this chapter; nor is it intended by this chapter to interfere with abrogate or annul any easement, covenants or other agreements between parties; provided, however, that where this chapter imposes a greater restriction upon the use of buildings or requires larger open spaces or larger lot areas than are imposed or required by this chapter or agreements, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § F), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-57. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the sections of this chapter shall be fined in accordance with the schedule of rates, fees, fines and penalties as adopted by the city council from time to time and found in appendix B of the Code of Ordinances. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. XI, § G), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 97-40, § 1, 6-10-1997) 
Secs. 122-58-122-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DISTRICTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 122-86. - District classifications. 
    In order to classify, regulate and restrict the locations of trade and industries and the location of buildings designated for specified areas; to regulate and limit the height and bulk of buildings erected or altered; to regulate and limit the intensity of the use of lot areas and regulate and determine the areas of yards, courts and other open spaces within the surroundings of such buildings; and to provide for the development of property as a planned unit development, the areas within the city and the areas subject to annexation thereto are classified into districts. The use, height and area regulations are uniform in each district classification, and the districts shall be known as follows: 
RESIDENCE DISTRICTS R-1 Single-family residence district (10,000 square feet minimum lots) R-2 Single-family residence district (8,400 square feet minimum lots) R-3 General residence district R-4 Intermediate residence district R-5 Single-family residence district (32,600 square feet) TRANSITIONAL DISTRICTS T-1 Office, institutional and research district T-2 Office, institution (transitional) district COMMERCIAL DISTRICTS C-1 Commercial district C-2 General commercial services district C-3 Minor commercial services district MANUFACTURING DISTRICTS M-1 Manufacturing district M-2 Multiple-purpose district (planned development)  
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 1), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 89-68, § 1, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 91-71, § 1, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 122-87. - Zoning maps. 
(a)  The boundaries of each zoning district within the city limits are indicated upon the Zoning Map of the City of Rolling Meadows, Illinois, which is attached to Ordinance No. 626 and made a part of this chapter. The proposed designation of district classifications for lands subject to annexation to the city are shown on a map entitled "Master Plan Land Use Map" which is attached to Ordinance No. 626 and made a part of this chapter. 
(b)  The zoning maps and subsequent amendments thereto and all notations, references and other matters shown thereon shall be as much a part of this chapter as if the notations, references, designation of use districts and other matters set forth by the maps were fully described in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 2), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-88. - Annexed territory. 
(a)  Any territory annexed to the city shall automatically, upon such annexation, be classified within the R-1 single-family residence district and be subject to all conditions and regulations applicable to territory in such district. 
(b)  The community development department shall assign an address to all property which is annexed within the corporate boundaries of the city.
