Upon the assignment of an address, the property owner shall display the assigned address by placing the address on the street side of the building in such a manner so that it is visible from the street. Failure to use and display the assigned address shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day a violation occurs shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 3), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 85-52, § 1, 8-27-1985) 
Sec. 122-89. - Boundary lines. 
    Wherever any uncertainty exists as to the boundary of any use district as shown on the zoning map incorporated in this chapter, the following rules shall apply: 
(1)  The district boundary lines are indicated as following streets, alleys or similar rights-of-way, and they shall be construed as following the centerlines thereof. 
(2)  Where district boundary lines are indicated as approximately following lot lines, such lot lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
(3)  Where a lot held in one ownership and of record on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives is divided by a district boundary line, the entire lot shall be construed to be within the less restricted district. However, this construction shall not apply if it increases the area of the less restricted portion of the lot by more than 20 percent. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 4), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-90. - Minimum areas for zoning districts. 
    The minimum areas that may constitute a separate or detached part of any of the zoning districts listed in this section on the comprehensive amended zoning map or subsequent amendments to the zoning map shall be as shown on the table in this section. When a nonresidential district is directly across the street from or abuts the district with the same or less restrictive classification, the area of the land directly across the street or abutting the property may be included in the calculations in meeting the minimum requirements. The minimum areas of zoning districts shall be as follows: 
Zoning District Minimum 
 Area R-1 Single-family residence district (10,000 square feet minimum lots) No minimum R-2 Single-family residence district (8,400 square feet minimum lots) No minimum R-3 General residence district 2 acres R-4 Intermediate residence district 1 acre R-5 Single-family residence district (32,600 square feet minimum lot) No minimum T-1 Office, institutional and research district 2 acres T-2 Office, institution (transitional) district 2 acres C-1 Commercial district 1 acre C-2 General commercial services district 4 acres C-3 Minor commercial district 1 acre M-1 Manufacturing district 10 acres M-2 Multipurpose district-planned development only 20 acres  
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 5), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 89-68, § 2, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 91-71, § 2, 12-10-1991) 
Sec. 122-91. - Zoning of streets, alleys, public ways and railroad rights-of-way. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, all streets, alleys, public ways and railroad rights-of-way, if not otherwise specifically designated, shall be deemed to be in the same zone as the property immediately abutting upon such alleys, streets, public ways and railroad rights-of way. The centerline of a street, alley, public way or railroad right-of-way, unless otherwise specifically designated, shall be deemed to be the district boundary. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IV, § 6), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-92. - Adult regulated use locations. 
(a)  Adult regulated uses are prohibited in all districts other than the M-1 and M-2 multipurpose district and are further prohibited within the following distances from the following specified uses or zones: 
(1)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any residential district, known as R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or R-5, or any single-family or multiple-family residential use. 
(2)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any public or private school or day care center. 
(3)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any church or other religious facility or institution. 
(4)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any cemetery or mental health center. 
(5)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any public housing, public library, public park or recreation area. 
(6)  Adjacent to, or within 1,000 feet of, a school route. 
(7)  Within, or within 1,000 feet of, any other adult regulated use. 
(b)  The distances provided in this section shall be measured by following a straight line, without regard to intervening buildings, from the nearest point of the property parcel upon which the proposed use is to be located, to the nearest point of the parcel of property, right-of-way, or the land use district boundary line from which the proposed land use is to be separated. 
(c)  An adult regulated use which is established in conformity with the locational restrictions of this section 122-92 shall not be made nonconforming if, subsequent to the establishment of the adult regulated use, a residential zone, public or private school, church, religious facility, mental health center, public library, public park, recreation area or school route is created or established within the distance limitations for an adult regulated use specified in this section 122-92. However, if any adult regulated use is terminated or discontinued for a period of 30 days or more subsequent to the location of a use imposing a distance limitation on the adult regulated use, then the adult regulated use shall become a nonconforming use. 
(Ord. No. 00-04, § 3, 3-14-2000) 
Secs. 122-93-122-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL 

Sec. 122-121. - Purpose. 
    The residence districts set forth in this division are established in order to protect public health and promote public safety, convenience, comfort, morals, prosperity and welfare. These general goals include among others the following specific purposes: 
(1)  Protect residential areas against fire, explosion, noxious fumes, offensive noise, smoke, vibrations, dust, odors, heat, glare and other objectionable factors. 
(2)  Protect residential areas to the extent possible and appropriate in each area against unduly heavy motor vehicle traffic, especially through traffic, and alleviate congestion by promoting off-street parking. 
(3)  Protect residential areas against undue congestion of public streets and other public facilities by controlling the density of population through regulation of the bulk of buildings. 
(4)  Protect and promote the public health and comfort by providing for ample light and air to buildings and the windows thereof. 
(5)  Promote public comfort and welfare by providing for usable open space on the same zoning lot with residential development. 
(6)  Provide sufficient space in appropriate locations to meet the probable need for future residential expansion and to meet the need for necessary and desirable services in the vicinity of residences, which increase safety and amenity for residents and which do not exert objectionable influences. 
(7)  Promote the best use and development of residential land in accordance with a comprehensive land use plan, promote stability of residential development and protect the character and desirable development, and protect the value of land and improvements and so strengthen the economic base of the city. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 1), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-122. - R-1 single-family residence district. 
(a)  Area; minimum lot size. In the R-1 single-family residence district, no minimum area shall be required for zoning, and lots shall be a minimum of 10,000 square feet. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No buildings or premises improved or unimproved shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-1 single-family residence district, unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family detached dwellings. 
(2)  Accessory buildings, as defined herein and regulated by section 122-10. 
(3)  Signs, as specified in this section. 
(4)  Residential off-street parking facilities, as specified in this section. 
(5)  Churches, elementary and high schools, public and private, public parks and playgrounds, provided the zoning lot for the use has an area of not less than one acre and has sufficient area to provide for both building space and required off-street parking. 
(6)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(7)  Fire stations and police stations. 
(8)  Family community residences, provided the sponsoring agency obtains an occupancy certificate prior to establishing a family community residence. No dwelling unit shall be occupied as a family community residence until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for a family community residence unless: 
a.  The family community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line; and 
b.  The applicant demonstrates that he has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate the proposed family community residence. 
The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a family community residence if its license or certification is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another operator or another dwelling. 
(9)  Colleges, universities and for-profit or not-for-profit educational training activities, excluding trade schools dealing with industrial arts. 
(10)  Special uses. The following special uses, subject to the conditions stipulated in the requirements provided in article V of this chapter: 
a.  Country clubs, golf courses, tennis courts and similar recreation uses, not including commercial community swimming pools, provided that any principal building or accessory swimming pool shall be located not less than 100 feet from any other lot in any R district. 
b.  Day care centers, when part of a church, school, community center or recreational building in public parks. 
c.  Hospitals, not including animal hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes, public or private, on tracts of land having a minimum area of five acres. 
d.  Municipal recreation building or community center. 
e.  Public utility facilities. 
f.  The following temporary permit uses subject to application to and issuance by the community development director of a permit therefor: 
1.  Single-family attached dwellings, provided the number of dwellings be limited to five attached units in one cluster and further provided that the buildings and accessory buildings shall not cover more than 30 percent of each lot. 
2.  A temporary building or yard for construction materials and equipment, both incidental and necessary to construction in the zoning district. Each permit shall specify the location of the building or yard and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than six calendar months and shall not be renewed for more than four successive periods at the same location. 
3.  A temporary office, both incidental and necessary for the sale or rental of real property. Each permit shall specify the location of the office and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than one year and shall not be renewed for more than five successive periods at the same location. 
g.  Single-family, semidetached dwellings, provided the number of dwellings be limited to five attached units in one cluster and further provided that the buildings and accessory buildings shall not cover more than 30 percent of each lot. 
h.  Municipal and governmental office buildings or court facilities, and uses necessarily incidental thereto. 
i.  Community residences subject to the following: 
1.  The facility must be located on a lot a minimum of 10,000 square feet in area and contain a minimum land area of 1,600 square feet per resident. 
2.  Landscaping is required pursuant to section 122-23, notwithstanding the exception to R-1 zoning, stated in that section. 
3.  The sponsoring agency must obtain a certificate of occupancy from the community development director prior to establishing the community residence. 
4.  The community residence must be located at least 1,000 feet from any other community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line. 
5.  The sponsor must demonstrate that it has obtained or is eligible to obtain the appropriate state licenses or permits to operate a community residence. 
6.  No dwelling shall be occupied as a community residence unless a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operate is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
j.  Wind-powered generators subject to the following: 
1.  No part shall be constructed of wood. 
2.  All moving parts shall be protected from contact, and the wind-driven blades shall be allowed to approach no closer than ten feet from grade. 
k.  Noncommercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
l.  Municipal libraries. 
m.  Vocational and rehabilitative educational activities and uses necessarily incidental thereto. 
n.  Group community residence subject to the following: 
1.  The group community residence must be located on a lot a minimum of 10,000 square feet in area and contain a minimum land area of 1,600 square feet per resident. 
2.  The group community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line. 
3.  The sponsor must demonstrate that it has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate as a group community residence. 
4.  No dwelling shall be occupied as a group community residence unless a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operate is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
o.  Trade schools or activities dealing with industrial arts and skills. 
(11)  Cemeteries. 
(c)  Building height. The maximum building height allowed for lot platted or parcels deed prior to December 31, 1970 shall be 30 feet. Building height shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings: a maximum of 35 feet and not over two and one-half stories. 
(2)  Churches and permitted nonresidential structures: a maximum of 90 feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 35 feet for the main structures. 
(d)  Setback . 
(1)  The minimum setback for buildings along arterial primary, major and secondary streets shown on the official plan of the city shall be in accordance with section 122-20, and the requirements along minor streets shall be as follows: the minimum setback shall be not less than 30 feet, except where all of the improved lots in any one block are developed with buildings which establish a setback greater or less than 30 feet, and the improved lots comprise 25 percent or more of the frontage in the block; such greater or lesser setback shall become the minimum setback in such block. No building erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered shall project beyond the setback so established in the block; provided, however, that this shall not be interpreted to require a setback of more than 60 feet. 
(2)  For a corner lot, the side yard setback abutting the roadway shall be not less than 20 feet. 
(e)  Side yards (for single-family residence uses). The side yards shall not be less than ten feet. On a corner lot, the side yard may be opposite either property line fronting on a street, provided the remaining yard is designated the rear yard. For single-family residences built prior to January 1, 1993, an attached garage may not be closer than five feet from the side property line, provided the garage is no more than 22 feet wide with a depth of no more than 20 feet. 
(f)  Rear yards (for single-family residence uses). There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(g)  Yards (for nonresidential permitted uses and special uses). Front, side and rear yards shall be as required for single-family dwelling uses for buildings less than 35 feet in height, but for a building 35 feet or more in height each yard, front, side and rear, as required for single-family dwellings, shall be increased in width or depth by two feet for each additional one foot of building height over 35 feet. 
(h)  Floor area per dwelling. Every one-story dwelling erected in any R-1 single-family residence district shall have a total ground floor area of not less than 900 square feet, measured from the outside of the exterior walls, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. Every dwelling of more than one story erected in any R-1 single-family residence district shall have a total floor area, measured from the outside of the exterior walls, of not less than 1,200 square feet, of which a minimum of 900 square feet shall be the ground floor area of the first floor abovegrade, including utility rooms but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. 
    The maximum floor area ratio ((F.A.R.) for single family attached and detached dwellings shall be as follows: 
Lot Size Floor Area Ratio 
(F.A.R.) 5,000 - 8,400 .45 8,400 - 10,000 .40 10,000 - 20,000 .35 20,000 - above .30  
    Area of attached and detached garages over the first 500 square feet shall be included in the gross floor area used to compute the floor area ratio. 
(i)  Lot area and width. 
(1)  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 10,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 60 feet. 
(2)  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and individual septic tanks, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall have an area of not less than 20,000 square feet and width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet. 
(3)  When a dwelling is to be served by a private well facility and an individual septic tank, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 20,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet. 
(4)  No building with its accessory building shall occupy in excess of 30 percent of the area on interior lot. 
(j)  Off-street parking and loading. The off-street parking and loading sections of this chapter shall apply as follows: 
(1)  For all buildings and structures erected and all uses of land established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, accessory parking and loading facilities shall be provided as set forth in this chapter. However, where a building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives and provided that construction is begun within six months of such effective date and diligently prosecuted to completion, parking and loading facilities shall comply with requirements existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives. 
(2)  When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through additional dwelling units, gross floor area, seating capacity or other units of measurement specified in this chapter for required parking or loading facilities, parking and loading facilities as required shall be provided for such increase in intensity of use. However, no building or structure lawfully erected or used, lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall be required to provide such additional parking or loading facilities unless and until the aggregate increase in units of measurement shall equal not less than 15 percent of the units of measurement existing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, in which event parking or loading facilities as required shall be provided for the total increase. 
(3)  Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use would exceed those for the existing use if the latter were subject to the parking and loading requirements of this chapter. 
(k)  Existing parking and loading facilities. Accessory off-street parking or loading facilities which were in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives or were provided voluntarily after such effective date shall not be reduced below or, if already less than, shall not further be reduced below the requirements of this chapter for a similar new building or use. 
(l)  Permissive parking and loading facilities. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of contiguous off-street parking or loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings, provided that all sections in this chapter governing the location, design, improvement and operation of such facilities are adhered to. 
(m)  Damage or destruction. For any conforming or legally nonconforming building or use which is in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives which subsequently thereto is damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause and which is reconstructed, reestablished or repaired, off-street parking or loading facilities need not be provided, except that parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction shall be restored or continued in operation. However, if the principal building or structure is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value, it shall then be necessary to restore or maintain parking or loading facilities as required by this chapter for equivalent new uses or construction. 
(n)  Submission of plot plan. Any application for a building permit shall include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing any parking or loading facilities to be provided in compliance with this chapter. 
(o)  Additional parking regulations. 
(1)  Use of facilities. Except as otherwise indicated, required accessory off-street parking facilities shall be solely for the parking of passenger automobiles of occupants or their guests. 
(2)  Computation. When determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(3)  Size. A required off-street parking space shall be at least nine feet in width and at least 20 feet in length, exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps or work areas. Such space shall have a vertical clearance of at least seven feet. 
(4)  Driveway. Each required off-street parking space shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway of such width and design as to provide safe and efficient means of vehicular access to such parking space. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or other public way in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across public property or requiring a curb shall exceed a width of 25 feet. 
(5)  Location in yards. Off-street parking spaces and driveways within yard areas shall conform to the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 of this Code relating to driveways. 
(6)  Repair and service. No motor vehicle repair work of any kind shall be permitted in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities provided in any residence district. The sale of gasoline and motor oil in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities is not permitted in any residence district. 
(7)  Vehicles displayed and offered for sale. Vehicles displayed and offered for sale are subject to the following restrictions: 
a.  The owner of the vehicle must reside on the property on the premises where the vehicle is displayed and offered for sale. 
b.  Not more than two vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale at any one time. 
c.  Not more than four vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale within a 12-month period. 
d.  Any sign displaying a vehicle for sale shall be located inside the vehicle. 
(p)  Location of off-street parking. Parking spaces on individual lots, accessory to dwelling units, shall not be located on the public right-of-way. Parking spaces accessory to dwellings shall be located on the same zoning lot as the use served. 
(q)  Parking spaces. Parking spaces shall be provided as follows for the following uses: 
(1)  Dwelling uses. A minimum of two parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit, excluding garage or carport area. 
(2)  Churches, temples and other religious institutional uses. One parking space shall be provided for each five seats or for each 90 inches of seating space, whichever is less. 
(3)  Colleges, universities and businesses, professional and trade schools. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees, and one parking space shall be provided for each six students based on the maximum number of students attending class on the premises at any one time during any 24-hour period. 
(4)  Municipal or privately owned recreational buildings or community centers. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the visiting public. 
(5)  Public utility and public service uses. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the public. 
(6)  Elementary, junior high, high schools. For elementary and junior high schools, two parking spaces shall be provided for each 30 students of design capacity. For high schools, one off-street parking space shall be provided for each seven students of design capacity. 
(7)  Private clubs and lodges. Parking spaces equal in number to ten percent of the capacity of the number of persons the facility will accommodate shall be provided. 
(8)  Convents, fraternal institutions, rectories, parish houses and swimming pools. The planning and zoning commission shall determine the number of parking spaces to be provided for convents, fraternal institutions, rectories, parish houses and swimming pools. 
(9)  Uses not provided for. For uses not specifically covered in the schedule of parking requirements in this subsection, parking spaces shall be provided on the same basis as required for the most similar listed use or as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(r)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 pounds or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city Code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this chapter. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 pounds, parked or stored on any residential premises shall be limited to one if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, roadwork, or for use on a farm (including but not limited to bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residence district unless such equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(s)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with the following, and only those signs specifically permitted by the text of this subsection shall be permitted and none others: 
(1)  No sign shall be erected except the following nonflashing, nonilluminated signs: 
a.  Nameplate or identification signs, subject to the following: 
1.  There shall be no more than one nameplate not exceeding two square feet in area for each dwelling unit indicating the name of the occupant. 
2.  Every building shall have a minimum of one sign displaying the address of the building, and the sign shall be visible in its entirety from the street. 
3.  For churches and institutions, one identification sign not exceeding ten square feet in area shall be permitted subject to the following: 
i.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way. 
ii.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than ten feet above curb level. 
b.  For sale and to rent signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign shall be erected, and the total area shall not exceed nine square feet. 
2.  The signs shall be displayed a minimum of 15 feet from the front property line and shall not project above the height of an exterior wall. 
3.  Not more than one sign shall be erected with a total area not exceeding nine square feet to indicate the sale of vacant property. If the vacant property exceeds one acre in size for sale or to rent sign may be erected, and the total area shall not exceed 64 square feet, and the sign must be back 30 feet from the property line, and the sign permits shall expire one year after the date of issuance. The height of the sign shall not exceed ten feet. 
c.  Billboards shall not be permitted in residence districts with the exception of two billboards for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of homes in a subdivision under construction, not to exceed ten square feet per each acre, and such billboards shall not exceed a cumulative total of 150 square feet. Their construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
1.  No billboards shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
2.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the issuance or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
3.  The location and arrangement of the billboards are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  Open house and signs subject to the following conditions: 
1.  At any time, on any tract of real estate, not more than one open house sign shall be permitted which shall not exceed six square feet in gross surface area per sign face. 
2.  Open house signs may be placed on the public parkway at various intersections; however, they shall not interfere with any motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
3.  Such signs shall only be allowed on Friday, Saturday and Sunday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
4.  All open house signs must have attached identification denoting the person who is responsible for the placement and removal of the signs. 
5.  At any given time, on any given tract of real estate or intersection, not more than one open house sign directing the public in any one direction may be placed by the same business entity (i.e., same business name). This subsection shall not prohibit the placement of two or more signs by the same business entity so long as those signs direct the public in a different direction. 
e.  Garage sale signs subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one on premises sign which shall not exceed six square feet in area. 
2.  Directional signs may be placed on the public parkway at intersections provided: 
i.  They are not affixed to a utility pole, fence or public sign. 
ii.  They do not obstruct motorist's vision. 
iii.  They do not exceed a total of three signs. 
3.  Signs shall only be allowed on Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
4.  Approval has been granted by the property owner directly adjacent to and who has maintenance responsibilities for the public way upon which the sign is placed. Without such approval the property owner is authorized to remove the sign. 
f.  Temporary construction and home improvement services signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign per premise shall be allowed. 
2.  No sign shall be erected prior to the beginning of the construction and once the work is complete, the sign must be removed. 
3.  Signs identifying contractors or home improvement services shall not exceed four square feet per sign face advertising the name of the company providing the service and any additional contact information for such service only. 
4.  Such signs shall be located no closer than fifteen feet to the property line. 
5.  A permit shall be required for such sign. 
(2)  Directional signs and signs accessory to parking areas shall be permitted, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Directional signs erected by the city, not exceeding two square feet in area. 
b.  Signs directing entrances to or exits from a parking area and limited to one sign for each such entrance or exit and to a maximum size of two square feet each shall be permitted. 
c.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way, except directional signs erected by the city. 
d.  Height. The top of directional signs shall not be higher than eight feet above curb level. 
(3)  Permitted nonflashing signs, i.e., bulletin boards, for churches or nonprofit institutions, shall be permitted subject to the following conditions. 
a.  There shall be not more than one sign per lot, and no sign shall exceed 18 square feet in area or be closer than eight feet to any other zoning lot. 
b.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
(4)  School, intuitional, non-profit organizations and churches located upon land three acres or more in size shall be allowed signage subject to the following: 
a.  Freestanding signs-One freestanding sign of an area not exceeding ten percent of the lot's frontage or 100 square feet, whichever is less. The signs height shall not exceed six feet. 
b.  Wall signs-One wall sign of an area not exceeding ten percent of the wall area to which the sign is affixed or 100 square feet, whichever is less. 
c.  Temporary signs-Temporary special event and similar signs are permitted subject to the following restrictions: 
1.  No more than two temporary signs shall be placed on the property at any one time. 
2.  The display of temporary signs shall be limited to a cumulative total of 120 days per calendar year per premises. 
3.  Temporary sign(s) shall not be erected more than 30 days prior to the event and shall be removed immediately after the termination of the event of activity. 
4.  The temporary sign(s) shall not exceed 100 square feet. 
5.  The location and arrangement of the temporary sign is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
6.  Temporary sign shall be designed to be stable under all weather conditions.

Sec. 122-123. - R-2 single-family residence district. 
(a)  Area; minimum size of lots. In the R-2 single-family residence district, no minimum area shall be required, and the minimum size of lots shall be 8,400 square feet. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-2 residence district unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
(2)  Special uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
(c)  Building height. The maximum building height allowed for lot platted or parcels deed prior to December 31, 1970 shall be 30 feet. The building height shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family detached dwellings: a maximum of 35 feet and not over 21/2 stories. 
(2)  Churches and permitted nonresidential structures: a maximum of 90 feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 35 feet for the main structures. 
(d)  Setback. The minimum setback for buildings along arterial, primary, major and secondary streets shown on the official plan of the city shall be in accordance with section 122-20, and the requirements for minor streets shall be not less than 30 feet. 
(e)  Side yards (for single-family residence uses). The side yards shall be not less than ten feet. On a corner lot the side yard may be opposite either property line fronting on the street, provided the remaining yard is designated the rear yard. For single-family residences built prior to January 1, 1993, an attached garage may not be closer than five feet from the side property line, provided the garage is no more than 22 feet wide with a depth of no more than 20 feet. 
(f)  Rear yards (for single-family residence uses). There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(g)  Yards (for nonresidential permitted uses and special uses). Front, side and rear yards shall be as required for single-family dwelling uses for buildings less than 35 feet in height, but for a building 35 feet or more in height each yard, front, side and rear, as required for single-family dwellings shall be increased in width or depth by two feet for each additional one foot of building height over 35 feet. 
(h)  Floor area per dwelling. Every one-story dwelling erected in any R-2 single-family district shall have a total ground floor area of not less than 900 square feet measured from the outside of the exterior walls, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. Every dwelling of more than one story erected in any R-2 single-family district shall have a total floor area measured from the outside of the exterior walls of not less than 900 square feet, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes, except that enclosed space intended for habitable rooms which are to be completed within a reasonable time may be considered in computing such floor areas. 
    The maximum floor area ratio (F.A.R.) for single family attached and detached dwellings shall be as follows: 
Lot Size Floor Area Ratio 
(F.A.R.) 5,000 - 8,400 .45 8,400 - 10,000 .40 10,000 - 20,000 .35 20,000 - above .30  
    Area of attached and detached garages over the first 500 square feet shall be included in the gross floor area used to compute the floor area ratio. 
(i)  Lot area and width. 
(1)  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 8,400 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 60 feet. 
(2)  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and individual septic tanks, a single-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 20,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet, except as provided in sections 122-4-122-24. 
(3)  When a dwelling is to be served by private well facilities and individual septic tanks, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 20,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet, except as provided in sections 122-4-122-24. 
(4)  No building with its accessory buildings shall occupy in excess of 30 percent of the area of an interior lot and no more than 30 percent of the area of a corner lot. 
(5)  See definition of lot area measurement. 
(j)  Lot area of corner lots. All corner lots in the R-2 district shall be a minimum of 10,000 square feet. 
(k)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as permitted in R-1 residential district. 
(l)  Signs. Permitted signs in R-2 zoning districts shall be as permitted in the R-1 zoning district. 
(m)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 lbs., or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this comprehensive zoning code. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 lbs., parked or stored on any residential premises, shall be limited to one if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, road work, or for use on a farm (including, but not limited to, bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residential district unless said equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 3), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 731, § 5, 6-24-1975; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 34, 35, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 93-07, §§ 12, 13, 2-23-1993; Ord. No. 99-51, § 17, 11-9-1999; Ord. No. 04-29, §§ 2, 7, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 122-124. - R-3 general residence district. 
(a)  Size. In the R-3 general residence district, a minimum of two acres required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-3 general residence district unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
(2)  Two-family detached dwellings. 
(3)  Two-family semidetached dwellings. 
(4)  Apartments. 
(5)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(6)  Special uses as follows: 
a.  Special uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
b.  Nursery schools, day nurseries and child care centers, provided there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided, further, the area shall be fenced and screened from view from any adjoining lot in any single-family residence district. 
c.  Health and medical institutions, including convalescent homes; medical, dental, mental or optical clinics and hospitals including rehabilitation and treatment centers and also including juvenile counseling and guidance centers. 
d.  Community centers. 
e.  Noncommercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
f.  Mechanical amusement device centers, provided such center is located within a community center and there are not more than five devices. 
(7)  Accessory buildings as defined in this chapter and regulated by section 122-10. 
(8)  Rental and managing offices for the multifamily development. 
(c)  Building height. For single-family and two-family dwellings of all types, the building height shall not exceed two stories or 30 feet in height; provided, however, that the floor area ratio shall not exceed 1.0 times the lot area. Apartment buildings are limited to four stories or 50 feet in height and a floor area ratio that shall not exceed 1.0. 
(d)  Setback. The minimum setback for buildings along arterial primary, major and secondary streets shown on the official plan of the city shall be in accordance with section 122-20, and the requirements for minor streets shall be not less than 30 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(e)  Side yards (for residence uses). 
(1)  For one-family and two-family dwellings, no side yard shall be less than 15 feet. 
(2)  For apartment dwelling units of more than two stories in height, the side yard of each of the principal buildings shall be a minimum of 15 feet or as determined by the floor area ratio formula, whichever is greater. 
(f)  Rear yards (for residence uses). Each lot shall have a rear yard not less than 30 feet in depth, measured from the rear lot line. 
(g)  Yards (for nonresidential permitted uses, apartment uses and special uses). Front, side and rear yards shall be as required for single-family and two-family dwelling uses for buildings less than 30 feet in height, but for a building 30 feet or more in height the side yard shall be as required for single-family and two-family dwelling uses except as modified by the floor area ratio formula. 
(h)  Floor area per dwelling. Every single-family detached dwelling erected in any R-3 residence district shall have a minimum of 900 square feet of livable floor area, excluding all areas occupied by basement, garages, porches, attics, stairways, and storage, utility and heating rooms. Single-family attached buildings, two-family dwellings and apartments shall have the following minimum floor area requirements: 
(1)  Three bedroom, 1,000 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(2)  Two bedroom, 800 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(3)  One bedroom, 600 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(4)  Studio or efficiency units, 500 square feet per dwelling unit. 
    The maximum floor area ratio ((F.A.R.) for single family attached and detached dwellings shall be as follows: 
Lot Size Floor Area Ratio 
(F.A.R.) 5,000 - 8,400 .45 8,400 - 10,000 .40 10,000 - 20,000 .35 20,000 - above .30  
    Area of attached and detached garages over the first 500 square feet shall be included in the gross floor area used to compute the floor area ratio. 
(i)  Screening from R-1, R-2, and R-5 use districts. Any portion of the property of R-3 zoning must be screened with a fence a minimum of six feet in height. 
(j)  Lot area and width. All uses permitted in the R-3 general residence district shall be served by a public water supply and public sanitary sewers. The lot area and width shall be as follows: 
(1)  The minimum lot area shall be 8,400 square feet with a minimum width of 60 feet, except corner lots, which shall be a minimum of 10,000 square feet in area. 
(2)  For single-family attached, semidetached and two-family dwellings, each lot shall have a minimum area of 10,400 square feet and a minimum width of 80 feet at the building line, and the minimum lot area per dwelling unit shall be not less than 5,200 square feet. 
_____ 
(3)  For apartment buildings each zoning lot shall have a minimum area of 24,000 net square feet and a minimum width at the building line of 100 feet, and the minimum lot area per dwelling unit shall be in accordance with the following table: 
  Type of
