_____ 
(4)  The buildings including accessory buildings on any lot shall not cover, in the aggregate, more than 30 percent of the net area of each lot. 
(5)  Lot area measurement for calculation of lot area per family. The lot area per dwelling unit, when prescribed as a density control measure for single-family, two-family, multiple-family or apartment development, shall be measured with the exclusion of the land in the public street right-of-way. Where private streets or driveways are offered in lieu of public streets as a part of a development having an area of five acres or more, the applicable net square foot area to be divided for determining the minimum number of permitted dwelling units shall be determined by deducting from the gross lot area the square foot area obtained by multiplying 66 times the lineal measure of the private streets or driveways. 
(k)  Requirements for inner courts. An inner court shall have a width of not less than 12 feet, a length of not less than one-fifth of the height of such court, nor shall its area be less than twice the square of its required least dimension. 
(l)  Requirements for outer courts. The width of an outer court shall not be less than one-fifth of the height of such court nor less than one-fifth of the length of such court. 
(m)  Projections in outer courts. When an outer court is partially enclosed by projections, the sum of the projections shall not exceed 25 percent of the greatest required width of the court. 
(n)  Space of detached building on same zoning lot. Where more than one detached building containing dwelling units is located on a zoning lot, the following standards shall be required in accordance with specifications described: 
(1)  If one or more living rooms or bedrooms obtains more than 25 percent of the light and ventilation required by the city building code through openings facing on an open area between the buildings, the distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings shall be as follows: 
a.  At a wall containing living room windows, a minimum of 40 feet; and 
b.  At a wall containing bedroom windows, a minimum of 30 feet. 
(2)  If 25 percent or less of the required window area of a living room faces an open area between buildings, the distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings shall be not less than 30 feet. 
(3)  Under all other conditions except as permitted in subsection (o)(4) of this section, the distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings containing windows shall not be less than 30 feet. 
(4)  Where the walls of two buildings face each other, and the portions of the faces which overlap or that are directly opposite each other do not exceed 15 feet in length and there are no windows in either of the opposing faces, the distance between the walls shall be not less than 30 feet. 
(5)  If windows of a living unit are located in a wall opposite an accessory building, the minimum distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings shall be not less than as established in this section for buildings containing dwelling units. 
(o)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted as follows: 
(1)  Signs for multifamily projects as subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The total cumulative square footage of signs allowed shall be 50 square feet plus one square foot for each dwelling unit, with a maximum allowed of 150 square feet. 
b.  No sign shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level, and no sign shall project beyond the property line. 
c.  The signs shall advertise or identify only the project upon which the sign is erected. 
d.  The number, size, location, copy, and arrangement of the signs are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
(2)  During initial development two billboards for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of units within a multifamily development not to exceed 200 square feet total, and they shall not be located nearer than 25 feet to the property line and shall advertise or identify only the property upon which the sign is located. The billboards' construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  No billboard shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
b.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance or sooner, if all the units are rented or sold. 
c.  The location and arrangement of the billboard is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  Signs allowed in subsection (o)(1) of this section are not allowed if billboards in accordance with this subsection are erected. 
(3)  Subdivision entrance identification signs subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Not to exceed two signs per approved subdivision; 
b.  One sign per corner lot; 
c.  Each sign shall not exceed 30 square feet in area; 
d.  Each sign shall not exceed six feet in height; 
e.  Signs are not to interfere with motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
(4)  Temporary construction and home improvement services signs, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Not more than one sign per premise shall be allowed. 
b.  No sign shall be erected prior to the beginning of the construction and once the work is complete, the sign must be removed. 
c.  Signs identifying contractors or home improvement services shall not exceed four square feet per sign face advertising the name of the company providing the service and any additional contact information for such service only. 
d.  Such signs shall be located no closer than 15 feet to the property line. 
e.  A permit shall be required for such sign. 
(p)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as permitted in the R-1 residence district except that for each apartment dwelling unit two parking spaces shall be provided. 
(q)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 lbs., or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this comprehensive zoning code. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 lbs., parked or stored on any residential premises, shall be limited to one if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, road work, or for use on a farm (including, but not limited to, bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residential district unless said equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(r)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 4), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 696, § 1, 7-9-1974; Ord. No. 699, § 1, 7-23-1974; Ord. No. 731, § 6, 6-24-1975; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 36, 38-40, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 84-57, § 1, 11-13-1984; Ord. No. 85-47, § 37, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 91-54, § 1, 9-24-1991; Ord. No. 91-71, §§ 7, 8, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 99-51, § 17, 11-9-1999; Ord. No. 93-50, § 1, 9-14-1993; Ord. No. 02-04, § 2, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 04-29, § 3, 6-8-2004; Ord. No. 12-12, § 2, 3-13-2012) 
Editor's note- Section 14 of Ord. No. 02-04, adopted Feb. 12, 2002, states that the provisions pertaining to pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall be of no further force and effect from and after 18 months from the effective date thereof, unless extended by action of the city council prior to the expiration of the 18 months. 
Sec. 122-125. - R-4 intermediate district. 
(a)  Size. In the R-4 intermediate district, a minimum of one acre shall be required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No building or premises improved or unimproved shall be used, and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-4 intermediate residence district unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family attached dwellings, provided a building contains not more than six units and is developed pursuant to article IV pertaining to planned developments. 
(2)  Uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
(3)  Uses permitted in the R-2 residence district. 
(4)  Two-family detached dwellings. 
(5)  Two-family semidetached dwellings (duplex). 
(6)  Planned development, as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(7)  Special uses as follows: 
a.  Special uses permitted in the R-1 residence district. 
b.  Community center and/or clubhouse when owned and operated by the development's association. 
(8)  Accessory buildings, as defined in this chapter and regulated by section 122-10. 
(c)  Building height. Dwellings of all types shall not exceed two stories or 39 feet in height. 
(d)  Setback. The minimum setback for buildings shall not be less than 30 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(e)  Side yards. 
(1)  For one-family and two-family dwellings, no side yard shall be less than ten feet. 
(2)  For single-family attached dwellings, no side yard shall be less than 15 feet. 
(f)  Rear yards (for residence uses). Each lot shall have a rear yard not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot, provided it is no less than 20 feet; however, it need not exceed 30 feet. 
(g)  Floor area per dwelling. Every single-family detached dwelling erected in any R-4 intermediate residence district shall have a minimum of 900 square feet of liveable floor area, excluding all areas occupied by basement, garages, porches, attics, stairways and storage, utility and heating rooms. Single-family attached buildings and two-family dwellings shall have the following minimum floor area requirements: 
(1)  Three bedrooms, 1,000 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(2)  Two bedrooms, 800 square feet, per dwelling unit. 
(3)  One bedroom, 600 square feet per dwelling unit. 
In no case shall the total floor area exceed five-tenths times the area of the lot. 
    The maximum floor area ratio ((F.A.R.) for single family attached and detached dwellings shall be as follows: 
Lot Size Floor Area Ratio 
(F.A.R.) 5,000 - 8,400 .45 8,400 - 10,000 .40 10,000 - 20,000 .35 20,000 - above .30  
    Area of attached and detached garages over the first 500 square feet shall be included in the gross floor area used to compute the floor area ratio. 
(h)  Lot area and width. All uses permitted in the R-4 intermediate residence district shall be served by a public water supply and public sanitary sewers. The lot area and width shall be as follows: 
(1)  For single-family detached dwellings, the minimum lot area shall be 8,400 square feet with a minimum width of 60 feet, except corner lots, which shall be a minimum of 10,000 square feet. 
(2)  For semidetached and two-family dwellings, each lot shall have a minimum area of 13,400 square feet and a minimum width of 80 feet at the building line, and the minimum land area per dwelling unit shall be not less than 6,700 square feet. 
(3)  For single-family attached dwellings, the minimum land area per dwelling unit shall be not less than 6,700 square feet. 
(4)  The buildings, including accessory buildings and uses on any lot, shall not cover more than 30 percent of the area of each lot. 
(5)  Lot area measurement for calculation of lot area per family. The lot area per dwelling unit, when prescribed as a density control measure for single-family detached, single-family attached, and two-family development, shall be measured with the exclusion of the land in the public right-of-way. Where private streets or driveways are offered in lieu of public streets as a part of a development having an area of five acres or more, the applicable net square foot area to be divided for determining the minimum number of permitted dwelling units shall be determined by deducting from the gross lot area the square foot area obtained by multiplying 60 times the lineal measure of the private streets or driveways. 
(i)  Requirements for inner courts. An inner court shall have a width of not less than 12 feet, a length of not less than one-fifth of the height of such court, nor shall its area be less than twice the square of its required least dimension. 
(j)  Requirements for outer courts. The width of an outer court shall not be less than one-fifth of the height of such court nor less than one-fifth of the length of such court. 
(k)  Projections in outer courts. When an outer court is partially enclosed by projections, the sum of the projections shall not exceed 25 percent of the greatest required width of the court. 
(l)  Space of detached building on same zoning lot. Where more than one detached building containing dwelling units is located on a zoning lot, the following standards shall be required in accordance with specifications described: 
(1)  If one or more living rooms or bedrooms obtain more than 25 percent of the light and ventilation required by the city building code through openings facing on an open area between buildings, the distance between the opposite walls of the two buildings shall be as follows: 
a.  At a wall containing living room windows, a minimum of 40 feet; and 
b.  At a wall containing bedroom windows, a minimum of 30 feet. 
(2)  If 25 percent or less of the required window area of a living room faces an open area between buildings, the distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings shall not be less than 30 feet. 
(3)  Under all other conditions, except as permitted in subsection (l)(4) of this section, the distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings containing windows shall not be less than 30 feet. 
(4)  Where the walls of two buildings face each other and the portions of the faces which overlap or are directly opposite each other do not exceed 15 feet in length, and there are no windows in either of the opposing faces, the distance between the walls shall be not less than 30 feet. 
(5)  If windows of a living unit are located in a wall opposite an accessory building, the minimum distance between the opposing walls of the two buildings shall be not less than as established in this section for buildings containing dwelling units. 
(m)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as required in the R-1 residence district. 
(n)  Permitted signs. Signs for the R-4 intermediate residence district shall be as permitted in the R-1 single-family residence district. 
(o)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 lbs., or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this comprehensive zoning code. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 lbs., parked or stored on any residential premises, shall be limited to one if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, road work, or for use on a farm (including, but not limited to, bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residential district unless said equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 5), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 89-68, § 6, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 99-09, § 12, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 99-51, § 17, 11-9-1999; Ord. No. 04-29, § 4, 6-8-2004) 
Sec. 122-126. - R-5 single-family residence district. 
(a)  Area. In the R-5 single-family residence district, no minimum area shall be required for zoning the minimum lot size of 32,600 square feet. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No buildings or premises improved or unimproved shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-5 single-family residence district unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family detached dwellings. 
(2)  Accessory buildings, as defined in this chapter and regulated by section 122-10. 
(3)  Signs, as specified in this section. 
(4)  Residential off-street parking facilities, as specified in this section. 
(5)  Churches, elementary and high schools, public and private, public parks and playgrounds, provided the zoning lot of the use has an area of not less than one acre and has sufficient area to provide for both building space and required off-street parking. 
(6)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(7)  Fire stations and police stations. 
(8)  Reserved. 
(9)  Family community residences, provided the sponsoring agency obtains an occupancy certificate prior to establishing a family community residence. No dwelling unit shall be occupied as a family community residence until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for a family community residence unless: 
a.  The family community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line; and 
b.  The applicant demonstrates that it has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate the proposed family community residence; 
c.  The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operation is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
(10)  The following temporary uses subject to application to and issuance by the community development director of a permit thereof: 
a.  Temporary building or yard for construction materials and equipment, both incidental and necessary to construction in the zoning district. Each permit shall specify the location of the building or yard and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than six calendar months and shall not be renewed for more than four successive periods at the same location. 
b.  Temporary office, both incidental and necessary for the sale or rental of real property. Each permit shall specify the location of the office and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than one year and shall not be renewed for more than five successive periods at the same location. 
(11)  Special uses. The following special uses shall be permitted, subject to the conditions stipulated in the requirements provided in article V of this chapter: 
a.  Country clubs, golf courses, tennis courts and similar recreation uses, not including commercial community swimming pools, provided that any principal building or accessory swimming pool shall be located not less than 100 feet from any other lot in any R district. 
b.  Home occupations. 
c.  Municipal recreation building or community center. 
d.  Public utility facilities. 
e.  Cemeteries. 
f.  Municipal and governmental office buildings or court facilities and uses necessarily incidental thereto. 
g.  Wind-powered generators subject to the following: 
1.  No part shall be constructed of wood. 
2.  All moving parts shall be protected from contact, and the wind-driven blades shall be allowed to approach no closer than ten feet from grade. 
h.  Noncommercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
i.  Municipal libraries. 
j.  Group community residence subject to the following: 
1.  The group community residence must be located on a lot a minimum of 10,000 square feet in area and contain a minimum land area of 1,600 square feet per resident. 
2.  The group community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line. 
3.  The sponsor must demonstrate that it has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate as a group community residence. 
4.  No dwelling shall be occupied as a group community residence unless a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operate is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
5.  Landscaping is required pursuant to section 122-23, notwithstanding the exception to R-5 zoning stated in that section. 
(c)  Building height. The maximum building height allowed for lot platted or parcels deed prior to December 31, 1970 shall be 30 feet. Building height shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single-family dwellings: a maximum of 35 feet and not over 21/2 stories. 
(2)  Churches and permitted nonresidential structures: a maximum of 90 feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 35 feet for the main structures. 
(3)  Setback. The minimum setback shall not be less than 30 feet, except where all of the improved lots in any one block are developed with buildings which establish a setback greater or less than 30 feet, and the improved lots comprise 25 percent or more of the frontage in the block, such greater or lesser setback shall become the minimum setback in such block. No building erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered shall project beyond the setback so established in the block; provided, however, that this shall not be interpreted to require a setback of more than 60 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(d)  Side yards (for single-family residence uses). The side yards shall not be less than ten feet. On a corner lot, the side yard may be opposite either property line fronting on the street, provided the remaining yard is designated the rear yard. For single-family residences built prior to January 1, 1993, an attached garage may not be closer than five feet from the side property line, provided the garage is no more than 22 feet wide with a depth of no more than 22 feet. 
(e)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(f)  Yards (for nonresidential permitted uses and special uses). Front, side and rear yards shall be as required for single-family dwelling uses for buildings less than 35 feet in height, but for a building 35 feet or more in height each yard, front, side and rear, as required for single-family dwellings, shall be increased in width or depth by two feet for each additional one foot of building height over 35 feet. 
(g)  Floor area per dwelling. Every one-story dwelling erected in any R-1 single-family residence district shall have a total ground floor area of not less than 900 square feet, measured from the outside of the exterior walls, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. Every dwelling of more than one story erected in any R-5 single-family residence district shall have a total floor area measured from the outside of the exterior walls of not less than 1,200 square feet, of which a minimum of 900 square feet shall be the ground floor area of the first floor abovegrade, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. 
    The maximum floor area ratio ((F.A.R.) for single family attached and detached dwellings shall be as follows: 
Lot Size Floor Area Ratio 
(F.A.R.) 5,000 - 8,400 .45 8,400 - 10,000 .40 10,000 - 20,000 .35 20,000 - above .30  
    Area of attached and detached garages over the first 500 square feet shall be included in the gross floor area used to compute the floor area ratio. 
(h)  Lot area and width. 
(1)  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less than 32,600 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 90 feet. 
(2)  When a dwelling is to be served by a well or public water supply and individual septic tanks, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall have an area of not less than 43,560 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet. 
(3)  No building with its accessory building shall occupy in excess of 30 percent of the lot area. 
(4)  See definition of lot area measurement. 
(i)  Off-street parking and loading. The off-street parking and loading sections of this chapter shall apply as follows: 
(1)  When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through additional dwelling units, gross floor area, seating capacity or other units of measurement specified in this chapter for required parking or loading facilities as required in this section shall be provided for such increase in intensity of use. However, no building or structure lawfully erected or used, lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall be required to provide such additional parking or loading facilities unless and until the aggregate increase in units of measurement shall equal not less than 15 percent of the units of measurement existing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives; in which event parking or loading facilities as required in this section shall be provided for the total increase. 
(2)  Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use would exceed those for the existing use if the latter were subject to the parking and loading sections of this chapter. 
(j)  Existing parking and loading facilities. Accessory off-street parking or loading facilities which were in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives or were provided voluntarily after such effective date shall not be reduced below or, if already less than, shall not further be reduced below the requirements of this chapter for a similar new building or use. 
(k)  Permissive parking and loading facilities. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of contiguous off-street parking or loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings, provided that all regulations in this chapter governing the location, design, improvement and operation of such facilities are adhered to. 
(l)  Damage or destruction. For any conforming or legally nonconforming building or use which is in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, which subsequently thereto is damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause and which is reconstructed, reestablished or repaired, off-street parking or loading facilities need not be provided, except that parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction shall be restored or continued in operation. However, if the principal building or structure is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value, it shall then be necessary to restore or maintain parking or loading facilities as required by this chapter for equivalent new uses or construction. 
(m)  Submission of plot plan. Any application for a building permit shall include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing any parking or loading facilities to be provided in compliance with this chapter. 
(n)  Additional parking regulations. 
(1)  Use. Except as otherwise indicated, required accessory off-street parking facilities shall be solely for the parking of passenger automobiles of occupants or their guests. 
(2)  Computation. When determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(3)  Size. A required off-street parking space shall be at least nine feet in width and at least 20 feet in length, exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps or work areas. Such space shall have a vertical clearance of at least seven feet. 
(4)  Driveways. Each required off-street parking space shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway of such width and design as to provide safe and efficient means of vehicular access to such parking space. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or other public way in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across property or requiring a curb shall exceed a width of 25 feet. 
(5)  Location in yards. Off-street parking spaces and driveways within yard areas shall conform to the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 relating to driveways. 
(6)  Repair and service. No motor vehicle repair work of any kind shall be permitted in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities provided in any residence district. The sale of gasoline and motor oil in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities is not permitted in any residence district. 
(7)  Vehicles displayed and offered for sale. Vehicles displayed and offered for sale are subject to the following restrictions: 
a.  The owner of the vehicle must reside on the property on the premises where the vehicle is displayed and offered for sale. 
b.  Not more than two vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale at one time. 
c.  Not more than four vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale within a 12-month period. 
d.  Any sign displaying a vehicle for sale shall be located inside of the vehicle. 
(o)  Location of off-street parking. Parking spaces on individual lots, accessory to dwelling units, shall not be located on the public right-of-way. Parking spaces accessory to dwellings shall be located on the same zoning lot as the use served. 
(p)  Parking spaces. Parking spaces shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Dwelling uses. A minimum of two parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit, excluding garage or carport area. 
(2)  Churches, temples and other religious institutional uses. One parking space shall be provided for each five seats or for each 90 inches of seating space, whichever is less. 
(3)  Colleges, universities and businesses, professional and trade schools. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees, and one parking space shall be provided for each six students based on the maximum number of students attending class on the premises at any one time during any 24-hour period. 
(4)  Municipal or privately owned recreational buildings or community centers. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the visiting public. 
(5)  Public utility and public service uses. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the public. 
(6)  Elementary, junior high and high schools. For elementary and junior high schools, two parking spaces shall be provided for each 30 students of design capacity. For high schools, one off-street parking space shall be provided for seven students of design capacity. 
(7)  Other parking spaces. The plan commission shall determine the number of parking spaces to be provided for convents, fraternal institutions, rectories, parish houses and swimming pools. 
(8)  Uses not provided for. For uses not specifically covered in this schedule of parking requirements in this subsection, parking spaces shall be provided on the same basis as required for the most similar listed use or as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(q)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 pounds or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city Code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this chapter. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 pounds, parked or stored on any residential premises shall be limited to one, if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, roadwork, or for use on a farm (including but not limited to bulldozer, road grader, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residence district unless such equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(r)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with the following, and only those signs specifically permitted by the text of this section shall be permitted and none others: 
(1)  No sign shall be erected except the following nonflashing, nonilluminated signs: 
a.  Nameplate or identification signs, subject to the following: 
1.  There shall be no more than one nameplate not exceedingtwo square feet in area for each dwelling unit indicating the name of the occupant. 
2.  Every building shall have a minimum of one sign displaying the address of the building, and the sign shall be visible in its entirety from the street. 
3.  For churches and institutions, one identification sign not exceeding ten square feet in area shall be permitted, subject to the following: 
i.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way. 
ii.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than ten feet above curb level. 
b.  For sale and to rent signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign shall be erected, and the total area shall not exceed nine square feet. 
2.  The sign shall be displayed a minimum of 15 feet from the front property line and shall not project above the height of an exterior wall. 
3.  Not more than one sign shall be erected with a total area not exceeding nine square feet to indicate the sale of vacant property. If the vacant property exceeds one acre in size, a for sale or to rent sign may be erected, and the total area shall not exceed 64 square feet, and must be back 30 feet from the property line, and the sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance. The height of the sign shall not exceed ten feet. 
c.  Billboards shall not be permitted in the R-5 residence districts with the exception of two billboards for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of homes in a subdivision under construction, not to exceed ten square feet per each acre and which shall not exceed a cumulative total of 150 square feet. Their construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
1.  No billboard shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
2.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the issuance or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
3.  The location and arrangement of the billboards are subject to the specific approval of the director of building and zoning. 
d.  Open house and signs subject to the following conditions: 
1.  At any time, on any tract of real estate, not more than one open house sign shall be permitted which shall not exceed six square feet in gross surface area per sign face. 
2.  Open house signs may be placed on the public parkway at various intersections; however, they shall not interfere with any motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
3.  Such signs shall be allowed on Friday, Saturday and Sunday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
4.  All open house signs must have attached identification denoting the person who is responsible for the placement and removal of the signs. 
5.  At any given time, on any given tract of real estate or intersection, not more than one open house sign directing the public in any one direction may be placed by the same business entity (i.e., same business name). This subsection shall not prohibit the placement of two or more signs by the same business entity so long as those signs direct the public in a different direction. 
e.  Garage sale signs subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one on-premise sign which shall not exceed six square feet in area. 
2.  Directional signs may be placed on the public parkway at intersections provided: 
i.  They are not affixed to a utility pole, fence or public sign. 
ii.  They do not obstruct motorists; vision. 
iii.  They do not exceed a total of three signs. 
3.  Signs shall only be allowed on Thursday[s], Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
f.  Temporary construction and home improvement services signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign per premise shall be allowed. 
2.  No sign shall be erected prior to the beginning of the construction and once the work is complete, the sign must be removed. 
3.  Signs identifying contractors or home improvement services shall not exceed four square feet per sign face advertising the name of the company providing the service and any additional contact information for such service only. 
4.  Such signs shall be located no closer than 15 feet to the property line. 
5.  A permit shall be required for such sign. 
(2)  Directional signs and signs accessory to parking areas, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Directional signs erected by the city, not exceeding two square feet in area. 
b.  Signs directing entrances to or exits from parking area and limited to one sign for each such entrance or exit and to a maximum size of two square feet each shall be permitted. 
c.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way, except directional signs erected by the city. 
d.  Height. The top of directional signs shall not be higher than eight feet above curb level. 
(3)  Permitted nonflashing signs, i.e., bulletin boards, for churches or nonprofit institutions, shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  There shall not be more than one sign per lot, and no sign shall exceed 18 square feet in area or be closer than eight feet to any other zoning lot. 
b.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
(4)  Subdivision entrance identification signs subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Not to exceed two signs per approved subdivision; 
b.  One sign per corner lot; 
c.  Each sign shall not exceed 30 square feet in area; 
d.  Each sign shall not exceed six feet in height; 
e.  Signs are not to interfere with motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 6), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 91-71, § 11, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 92-34, §§ 3, 4, 4-28-1992; Ord. No. 93-07, §§ 14, 15, 2-23-1993; Ord. No. 93-37, § 1, 7-13-1993; Ord. No. 04-29, §§ 5, 8, 6-8-2004; Ord. No. 12-12, § 3, 3-13-2012; Ord. No. 17-19, § 29, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 122-127. - R-6 Single-family residence district. 
(a)  Area. In the R-6 single-family residence district, no minimum area shall be required for zoning the minimum lot size of 20,000 square feet. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No buildings or premises improved or unimproved shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any R-6 single-family residence district unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Single-family detached dwellings. 
(2)  Accessory buildings, as defined in this chapter and regulated by section 122-10. 
(3)  Signs, as specified in this section. 
(4)  Residential off-street parking facilities, as specified in this section. 
(5)  Churches, elementary and high schools, public and private, public parks and 
(6)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(7)  Fire stations and police stations. 
(8)  Reserved. 
(9)  Family community residences, provided the sponsoring agency obtains an occupancy certificate prior to establishing a family community residence. No dwelling unit shall be occupied as a family community residence until a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for a family community residence unless: 
a.  The family community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line; and 
b.  The applicant demonstrates that it has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate the proposed family community residence; 
c.  The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operate is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
(10)  The following temporary uses subject to application to and issuance by the community development director of a permit thereof: 
a.  Temporary building or yard for construction materials and equipment, both incidental and necessary to construction in the zoning district. Each permit shall specify the location of the building or yard and the area of permitted operation. Each permit shall be valid for a period of not less than six calendar months and shall not be renewed for more than four successive periods at the same location. 
b.  Temporary office, both incidental and necessary for the sale or rental of real property. Each permit shall specify the location of the office and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than one year and shall not be renewed for more than five successive periods at the same location. 
(11)  Special uses. The following special uses shall be permitted, subject to the conditions stipulated in the requirements provided in article V of this chapter. 
a.  Country clubs, golf courses, tennis courts and similar recreation uses, not including commercial community swimming pools, provided that any principal building or accessory swimming pool shall be located not less than 100 feet from any other lot in any R district. 
b.  Municipal recreation building or community center. 
c.  Public utility facilities. 
d.  Cemeteries. 
e.  Municipal and governmental office building or court facilities and uses necessarily incidental thereto. 
f.  Wind-powered generators subject to the following: 
1.  No part shall be constructed of wood. 
2.  All moving parts shall be protected from contact, and the wind-driven blades shall be allowed to approach no closer than ten feet from grade. 
g.  Noncommercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
h.  Municipal libraries. 
i.  Group community residence subject to the following: 
1.  The group community residence must be located on a lot a minimum of 10,000 square feet in area and contain a minimum land area of 1,600 square feet per resident. 
2.  The group community residence is located at least 1,000 feet from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot line. 
3.  The sponsor must demonstrate that it has either obtained or is eligible for state licensing or certification to operate as a group community residence. 
4.  No dwelling shall be occupied as a group community residence unless a certificate of occupancy has been issued by the community development director. The community development director may revoke a certificate of occupancy for a community residence if its license or certification to operate is revoked. A certificate of occupancy is not transferable to another sponsor or another dwelling. 
5.  Landscaping is required pursuant to section 122-23, notwithstanding the exception to R-6 zoning stated in that section. 
(c)  Building height. Building height shall be as follows: 
(1)  Single family dwellings: a maximum of 35 feet of not over 2 1/2 stories. 
(2)  Churches and permitted nonresidential structures: a maximum of 90 feet for towers or steeples, but not more than 35 for the main structure. 
(3)  Setback. The minimum setback shall not be less than 30 feet, except where all of the improved lots in any one block are developed with buildings which establish a setback greater or less than 30 feet, and the improved lots comprise 25 percent or more of the frontage in the block, such greater or lesser setback shall become the minimum setback in such block. No building erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered shall project beyond the setback so established in the block; provided, however that this shall not be interpreted to require a setback of more than 60 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(d)  Side yards (for single-family residence uses). The side yards shall not be less than ten feet. On a corner lot, the side yard may be opposite either property line fronting on the street, provided the remaining yard is designated the rear yard. For single family residences built prior to January 1, 1993, an attached garage may not be closer than five feet from the side property line, provided the garage is no more than 22 feet wide with a depth of no more than 22 feet. 
(e)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(f)  Yards (for nonresidential permitted uses and special uses). Front, side and rear yards shall be as required for single family dwelling uses for buildings less than 35 feet in height, but for a building 35 feet or more in height each yard, front, side and rear, as required for single family dwellings, shall be increased in width or depth by two feet for each additional one foot of building height over 35 feet. 
(g)  Floor area per dwelling. Every one-story dwelling erected in any R-6 single family residence district shall have a total ground floor area of not less than 900 square feet, measured from the outside of the exterior walls, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. Every dwelling of more than one story erected in any R-6 single family residence district shall have a total floor area measured from the outside of the exterior walls of not less tan 1,200 square feet, of which a minimum of 900 square feet shall be the ground floor area of the first floor above grade, including utility rooms, but excluding cellars, basements, open porches, breezeways, garages and other spaces that are not used frequently or during extended periods for living, eating or sleeping purposes. 
(h)  Lot area and width. 
1.  When a dwelling is to be served by public water supply and sanitary sewer facilities, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall be on a lot having an area of not less tan 20,000 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 75 feet. 
2.  When a dwelling is to be served by a well or public water supply and individual septic tanks, a one-family detached dwelling erected shall have an area of not less tan 43,560 square feet and a width at the established building line of not less than 100 feet. 
3.  No building with its accessory building shall occupy in excess of 30 percent of the lot area. 
4.  See definition of lot area measured. 
(i)  Off street parking and loading. The off-street parking and loading sections of this chapter shall apply as follows: 
(1)  When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through additional dwelling units, gross floor area, seating capacity or other units of measurement specified in this chapter for required parking or loading facilities as required in this section shall be provided for such increase in intensity of use. However, no building or structure lawfully erected or used, lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall be required to provide such additional parking or loading facilities unless and until the aggregate increase in units of management shall equal not less than 15 percent of the units of measurement existing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives; in which event parking or loading facilities as required in this section shall be provided for the total increase. 
(2)  Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use would exceed those for the existing use if the latter were subject to the parking and loading sections of this chapter. 
(j)  Existing parking and loading facilities. Accessory off-street parking or loading facilities which were in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives or were provided voluntarily after such effective date shall not be reduced below or, if already less than, shall not further be reduced below the requirements of this chapter for a similar new building or use. 
(k)  Permissive parking and loading facilities. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of contiguous off-street parking or loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings provided that all regulations in this chapter governing the location, design, improvement and operation of such facilities are adhered to. 
(l)  Damage or destruction. For any conforming or legally nonconforming building or use which is in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, which subsequently thereto is damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause of which is reconstructed, reestablished or repaired, off-street parking or loading facilities need not be provided, except that parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction shall be restored or contained in operation. However, if the principal building or structure is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value, it shall then be necessary to restore or maintain parking or loading facilities as required by this chapter for equivalent new uses or construction. 
(m)  Submission of plot plan. Any application for a building permit shall include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing any parking or loading facilities to be provided in compliance with this chapter. 
(n)  Additional parking regulations. 
(1)  Use. Except as otherwise indicated, required accessory off-street parking facilities shall be solely for the parking of passenger automobiles or occupants or their guests. 
(2)  Computation. When determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(3)  Size. A required off-street parking space shall be at least nine feet in width and at least 20 feet in length, exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps or work areas. Such space shall have a vertical clearance of at least seven feet. 
(4)  Driveways. Each required off-street parking spaces shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway of such width and design as to provide safe and efficient means of vehicular access to such parking space. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or other public way in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across property or requiring a curb shall exceed a width of 25 feet. 
(5)  Location in yards. Off-street parking spaces and driveways within yard areas shall conform to the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 relating to driveways. 
(6)  Repair and service. No motor vehicle repair work of any kind shall be permitted in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities provided in any residence district. The sale of gasoline and motor oil in conjunction with accessory off-street parking facilities is not permitted in any residence district. 
(7)  Vehicles displayed and offered for sale. Vehicles displayed and offered for sale are subject to the following restrictions: 
a.  The owner of the vehicle must reside on the property on the premises where the vehicle is displayed and offered for sale. 
b.  Not more than two vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale at one time. 
c.  Not more than four vehicles shall be displayed and offered for sale within a 12-month period. 
d.  Any sign displaying a vehicle for sale shall be located inside the vehicle. 
(o)  Location of off-street parking. Parking spaces on individual lots, accessory to dwelling units, shall not be located on the public right-of-way. Parking spaces accessory to dwellings shall be located on the same zoning lot as the use served. 
(p)  Parking spaces. Parking spaces shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  Dwelling uses. A minimum of two parking spaces shall be provided for each dwelling unit, excluding garage or carport area. 
(2)  Churches, temples, and other religious institutional uses. One parking space shall be provided for each five seats or for each 90 inches of seating space, whichever is less. 
(3)  Colleges, universities and businesses, professional and trade schools. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees, and one parking space shall be provided for each six students based on the maximum number of students attending class on the premises at any one time during any 24-hour period. 
(4)  Municipal or privately owned recreational buildings or community centers. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the visiting public. 
(5)  Public utility and public service uses. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the planning and zoning commission to serve the public. 
(6)  Elementary, junior high and high schools. For elementary and junior high schools, two parking spaces shall be provided for each 30 students of design capacity. For high schools, one off-street parking space shall be provided for seven students of design capacity. 
(7)  Other parking spaces. The plan commission shall determine the number of parking spaces to be provided for covenants, fraternal institutions, rectories, parish houses and swimming pools. 
(8)  Uses not provided for. For uses not specifically covered in this schedule of parking requirements in this subsection, parking spaces shall be provided on the same basis as required for the most similar listed use or as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(q)  Parking of second division vehicles. No vehicle of the second division, so classified by the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code, exceeding 8,000 pounds or exceeding a length of 20 feet, height of 12 feet, or width of eight and one-half feet, excluding recreational vehicles otherwise provided for in the city Code, shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in the residence district pursuant to this chapter. The number of second division vehicles not exceeding 8,000 pounds, parked or stored on any residential premises shall be limited to one, if that vehicle is used for a business or commercial purpose. No equipment or machinery designed for the movement of earth, roadwork, or for use on a farm (including but not limited to bulldozer, road grazer, tractor, crane, or roller) shall be parked or stored on any residential premises classified in a residence district unless such equipment and machinery is actually engaged in work on the subject premises. 
(r)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with the following, and only those signs specifically permitted by the text of this section shall be permitted and none others: 
(1)  No sign shall be erected except the following non-flashing, non-illuminated signs: 
a.  Nameplate or identification signs, subject to the following: 
1.  There shall be no more than one nameplate not exceeding two square feet in area for each dwelling unit indicating the name of the occupant. 
2.  Every building shall have a minimum of one sign displaying the address of the building, and the sign shall be visible in its entirety from the street. 
3.  For churches and institutions, one identification sign not exceeding ten square feet in area shall be permitted, subject to the following: 
i.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way. 
ii.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than ten feet above curb level. 
b.  For sale and to rent signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign shall be erected, and the total area shall not exceed nine square feet. 
2.  The sign shall be displayed a minimum of 15 feet from the front property line and shall not project above the height of an exterior wall. 
3.  Not more than one sign shall be erected with a total area not exceeding nine square feet to indicate the sale of vacant property. If the vacant property exceeds one acre in size, a for sale or to rent sign may be erected, and the total area shall not exceed 64 square feet, and must be back 30 feet from the property line, and the sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance. The height of the sign shall not exceed ten feet. 
c.  Billboards shall not be permitted in the R-6 residence districts with the exception of two billboards for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of homes in a subdivision under construction, not to exceed ten square feet per each acre and which shall not exceed a cumulative total of 150 square feet. Their construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
1.  No billboard shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
2.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the issuance or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
3.  The location and arrangement of the billboards are subject to the specific approval of the director of community development. 
d.  Open house, garage and rummage sale signs subject to the following conditions: 
1.  At any time, on any tract of real estate, not more than one open house sign shall be permitted which shall not exceed six square feet in gross surface area per sign face. 
2.  Open house signs may be placed on the public parkway at various intersections; however, they shall not interfere with any motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
3.  Such signs shall be allowed on Friday, Saturday and Sunday between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
4.  All open house signs must have attached identification denoting the person who is responsible for the placement and removal of the signs. 
5.  At any given time, on any given tract of real estate or intersection, not more than one open house sign directing the public in any one direction may be placed by the same business entity (i.e. same business name). The subsection shall not prohibit the placement of two or more signs by the same business entity so long as those signs direct the public in a different direction. 
e.  Temporary construction and home improvement services signs, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Not more than one sign per premise shall be allowed. 
2.  No sign shall be erected prior to the beginning of the construction and once the work is complete, the sign must be removed. 
3.  Signs identifying contractors or home improvement services shall not exceed four square feet per sign face advertising the name of the company providing the service and any additional contact information for such service only. 
4.  Such signs shall be located no closer than 15 feet to the property line. 
5.  A permit shall be required for such sign. 
(2)  Directional signs and signs necessary to parking areas, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Directional signs erected by the city, not exceeding two square feet in area. 
b.  Signs directing entrances to or exits from parking area and limited to one sign for each entrance or exit and to a maximum size of two square feet each shall be permitted. 
c.  Projection. No sign shall project beyond the property line into the public way, except directional signs erected by the city. 
d.  Height. The top of directional signs shall not be higher than eight feet above the curb level. 
(3)  Permitted non-flashing signs, i.e. bulletin boards, for churches or non-profit institutions, shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  There shall not be more than one sign per lot, and no sign shall exceed 18 square feet in area or be closer than eight feet to any other zoning lot. 
b.  Height. The top of a sign shall not be higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
(4)  Subdivision entrance identification signs subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Not to exceed two signs per approved subdivision. 
b.  One sign per corner lot. 
c.  Each sign shall not exceed 30 square feet in area. 
d.  Each sign shall not exceed six feet in height. 
e.  Signs are not to interfere with motor vehicle driver's line of vision. 
(Ord. No. 03-62, § 2, 10-14-2003; Ord. No. 12-12, § 4, 3-13-2012; Ord. No. 17-19, § 30, 6-13-2017) 
Secs. 122-128-122-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRANSITIONAL[3]
