Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 122-156. - T-1 office, institutional and research district. 
(a)  Size. In the T-1 office, institutional and research district a minimum of two acres shall be required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any T-1 office, institutional and research district as provided in this chapter except for the following uses: 
(1)  Motels, hotels and extended stay hotels and motels. 
(2)  Principal offices of professional persons. 
(3)  Offices for administrative, executive, professional research or similar organizations (nonretail); provided, however, that merchandise related to the operations of manufacturers' agents may be displayed on the premises incidental to the principal use within administrative offices and shall be limited to pilot and component development facilities without mass production for sale and public consumption. 
(4)  Colleges, junior colleges, universities, churches, elementary and high schools, public parks and playgrounds. 
(5)  Indoor restaurants and cocktail lounges. 
(6)  Funeral homes with an accessory residential dwelling for an owner or employee; provided, however, that the use shall not include a crematorium. 
(7)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(8)  Banks and savings and loan associations. 
(9)  State lottery video game machines in the alcoholic beverage service area only of premises holding a class AA-1 or class A-1 alcoholic liquor license. 
(10)  Banquet facilities. 
(11)  Performing Arts Center and Theater. 
(12)  Health clubs and physical fitness centers not to exceed 7,500 square feet in size. 
(13)  Governmental recreation and assembly buildings. 
(14)  Fire stations. 
(15)  Special uses permitted in the T-1 office, institutional and research district shall be as follows: 
a.  Nursery schools, day nurseries and child care centers, providing there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided that the area be fenced and screened from view from any adjoining lot in any single-family residential district. 
b.  Health and medical institutions, including convalescent homes, medical, dental, mental or optical clinics and hospitals, including rehabilitation and treatment centers and also including juvenile counseling and guidance centers. 
c.  Philanthropic and eleemosynary institutions. 
d.  Community centers. 
e.  Fraternity, sorority or lodge building. 
f.  Studio for professional work or teaching of any form of fine arts, photography, music, drama, dance, but not including commercial gymnasium. 
g.  Mechanical device amusement centers in hotels, motels, motor inns, and governmental recreation and assembly buildings. 
h.  Drive-in banks subject to the following: 
1.  Intent and purpose. It is recognized that drive-in banks warrant special consideration because of their design and operation which is unique, such as dependence on vehicular traffic, unenclosed nature of the activity, distinctive physical appearance and long hours of operation. Therefore, the following standards are to serve as guidelines for approval or denial of applications for drive-in banks. These standards are intended to encourage better land planning and use techniques with maximum use of aesthetically pleasing architecture, landscaping, site layout and design. The compliance with these standards and any condition of approval shall be in addition to compliance with the regulations of the district. 
2.  Building site and frontage. The minimum building site shall be 22,000 square feet with a minimum frontage on any public right-of-way of 150 feet. 
i.  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
j.  Senior living centers or assisted living establishments subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Parking is to be provided at the rate of 0.75 parking stall per guestroom; however, if regular transportation is provided to the occupants, the ratio may be reduced to 0.5 parking stall per guestroom. 
2.  Outdoor recreational open space shall be provided at the rate of 75 square feet per guestroom. The design and landscaping of the open space shall be as approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
3.  Guestrooms are to be a minimum of 230 square feet in area, including the bathroom, for a single occupancy and a minimum of 305 square feet, including the bathroom, for a double occupancy. 
4.  A primary living room/lounge area shall be provided with its minimum size to equal 15 square feet per guestroom but not less than 200 square feet. 
5.  Secondary lounge and kitchen areas shall be provided on each guest floor at a minimum size to equal six feet per guestroom on the floor but not less than 150 square feet. 
6.  An activity room, other than the living room/lounge, shall be provided with its minimum size to equal 15 feet per guest but not less than 200 square feet. 
7.  A main dining room shall be provided with its minimum size to equal 12 square feet per guest but not less than 200 square feet. 
8.  Public restrooms for each sex shall be provided on the main floor. 
9.  Applicable license code regulations and requirements must be met. 
k.  Permanent outdoor business activities. 
l.  Private business persons' club, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Parking shall be provided at the rate of one parking space per 75 square feet of seating area plus one space for every two employees; and 
2.  A manager employed by the club must be on premise during operating hours. 
(c)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio in the T-1 district shall not exceed 1.0 times the lot area. 
(d)  Setback. The minimum setback for buildings along arterial primary, major and secondary streets shown on the official plan of the city shall be in accordance with section 122-20, and the requirements along minor streets shall be not less than 30 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(e)  Side yards. The side yards shall not be less than 15 feet. 
(f)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard having a depth of lot not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(g)  Maximum lot cover. The maximum area occupied by all buildings on any lot shall not exceed 65 percent of the total area of the lot. 
(h)  Floor area per dwelling. The minimum floor area per dwelling unit for motels, hotels and motor inns in the T-1 district shall be 180 square feet per dwelling unit. 
(i)  Screening. T-1 zoned lots are to be screened from adjacent R-1 and R-2 zoned lots by a fence not less than six feet in height. 
(j)  Lot area and width. All uses permitted in the T-1 office, institutional and research district shall be served by public water and sanitary sewers. The minimum lot area shall be 20,000 square feet, the minimum width at the established building line shall be 100 feet and the minimum lot area per dwelling unit for motels and motels shall be 1,000 square feet. 
(k)  Requirements for inner courts. An inner court shall have a width of not less than 12 feet, a length of not less than one-fifth of the height of such court, nor shall its area be less than twice the square of its required least dimension. 
(l)  Requirements for outer courts. The width of an outer court shall not be less than one-fifth of the height of such court nor less than one-fifth of the length of such court. 
(m)  Advertising bus shelter. An off-premise sign located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.) which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this Zoning Code, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city, subject to the following: 
(1)  The bus shelter shall be illuminated for the safety of the users. 
(2)  No advertising of tobacco or alcohol products shall be permitted; any advertising must be in conformance with guidelines adopted by the city council. 
(3)  The area of advertising signage shall not exceed 48 square feet, 24 square feet on a single side; and be restricted to one of the four sides of the shelter. The display shall not totally obstruct the view into the shelter from the outside; i.e., a visible gap is provided at the bottom and the top to permit a view of persons using the bus shelter. 
(4)  A lease agreement for the bus shelter be in place between the city and a corporation formed pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.). 
(5)  Any other conditions imposed by the city council through the adoption of the special use ordinance. 
(n)  Projections in outer courts. When an outer court is partially enclosed by projections, the sum of the projections shall not exceed 25 percent of the greatest required width of the court. 
(o)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with the following, and only those signs specifically permitted shall be allowed and none others: 
(1)  a.  One sign which pertains to the use conducted within the main building which is displayed flat against a wall of the building and which does not project above the roofline and does not exceed 25 percent of the square footage of the wall area on which the sign is to be affixed, or a maximum of 150 square feet. 
b.  A second wall sign sized in like manner shall be permitted for buildings in excess of 10,000 square feet in total floor area. 
(2)  Signs on secondary walls, for the purpose of identifying loading docks and secondary entrances, shall not exceed an area of one square foot per five lineal feet of that face width on which the sign is located, or a maximum of 20 square feet. 
(3)  Signs for the purpose of directing vehicular traffic on-site subject to the following: 
a.  The size of the sign is not to exceed six square feet in area and the height shall not exceed five ft. measured to the top of the sign. 
b.  Not more than 33 percent of the sign area shall be devoted to a corporate logo, advertising or identification. 
c.  The number, location and arrangement of the said signs shall be per the approval of the community development director. 
(4)  Freestanding signs. One freestanding sign per zoning lot which pertains to a business or businesses conducted on the zoning lot; provided, however: 
a.  The gross area of the sign, in square feet, shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. However, if the sign is illuminated the gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. 
b.  No portion of the sign shall extend over the property line. 
c.  Any such sign shall not exceed 15 feet in height above the curb level. 
d.  No sign as provided for in this subsection shall exceed 150 square feet in gross area. 
e.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign only the largest frontage of the zoning lot shall be used. 
f.  Each zoned lot in excess of three acres in size shall be allowed one additional freestanding sign per each three acres of land area in excess of the first three acres, up to a maximum of three signs. Said sign to be sized and located per the foregoing in this section. 
(5)  During initial development two billboards for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of sites or buildings not to exceed 200 square feet each, and they shall not be located nearer than 25 feet to the property line or boundary line of the property on which the sign is to be located and shall advertise or identify only the property upon which the sign is erected. The billboard's construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  No billboard shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
b.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the date of issuance, or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
c.  The location and arrangement of the billboard is subject to the specific approval of the director of building and zoning. 
(6)  Signs indicating vacant property for sale, lease or rent shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  One sign per five acres or fraction thereof up to a maximum of three signs. 
b.  The cumulative total of signs shall not exceed 300 square feet and no single sign shall exceed 120 square feet 
c.  The location and arrangement of said signs are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance or upon the sale or lease of the land. 
(7)  The maximum of permanent freestanding and wall signs shall not exceed 150 square feet. 
(8)  Signs indicating developed property for sale, lease or rent shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  One sign per five acres or fraction thereof up to a maximum of three signs. 
b.  The cumulative total of signs shall not exceed 300 square feet and no single sign shall exceed 120 square feet. 
c.  The location and arrangement of the signs are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the date of issuance or upon the sale or lease of the land. 
(9)  One banner is permitted for a period not to exceed 30 days per calendar year per premises. The banner area shall not exceed ten percent of the wall area of the premises and in no case shall exceed 100 square feet. The location and arrangement of the banner is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
(10)  School, institutional, non-profit organizations and churches located upon land three acres or more in size shall be allowed signage subject to the following: 
a.  Freestanding signs. One freestanding sign of an area not exceeding 10 percent of the lot's frontage or 100 square feet, whichever is less. The signs height shall not exceed six feet. 
b.  Wall signs. One wall sign of an area not exceeding 10 percent of the wall area to which the sign is affixed or 100 square feet, whichever is less. 
c.  Temporary signs. Temporary special event and similar signs are permitted subject to the following restrictions: 
1.  No more than two temporary signs shall be placed on the property at any one time. 
2.  The display of temporary signs shall be limited to a cumulative total of 120 days per calendar year per premises. 
3.  Temporary sign(s) shall not be erected more than 30 days prior to the event and shall be removed immediately after the termination of the event of activity. 
4.  The temporary sign(s) shall not exceed 100 square feet. 
5.  The location and arrangement of the temporary sign is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
6.  Temporary sign shall be designed to be stable under all weather conditions. 
(11)  Directories. Each multi-tenant building is permitted one freestanding or wall directory sign not exceeding eight ft. In height and 24 square feet in area. Arrangement and location of director signage shall be approved by the community development director. 
(12)  Illinois Rte. 53 Expressway sign overlay district. 
a.  Purpose. The purpose of this district is to provide areas along the Illinois Route 53 expressway through the City of Rolling Meadows for the erection of off-premises advertising signs as defined in section 122-3(c) of the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance of Rolling Meadows, Illinois of 1972; limit the area where such signs are permitted to certain lands zoned T-1 office, Institutional and Research District and M-1 Manufacturing District and located immediately west of the adjacent of Illinois Route 53 Expressway generally between Euclid Avenue and US Route 14 (Northwest Highway) and immediately east of Illinois Route 53 north of Euclid to a point of 1,300 feet north of the centerline of Euclid Avenue. 
b.  Location of district boundaries. All incorporated land currently zoned T-1 office, institutional and research district and M-1 manufacturing district west of and adjacent to Illinois Route 53 Expressway generally between Euclid Avenue and U.S. Route 14 (Northwest Highway), and east of and adjacent to Illinois Route 53 Expressway from the centerline of Euclid Avenue terminating 1,300 feet north of the centerline of Euclid Avenue, in the City of Rolling Meadows. The width of the overlay district shall be 100 feet from the edge of the Route 53 right-of-way along that span. 
c.  Permitted uses. 
1.  Off-premise advertising signs (billboards). 
d.  Dimensional standards. 
1.  Maximum height: 60 feet above the immediate adjacent expressway pavement surface. 
2.  Maximum size: 1,200 square feet gross surface area per face. 
3.  Maximum length: 60 feet. 
4.  Minimum separation: 700 linear feet measured from pole-to-pole from one existing off-premises advertising sign to another existing off-premises advertising sign on the same side of the expressway. 
e.  Applicable provisions. 
1.  Any new off-premises advertising signs, including electronic message and digital display signs ("digital signs"), with an advertisement or information pertaining to business conducted off the property, may be located on property within the City of Rolling Meadows' Illinois Rte. 53 Expressway sign overlay district. 
2.  No off-premises advertising sign shall be located in such a position that it obscures the view of vehicular or pedestrian traffic in such a manner as to endanger the safe movement thereof. 
3.  No off-premises advertising sign shall be located within 500 feet, measured from the closest point of the sign to the closest property line of any lot used for residential purposes. No digital off-premises advertising sign (face) shall be located within 1,000 feet of any lot used for residential purposes. Hotels and motels are not considered residential uses for purposes of this section. 
4.  No off-premises advertising sign shall be erected or maintained upon or above the roof of any building or structure. 
5.  Off-premise advertising signs shall not be "stacked" one on top of another or placed together horizontally "end-to-end" or "side-by-side." 
6.  Only one off-premise advertising sign shall be erected per zoning lot. 
7.  Off-premise advertising signs may be single-faced or double-faced but no off-premises advertising sign shall contain more than one face on each side of the display and the surface area shall not exceed a total of 1,200 square feet of gross surface area per face. 
8.  No off-premise sign shall exceed 60 feet above the level of the immediate adjacent expressway pavement surface. 
9.  Lighting. 
i.  No off-premise advertising sign shall be so illuminated that the light intensity or brightness adversely affects the safe vision of operators of vehicles moving on public or private streets, highways, or parking areas or of pedestrians. 
ii.  No off-premise advertising sign shall be illuminated by any exposed tubes or bulbs, strobe or incandescent lamp or floodlights, nor shall any off-premises advertising sign incorporate any reflective device. 
iii.  Flashing off-premise advertising signs are prohibited. In addition, no off-premises advertising sign shall contain or be illuminated by revolving, rotating, animated or any other form of moving light or lights. 
iv.  No off-premises advertising sign shall be so illuminated that the light intensity or brightness causes direct glare into or upon any building or in any other way adversely affects surrounding or facing properties. 
v.  All lighting shall be shielded and directed towards the face of the sign to prevent spillage to the surrounding area. 
10.  Digital messaging. 
i.  Hold time: A minimum ten second hold time shall be maintained for any message, sign, logo, image or other display on an off-premises advertising sign. 
ii.  Static: All messages or displays must be static. No flashing of images displayed on an off-premises advertising sign shall be permitted. "Flashing" in this context shall mean where the sign alternates suddenly between being fully illuminated and non-fully illuminated for the purpose of drawing attention to the off-premises advertising sign. 
iii.  Transition time: Regardless of technology used, changes between messages or displays must be instantaneous. 
iv.  No speakers or other audio systems shall be attached to the off-premises advertising sign, and no audio presentations shall emanate from the off-premises advertising sign. 
v.  No motion pictures shall be displayed on off-premises advertising signs. 
11.  Appearance and maintenance. 
i.  Exposed backs of signs, poles and other support structures shall be required to be painted or shielded to minimize adverse visual impacts and to present a finished appearance so as to improve the visual appearance. 
ii.  Supporting structures shall be adequately screened from abutting properties with a combination of fencing and vegetation (existing and proposed) as shown on a landscape diagram. 
iii.  All off-premise advertising signs, including the sign faces, supporting structures, lights and landscaping shall be kept in good repair and free from tears, rust and other indication of deterioration. 
iv.  Off-premise advertising signs and support structures shall be removed within one month of cessation of use. "Cessation of use," shall be defined as a period of 90 consecutive days in which the sign is not used or there is no intent to resume the use or activity of the sign. 
12.  All off-premises advertising signs shall be subject to the City of Rolling Meadows annual sign and inspection fee as outlined in Appendix B entitled, "Schedule of Rates, Fees, Fines and Penalties" of the Code of Ordinances, City of Rolling Meadows, Illinois 
13.  Application requirements. An applicant for an off-premise advertising sign shall first obtain an approved permit from the Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT). Along with the IDOT permit, the application submission to the city shall also include: 
i.  A site plan on a current plat of survey for the property which shall show the location of the proposed sign in relation to all property lines and structures (principal and accessory) on the property, where applicable, easements, right-of-ways, utilities if nearby, etc.; 
ii.  A general description of structural design and construction materials of the sign; 
iii.  A color rendering/drawing of the proposed sign which shall contain specifications as to the height, perimeter, and area dimensions, means of support (support structure), methods of illumination, if any, source and location of power, and any other significant aspect of the proposed sign; 
iv.  A written certification by a professional engineer as to the wind load, structural performance, lighting characteristics, and orientation. Verification that the underlying soil is capable of sustaining the proposed load and that the electrical and structural strength of the proposed sign is satisfactory. 
v.  A landscape plan encircling the support area of the sign. 
vi.  Any other information requested by the community development department in order to carry out the purpose and intent of this overlay district. 
vii.  Each sign face shall be considered a separate sign for purposes of permit and filing fees. 
(p)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as permitted in the C-1 commercial district, except as follows for a motel, motor inn or hotel: 
(1)  Off-street parking and loading requirements for motels, motor inns and hotels shall be as follows: 
a.  One parking space shall be provided for each lodging unit of a motel, motor inn or hotel. No more than ten percent of the required parking spaces shall be in front of any building; however, the total number of parking spaces in front of any building shall not exceed 20; 
b.  One parking space shall be provided for every 150 gross square feet of floor area of the restaurant/dining area, excluding kitchen and storage areas; 
c.  One parking space shall be provided for every 100 gross square feet of floor area for a cocktail lounge or bar area; plus 
d.  One parking space shall be provided for every 75 square feet of banquet or meeting room facility. 
(2)  Lighting. Any lighting used to illuminate off-street parking areas shall be directed away from residential properties in such a way as not to create a nuisance to either residential properties or oncoming vehicles on a public street. 
(q)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26.

Sec. 122-157. - T-2 office, institution (transitional) district. 
(a)  Permitted uses. No building or use, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any T-2 office, institution (transitional) district, as provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Principal offices of professional persons. 
(2)  Offices for administrative, executive, professional, research or similar organizations (nonretail). 
(3)  Banks and savings and loan associations. 
(4)  Planned developments, as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(5)  Fire stations. 
(6)  Special uses permitted in the T-2 office, institution (transitional) district shall be as follows: 
a.  Nursery schools, day nurseries and child care centers, providing there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided that the area be fenced and screened from view from any adjoining single-family residence district. 
b.  Health and medical institutions, including convalescent homes, medical, dental and mental or optical clinics, including rehabilitation and treatment centers and also including juvenile counseling and guidance centers. 
c.  Studio for professional work or teaching of any form of fine arts, photography, music, drama, dance, but not including gymnasiums. 
d.  Drive-in banks, provided they are in accordance with subsection 122-193(b)(16)a. 
e.  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
f.  Shelter for victims of domestic abuse. 
g.  Funeral homes with accessory residential dwelling for an owner or employee provided, however, that the use shall not include a crematorium. 
h.  Permanent outdoor business activities. 
(b)  Floor area ratio. The floor area ratio in the T-2 district shall not exceed 0.5. 
(c)  Setback. The minimum setback for buildings shall not be less than 30 feet. The setback requirements shall be observed on each street side of a corner lot. 
(d)  Side yards. The side yard shall be not less than 15 feet. 
(e)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard having a depth of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot measured from the rear lot line, but such yard need not exceed 30 feet. 
(f)  Maximum lot coverage. The maximum area occupied by all buildings on any lot shall not exceed 50 percent of the total area of the lot. 
(g)  Screening. T-2 zoned lots are to be screened from adjacent R-1 and R-2 zoned lots by a fence not less than six feet in height. 
(h)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as required in the C-1 commercial district; provided, however, that not more than ten percent of the required parking is permitted in the required 30-foot setback. Any lighting used to illuminate off-street parking areas shall be directed away from residential properties or oncoming vehicles on a public street. 
(i)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted in accordance with the following, and only those signs specifically permitted shall be allowed and none others: 
(1)  Wall signs. 
a.  One sign which pertains to the use conducted within the principal building, which is displayed flat against a wall of the building and which does not project above the roofline and does not exceed ten percent of the square footage of the wall area on which the sign is to be affixed, but in no case shall the sign exceed 150 square feet. 
b.  A second wall sign sized in like manner shall be permitted for buildings in excess of 10,000 square feet in total floor area. 
(2)  Signs on secondary walls. Signs on secondary walls for the purpose of identifying loading docks and secondary entrances shall not exceed an area one square foot per five lineal feet of that face width on which the sign is located, but in no case shall the sign exceed 20 square feet. 
(3)  [Vehicular traffic signs.] Signs for the purpose of directing vehicular traffic on site subject to the following: 
a.  The size of the sign is not to exceed six square feet in area and the height shall not exceed five ft. measured to the top of the sign. 
b.  Not more than 33 percent of the sign area shall be devoted to a corporate logo, advertising or identification. 
c.  The number, location and arrangement of said signs shall be per the approval of the community development director. 
(4)  Freestanding signs. One freestanding sign per zoning lot which pertains to the use within the principal building on such zoning lot shall be permitted, providing the following: 
a.  The gross area of a nonilluminated sign, in square feet, shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot, and illuminated signs shall not exceed one-half times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. 
b.  No portion of the sign shall extend over the property line. 
c.  Any such sign shall extend over the property line. 
d.  Reserved. 
e.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign only, the largest frontage of the zoning lot shall be used in computing the area. 
f.  Each zoned lot in excess of three acres in size shall be allowed one additional sign per each three acres of land area in excess of the first three acres up to a maximum of three signs. Said signs to be sized and located per the foregoing sections. 
(5)  Billboard signs. During initial development, one billboard sign for the purpose of identification for the sale or rental of sites or buildings shall be permitted, not to exceed 150 square feet in area. The sign shall advertise or identify only the property upon which the sign is erected. The billboard's construction shall be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  No billboard shall be nearer than 25 feet to any property line. 
b.  No billboard shall project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
c.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance or sooner, if all units or sites are rented or sold. 
(6)  Signs on vacant property for sale, lease or rent. One sign indicating vacant property for sale, lease or rent shall not exceed 100 square feet in an area and shall comply with the following conditions: 
a.  The sign shall not project higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
b.  The location and arrangement of the sign is subject to the specific approval of the director of building and zoning. 
c.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance. 
(7)  Signs indicating developed property for sale, lease or rent shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  One sign per five acres or fraction thereof up to a maximum of three signs. 
b.  The cumulative total of signs shall not exceed 300 square feet And no single sign shall exceed 120 square feet 
c.  The location and arrangement of said signs are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance, or upon the sale or lease of the land. 
(8)  One banner is permitted for a period not to exceed 30 days per calendar year per premises. The banner area shall not exceed ten percent of the wall area of the premises and in no case shall it exceed 100 square feet. The location and arrangement of the banner is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
(9)  Directories. Each multi-tenant building is permitted one freestanding or wall directory sign not exceeding eight ft. in height and 24 square feet in area. The arrangement and location of the directory signage shall be as approved by the community development director. 
(j)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. VIII, § 8), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 89-68, § 7, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 91-71, § 10, 12-10-1991; Ord. No. 93-07, § 17, 2-23-1993; Ord. No. 99-09, §§ 20-27, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 02-04, § 4, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 02-29, § 2, 6-11-2002; Ord. No. 04-08, § 3, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 17-29, § 2, 9-26-2017) 
Editor's note- Section 14 of Ord. No. 02-04, adopted Feb. 12, 2002, states that the provisions pertaining to pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall be of no further force and effect from and after 18 months from the effective date thereof, unless extended by action of the city council prior to the expiration of the 18 months. 
Secs. 122-158-122-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - COMMERCIAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 122-186. - Purpose. 
    The commercial districts set forth in this division are established to protect public health; to promote public safety, comfort, convenience and the general welfare; and to protect the economic base of the city and the value of property. These general purposes include, among others, the specific objectives to: 
(1)  Promote the most desirable use of land in accordance with a well-considered plan so that adequate space is provided in appropriate locations for the various types of business uses, thereby protecting and strengthening the economic base of the city. 
(2)  Place in separate districts those businesses which may create noise, odors, hazards, unsightliness, or which may generate excessive traffic. 
(3)  Permit selected business users in districts where adjacent to or inclusion in a residential area has sufficient elements of service or convenience to such areas to offset the disadvantage. 
(4)  Encourage the grouping in appropriate locations of compatible business uses which will tend to draw trade that is mutually interchangeable and so promote public convenience and business prosperity and contribute to the alleviation of traffic and pedestrian congestion. 
(5)  Provide for the establishment of off-street parking facilities, permitted and required, so as to alleviate traffic congestion and so promote shopping convenience and business prosperity. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 1), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-187. - C-1 commercial district. 
(a)  Size. In the C-1 commercial district a minimum of two acres shall be required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. All of the following permitted uses, except the required off-street parking facilities, shall be conducted wholly within an enclosed building, and no building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any C-1 commercial district, unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Alcoholic liquor sales. 
(2)  Antique shop. 
(3)  Art and school supply store. 
(4)  Art galleries and studios. 
(5)  Auto parts stores. 
(6)  Bakery shop, including the baking and processing of food products, when prepared for retail use on the premises only. 
(7)  Banks and financial institutions. 
(8)  Barbershop, beauty parlor, massage or similar personal service shop. 
(9)  Bicycle sales and repair. 
(10)  Book and stationery stores. 
(11)  Butcher shop, excluding the slaughtering of animals and poultry on the premises. 
(12)  Camera and photographic supply shops for retail sale. 
(13)  Carpet, rug and flooring stores. 
(14)  Ceramic shops. 
(15)  Coin and philatelic stores. 
(16)  Cold storage lockers, excluding slaughtering. 
(17)  Confectionery store. 
(18)  Currency exchange. 
(19)  Custom dressmaking, millinery, tailoring or shoe repair, when conducted for retail sales on the premises only. 
(20)  Department stores. 
(21)  Drugstores. 
(22)  Dry cleaning and pressing establishments, when employing facilities for the cleaning and pressing of not more than 750 pounds of dry goods per day, and when using perchloroethylene or other similar nonflammable solvents approved by the fire department. 
(23)  Dry goods store. 
(24)  Electrical appliance store and repair, but not including appliance assembly or manufacturing. 
(25)  Florist shop and conservatory for retail trade on the premises only. 
(26)  Foodstore, fruit store or delicatessen. 
(27)  Furniture store and upholstery, when conducted as part of the retail operations and secondary to the main use. 
(28)  Furrier, when conducted for retail trade on the premises only. 
(29)  Garden supplies and seed stores. 
(30)  Gift shops. 
(31)  Haberdashery. 
(32)  Hardware stores. 
(33)  Hobby stores. 
(34)  Household appliance stores. 
(35)  Indoor play park. 
(36)  Interior decorating shops, including upholstery and making of draperies, slip covers and other similar articles, when conducted as part of the retail operations and secondary to the main use. 
(37)  Jewelry and watch repair. 
(38)  Launderette and laundromat, or coin-operated dry cleaning establishment, using nonflammable solvents. 
(39)  Leather goods and luggage store. 
(40)  Loan offices, when located above the first floor and above a business use permitted in this section. 
(41)  Locksmiths. 
(42)  Meat markets. 
(43)  State lottery video game machines in the alcoholic beverage service area only of premises holding a class AA-1 or class A-1 alcoholic liquor license. 
(44)  Millinery shop. 
(45)  Music and musical instrument sales and repair, retail trade only. 
(46)  Newsstand. 
(47)  Notions store. 
(48)  Office supply store, retail. 
(49)  Offices, business and professional, including medical, dental, optical and podiatry clinics. 
(50)  Paint and wallpaper store. 
(51)  Parking lots and public garages. 
(52)  Photography studio. 
(53)  Planned Development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(54)  Public utility collection offices. 
(55)  Record shop. 
(56)  Restaurant, tearoom or cafe. 
(57)  Savings and loan association. 
(58)  Sewing machine sales and service. 
(59)  Shoe repair store. 
(60)  Shoe store. 
(61)  Signs as provided in this section. 
(62)  Sporting goods store. 
(63)  Tailor and dressmaker. 
(64)  Taxicab dispatching and office. 
(65)  Telegraph offices. 
(66)  Tobacco shops. 
(67)  Toy store. 
(68)  Upholstery shop. 
(69)  Special uses as follows: 
a.  Churches, church schools and others places of worship, provided the property fronts on a dedicated right-of-way and the zoning lot for the use has an area of not less than 60,000 square feet. 
b.  Government and public utility buildings. 
c.  Hospitals and sanitariums, not including animal hospitals. 
d.  Private clubs, lodge halls and headquarters of fraternal orders. 
e.  Bus terminal. 
1.  Advertising bus shelter. An off-premise sign located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.) which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this Zoning Code, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city, subject to the following: 
i.  The bus shelter shall be illuminated for the safety of the users. 
ii.  No advertising of tobacco or alcohol products shall be permitted; any advertising must be in conformance with guidelines adopted by the city council. 
iii.  The area of advertising signage shall not exceed 48 square feet, 24 square feet on a single side; and be restricted to one of the four sides of the shelter. The display shall not totally obstruct the view into the shelter from the outside; i.e., a visible gap is provided at the bottom and the top to permit a view of persons using the bus shelter. 
iv.  A lease agreement for the bus shelter be in place between the city and a corporation formed pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.). 
v.  Any other conditions imposed by the city council through the adoption of the special use ordinance. 
f.  Commercial trade schools. 
g.  Mechanical device amusement center. 
h.  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
i.  Day care center and day nurseries. Nursery schools, day nurseries and child care centers, provided there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided that the area shall be fenced and screened from view from any adjoining lot in any single-family residential district. 
j.  Permanent outdoor business activities. 
(70)  Accessory buildings and off-street parking and loading areas. 
(71)  Temporary outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27. 
(72)  Physical fitness centers not to exceed 7,500 square feet in size. 
(c)  Required conditions of use. All uses permitted in the C-1 commercial district shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Dwelling units and lodging rooms are not permitted. 
(2)  All business or service or processing of stores, shops or businesses listed in subsection (b) of this section shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building, except for automobile parking, for autos in running condition, and off-street loading. Outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27 shall be allowed. 
(3)  All products produced, whether primary or incidental, shall be sold at retail on the premises where produced. 
(4)  Establishments of the drive-in type, offering goods or services directly to customers waiting in parked motor vehicles and automobile service stations, are not permitted. 
(5)  The repair or processing of goods shall be limited to those which are not objectionable because of odor, dust, smoke, noise, vibration or water-carried waste. 
(d)  Building height. No building shall be erected or enlarged to exceed a height of two stories or 30 feet. 
(e)  Front yards. Each main building or portion thereof serving as a business shall have a front yard of not less than 15 feet in depth; provided, however, that when off-street parking is provided in front of the building, the setback shall be as provided in the parking provisions of this chapter. If the property is a corner lot, the setback requirement will apply to both frontages. 
(f)  Side yards. No side yards are required, except when such use abuts upon the side of a lot in an R district, in which case there shall be a side yard on the lot in the district the same as specified for the adjacent R district, and in addition the yard shall have a six-foot fence or other screen as may be approved by the planning and zoning commission from any adjoining lot in the R district. Such fence or screening will be maintained by the owner. 
(g)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot, but such rear yards shall be at least 30 feet, and in addition shall have a six-foot fence or other screen as may be approved by the planning and zoning commission from any adjoining lot in the R district. Such fence or screening will be maintained by the owner. 
(h)  Large retail structure: Single structures in excess of 10,000 square feet in area shall be designed and built in accordance with the following standards set forth herein. 
(1)  Aesthetic character. 
a.  Facades greater than 100 feet in length, measured horizontally, shall incorporate wall plane projections or recesses having a depth of at least three percent of the length of the facade and extending at least 20 percent of the length of the facade. No uninterrupted length of any facade shall exceed 100 horizontal feet. 
b.  Ground floor facades that face public streets shall have arcades, display windows, entry areas, awnings, or other such features along no less than 60 percent of their horizontal length. 
Where principal buildings contain multiple stores which occupy less than 10,000 square foot of gross floor area, with separate, exterior customer entrances. 
a.  The street level facade of such stores shall be transparent between the height of three feet and eight feet above the walkway grade for no less than 60 percent of the horizontal length of the building facade of such additional stores, 
b.  Windows shall be recessed and should include visually prominent sills, shutters, or other such forms of framing. 
Building facades must include a repeating pattern that shall include no less than three of the elements listed below. At least one of these elements shall repeat horizontally. All elements shall repeat at intervals of no more than 30 feet, either horizontally or vertically. 
a.  Color change; 
b.  Texture change; 
c.  Material module change. 
Expression of architectural or structural bay through a change in plane no less than 12 inches in width, such as an offset, reveal, or projection rib. 
Roofs shall comply with no less than two (2) of the following features: 
a.  Parapets concealing flat roofs and rooftop equipment, such as HVAC units, from public view. The average height of such parapets shall not exceed 15 percent of the height of the supporting wall and such parapets shall not at any point exceed one-third of the height of the supporting wall. Such parapets shall feature three dimensional cornice treatments. 
b.  Overhanging eaves, extending no less than three feet past the supporting walls. 
c.  No sloping roofs height shall exceed the average height of the supporting walls, nor shall it have an average slope greater than or equal to one foot of vertical rise for every three feet of horizontal run end less than or equal to one foot of vertical rise for every one foot of horizontal run. 
d.  Three or more roof slope planes. 
Exterior building materials shall comply with the following: 
a.  Predominant exterior building materials may include: 
1.  Brick; 
2.  Wood; 
3.  Sandstone; 
4.  Other native stone; or 
5.  Tinted and textures concrete masonry units. 
b.  Facade colors shall be neutral or earth tone colors. The use of high intensity colors, black, metallic, or fluorescent colors is prohibited. 
c.  Building trim and accent areas may feature brighter colors, including primary colors, but neon tubing shall be unacceptable building trim. 
d.  Predominant exterior building materials may not include the following: 
1.  Smooth-faced concrete block; 
2.  Tilt-up concrete panels; 
3.  Pre-fabricated steel panels. 
Each principal building on a site shall have clearly defined, highly visible customer entrances featuring no less than three of the following: 
a.  Canopies; 
b.  Overhangs; 
c.  Recesses/projections; 
d.  Arcades; 
e.  Raised corniced parapets over the door; 
f.  Peaked roof forms; 
g.  Arches; 
h.  Outdoor patios; 
i.  Display windows; 
j.  Architectural details such as tile work and moldings, which are integrated into the building structure and design; 
k.  Integral plants or wing walls that incorporate landscaped areas and/or places for sitting. 
Where additional stores will be located in the principal building, each such store shall have at least one (1) exterior customer entrance, which shall conform to the above requirements. 
All building faces which are visible from adjoining properties and/or public streets shall comply with the requirements of subsection 122-187(h)(1). 
(2)  Site design. 
All sides of a principal building that directly face an abutting public street shall feature at least one customer entrance. Where a principal building faces more than two abutting public streets, this requirement shall apply only to two sides of the building, including the side of the building facing the primary street and another side of the building facing a second street. 
No more than 50 percent of the off-street parking area for the entire property shall be located between the front facade of the principal building(s) and the primary abutting street. 
The minimum setback for any building facade shall be 35 feet from the nearest property line. Where the facade faces adjacent residential uses, an earthen berm no less than six feet in height, containing at a minimum evergreen trees planted at intervals of 20 feet on center, or in clusters or clumps shall be provided. 
Outdoor storage, trash collection, loading and unloading requirements are as follows: 
a.  Areas for outdoor storage, truck parking, trash collection or compaction, loading or other such uses shall not be visible from abutting streets. 
b.  No areas for outdoor storage, trash collection or compaction, loading or other such uses shall be located within 20 feet of any public street, public sidewalk or internal pedestrian way. 
c.  Loading docks, truck parking, outdoor storage, utility meters, HVAC equipment, trash collection, trash compaction and other service functions shall be incorporated into the overall design of the building and the landscaping so that the visual and acoustic impacts of these functions are fully contained and out of view from adjacent properties and public streets and no attention is attracted to the functions by the use of screen materials that are different from or inferior to the principal materials of the building and landscape. 
d.  If otherwise allowed by this Code, non-enclosed areas for the storage and sale of seasonable inventory shall be permanently defined and screened with walls and/or fences. Materials, colors and design of screening walls and/or fences and the cover shall conform to those used as predominant materials and colors on the building. If such areas are to be covered, then the covering shall conform to those uses as predominant materials and colors on the building. 
(3)  Variances. 
a.  In consideration of all variations to the provisions of subsection (h), the city council shall, before granting any variations in a specific case, first determine that the proposed variation will not impair an adequate supply of light and air to adjacent property or unreasonably increase the congestion in public streets or increase the danger of fire or endanger the public safety or unreasonably diminish or impair established property within the surrounding area, or in any other respect impair the public health, safety, comfort, or welfare of the inhabitants of the city. Any such variance shall be granted only by the adoption of an ordinance by the city council after a public hearing before the plan commission as herein provided. 
b.  Variances may be granted only by an ordinance passed by a majority vote of the city council after an application for a variance has been submitted to the plan commission and after the public hearing is scheduled and held by the plan commission and its findings and recommendations are reported to the city council as provided herein. 
c.  The plan commission may recommend and the city council may provide such conditions and restrictions upon the design and for such building construction for which a variance is granted as may be deemed necessary to promote the general objectives of this section and to minimize any injury to persons or property in the neighborhood. Failure to maintain such conditions or restrictions as may have been imposed shall constitute grounds for revocation of the authorizations for such variance whereupon the permittee or owner shall promptly bring the premises into compliance with this ordinance. 
d.  All requests for variances in the requirements herein set forth or appeals from any rulings of the community development director shall be directed to the plan commission by serving written notice on the community development director who, in turn, shall immediately transmit the notice to the plan commission. The plan commission shall set a public hearing date for said appeal or request for variance within 30 days thereafter. The community development director shall take no further action on the matter pending the commission's decision, except for unsafe conditions, which present an immediate and serious danger to the public. 
e.  No actions of the city council taken under this section shall be construed as amendments to the provisions of this section unless otherwise provided by the city council. 
(i)  Off-street parking and loading. The off-street parking and loading provisions of this chapter shall apply as follows: 
(1)  Accessory facilities. For all buildings and structures erected and all uses of land established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, accessory parking and loading facilities shall be provided as required by this division. However, where a building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, and provided that construction is begun within six months of such effective date and diligently prosecuted to completion, parking and loading facilities shall comply with requirements existing at the time this chapter was adopted. 
(2)  Increase in intensity of use. When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through additional gross floor area, seating capacity or other units of measurement specified in this division for required parking or loading facilities, parking and loading facilities as required shall be provided for such increase in intensity of use. However, no building or structure lawfully erected or use lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall be required to provide such additional parking or loading facilities unless and until the aggregate increase in units of measurement shall equal not less than 15 percent of the units of measurement existing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, in which event parking or loading facilities as required in this division shall be provided for the total increase. 
(3)  Change to new use. Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use would exceed those for the existing use if the latter were subject to the parking and loading provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Existing parking and loading facilities. Accessory off-street parking or loading facilities which were in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives or which were provided voluntarily after such effective date shall not be reduced below or, if already less than, shall not further be reduced below the requirements of this chapter for a similar new building or use. 
(5)  Permissive parking and loading facilities. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of contiguous off-street parking or loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings, provided that all regulations in this chapter governing the location, design, improvement and operation of such facilities are adhered to. 
(6)  Damage or destruction. For any conforming or legally nonconforming building or use which is in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives, which subsequently thereto is damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause and which is reconstructed, reestablished or repaired, off-street parking or loading facilities need not be provided, except that parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction shall be restored or continued in operation. However, if the principal building or structure is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value, it shall then be necessary to restore or maintain parking or loading facilities as required by this chapter for equivalent new uses or construction. 
(7)  Submission of plot plan. Any application for a building permit shall include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing any parking or loading facilities to be provided in compliance with this chapter. 
(j)  Floor area ratio. Floor area ratio shall not exceed 1.0 times lot area. 
(k)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 2), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 744, § 1, 10-25-1975; Ord. No. 825, § 1, 6-14-1977; Ord. No. 84-57, § 1, 11-13-1984; Ord. No. 85-8, § 3, 2-26-1985; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 48-50, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 87-29, § 1, 6-23-1987; Ord. No. 91-59, § 2, 10-8-1991; Ord. No. 97-66, § 2, 8-12-1997; Ord. No. 99-11, § 1, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 04-08, §§ 4-6, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 05-27, § 2, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 12-14, § 1, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 12-31, § 1, 9-11-2012; Ord. No. 17-19, § 32, 6-13-2017) 
Editor's note- Section 14 of Ord. No. 02-04, adopted Feb. 12, 2002, states that the provisions pertaining to pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall be of no further force and effect from and after 18 months from the effective date thereof, unless extended by action of the city council prior to the expiration of the 18 months. 
Sec. 122-188. - Additional parking regulations. 
(a)  Computation. For the C-1 commercial district, when determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(b)  Size. A required off-street parking space shall be at least nine feet in width and at least 20 feet in length, exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps or work areas. Such spaces shall have a vertical clearance of at least seven feet. 
(c)  Driveways. Each required off-street parking space shall open directly upon an aisle or a driveway of such width and design as to provide safe and efficient means of vehicular and pedestrians access to such parking space. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular and pedestrians access to a street or other public way in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across public property or requiring a curb shall exceed a width of 25 feet. 
(1)  Driveway width. The width of a driveway shall be as approved by the city engineer based on the anticipated use, traffic volume, location, geometrics and acceptable design standards. 
(2)  Safe access. Off-street parking spaces shall not be situated in such a manner as to block, impede, or cause disorder narrow or otherwise render unsafe any driveway or access to the site or parking area nor shall it hinder or cause disorder to emergency vehicle access to the structure or structures on the site. 
(3)  Double parking on premises. Only vehicles awaiting servicing or repair on the premises may be parked a maximum of two deep (double parked) adjacent to an approved aisle except such double parking is prohibited in a setback area 30 feet from the property line fronting a public street. 
(4)  Backing onto the public street. The off-street parking design shall not cause or encourage an exiting vehicle to back onto the public street. 
_____
(d)  Location in yards. Off-street parking spaces and driveways within yards areas shall conform to the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 relating to driveways.
