(e)  Design and maintenance. 
(1)  Open and enclosed parking spaces. Accessory parking spaces located on the same lot as occupied by the use served may be open to the sky or enclosed in a building. 
(2)  Bumper guards, driveways and surfacing. Driveways connecting parking areas with the public roadways shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the minimum requirements and specifications for driveways pursuant to applicable city ordinances. 
(3)  Lighting. Any lighting used to illuminate off-street parking areas shall be directed away from residential properties in such a way as not to create a nuisance to either residential properties or oncoming vehicles. 
(f)  Vehicles displayed and offered for sale. Vehicles displayed and offered for sale within any commercial property are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The owner of the vehicle must be on the premises at all times when the vehicle is displayed and offered for sale. 
(2)  Any sign displaying a vehicle for sale shall be located within the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 3), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 96-50, § 9, 10-22-1996; Ord. No. 99-10, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-1999) 
Sec. 122-189. - Schedule of parking requirements. 
    For the uses in the C-1 commercial district listed in this section, accessory off-street parking spaces shall be provided as required in this section. Parking spaces required on an employee basis shall be based on the maximum number of employees on duty on the premises at any one time. The uses and the parking space requirements shall be as follows: 
(1)  Private clubs and lodges. Parking spaces shall be provided equal in number to 30 percent of the capacity of persons such club or lodge was constructed to accommodate. 
(2)  Establishments dispensing food or beverages for consumption on premises. One parking space shall be provided for each 50 square feet of public seating area, plus one parking space for each two employees. 
(3)  Furniture and appliance stores, household equipment or furniture repair shops. One parking space shall be provided for each 600 square feet of sales floor area plus one parking space per every two employees. 
(4)  Retail stores and banks. One parking space shall be provided for each 150 square feet of sales floor area and one parking space per every two employees. 
(5)  Offices. One parking space shall be provided for each 250 square feet of floor space, exclusive of basement area. 
(6)  Community service uses. Community service uses shall provide parking as follows: 
a.  Churches, temples, schools and colleges and other institutional uses. One parking space shall be provided for each five seats or for each 90 inches of seating space, whichever is less. 
b.  Public utility and public service uses. One parking space shall be provided for each three employees, plus spaces adequate in number as determined by the zoning commission to serve the public. 
c.  Bowling alleys. Four parking spaces shall be provided for each alley, plus such additional parking spaces as may be required for affiliated uses (bars, restaurants, etc.) plus one parking space per two employees. 
(7)  Mixed uses. When two or more uses are located on the same zoning lot or within the same building, parking spaces equal in number to the sum of the separate requirements for each such use shall be provided. No parking space or portion thereof shall serve as a required space for more than one use unless otherwise authorized by the planning and zoning commission. 
(8)  Theaters (indoor). One parking space shall be provided for each four seats, plus one space for each six seats over 400 seats. 
(9)  Other uses. For uses not listed in subsections (1) through (8) of this section, parking spaces shall be provided on the same basis as required for the most similar listed use, as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(10)  Undertaking establishments, funeral parlors. One parking space shall be provided for each 75 square feet of parlor or waiting room area, plus 20 stacking spaces for procession assembly. 
(11)  Freestanding buildings in business complex. 
a.  No business complex or shopping center shall be developed or improved with a freestanding building which requires the loss of existing parking spaces in the business complex or shopping area or will contribute to or cause congestion in the city streets or in private parking areas of the business complex which would be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the city residents. 
b.  A business complex or shopping center is defined as one or more buildings occupied by two or more businesses having common service and/or parking areas adjacent to such buildings or building. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 4), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 52, 54, 56-59, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 17-19, § 33, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 122-190. - Loading. 
(a)  Location. All required loading berths for the C-1 commercial district shall be located on the same zoning lot as the use served. No loading berth for vehicles over two tons' capacity shall be closer than 50 feet to any property in a residence district unless completely enclosed by a building wall or uniformly painted solid fence or wall or any combination thereof not less than six feet in height. No permitted or required loading berth shall be located within 25 feet of the nearest point of intersection of any two streets. Any loading berth located in a required rear yard shall be open to the sky. 
(b)  Size. Unless otherwise specified, a required loading berth shall be at least 12 feet in width, 50 feet in length and 14 feet in height, exclusive of access aisles and maneuvering space. 
(c)  Access. Each required off-street loading berth shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular access to a street or alley in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements and which shall be subject to approval of the community development director. 
(d)  Surfacing. All open off-street loading berths shall be improved with a compact macadam base, not less than seven inches thick, surfaced with not less than two inches of asphaltic concrete or some comparable all-weather, dustless material. 
(e)  Repair and service. No motor vehicle repair work or service of any kind shall be permitted in conjunction with the loading facilities. 
(f)  Use of berths for space requirements of parking facilities. Spaces allocated to any off-street loading berth shall not, while so allocated, be used to satisfy the space requirements for any off-street parking facilities or portions thereof. 
(g)  Special uses. For special uses other than prescribed in this division, loading berths adequate in number and size to serve such uses shall be as determined by the planning and zoning commission or public works director or his designee. 
(h)  Receiving facilities. Uses for which off-street loading facilities are required in this division, but which are located in buildings of less floor area than the minimum prescribed for such required facilities, shall be provided with adequate receiving facilities off any adjacent alley, service drive or open space on the same lot which is accessible by motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 5), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 17-19, § 34, 6-13-2017) 
Sec. 122-191. - Off-street loading and unloading requirements. 
    Where property uses in the C-1 commercial district include the loading and unloading of materials or merchandise from vehicles, off-street loading and unloading facilities shall be provided in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  For buildings containing restaurants or any retail shops and having 10,000 to 100,000 square feet of gross floor area, one off-street loading and unloading space, plus one additional such space for each additional 100,000 square feet of gross floor area or fraction thereof in excess of 100,000 square feet. 
(2)  For banks, business or professional offices or public buildings containing 40,000 to 100,000 square feet of gross floor area, one off-street loading and unloading space, plus one additional such space for each additional 100,000 square feet of gross floor area or fraction thereof in excess of 100,000 square feet. 
(3)  For buildings containing furniture and appliance stores or motor vehicle sales and having 8,000 to 25,000 square feet of gross floor area, one off-street loading and unloading space, plus one additional such space for each additional 25,000 square feet of gross floor area or fraction thereof in excess of 25,000 square feet. 
(4)  For buildings not specifically provided for in subsections (1) through (3) of this section and which have more than 10,000 square feet of gross floor area, exclusive of basement area and less than 40,000 square feet of gross floor area, one off-street loading and unloading space, plus one additional such space for each additional 60,000 square feet of gross floor area in excess of 40,000 square feet. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 6), 12-14-1972) 
Sec. 122-192. - Permitted signs. 
    The following signs shall be permitted in the C-1 commercial district: 
(1)  Wall signs. 
a.  One sign shall be permitted which pertains to a use conducted within the main building which is displayed flat against a wall of the building and which does not project above the roofline and does not exceed 25 percent of the square footage of the wall area including glass area within the wall on which the sign is to be affixed. However, in no case shall a sign exceed 200 square feet in area. 
b.  For one-story multitenant commercial buildings (shopping centers), each tenant space is allowed one wall sign equal in area to 25 percent of the front wall area of that tenant space, but not to exceed 200 square feet. 
c.  Signs on secondary faces of the building shall have specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  Signs for the purpose of directing vehicular traffic on site subject to the following: 
1.  The size of the sign is not to exceed six square feet in area and the height shall not exceed five ft. measured to the top of the sign. 
2.  Not more than 33 percent of the sign area shall be devoted to a corporate logo, advertising or identification. 
3.  The number, location and arrangement of said signs shall be per the approval of the community development director. 
e.  Tenant spaces located at the corner of a multi-tenant building shall be allowed one additional wall sign on the second wall face provided the cumulative total area of both signs does not exceed the maximum allowable area for a single wall sign. 
(2)  Freestanding signs. For a business complex or shopping center consisting of one or more buildings occupied by two or more businesses and having a common service and parking area adjacent to such building, one freestanding sign shall be permitted which pertains to a business conducted within such business complex or shopping center; provided, however, that: 
a.  Any such sign constructed shall not exceed 20 feet in height above curb level. 
b.  The gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such lot. However, if the sign is illuminated, the gross area in square feet of the sign shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no sign constructed shall exceed 200 square feet in gross area. No portion of the sign shall extend over the property lines. 
c.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway, or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign only the largest frontage shall be considered. 
d.  Automobile service station signs may also include a gasoline price sign indicating pump price, but the square footage of this sign is to be included in the square footage total for the freestanding sign. Island canopy advertising signs are prohibited if the lot has a freestanding sign. 
e.  Freestanding signage within any special signage district shall conform to the regulations specific to that special district. 
(3)  Individual business. For a business not located in a business complex or shopping center described in subsection (2) of this section or if a business located in a building which is the sole business located in a building is not less than 75 feet from the main building in a business complex or shopping center described in subsection (2) of this section, one freestanding sign pertaining to such business shall be permitted; provided, however: 
a.  Any such sign constructed shall not exceed 20 feet above curb level. 
b.  The gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. However, if the sign is illuminated, the gross area in square feet of this sign shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no sign constructed shall exceed 200 square feet in gross area. 
c.  No portion of the sign shall extend over the property line. 
d.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway, or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign only the largest frontage shall be considered. 
(4)  Miscellaneous signs. 
a.  Signs indicating property for sale, lease, or rent shall not exceed 100 square feet in area, and are subject to the following conditions: 
1.  The number, size, location and arrangement of the signs are subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
2.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the date of issuance. 
b.  At the time a project is under construction, billboards will be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
1.  The total shall not exceed two billboards, each of which may not exceed 200 square feet in area. 
2.  The billboard shall be no higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
3.  The sign permits shall expire one year after the date of issuance or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
4.  The location and arrangement of the billboards shall be subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
c.  Automobile service station fuel pump cabinets may have two advertising signs per cabinet not to exceed one square foot each, other than trademarks, logos or other symbols which identify the company. Outdoor displays of products incidental to the principal use of an automobile service station may have advertising matter in the form of one sign per outdoor display, not to exceed four square feet per sign. 
(5)  Off-premises signs. 
a.  Off-premises signs shall be permitted only if located in a business area as defined in this chapter. 
b.  An off-premises sign shall not be erected or maintained with overall height, including ornamental base or apron, supports and other structural members, which exceeds 20 feet above the level of the highway upon which the sign faces or above the adjoining ground level if such ground level is above the highway roadway surfaced level. 
c.  The gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. However, if the sign is illuminated, the gross area and square feet of the sign shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no sign constructed shall exceed 200 square feet in gross area. 
d.  No portion of the sign shall extend over the property line. 
e.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway, or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign only the largest frontage shall be considered. 
(6)  Banners. One banner is permitted for a period not to exceed 45 days per calendar year per premises. The banner area shall not exceed ten percent of the wall area of the premises and in no case shall it exceed 100 square feet. The location and arrangement of the banner is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
(7)  Signage within any special signage district shall conform to the regulations specific to that special district. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 7), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 731, § 8, 6-24-1975; Ord. No. 79-60, §§ 3, 4, 10-23-1979; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 60-62, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 88-35, § 4, 5-10-1988; Ord. No. 93-07, § 18, 2-23-1993; Ord. No. 99-09, §§ 28-32, 2-23-1999) 
Sec. 122-193. - C-2 general commercial services district. 
(a)  Size. The C-2 general commercial services district shall require a minimum of four acres for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. All of the following permitted uses shall be conducted in accordance with the required conditions of subsection (c) of this section, and no building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any C-2 general commercial services district, unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Any uses permitted in the C-1 district. 
(2)  Air conditioning and heating salesroom. 
(3)  Automobile sales and service conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building. 
(4)  Bowling alley and billiards. 
(5)  Department, furniture or radio store; dress shop sales. 
(6)  Household appliance repair. 
(7)  Public libraries, art galleries and museums. 
(8)  Music conservatory or dance studio. 
(9)  Nonmanufacturing laboratories. 
(10)  Planned development, as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(11)  Public service, including fire and police stations, telephone exchange, post office, public utility service office and similar uses. 
(12)  Indoor theater. 
(13)  Undertaker. 
(14)  Veterinarian (wholly within enclosed building). 
(15)  Retail/wholesale business. For the purposes of this division, a retail/wholesale business shall be defined as a business which conducts a retail and wholesale business from the same facility and sales floor area. 
(16)  Special uses as follows: 
a.  Automobile service stations and other drive-in businesses such as banks, restaurants, refreshment stands or dry cleaners. 
1.  Intent and purpose. It is recognized that drive-in businesses warrant special consideration because of their design and operation which is unique, such as dependence on vehicular traffic, unenclosed nature of the activity, distinctive physical appearance and long hours of operation. Therefore, the standards in this subsection are to serve as guidelines for approval or denial of applications for drive-in businesses. These standards are intended to encourage better land planning and use techniques with maximum use of aesthetically pleasing architecture, landscaping, site layout and design. The compliance with these standards and any condition of approval shall be in addition to compliance with the regulations of the district. 
2.  General conditions for drive-in businesses. 
i.  A special use granted for an automobile service station or other drive-in business shall not permit the sale, giving or otherwise dispensing a product or service not incidental and necessary to the principal use, except that automobile service stations may be permitted those nonincidental sales as described in subsection (b)(16)a.3 of this section pertaining to specific conditions for automobile service stations. 
ii.  Building site and frontage. The minimum building site shall be 22,000 square feet with a minimum frontage on any public right-of-way of 150 feet. 
iii.  Trash areas. Bins for the storage of trash, refuse and discarded materials shall be provided on the site. 
iv.  Lights. Any lights used to illuminate or advertise an automobile service station or other drive-in business, shall be directed away from adjacent properties and street. 
v.  Parking. Parking shall be as permitted in the C-1 district. 
3.  Specific conditions for automobile service stations. 
i.  Nonincidental sales. Automobile service stations may sell products non incidental to the principal use. Food service such as delis and fast food is permitted provided the floor area devoted to such use does not exceed 33 percent of the total floor area or 700 square feet, whichever is less. The gross floor area within the building used for the retail sale of incidental and nonincidental goods shall not exceed 600 square feet. Outdoor storage or products not incidental to the principal use are permitted only as follows: rock salt in bags only, block salt and charcoal in bags only, provided the outdoor storage is screened from view by a six-foot fence which blends with the architecture and aesthetics of the main structure. Outside storage shall not exceed 150 square feet of coverage of the lot. Outdoor display of nonincidental products is prohibited. Milk and ice may be handled and sold from separate storage lockers kept inside or outside the automobile service station. 
ii.  Incidental sales. Outdoor displays of products incidental to the principal use are permitted only as follows: not more than three tire display racks with a capacity of not more than 50 tires each are permitted. Not more than one display storage cabinet for windshield wipers and accessories is permitted. Not more than four display storage cabinets for motor oil are permitted. Windshield washer solvent displays are permitted, provided accumulative total of containers does not exceed 20. All display racks and cabinets are to be kept in good condition. All outdoor displays of incidental products are to be stored in the service station structure during the period the service station is closed. Storage outdoors of incidental products is prohibited. 
iii.  Vending machines. Automatic vending machines are permitted for the dispensing of soft drinks, candy bars, gum, cookies, and prepackaged snacks, cigarettes or other products permitted by applicable city ordinances. The 
total number of vending machines and storage lockers outdoors may not exceed three, and each may not be larger than 70 cubic feet capacity. 
iv.  Parking. Parking for automobile service stations shall be permitted as in the C-1 district. 
v.  Storage and rental of utility trailers. Utility trailers may be stored and rented at automobile service stations by specific permission of the city council, provided that the trailers are not over 16 feet long or over seven feet high and that the storage area for such trailers is enclosed on all sides by a screen, wall or landscaping or any combination thereof at least seven feet tall. 
b.  Outdoor used-car sales lots only along Algonquin, Golf and Wilke Roads and in accordance with the following regulations: 
The outdoor used car sales lot operation must conform to all city regulations including, but not limited to, "Signs" (section 122-22), "Driveways and Parking Areas" (article VII of chapter 18 Building Code (section 18-243) as well as the following: 
1.  No outdoor used car sales lot operation shall be located immediately abutting a residentially zoned district and/or use and service bay doors shall not face residentially zoned district and/or use. 
2.  Parking of vehicles shall conform to section 18-245 of the city's Municipal Code for commercial parking areas. The entire sales lot and off street parking area must be paved and a perimeter curb or barrier must be provided to prevent encroachment of vehicles for sale into the required landscaped and landscaped areas. 
i.  There shall be no parking of vehicles on anything other than a paved surface within the confines of the lot's property lines. 
3.  No automobile shall be stored or displayed nearer to the property line than eight feet. 
4.  All motor vehicle sales lots shall buffer the activities form adjacent parcels by landscaping or other buffering materials. Preferred materials shall be decorative fencing and/or vegetative material. 
5.  Adequate customer and employee parking must be provided in off-street parking spaces. The employee and customer parking shall be clearly designated and shall not be used for the parking, storage or display of motor vehicles, for sale, rental or hire. 
6.  Said lot must contain a permanent building, containing a foundation and meets the current building codes for the prescribed business activities. Suitable sanitary facilities shall be available for use and convenience of employees as well as general public. 
7.  The architectural appearance and functional plan of the building and site may not be so dissimilar to the existing buildings or area as to cause impairment in property values or constitute an adverse effect within a reasonable distance of the operation. 
8.  No bodywork or painting shall be performed unless approved as part of the special use permit and meets all state and local building and fire code regulations. Any bodywork or painting allowed as part of the special use must be on cars owned, sold or under warranty by the person or persons operation the business. 
9.  All mechanical repairs must be limited to cars owned, sold or under warranty by the person or persons operation the business. 
10.  All exterior lighting shall be designed and oriented so as to not shine or spill onto adjacent properties in order to minimize its visual impact. A photometric plan shall be submitted for review. 
11.  No exterior public address system, music, etc. shall be permitted. 
12.  Gasoline pumping is prohibited. No person shall store, sell or pump gasoline on the premises. 
13.  No outside repairs permitted. Repair work, storage and sale of auto parts and accessories shall be conducted within a fully enclosed structure. 
14.  All vehicles and equipment parked and/or displayed outside must be in operational condition. 
15.  No outdoor stock piling of parts, materials or equipment shall be permitted. 
16.  The property upon which any used car lot is located must be maintained in a neat and orderly manner with no accumulation or junk vehicles, tires, auto parts, garbage, refuse or debris on the property. 
17.  The removal of snow must not adversely affect adjacent properties. 
18.  No exterior display of banners, pennants, ribbons, or other similar temporary advertising materials shall be permitted in any outdoor sales area. 
19.  Hours of operation shall be limited to 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Saturday and closed on Sunday. 
c.  Miniature golf courses. General conditions for miniature golf courses shall be as follows: 
1.  Parking requirements. Two spaces per hole; if the facility is in conjunction with another use, the total required is cumulative. (Each use or business is computed separately and added.) 
2.  Minimum land use. Exclusive of parking, a minimum of 500 square feet of land shall be required per hole. 
3.  Illumination. All lighting of a miniature golf facility is to be concentrated on the course and shall be prevented from causing a glare on or striking the street or nearby property. No illumination is to increase the surrounding brightness at any residential property line more than one footcandle. 
4.  Screening and landscaping. Those portions of the miniature golf facility adjacent to adjoining property must be screened from the property by trees or vegetation a minimum of 12 feet in height spaced to afford an effective separation. In addition to this vegetation, there shall be a minimum of a six-foot high screening fence. 
5.  Noise. The noise level produced by mechanical devices, sirens, bells, whistles, music, etc., used in conjunction with the facility shall not exceed the decibel level allowed by the state environmental protection agency. 
d.  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
e.  Rental of motor vehicles and trailers not exceeding 36,000 pounds gross weight, with not more than two axles, subject to consideration by the special use committee of the following facts, among others it deems pertinent: 
1.  Impact of the use on parking and vehicular movement on the premises. 
2.  Screening. 
3.  Number of vehicles or trailers permitted on the premises. 
4.  Hours of operation. 
5.  Illumination. 
6.  Location of the use on the premises. 
7.  Conformity with applicable city codes. 
f.  Indoor motorized cart racing facility and accessory amusement devices and food concessions subject to the following requirements: 
1.  The facility must have a permit to operate from the state carnival and amusement safety board. 
_____

3.  Required off-street parking. One parking space per cart on the premises; one space per 150 gross square feet of office, concession, waiting and reception area; and one space per every two employees at peak hour. 
g.  Permanent outdoor business activities. 
h.  Reserved. 
i.  Advertising bus shelter. An off-premise sign located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.) which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this Zoning Code, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city, subject to the following: 
1.  The bus shelter shall be illuminated for the safety of the users. 
2.  No advertising of tobacco or alcohol products shall be permitted; any advertising must be in conformance with guidelines adopted by the city council. 
3.  The area of advertising signage shall not exceed 48 square feet, 24 square feet on a single side; and be restricted to one of the four sides of the shelter. The display shall not totally obstruct the view into the shelter from the outside; i.e., a visible gap is provided at the bottom and the top to permit a view of persons using the bus shelter. 
4.  A lease agreement for the bus shelter be in place between the city and a corporation formed pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.). 
5.  Any other conditions imposed by the city council through the adoption of the special use ordinance. 
(17)  Pet shops as defined by section 22-726 of this Code. 
(18)  Kennels. 
(19)  Temporary outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27. 
(c)  Required conditions of use. All uses permitted in the C-2 general commercial service district shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Dwelling units and lodging rooms are not permitted below the second floor of any structure except when included as part of a plan development approved in accordance with article IV of this Code. 
(2)  All businesses or services shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building unless specifically provided otherwise in this section. Outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27 shall be allowed. 
(3)  All products produced, whether primary or incidental, shall be sold at retail on the premises where produced. 
(4)  No more than five persons shall be engaged in fabrication, repair and processing of materials, except that this subsection shall not apply to the preparation of food in restaurants, cafes or soda fountains. 
(5)  The repair or processing of goods shall be limited to those which are not objectionable because of odor, dust, smoke, noise, vibration, or water-carried waste. 
(d)  Building heights. The maximum building height shall be the same as required in the C-1 districts. 
(e)  Front yards. Each main building or portion thereof, serving as a business, shall have a front yard of not less than 90 feet in depth. 
(f)  Side yards. No side yards shall be required, except where such use abuts upon the side of a lot in an R district, in which case there shall be a side yard on the lot in the commercial district the same as specified for the residence district, and in addition the yard shall have a six-foot fence and/or screening from any adjoining lot in the R district, as approved by the planning and zoning commission. Such fence or screening will be maintained by owner. 
(h)  Freestanding buildings in business complex or shopping center. No business complex or shopping center shall be developed or improved with a freestanding building which requires the loss of existing parking spaces in the business complex or shopping area or which will contribute to or cause congestion in the city streets or in private parking areas of the business complex which would be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the city residents. A business complex or shopping center is defined as one or more buildings occupied by two or more businesses having common service and/or parking areas adjacent to such buildings or building. 
(i)  Large retail structures. Single structures in excess of 10,000 square feet in area shall be designed and built in accordance with the requirements found in article V, section 122-187 of this Code. 
(j)  Permitted signs. Signs shall be permitted as in the C-1 zoning district. 
(k)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be as permitted in the C-1 district. 
(l)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 8), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 684, § 1, 4-9-1974; Ord. No. 731, § 9, 6-24-1975; Ord. No. 79-60, §§ 1, 2, 10-23-1979; Ord. No. 82-29, § 1, 12-14-1982; Ord. No. 84-57, § 1, 11-13-1984; Ord. No. 85-47, §§ 63-65, 8-13-1985; Ord. No. 85-27, § 1, 5-28-1985; Ord. No. 85-54, §§ 1, 2, 8-27-1985; Ord. No. 86-33, § 1, 5-27-1986; Ord. Sec. 122-194. - C-3 minor commercial services district. 
(a)  Size. In the C-3 minor commercial services district, a minimum of one acre shall be required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. All of the following permitted uses, except the required off-street parking facilities, shall be conducted wholly within an enclosed building, and no building or premises, improved or unimproved, shall be used and no building shall be erected or altered within any C-3 minor commercial services district, unless otherwise provided in this chapter, except for the following uses: 
(1)  Antique shop. 
(2)  Art and school supply store. 
(3)  Art galleries and studios. 
(4)  Bakery shop, including the baking and processing of food products, when prepared for retail use on the premises only. 
(5)  Barbershop, beauty parlor, massage or similar personal service shop. 
(6)  Book and stationery stores. 
(7)  Butcher shop, excluding the slaughtering of animals and poultry on premises. 
(8)  Camera and photographic supply shops for retail sale. 
(9)  Ceramic shops. 
(10)  Coin and philatelic stores. 
(11)  Confectionery store. 
(12)  Currency exchange. 
(13)  Custom dressmaking, millinery, tailoring or shoe repair when conducted for retail sales on the premises only. 
(14)  Drugstores. 
(15)  Dry goods store. 
(16)  Electrical appliance store and repair, but not including appliance assembly or manufacturing. 
(17)  Florist shop and conservatory for retail trade on the premises only. 
(18)  Foodstore, fruit store or delicatessen. 
(19)  Furrier, when conducted for retail trade on the premises only. 
(20)  Haberdashery. 
(21)  Hardware stores. 
(22)  Hobby stores. 
(23)  Household appliance stores. 
(24)  Interior decorating shops, including upholstery and making of draperies, slip covers and other similar articles, when conducted as part of the retail operations and secondary to the main use. 
(25)  Jewelry and watch repair. 
(26)  Launderette and laundromat, or coin-operated dry cleaning establishment, using nonflammable solvents. 
(27)  Leather goods and luggage store. 
(28)  Loan officer, when located above the first floor and above a business as permitted in this section. 
(29)  Locksmiths. 
(30)  Meat markets. 
(31)  Millinery shops. 
(32)  Music and musical instrument sales and repair, retail trade only. 
(33)  Newsstands. 
(34)  Notions stores. 
(35)  Office supply stores, retail. 
(36)  Offices, business and professional, including medical, dental, optical and podiatry clinics. 
(37)  Optician, optometrist. 
(38)  Photograph studio. 
(39)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(40)  Public utility collection offices. 
(41)  Record shop. 
(42)  Savings and loan association. 
(43)  Sewing machine sales and service. 
(44)  Shoe repair store. 
(45)  Shoe store. 
(46)  Signs, as provided in this section. 
(47)  Sporting goods store. 
(48)  Tailor and dressmaker. 
(49)  Telegraph offices. 
(50)  Tobacco shops. 
(51)  Toy store. 
(52)  Upholstery shop. 
(53)  Accessory buildings and off-street parking and loading areas. 
(54)  Special uses as follows: 
a.  Churches, church schools and other places of worship, provided the property fronts on a dedicated right-of-way and the zoning lot for the use has an area of not less than 60,000 square feet. 
b.  Government and public utility buildings. 
c.  Hospitals, not including animal hospitals, and sanitariums. 
d.  Private clubs, lodge halls and headquarters of fraternal orders. 
e.  Commercial trade schools. 
f.  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
g.  Day care centers and day nurseries. Nursery schools, day nurseries and child care centers are permitted as a special use, provided there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided that the area shall be fenced and screened from view from any adjoining lot in any single-family residential district. 
h.  Advertising bus shelter. An off-premise sign located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.) which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this Zoning Code, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city, subject to the following: 
1.  The bus shelter shall be illuminated for the safety of the users. 
2.  No advertising of tobacco or alcohol products shall be permitted; any advertising must be in conformance with guidelines adopted by the city council. 
3.  The area of advertising signage shall not exceed 48 square feet, 24 square feet on a single side; and be restricted to one of the four sides of the shelter. The display shall not totally obstruct the view into the shelter from the outside; i.e., a visible gap is provided at the bottom and the top to permit a view of persons using the bus shelter. 
4.  A lease agreement for the bus shelter be in place between the city and a corporation formed pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.). 
5.  Any other conditions imposed by the city council through the adoption of the special use ordinance. 
(55)  Temporary outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27. 
(56)  Physical fitness centers not to exceed 7,500 square feet in size. 
(c)  Required conditions of use. All uses permitted in the C-3 minor commercial services district shall be subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Dwelling units and lodging rooms are not permitted. 
(2)  All business or service or processing of stores, shops or businesses listed in subsection (b) of this section shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building, except for automobile parking for autos in running condition and off-street loading. Outdoor business activities in accordance with section 122-27 shall be allowed. 
(3)  All products, whether primary or incidental, shall be sold at retail on the premises where produced. 
(4)  Establishments of the drive-in type, offering goods or services directly to customers waiting in parked motor vehicles and automobile service stations, are not permitted. 
(5)  The repair or processing of goods shall be limited to those which are not objectionable because or odor, dust, smoke, noise, vibration or water-carried waste. 
(d)  Building height. No building shall be erected or enlarged to exceed a height of two stories or 30 feet. 
(e)  Front yards. Each main building or portion thereof serving as a business shall have a front yard of not less than 30 feet in depth; provided, however, that when off-street parking is provided in front of the building, the setback shall be as provided in the parking provisions of this chapter. If the property is a corner lot, the setback requirement will apply to both frontages. 
(f)  Side yards. There shall be a side yard not less than 15 feet, and it shall have a six-foot fence or other screen as may be approved by the planning and zoning commission from any adjoining lot in the R district. Such fence or screening will be maintained by the owner of the commercially zoned property. 
(g)  Large retail structures . Single structures in excess of 10,000 square feet in area shall be designed and built in accordance with the requirements found in article IX, section 122-1877 of this Code. 
(h)  Rear yards. There shall be a rear yard of not less than 25 percent of the depth of the lot, but such rear yard shall be at least 30 feet and, in addition, shall have a six-foot fence or other screen as may be approved by the planning and zoning commission from any adjoining lot in the R district. Such fence or screening will be maintained by owner. 
(i)  Off-street parking and loading. Off-street parking and loading shall be in conformance with the requirements for off-street parking and loading of the C-1 commercial district as provided in subsection 122-187(h) and in sections 122-188 through 122-191. 
(j)  Signs. 
(1)  Generally. Signs shall be permitted as follows: 
a.  One sign which pertains to a use conducted within the main building which is displayed flat against a wall of the building and which does not project above the roofline and does not exceed 25 percent of the square footage of the wall area, including glass area within the wall on which the sign is affixed, shall be permitted. However, in no case shall a sign exceed 200 square feet in area. 
b.  For one-story, multitenant commercial buildings (shopping centers), each tenant space is allowed one wall sign equal in area to 25 percent of the front wall area of that tenant space, but not to exceed 200 square feet. 
c.  Signs on secondary faces of the building shall have specific approval of the community development director. 
d.  Signs for the purpose of directing vehicular traffic on site subject to the following: 
1.  The size of the sign is not to exceed six square feet in area and the height shall not exceed five ft. measured to the top of the sign. 
2.  Not more than 33 percent of the sign area shall be devoted to a corporate logo, advertisement or identification. 
3.  The number, location and arrangement of said signs shall be per the approval of the community development director. 
(2)  Freestanding signs. For a business complex or shopping center consisting of one or more buildings occupied by two or more businesses and having a common service and parking area adjacent to such building, one freestanding sign which pertains to a business conducted within such business complex or shopping center shall be permitted; provided, however: 
a.  Any such sign constructed shall not exceed 15 feet in height above curb level. 
b.  The gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such lot. However, if the sign is illuminated, the gross area in square feet of sign shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no sign constructed shall exceed 100 square feet in gross area. No portion of the sign shall extend over the property lines. 
c.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign, only the largest frontage shall be considered. 
(3)  Individual business. For a business not located in a business complex or shopping center described in subsection (i)(2) of this section, or if a business located in a building which is the sole business located in a building is not less than 75 feet from the main building in a business complex or shopping center described in subsection (i)(2) of this section, one freestanding sign pertaining to such business shall be permitted; provided, however: 
a.  Any such sign constructed shall not exceed 15 feet above curb level. 
b.  The gross area of the sign in square feet shall not exceed two times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. However, if the sign is illuminated, the gross area in square feet of this sign shall not exceed one times the lineal feet of frontage of such zoning lot. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no sign constructed shall exceed 100 square feet in gross area. 
c.  No portion of the sign shall extend over the property line. 
d.  If a zoning lot has frontage on more than one street, highway or other public right-of-way, in computing the allowable gross area of the sign, only the largest frontage shall be considered. 
e.  Tenant spaces located at the corner of a multi-tenant building shall be allowed one additional wall sign on the second wall face provided the cumulative total area of both signs does not exceed the maximum allowable area for a single wall sign. 
(4)  Miscellaneous signs. Signs indicating property for sale, lease or rent shall not exceed 50 square feet in area and are subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The total shall not exceed one billboard, which may not exceed 100 square feet in area. 
b.  The billboard shall be no higher than 15 feet above curb level. 
c.  The sign permit shall expire one year after the date of issuance or sooner if all units are rented or sold. 
d.  The location and arrangement of the billboards shall be subject to specific approval of the community development director. 
(5)  Signage within any special signage district shall conform to the regulations specific to that special district. 
(6)  One banner is permitted for a period not to exceed 45 days per calendar year per premises. The banner area shall not exceed ten percent of the wall area of the premises and in no case shall exceed 100 square feet The location and arrangement of the banner is subject to the specific approval of the community development director. 
(k)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26. 
(Ord. No. 626, § 3 (art. IX, § 9), 12-14-1972; Ord. No. 89-68, § 8, 11-28-1989; Ord. No. 97-66, § 2, 8-12-1997; Ord. No. 99-09, §§ 33-35, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 99-11, § 3, 2-23-1999; Ord. No. 02-04, § 7, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 04-08, §§ 10-12, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 12-14, § 2, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 17-19, § 36, 6-13-2017) 
Editor's note- Section 14 of Ord. No. 02-04, adopted Feb. 12, 2002, states that the provisions pertaining to pedestrian and bicycle facilities shall be of no further force and effect from and after 18 months from the effective date thereof, unless extended by action of the city council prior to the expiration of the 18 months.

DIVISION 5. - MANUFACTURING[5]

Sec. 122-221. - M-1 manufacturing district. 
(a)  Size. In the M-1 manufacturing district, a minimum of ten acres shall be required for zoning. 
(b)  Permitted uses. No building or land shall be used and no building shall be erected, structurally altered or enlarged, except for the following uses, subject to the conditions required by subsection (e) of this section: 
(1)  Adult regulated uses. 
(2)  Animal hospitals, pounds and shelters. 
(3)  Assembly of electrical appliances, electronic instruments and devices. 
(4)  Automobile painting, upholstering, repairing, reconditioning, body and fender works, but not including junkyards as defined in this chapter. 
(5)  Automobile sales and service. 
(6)  Beverages, nonalcoholic, bottling and distribution. 
(7)  Building material sales. 
(8)  Creamery or bottling plant. 
(9)  Retail sales of construction and decorating materials, provided not more than 50 percent of the total sales are made to consumers on the premises. 
(10)  Contractor or construction shops (indoor only) such as: building, cement, electrical, roofing, refrigeration, masonry, painting, plumbing, air conditioning, heating and ventilating. 
(11)  Garages and parking lots other than accessory uses. 
(12)  Greenhouses. 
(13)  Laboratories, medical, dental, research, experimental and testing, provided there is no danger from fire or explosion or of offensive noise, smoke, dust, odors, heat, glare, vibration or other objectionable conditions beyond the confines of the premises upon which the use is located. 
(14)  Laundry, cleaning and dyeing works and carpet and rug cleaning. 
(15)  Linen, towel, diaper and other similar supply services. 
(16)  The manufacture, compounding, processing, packaging or treatment of such products as bakery goods, candy, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, toiletries and food products excluding sauerkraut, vinegar, starch, glucose, yeast, and the slaughtering of animals, rendering or refining of fats and oils. 
(17)  The manufacture, compounding, assembling or treatment of articles or merchandise from the following previously prepared materials: bone, cellophane, canvas, cloth, cork, felt, fibre, feathers, fur, glass, hair, horn, tanned leather, paper, plastics, precious or semiprecious metals or stones, previously prepared metals, shell, textiles, wood (excluding planing mill) and yards. 
(18)  The manufacture of pottery and figurines or other similar ceramic products, using only previously pulverized clay, and kilns fired only by electricity or gas. 
(19)  Reserved. 
(20)  Public service uses as follows: 
a.  Bus garages and parking lots; 
b.  Natural gas distribution centers; 
c.  Electric substations; 
d.  Natural gas regulating centers and holding stations when owned and operated by a utility licensed by the state commerce commission; 
e.  Telephone exchanges; 
f.  Fire stations; 
g.  Reserved; 
h.  Reserved; 
i.  Police stations; 
j.  Water pumping stations; and 
k.  Water reservoirs. 
(21)  Residential uses as follows: dwelling units for watchmen and their families when located on the premises where they are employed in such capacity. 
(22)  Wholesale business, propane gas storage and sales, storage and warehouses, but not including freight terminals. 
(23)  Miscellaneous uses as follows: office or laboratories for administrative, executive, professional, research or similar organizations (nonretail). 
(24)  Planned development as regulated by article IV of this chapter. 
(25)  Accessory uses, incidental to permitted uses only, including cafeterias or dining rooms for employees and guests. 
(26)  Motor vehicle repair, major. 
(27)  Truck repairs. 
(28)  Truck sales and service. 
(29)  Ambulance service. 
(c)  Special uses. 
(1)  In the M-1 districts, an automobile service station may be allowed as a special use, if the site location and proposed developments are first approved pursuant to the requirements set forth in the C-2 general commercial services district and article V of this chapter. 
(2)  Municipal uses. Storage or repair of vehicles or other personal property; storage of materials for municipal use, such as salt, sand and asphalt patch material; processing, recycling or disposal of waste material, refuse or garbage including the disposition, storage or handling of paper, glass, metal or other solid wastes, but not including an incinerator. 
(3)  Motor vehicle new parts sales or sale of parts rebuilt or reconditioned off-premises. When on the same premises with motor vehicle sales, repair, reconditioning, and body and fender works, but not including junkyards. 
(4)  Commercial antenna structures in excess of 75 feet when otherwise complying with subsection 122-10(e). 
(5)  Child day care centers or day nurseries for exclusive use by children of employees of a business or entity located on the same property as the day care center or day nursery provided there is a minimum of 75 square feet of outdoor play area for each child to be cared for and provided that the outdoor play area shall be fenced and screened from view. 
(6)  The heliport shall be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
a.  The heliport must be a restricted landing area heliport, as defined by the state department of transportation, division of aeronautics. 
b.  The heliport shall only be used by rotary wing aircraft with a weight not exceeding 3,000 pounds. 
c.  The heliport is for private use only and shall not be used for commercial for-hire flights, fueling or repair of the aircraft. 
d.  The heliport is for use by one only specific aircraft. 
e.  The heliport pad shall not be located nearer than 500 feet from a residentially zoned district, hospital, nursing home, convalescent center, school, park or playground. 
f.  The heliport is an accessory use and must be located on the same lot as the principal use. 
(7)  Automobile laundries (carwashes) when in accordance with subsection 122-193(b)(16) of this chapter. 
(8)  Reserved. 
(9)  Rental of motor vehicles and trailers not exceeding 36,000 pounds, gross weight, with not more than two axels, subject to city council consideration and approval of the following conditions: 
a.  Impact of the use on parking and vehicular movement on the premises. 
b.  Screening. 
c.  Number of vehicles and lor trailers on the premises. 
d.  Hours of operation. 
e.  Illumination. 
f.  Location of the use on the premises.

h.  Required off-street parking: one parking space per cart on the premises; one space per 150 gross square feet of office, concession, waiting and reception area; and one space per every two employees at peak hour. 
(10)  Advertising bus shelter. An off-premise sign located on a bus shelter owned and maintained by a corporation created pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.) which bus shelter is located on a public way, as defined in this Zoning Code, which public way is under the jurisdiction and control of the city, subject to the following: 
a.  The bus shelter shall be illuminated for the safety of the users. 
b.  No advertising of tobacco or alcohol products shall be permitted; any advertising must be in conformance with guidelines adopted by the city council. 
c.  The area of advertising signage shall not exceed 48 square feet, 24 square feet on a single side; and be restricted to one of the four sides of the shelter. The display shall not totally obstruct the view into the shelter from the outside; i.e., a visible gap is provided at the bottom and the top to permit a view of persons using the bus shelter. 
d.  A lease agreement for the bus shelter be in place between the city and a corporation formed pursuant to the Regional Transportation Authority Act (701 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.). 
e.  Any other conditions imposed by the city council through the adoption of the special use ordinance. 
(11)  Personal training facility. A facility, 5,000 square feet or less, that specifically caters to the training needs of individual clients to meet their specific goals through the use of trainers/coaches who provide personalized fitness counseling by appointment only. These appointments are limited to four clients per trainer per hour. No more than three trainers on site at any one time in the conduct of the business. The size and staffing of the facility may be increased proportionately but not to exceed 10,000 square feet total. 
(12)  Medical cannabis cultivation centers. In determining the compliance of a proposed medical cannabis cultivation center, the following components of the medical cannabis cultivation center shall be evaluated based on the entirety of the circumstances affecting the particular property in the context of the existing and intended future use of properties in the vicinity of the proposed use: 
a.  The issuance or absence of issuance of a valid registration as a medical cannabis cultivation center by the Illinois Department of Agriculture to the proposed medical cannabis cultivation center. 
b.  The existence, if any, of a medical cannabis cultivation center located within the Illinois State Police District within which the City of Rolling Meadows is located. 
c.  The existence, if any, of a medical cannabis cultivation center located within the City of Rolling Meadows. 
d.  Compliance by the medical cannabis cultivation center with the following restrictions: 
1.  Compliance with state law and regulations. Medical cannabis cultivation centers shall comply with the requirements of the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act (Public Act 098-0122) and all regulations promulgated thereunder, as may be amended from time to time. 
2.  Single-use property. Medical cannabis cultivation centers shall not be established in multiple use or multi-tenant properties or on a property that shares parking with other uses. 
3.  Minimum distance from incompatible uses. No medical cannabis cultivation center shall be located, established, maintained, or operated on any lot that has a property line within 2,500 feet of the property line of any of the following uses: 
i.  A pre-existing public or private preschool or elementary or secondary school; 
ii  A pre-existing day care center, day care home, group day care home or part day child care facility; or 
iii.  A pre-existing area zoned for residential use. 
4.  Measurement. For the purposes of this section, distances shall be measured linearly in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest point on the property line of the lot on which the medical cannabis cultivation center is located to the nearest point on a property line of a use listed in subsection 3., above. 
5.  Retail sales prohibited. Medical cannabis cultivation centers shall not conduct any retail sales. 
6.  An operation plan must be submitted. An operation plan must include, but is not limited to, the security measures that will be provided such as exterior lighting, security cameras, and hours of operation. 
7.  Drive-through facilities are prohibited. 
8.  No outdoor, window, or on-site media display of merchandise and/or products related to a cultivation center allowed. 
9.  No exterior signage that includes the words "marijuana," "cannabis," or any related word or symbol. 
(13)  Medical cannabis dispensing facilities. In determining the compliance of a proposed medical cannabis dispensing facility, the following components of the medical cannabis dispensing facility shall be evaluated based on the entirety of the circumstances affecting the particular property in the context of the existing and intended future use of properties in the vicinity of the proposed use: 
a.  The issuance or absence of issuance of a valid registration as a medical cannabis dispensing facility by the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation to the proposed medical cannabis dispensing facility. 
b.  The existing number of medical cannabis dispensing facilities, if any, located within the dispensing organization district within which the City of Rolling Meadows is located as established by the regulations of the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation. 
c.  The existing number of medical cannabis dispensing facilities, if any, located within the City of Rolling Meadows. 
d.  Compliance by the medical cannabis dispensing facility with the following restrictions: 
1.  Compliance with state law and regulations. Medical cannabis dispensing facilities shall comply with the requirements of the Compassionate Use of Medical Cannabis Pilot Program Act (Public Act 098-0122) and all regulations promulgated thereunder, as may be amended from time to time. 
2.  Single-use property. Medical cannabis dispensing facilities 
shall not be established in multiple-use or multi-tenant properties or on a property that shares parking with other uses. 
3.  Minimum distance from incompatible uses. No medical cannabis dispensing facility shall be located, established, maintained, or operated in a house, apartment or condominium or on any lot that has a property line within 1,000 feet of the property line of any of the following uses: 
i.  A pre-existing public or private preschool or elementary or secondary school; 
ii.  A pre-existing day care center, day care home, group day care home or part day child care facility; or 
iii.  A pre-existing area zoned for residential use. 
4.  Measurement. For the purposes of this section, distances shall be measured linearly in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest point on the property line of the lot on which the medical cannabis dispensing facility is located to the nearest point on a property line of a use listed in subsection 3., above. 
5.  Hours of operation. Medical cannabis dispensing facilities shall only operate between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
6.  Drive-through windows. Medical cannabis dispensing facilities shall not dispense medical cannabis or other products through a drive-through window. 
7.  An operation plan must be submitted. An operation plan must include, but is not limited to, the security measures that will be provided such as exterior lighting, security cameras, and hours of operation. 
8.  The dispensing organization shall be the primary use of the tenant space in which it is located. Retail sales occurring within said facilities shall be accessory to the facility's intended use as a dispensing organization and shall not occupy greater than ten percent of the total square footage of the facility. 
9.  Signage regulations: 
i.  No outdoor, window, or on-site media display of merchandise and/or products related to a cultivation center allowed. 
ii.  No exterior signage that includes the words "marijuana," "cannabis," or any related word or symbol. 
iii.  A sign must be posted at or near all entrances that includes the following language: "Only cardholders, designated caregivers, and staff may enter these premises. Persons under the age of 18 are prohibited from entering." 
10.  Parking must be visible from the public road or private road in which it is accessible. It cannot be screened from the roadway with vegetation, fencing, or anything of similar nature. 
(14)  Outdoor used-car sales lots only along Algonquin, Golf and Wilke Roads and in accordance with the following regulations: 
The outdoor used car sales lot operation must conform to all city regulations including, but not limited to, "Signs" (section 122-22), "Driveways and Parking Areas" (article VII of chapter 18 Building Code (section 18-243) as well as the following: 
a.  No outdoor used car sales lot operation shall be located immediately abutting a residentially zoned district and/or use and service bay doors shall not face residentially zoned district and/or use. 
b.  Parking of vehicles shall conform to section 18-245 of the City's Municipal Code for commercial parking areas. The entire sales lot and off-street parking area must be paved and a perimeter curb or barrier must be provided to prevent encroachment of vehicles for sale into the required landscaped and landscaped areas. 
1.  There shall be no parking of vehicles on anything other than a paved surface within the confines of the lot's property lines. 
c.  No automobile shall be stored or displayed nearer to the property line than eight feet. 
d.  All motor vehicle sales lots shall buffer the activities form adjacent parcels by landscaping or other buffering materials. Preferred materials shall be decorative fencing and/or vegetative material. 
e.  Adequate customer and employee parking must be provided in off-street parking spaces. The employee and customer parking shall be clearly designated and shall not be used for the parking, storage or display of motor vehicles, for sale, rental or hire. 
f.  Said lot must contain a permanent building, containing a foundation and meets the current building codes for the prescribed business activities. Suitable sanitary facilities shall be available for use and convenience of employees as well as general public. 
g.  The architectural appearance and functional plan of the building and site may not be so dissimilar to the existing buildings or area as to cause impairment in property values or constitute an adverse effect within a reasonable distance of the operation. 
h.  No bodywork or painting shall be performed unless approved as part of the special use permit and meets all state and local building and fire code regulations. Any bodywork or painting allowed as part of the special use must be on cars owned, sold or under warranty by the person or persons operation the business. 
i.  All mechanical repairs must be limited to cars owned, sold or under warranty by the person or persons operation the business. 
j.  All exterior lighting shall be designed and oriented so as to not shine or spill onto adjacent properties in order to minimize its visual impact. A photometric plan shall be submitted for review. 
k.  No exterior public address system, music, etc. shall be permitted. 
l.  Gasoline pumping is prohibited. No person shall store, sell or pump gasoline on the premises. 
m.  No outside repairs permitted. Repair work, storage and sale of auto parts and accessories shall be conducted within a fully enclosed structure. 
n.  All vehicles and equipment parked and/or displayed outside must be in operational condition. 
o.  No outdoor stock piling of parts, materials or equipment shall be permitted. 
p.  The property upon which any used car lot is located must be maintained in a neat and orderly manner with no accumulation or junk vehicles, tires, auto parts, garbage, refuse or debris on the property. 
q.  The removal of snow must not adversely affect adjacent properties. 
r.  No exterior display of banners, pennants, ribbons, or other similar temporary advertising materials shall be permitted in any outdoor sales area. 
s.  Hours of operation shall be limited to 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday to Friday, 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Saturday and closed on Sunday. 
(15)  Dance studios. 
(16)  Research/medical facility which primarily performs on-site clinical research with accessory out-patient minor surgical services and general dermatological practice. 
(17)  Fine art and tattoo studio. 
(d)  Temporary uses. The following temporary permit uses shall be permitted, subject to application and issuance by the community development director of a permit therefor: 
(1)  Temporary building or yard for construction materials and equipment, both incidental and necessary to construction in the zoning district. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than six calendar months and shall not be renewed for more than four successive periods at the same location. 
(2)  Temporary office, both incidental and necessary for the sale or rental of real property. Each permit shall specify the location of the office and the area of permitted operation. Each such permit shall be valid for a period of not more than one year and shall not be renewed for more than five successive periods at the same location. 
(e)  Conditions of use. In the M-1 districts, all permitted uses are subject to the following: 
(1)  Any production, processing, cleaning, servicing, testing, repair or storage of goods, materials or products shall take place without creating disturbing influences to the use and occupancy of adjoining properties. 
(2)  All business, production, servicing and processing shall take place within completely enclosed buildings unless otherwise specified. Within 150 feet of the nearest point of any residence district, all storage shall be in completely enclosed buildings or structures, and storage located elsewhere in this district may be open to the sky, but shall be enclosed by a solid wall or fence, including solid doors or gates thereto, at least eight feet high, but in no case lower in height than the enclosed storage. However, open off-street parking facilities for the storage of motor vehicles may be unenclosed throughout the district except for such screening of parking and loading facilities as may be required under subsection (f) of this section. Outdoor business activities shall be in accordance with section 122-27. 
(f)  Parking and loading facilities. 
(1)  Accessory facilities. For all buildings and structures erected and all uses of land established after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, accessory parking and loading facilities shall be provided as required by this chapter. However, where a building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and provided that construction is begun within six months of such effective date and diligently prosecuted to completion, parking and loading facilities shall comply with requirements existing at the time this chapter was adopted. 
(2)  Increase of intensity of use. When the intensity of use of any building, structure or premises shall be increased through additional gross floor area, seating capacity, or other units of measurement specified in this chapter for required parking or loading facilities, parking and loading facilities as required in this division shall be provided for such increase in intensity of use. However, no building or structure lawfully erected or use lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be required to provide such additional parking or loading facilities unless and until the aggregate increase in units of measurement shall equal not less than 15 percent of the units of measurement existing upon the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, in which event parking or loading facilities as required shall be provided for the total increase. 
(3)  Change to new use. Whenever the existing use of a building or structure shall be changed to a new use, parking or loading facilities shall be provided as required for such new use. However, if the building or structure was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, additional parking or loading facilities are mandatory only in the amount by which the requirements for the new use would exceed those for the existing use if the latter were subject to the parking and loading provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Existing parking and loading facilities. Accessory off-street parking or loading facilities which were in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived or which were provided voluntarily after such effective date shall not be reduced below or, if already less than, shall not further be reduced below the requirements of this chapter for a similar new building or use. 
(5)  Permissive parking and loading facilities. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the voluntary establishment of contiguous off-street parking or loading facilities to serve any existing use of land or buildings, provided that all regulations in this chapter governing the location, design, improvement and operation of such facilities are adhered to. 
(6)  Damage or destruction. For any conforming or legally nonconforming building or use which is in existence on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, which subsequently thereto is damaged or destroyed by fire, collapse, explosion or other cause and which is reconstructed, reestablished or repaired, off-street parking or loading facilities need not be provided, except that parking or loading facilities equivalent to any maintained at the time of such damage or destruction shall be restored or continued in operation. However, if the principal building or structure is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent of its replacement value, it shall then be necessary to restore or maintain parking or loading facilities as required by this chapter for equivalent new uses or construction. 
(7)  Submission of plot plan. Any application for a building permit shall include therewith a plot plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, showing any parking or loading facilities to be provided in compliance with this chapter. 
(g), (h)  Reserved. 
(i)  Pedestrian and bicycle facilities. Developments or improved parcels five acres or more in size shall have pedestrian and bicycle facilities designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements contained in section 122-26.

Sec. 122-222. - Additional parking regulations. 
(a)  In the M-1 manufacturing district, except as otherwise indicated, required accessory off-street parking facilities provided for uses listed in this division shall be solely for the parking of passenger automobiles of patrons, occupants or their guests or employees of such uses. 
(b)  Computation. When determination of the number of off-street parking spaces required by this chapter results in a requirement of a fractional space, any fraction in excess of one-half shall be counted as one parking space. 
(c)  Collective use. Off-street parking facilities for separate uses may be provided collectively if the total number of spaces so provided collectively is not less than the sum of the separate requirements for each such use and provided that all regulations governing location of accessory parking spaces in relation to the use served are adhered to. Further, no parking space or portion thereof shall serve as required space for more than one use unless otherwise authorized by the zoning board of appeals. 
(d)  Size. A required off-street parking space shall be at least nine feet in width and at least 20 feet in length, exclusive of access drives or aisles, ramps, columns or office or work areas. Such space shall have a vertical clearance of at least seven feet. 
(e)  Access. Each required off-street parking space shall open directly upon an aisle or driveway of such width and design as to provide safe and efficient means of vehicular and pedestrians access to such parking space. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with appropriate means of vehicular and pedestrians access to a street or alley in a manner which will least interfere with traffic movements. No driveway across public property or requiring a curb shall exceed a width of 25 feet. 
(1)  Driveway width. The width of a driveway shall be as approved by the city engineer based on the anticipated use, traffic volume, location, geometrics and acceptable design standards. 
(2)  Safe access. Off-street parking spaces shall not be situated in such a manner as to block, impede, cause disorder or otherwise render unsafe any driveway or access to the site or parking area nor shall it hinder or cause disorder to emergency vehicle access to the structure or structures on the site. 
(3)  Double parking on premises. Only vehicles awaiting servicing or repair on the premises may be parked a maximum of two deep (double parked) adjacent to an approved aisle except such double parking is prohibited in the setback area 30 feet from the property line fronting on a public street. 
(4)  Backing onto public street. The off-street parking design shall not cause or encourage an exiting vehicle to back onto the public street. 
_____
(f)  Location in yards. Off-street parking spaces and driveways within yard areas shall conform to the requirements of article VII of chapter 18 of this Code pertaining to driveways.
